    {
        "body": "At the TAC meeting in October, TAC formed the\nProtocol Implementation Work Group (PIWG).  The\ntimeline for the work group's activities included\na milestone of ERCOT staff delivering a summary of\nthe Protocol/System gaps on November 15th.  This\nmessage is the delivery of that summary.\n\nThe Consortium conducted a reconciliation of the\nNovember 1 Protocols to the system design.  ERCOT\nstaff reviewed the reconciliation provided by the\nConsortium.  There were a number of issues\nincluded in the reconciliation that are still\nunder review with the vendors.  The finalization\nof that review is being completed as quickly as\npossible.  Based on the decisions during the\nreview, there may be some more issues that will\nneed to be added to the Protocol Implementation\nPlan (PIP).\n\nThere were a number of issues that relate to\nthings that are in the November 1 Protocols that\nare not in the current system design and will not\nbe available on June 1, 2001.  ERCOT staff worked\nvery hard over the last few days to prepare those\nissues to be sent to the PIWG for review and\ncriticality analysis.  ERCOT staff used the\nNovember 1 Protocols as a baseline.  We boxed the\nlanguage that related to things that would not be\navailable and in effect on June 1, 2001.  The box\nincludes a PIP Issue number, explanation of the\nreason the Nov. 1 language is in the box, and an\nexplanation of the restoration process for the\nNovember 1 language.  In the body of the Protocol\ndocument, we drafted redline language which\nreflects what will be in place on June 1, 2001.\n\nThe attached files contain:\n\n(1)   PIP Master List - This is a master list of\nall the Protocol Implementation Plan (PIP) issues\nthat have been identified to date.  It contains an\nissue name, Protocol subsection reference, summary\nof the issue, status, and ERCOT author.\n\n(2)  A file for each PIP issue which contains an\nexcerpt from the Nov. 1 Protocol reflecting the\nboxes and redlined language.\n\n(3)  Reconciliation documents for PIP issues that\nthe PIWG has already discussed.\n\nAll of these issues will be discussed at PIWG\nmeetings.  We will be working with Brad Jones,\nPIWG Chair, to set up the meeting days and the\nagenda for reviewing each of these issues.  The\nagenda will be published prior to the meetings so\nthat organizations have the opportunity to\nidentify the appropriate persons to attend.  In\naddition, ERCOT staff will be working with the\nPIWG during the discussions of each issue.\n\nThe PIWG has a lot to accomplish in a short amount\nof time.  ERCOT staff has prepared the issues to\nhelp expedite the process and contribute to the\nprocess.  We look forward to completing the PIP.\n\nCheryl F. Moseley\nBusiness Rules and Contracts Manager\nERCOT\n512/248-3880\n512/750-8152 cell\n512/248-3886 fax\n\n\nPlease note:  There will be a total of 9 e-mails\nincluding this one in this message.",

        "body": "Introducing NASDAQ-100 Index TIERS (sm)\nPrincipal-Protected* Trust Certificates\n\nTIERS Nasdaq-100 Principal-Protected* Trust Certificates are\nsecurities whose return is linked to the performance of\nthe Nasdaq-100 Index. At maturity, the Trust is scheduled to\nrepay the entire principal amount of the certificates, plus an\namount based on the return of the Nasdaq-100 Index subject to\na quarterly appreciation cap of 12%.\n\nPayment to the trust will be guaranteed pursuant to the\nterms of a financial guaranty insurance policy\nissued by Ambac Assurance Corporation.\n\nExpected to be Aaa rating by Moody's and AAA rating by\nStandard & Poor's.\n\nExpected to be priced April 11, 2001.\nExpected offering price is $10 per certificate.\n\n\nFor more information and a copy of the prospectus,\nplease go to:\n\nhttp://www.schwabnet.com/tiers/\n\nor\n\nSpeak with a Specialized Product Representative at\n1-800-551-1001 ext. 33 from 5:30 a.m. to 3:00 p.m. PDT.\n\n* When held to maturity.\n\n----------------------------------------------------------------\nA registration statement relating to these securities has been\nfiled with the Securities and Exchange Commission but has not\nyet become effective. These securities may not be sold nor may\noffers to buy be accepted prior to the time the registration\nstatement becomes effective. This communication shall not\nconstitute an offer to sell or the solicitation of an offer to\nbuy nor shall there be any sales of these securities in any\njurisdiction in which the offer, solicitation or sale would be\nunlawful prior to registration or qualification under the\nsecurities laws of any such State.\n\n\"TIERS\" is a registered service mark of Salomon Smith Barney\n\nCharles Schwab & Co.\n101 Montgomery Street\nSan Francisco, CA 94104\n\n----------------------------------------------------------------\nTo unsubscribe from the BondSource emails, please reply to\nthis message with Unsubscribe in the Message Body.\n\nFor your protection, we are unable to accept instructions to\nchange your email address sent in reply to this message. Edward Ondarza maintains oversight of origination in=\r\n=20\r\nthe pulp and paper sectors. We believe that=\r\n=20\r\nthe primary objectives of the CTG have been achieved, and in order to bette=\r\nr=20\r\nposition the organization for the remainder of 2000 and in response to Ray=\r\n=20\r\nBowen=01,s new position, the following changes will be made in the Commerci=\r\nal=20\r\nTransactions Group organization.\r\n\r\nTransaction Development:  Transaction Development, which was created to=20\r\nprovide focused deal execution capability to the Origination groups, will b=\r\ne=20\r\nmerged into each respective origination group and report solely to the grou=\r\np=20\r\nleaders.=20\r\n\r\nPortfolio Management:  All activities surrounding portfolio investments wil=\r\nl=20\r\nreport to Jeff Donahue. <stephanie-newell@reliantenergy.com>, \"Jeff Dasovich (E-mail)\" \n<jdasovic@enron.com>\ncc: \"Karen Edson\" <kedson@ns.net> \nSubject: Two Governor's Press Releases\n\n\nGOVERNOR DAVIS PRESSES FERC FOR ACTION ON WHOLESALE POWER RATES: Calls on\nFederal Regulators to Reduce Prices, Issue Refunds\n\nGOVERNOR DAVIS NAMES KAHN CHAIR OF THE GOVERNOR'S CLEAN ENERGY GREEN TEAM\n\n\n\nOFFICE OF THE GOVERNOR\n----------------------------------------------------------------------------\n----\nPR00:238\nFOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE\nSeptember 12, 2000\n\nGOVERNOR DAVIS PRESSES FERC FOR ACTION ON WHOLESALE POWER RATES\nCalls on Federal Regulators to Reduce Prices, Issue Refunds\n\nSAN DIEGO - At a Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) hearing today\nin San Diego, Governor Gray Davis reiterated his call to federal regulators\nto intervene \"to the fullest extent possible\" to lower electricity prices in\nCalifornia.\n\n\"FERC bears responsibility to ensure that a workably competitive market\nexists before California consumers and California's economy are subjected to\nunconstrained, market-based electricity prices,\" said Governor Davis in a\nstatement read by Energy Oversight Board Chairman Michael Kahn.\n\"Consequently, I renew my prior request that the Commission act with utmost\nspeed to intervene to the fullest extent possible to restore wholesale\nprices to fair levels and to remedy harms that have resulted from the\nexercise of market power.\"\n\nGovernor Davis noted that he and state lawmakers have taken dramatic action\nin recent weeks to provide rate relief. \"While these actions should provide\nshort-term rate predictability and longer-term benefits to customers in\nterms of improved supplies, the fundamental problem of exorbitant wholesale\nprices still exists and remains the responsibility of FERC to address,\" said\nthe governor. \"No combination of state actions can substitute for federal\naction to ameliorate the problems of California's wholesale markets.\"\n\nGovernor Davis has taken the following actions in reaction to rising\nelectricity prices in San Diego:\n\nOn June 14, he called for emergency reduction of electricity use by all\nstate facilities in the San Francisco Bay area in response to electricity\nemergency and rolling blackouts.\n\nOn June 15, he called on chairpersons of the Public Utilities Commission\n(PUC) to analyze the conditions that led to electricity shortages in the San\nFrancisco Bay area the previous day, including a statewide perspective on\nthe price and delivery of electricity. Report was completed, submitted to\nthe governor and released on August 2.\n\nOn July 27, 2000, Governor Davis called on federal and state regulators to\ntake swift action to extend the caps on wholesale electric rates in\nCalifornia and provide San Diego ratepayers with million of dollars in\nrefunds.\n\nIn letters written by the governor to two state regulatory agencies and two\nCalifornia-based panels charged with overseeing California's power market,\nhe called for a coordinated state effort to urge federal regulators to take\nstrong measures to reduce power rates in both the short- and long-term.\n\nOn August 2, 2000, Governor Davis issued three Executive Orders designed to\nreduce energy consumption by state government and speed up the time it takes\nnew power generating facilities to win approval from state agencies.\n\nOn August 9, 2000, Governor Davis called on the Public Utilities Commission\n(PUC) to establish a two-year plan that would cut electricity rates by\nnearly half for residential and business customers of San Diego Gas &\nElectric.\n\nThe governor also reached an agreement with the California Grocers\nAssociation that will save enough electricity to provide power to between\n50,000 and 60,000 homes during periods of peak demand, as grocers agreed to\nreduce power consumption by 10 percent during Stage One emergencies.\n\nOn August 10, 2000, Governor Davis wrote a letter to President Clinton\nurging him to expedite FERC's investigation to determine whether current\nelectric rates in San Diego were unjust.\n\nOn August 22, 2000, Governor Davis called on President Clinton to release\nemergency funds from the Low-Income Home Energy Assistance Program (LIHEAP)\nto the state to help low-income Californians pay their rapidly-rising\nelectricity bills.\n\nOn August 23, 2000, President Clinton responded to Governor Davis' request\nby releasing $2.6 million in emergency funds to help low-income Southern\nCalifornians cope with the surge in their electricity bills. The President\nalso asked federal regulators to speed up their investigation into the\noperation of U.S. power markets and urged the Small Business Administration\nto use its credit programs to help small firms hurt by the price increases.\n\nOn August 23, 2000, Governor Davis reached agreement with legislators on\nlegislation to provide relief to San Diego ratepayers. The governor signed\ntwo bills into law on September 6, 2000.\n\nPlease see attached letter (below).\n\n# # #\n\nSEPTEMBER 12, 2000\n\nSTATEMENT OF GOVERNOR GRAY DAVIS\n\nTO THE FEDERAL ENERGY REGULATORY COMMISSION CONCERNING ITS INVESTIGATION OF\nWHOLESALE PRICE ESCALATION IN CALIFORNIA\n\nThe Summer of 2000 has confronted California with an electricity crisis that\nseriously threatens the safety, health and well being of citizens and\nbusinesses throughout the state. At the heart of the crisis is the\nextraordinary run up in prices for wholesale electric energy and ancillary\nservices, accompanied by deteriorating service and reliability. In San\nDiego, electric customers' bills have more than doubled this summer,\nthreatening permanent harm to businesses and the health and welfare of\nresidential customers in the warm southern climate. All remaining California\nelectric consumers are faced with similar prospects as their legislated rate\nfreeze periods come to an end. In San Francisco we saw rolling blackouts for\nthe first time in our history.\n\nAs soon as the dimensions of the crisis became evident, I directed\nCalifornia regulators, including the Public Utilities Commission and the\nElectricity Oversight Board, and the Independent System Operator, to take\nimmediate steps to identify and implement specific measures to mitigate the\ndamage, including restoring price caps at Summer 1999 levels. I am happy to\nreport that those measures have been adopted, although not without\nconsiderable resistance from self-interested parties.\n\nIn recent weeks, I have worked with the California Legislature to enact\nfurther relief within the existing framework of options now available to the\nstate. These include provisions to stabilize retail rates, expedite\ngeneration licensing where possible, implement targeted demand reduction and\ndemand response and remove constraints in transmission and distribution\nsystems. I have also established a task force comprised of key state\nofficials which is developing measures to increase energy efficiency and\nalternative supplies and to expedite permitting by state agencies.\n\nWhile these actions should provide short-term rate predictability and\nlonger-term benefits to customers in terms of improved supplies, the\nfundamental problem of exorbitant wholesale prices still exists and remains\nthe responsibility of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to address.\nNo combination of state actions can substitute for federal action to\nameliorate the problems in California's wholesale markets.\n\nA joint report submitted to me on August 2nd by the Chairman of the\nCalifornia Electricity Oversight Board and the President of the California\nPublic Utilities Commission concluded that exorbitant wholesale prices in\nCalifornia result from wholesale market dysfunction and the exercise of\nmarket power by sellers. Subsequent reports by the Market Analysis\nDepartment and the Market Surveillance Committee of the California\nIndependent System Operator reach the same conclusions. Subsequent behavior\nof wholesale electric prices during August confirms their conclusions, and\nsubjects California to further economic damage. While I remain hopeful that\nCalifornia wholesale markets may ultimately become competitive and become\ncapable of serving the interests of consumers and the public, I cannot and\nwill not accept the liabilities to California that result from the current\nsituation for even a short period. I intend to take any and all steps\nnecessary to restore economic stability to the electric service\ninfrastructure of California.\n\nFERC bears the responsibility under its organic act to assure just and\nreasonable wholesale electric rates. FERC bears responsibility to ensure\nthat a workably competitive market exists before California consumers and\nCalifornia's economy are subjected to unconstrained, market-based\nelectricity prices. Consequently, I renew my prior request that the\nCommission act with utmost speed to intervene to the fullest extent possible\nto restore wholesale prices to fair levels and to remedy harms that have\nresulted from the exercise of market power.\n\n###\n\nOFFICE OF THE GOVERNOR\n----------------------------------------------------------------------------\n----\nA00:245\nFOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE\nSeptember 12, 2000\n\nGOVERNOR DAVIS NAMES KAHN CHAIR OF THE GOVERNOR'S CLEAN ENERGY GREEN TEAM\nSACRAMENTO - Governor Gray Davis today announced the appointment of Michael\nA. Kahn as chairman of the newly-created Governor's Clean Energy Green Team.\nThe Team was created by Governor Davis' signing of AB 970 by Assemblywoman\nDenise Moreno Ducheny (D-San Diego) on Wednesday.\n\nMr. Kahn, 51, of San Francisco, is the chairman of the California\nElectricity Oversight Board, and he also serves as vice-chair of the\nCalifornia Commission on Judicial Performance. He has been senior partner\nand head of litigation at Folger Levin & Kahn LLP since 1979. Mr. Kahn has\nheld numerous state and federal government appointments and assignments over\nthe last 15 years.\n\nMr. Kahn is the author of several articles and reports on litigation\npractice and Supreme Court history. He is a magna cum laude, Phi Beta Kappa\ngraduate of the University of California, Los Angeles. Mr. Kahn also earned\nmaster of arts and juris doctorate degrees from Stanford University, where\nhe was an editor of the Law Review. After graduation, he served for a year\nas a law clerk to Judge Ben C. Duniway of the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals\nin San Francisco.\n\nThe signing of AB 970 established the Governor's Clean Energy Green Team,\nwhich works to streamline the process of creating new power plants to ensure\nthat an adequate supply of power will exist to make a deregulated\nmarketplace work. The Team does this by working with local governments,\nidentifying environmental impacts, developing recommendations for low\ninterest financing programs for renewable energy and obtaining input on\nnatural gas supply, emission offsets and water supply.\n\nMembers do not receive a salary. This position does not require Senate\nconfirmation.\n\n# # #\n\nJulee Malinowski-Ball\nEdson + Modisette\nAssociate\n925 L Street Suite 1490\nSacramento CA 95814\n916-552-7070\nFAX-552-7075\njmball@ns.net\n\n\n\n\n\n\n",

        "body": "Glad to see we're doing our part to help the West's energy crisis...  we can \nmilk the heck out of this story :-) kd\n\nPGE wants to convert manure to methane\n\n04/03/2001\nAssociated Press Newswires\nCopyright 2001. The Associated Press. All Rights Reserved.\n\nSALEM, Ore. (AP) - Oregon's energy future may be chewing cud in Bernie \nFaber's pasture. \nHis 500 cows will provide tons of manure to be converted to methane to \ngenerate electricity in a pilot project operated by Portland General Electric.\nThe project is expected to generate about 100 kilowatts of electricity - \nenough for about 65 homes - by July. \n\"When you consider how many dairy farms there are in Oregon, this could be a \nsignificant source of power,\" said PGE spokesman Mark Fryburg. \nAbout 89,000 milk cows were reported on state farms in 1999. \nPGE wants to perfect the technology at Faber's Cal-Gon Farm. If the company \nsucceeds, small-scale power plants could become commonplace at Oregon dairy \nfarms. \n\"We would love to be able to engineer and design these things so we could do \nthem at smaller and smaller dairies over time,\" said Jeff Cole, PGE'; biogas \nprogram manger. \nPGE officials also are interested in developing a 4.5 megawatt, \nmethane-powered energy facility in Morrow County that could provide energy \nfor about 3,000 homes. It would depend on manure from dairies relocating to \nthe area to support a Tillamook County Creamery Association cheese plant. \nThe disposal of livestock waste has become an expensive and complex problem \nfor farms as environmental regulations tighten. \nA typical dairy cow produces about 150 pounds of waste each day. \nMethane-powered generators, such as PGE's project, reduce the odors \nassociated with dairies and create useful byproducts: a nitrogen-rich liquid \nfertilizer and an odorless dry fiber that can be used to make potting soils. \nAt Faber's farm, construction of a 28-foot high concrete tank where waste \nwill be converted into methane is nearly complete. \nPGE officials compare the tank to a giant stomach, where bacteria in manure \ncontinues the digestion process and produces flammable methane. \nA modified, internal combustion engine will burn the methane for fuel and \ndrive power turbines. After the manure is processed, the leftovers will be \npumped through a solid separator, taken off site, and composted. \nLiquids will be stored at a lagoon at the dairy.\n\nCopyright , 2000 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved. ",

    {
        "body": "Some ideas for Friday's comments - \n\nTwo of the Commission's stated goals in the ACR were:\n\nReduce the disparity in prices paid for energy among customer classes:  Enron \nsuggests a restatement of this goal.  Energy prices should be an accurate \nindication of the costs imposed on the system.  For example, the average cost \nof 1 kW @ 100% load factor is much different than 1 kW used at 30% load \nfactor, all on-peak, and much different than 1 kW used at 70% load factor, \nall off-peak.  In practice, each customer class has a mixture of customers \nleaning toward each of these extreme.  True equity requires that customers \nwith similar load patterns pay non-disparate energy prices, regardless of \nwhich class the customer is in.   A more proper statement of this goal is:  \nreduce the disparity between prices paid for energy and costs imposed on the \nsystem across all customer classes.  \n\nTier rates to promote conservation:  Enron suggests a restatement of this \ngoal. Traditionally, the California Commission has favored rate designs that \nreflect marginal costs.  Marginal cost pricing, in and of itself promotes \nefficient use of energy because of the many reasons the CPUC itself has cited \nover the years.  In the situation at hand,  the indicators of marginal cost \nin the wholesale power market are CDWR's purchase cost in hours when the CDWR \nis covering the net short, and the hourly wholesale spot market price (the \nwholesale on-peak forward curve, as a proxy)  in hours when the CDWR is not \nfilling the net short.  Conservation will be incented with use of price \nsignals that reflect market conditions.  A more proper statement of this goal \nis:  To provide customers with the motivation to respond appropriately, \ndesign marginal rates within the rate classes to reflect marginal wholesale \ncosts.\n\nRegarding these goals, it will take time for the commission and parties to do \nthis - which plays to EES URM and the idea of keeping the 3 cents as an \ninterim rate design while a 6 month rate design case can take place.  I think \nit is inconceivable, however, that the CPUC does not have strong price \nsignals in place for this summer.  So I think we use the \"equal percent of \nmarginal costs\" idea to get price signals in place, but much flatter ones \nthan in the ACR.  (for a variety of reasons, I don't think the 2-part real \ntime pricing being pushed by Mr. Stoness can fly without some radical \nmodifications, but let's talk).\n\nAbout the residential increase, we may want to weigh in on whether \nresidentail usage above 130% of baseline gets the full brunt of the total \nresidential increase or just 3 cents.  Let's talk about the politics.\n\nWe also will want to say 1) DA is exempt from the increase  2) any increase \nprior to the effective date of the new rate design should be 3 cents across \nthe board.",
        "headers": {

    {
        "body": "I still think it is imperative that we use our book position, by rate \nschedule and time period (on-peak, off-peak) , to quantify the sensitivity to \ndifferent types of rate designs.  For instance, if there is a large increase \nin summer on-peak, how much of the increase can we avoid with aggressive DSM, \netc.  Can we look at this quantification today?  \n\n\n\n\tScott Stoness@EES\n\t04/02/2001 09:34 PM\n\t\t \n\t\t To: James W Lewis/HOU/EES@EES\n\t\t cc: Don Black, Tamara Johnson/HOU/EES@EES, harry kingerski\n\t\t Subject: Draft Testimony re PGE/SCE for Discussion\n\nHarry and I are meeting tomorrow.  I would like any feedback you have related \nto the following:\n\nBased on our position we would prefer:\nLater surcharges\nLower surcharges\nSurcharges that are lower in the summer (flatter is better because it is \ncloser, the NPV effects and our rapidly diminishing position)\n\nThe proposal below could either result in:\nDelay of a month while they consider this complicated affair (low likelihood)\nLower surcharge if we can convince people that market rates are $300/MWh for \na year when they are actually $200.  We would only get a $20/MWh increase, as \ncompared to a $30/MWh increase.  ie (1-90%) times $300/MWh yields $30/MWh is \nour story when the actural is (1-90%)times $200/MWh yields $20/MWh.\nThe Enron rates below are effectively much flatter than the CPUC proposal.  \nThus we would be better off if accepted.\nAdditionally if our noise causes a flat $30/MWh increase to replace the CPUC \nproposal, we are better off.\n\nAdditionally, \nwe could sell hedging on the 10% exposed to markets.\nDSM related to capital investments should be less risky.\n\nThe risks to Enron are:\nProposal makes it easy to hit the large customers with a lower baseline (ie \n75% instead of 90%)\nWould make DSM more risky.  DSM providers would have to buy hedges to proceed.\n\nThe questions to answer are:\nCould Enron provide witnesses without drawing more negatives\nWould a partner tow the Enron line\n---------------------- Forwarded by Scott Stoness/HOU/EES on 04/02/2001 09:22 \nPM ---------------------------\n\n\nScott Stoness\n04/02/2001 09:21 PM\nTo: Tamara Johnson/HOU/EES@EES\ncc: harry kingerski \nSubject: Draft Testimony re PGE/SCE for Discussion\n\nSummary:\nThe CPUC should implement two part RTP/TOU rates for PGE/SCE.  A two part \nrate is a rate where customers pay their historical rate for consumption of \nnormal load and pay market value for consumption incremental (or decremental) \nto normal load.\nThe CPUC should define normal consumption as consumption over and above 90% \nof historical 2000 consumption.\nThe CPUC should define the hourly rate as the highest hourly price paid by \nDWR for spot purchases in that hour.\nIn the event that implementation of two part RTP/TOU rates is complicated to \ndesign, the $30/MWh surcharge should be applied to all customers until the \nimplementation of two part RTP/TOU rates is possible.\nThe current draft design, of the CPUC, is discriminatory to large customers.\nThe current draft design, of the CPUC, does not provide appropriate price \nsignals.\nThe current draft design, of the CPUC, results in rate increases to large \ncustomers that are unneccessarly high.\nThe current draft design, of the CPUC, results in rate increases to large \ncustomers, that are far in excess of those which the CPUC intended.\nThe current draft design, of the CPUC, results is static and does not respond \nto changing market conditions.\n\nDesign Goals:\nThe CPUC should design rates that:\nGive appropriate price signals to customers to consume / conserve energy as \nas close to marginal price as possible in as many hours as possible.\nTreat all rate classes in a fair and consistent manner.\nAchieve targeted revenue requirements.\nAre easy to administer and understand.\n\nSummary of CPUC Illustrative Design:\nThe CPUC has proposed rates that move on peak pricing in the summer close to \nmarginal rates:\nDraft proposal provides marginal price signal of about $370/MWh for E19 \nSecondary from in Summer Weekdays from noon to 6PM\nDraft proposal provides marginal price signal of about $75/MWh for E19 \nSecondary from in all other hours.\nCritique based on Design Goals:\nDraft proposals move toward marginal rates but fall short.\nThe rates for power, Mar 30 2001, based on DJ-NP15, on peak is $181.94/MWh.\nThe rates for power, Mar 30 2001, based on DJ-NP15, off peak is $93.46/MWh.\nThe proposed marginal rates for E19 Secondary, is $75/MWh for on peak and off \npeak.\nThis rate design will not encourage investments in assets that result in \nlower consumption in the winter or in off peak periods.\n Draft proposal falls short on treating customers on a consistent basis:\nE20 Transmission Voltage customers will experience a 87% rate increase.\nE19 Secondary voltage customers will experience a 41% rate increase.\nA10 Medium General Service customers will experience a 20% rate increase.\nA1 Small L&P customers will experience a 16% rate increase.\nThe marginal price signal for A10 will be $121/MWh vs $370/MWh for E-20 \ntransmission in the on peak summer.\nThe marginal price signal for E10 wills be 107/MWh vs $55/MWh for E-20 \ntransmission in the off peak periods.\nPGE has a longer summer period than SCE.  This results in a 69% increase for \nSCE TOU-8-Sub as compared to 87% increases for PGE E20 Transmission rate.  \nThe proposal also results in far different marginal price signals for SCE \ncustomers than PGE customers.  For example the on peak rate for SCE TOU-8-Sub \nis $128/MWh as compared to PGE E20 Transmission rate of $374/MWh.\nDraft proposal does do a good job of recovering $2.2b of revenue.\nDraft proposal require some implementation but given that the surcharge \nincrease does not ocur until May for PGE and June for SCE, it should be \npossible to implement.\n\nEnron Proposed Rates:\nEnron proposes:\nTwo part real time pricing time of use rate,\nUsage up to 90% of historical use would be billed at historical rates.\nUsage incremental or decremental to 90% of historical use, would be billed at \nDJ-NP15 On Peak and DJ-NP15 Off Peak, where customers has real time metering.\nUsage incremental or decremental to 90% of historical use, would be billed at \nDJ-NP15 On Peak and DJ-NP15 Off Peak averaged over the month, where customers \nhas time of use metering.\nUsage incremental or decremental to 90% of historical use, would be billed at \n45% of DJ-NP15 On Peak and 55% of DJ-NP15 Off Peak averaged over the month, \nwhere customers has just energy metering.\nCritique based on Design Goals:\nEnron proposals charge all customer at very close  to marginal rates.\nThus, within the constraints of using Dow Jones, the rates should be very \nclose to the actual marginal rates.\nThe rates will not be exact because they are:\nDetermined on the previous day\nOny differentiate between on and off peak, as compared to hour by hour.\nTo the extent that the customer does not have real time metering capability, \nthe rates will be determined on a class average basis.\nHowever, the rates be far superior to the CPUC draft design because:\nThey give better price signals to night consumption\nThey give better signals to weekend consumption\nThey give better signals to winter consumption\nThey are self correcting in that they do not require predetermination of \nmarginal costs.  For example, if summer costs are lower, the rate will be \nlower.\nThe Enron proposal will motivate DSM activities in winter, summer and off \npeak.\nEnron proposal results in similar rate structure and impact regardless of \nutility and rate class.\nThe Enron proposal results in a similar concept for commerical and industrial \nas with residential.  AB1X provides that residential customers that consume \nenergy below normal rates will not have increased rates.  This design also \nachieves the same effect for commercial and industrial customers.\nDraft proposal does do a good job of recovering $2.2b of revenue but even \nmore importantly it ensures tracking of costs.\nSetting the normal load at 90% of historical load results in a $30/MWh \nincrease if the market value for the entire year is $300/MWh.\nIn the event that the market value for the entire year is less than $300/MWh, \nthe resulting cost decreases will offset the lost revenue.\nThe Enron proposed rate design structure is flexi ble enough that it can \neasily be changed to achieve greater or lessor revenue to achieve price \nsignals and revenue targets.\nThe revenue outcome is less certain than the CPUC draft design however the \nimpact should be more certain because the revenue will automatically go up \nwhen the costs go up.\nDraft proposal require greater implementation details than the CPUC design \nbut such extra costs are worthwhile.\nThe Enron proposal requires:\nDetermination of historical loads for large customers\nDetermination of class consumption profiles for demand metered customers\nDetermination of class consumption profiles for energy metered customers\nDetermination of customer profiles in the event that the customers is a new \ncustomer\nThen Enron proposal has the following negatives:\nSome customers who have reduced load from historical levels will be better \noff even though they have not changed their behaviour in response to the new \nprice signals\nThe rates will require greater administrative costs since they are different \nfor each customer.\nThe rates may take more work to put in place for the utility\nThe rates will result in similar customers paying dissimilar rates, depending \nupon the historical consumption of the customers\n\nQ.  In the event that it is not possible to implement the Enron rates by June \n1, 2001, what would you propose a an interim solution:\nA.  The CPUC draft rates are so flawed, that it would be superior to just \nimplement a flat $30/MWh surcharge to all customers.  This approach would be \nfairer and simpler.\n\nQ.  Who would pay for the decremental consumption of customers?\nA.  The DWR will incur a decline in their costs equal to the decrease in \nrates of the utilities.  The are indifferent to buy more generation or \nselling less energy to customers.  Thus the DWR should be willing to pay for \ndecremental consumption.  In the event that the DWR is not agreeable to \npaying for decremental consumption, the utility should be allowed to borrow \nsuch funds and have the costs amortized for the next 10 years.  In the event \nthat the utility is unable to fund decremental consumption, the normal load \ncould be defined 85% of historical and the CPUC could eliminate credits \nresulting from decremental consumption.  Such solution would discourage \nconservation below 15% but would not be expected to diminish the \neffectiveness of the Enron proposed rates.\n\nQ.  Why is DJ-NP15 the right index to choose?\nA.  DJ-NP15 and DJ-SP15 are availble for each weekday for on and off peak \npricing.  The index is a mathematical average of trades in the previous day \nfor today.  The DJ index is compiled based on the information provided by \nmany of the large trading companies including Enron.  The numbers provided by \nthe participants are subject to audit.  Thus DJ is the best avaible \ninformation available for energy pricing.\n\nQ.  What index is suitable for weekends?\nA. Enron proposes that the average DJ-NP15 off peak energy charges for friday \nand monday be used to determine the weekend rates for the purpose of rate \nsetting.\n\n\n",

In very big ways!  In fact,\nTelluride has received over 3 feet of fresh powder since October 1 and the\ntemperatures have been frigid?which makes for excellent snowmaking\nconditions. Winter has come, and you know what that means ? YES! Time to\nstrap on some boards and make some turns!\n\n\nSNOW REPORT\nAs the snow has begun to come with increasing regularity, you can imagine\nthe local attitude begins to buoy. At lunch the other day, when we looked\nout the window and saw the big flakes coming down, we made a loud whoop\nwith our waiter, causing all heads in the restaurant to turn our way. But\nwhen the other diners saw the white stuff, EVERYONE started buzzing with\nthe anticipation. Folks are getting ready for the season. For a sneak\npreview, check out the photo of the day at\nwww.telluride-ski.com/dayphoto.html.\n\n\nBARGAINS & DEALS\nThe best-case scenario for skiing Telluride is to live here. But the NEXT\nbest-case scenario is that you get a screaming deal to vacation here. And\nthat's what Telluride and Mountain Village Visitor Services has for you.\nCheck out these packages for round-trip air, lodging and skiing from some\nof America's biggest hubs:\n\nDallas Special:          $831 per person - 5 nights lodging, 4 days skiing\nand roundtrip air to Montrose\nHouston Special:    $814 per person - 5 nights lodging, 4 days skiing and\nroundtrip air to Montrose\nChicago Special:    $825 per person - 5 nights lodging, 4 days skiing and\nroundtrip air to Montrose\nMiami Special:      $929 per person - 5 nights lodging, 4 days skiing and\nroundtrip air to Montrose\n\nTo get any of these specials, call 1-888-288-7360.\n\nIf you choose to put together a package on your own, check out the lodging\ndeals at www.telluride-ski.com and click on HOT DEALS.\n\n\nWHAT'S NEW\nYou can never have too much snow. With that in mind, the Telluride Ski\nResort installed a new snowmaking system this summer that guarantees that\nevery lift pod will have coverage on at least one run all season long! Yep.\nLifts 1, 4, 5, 6, 7 and 9 will have better conditions for riding and skiing\nfrom beginning to end. As the hipper folks say, the turns will be \"tasty.\"\n\nThe tastiest new addition to the mountain, however, is Allred's, a new\n140-seat restaurant that is guaranteed to delight even the most\ndiscriminating diners. Located mid-mountain at the gondola Station St.\nSophia, Allred's will serve as a private club by day in the winter, an\nupscale lunch spot in the summer and a fine dining experience in the\nevenings year-round. More on this epicurean dream in later e-rides. For\ndinner reservations, call 970-728-7474.\n\nOne other great new thing: It's easier to get to Telluride than ever\nbefore. You can now fly to Montrose EVERY DAY from Dallas/Ft. Worth on\nAmerican Airlines?but the flight will only have 129 seats, so be sure your\nbody is in one of them!\n\n\nWHAT'S HAPPENING\nOf course the most important thing on the Telluride calendar is November\n22, the Official Opening Day. But there are other things worth mentioning.\nLike the Sneak Preview of the mountain on November 21. For one day only you\ncan ski Telluride for $20, and all proceeds go to the Telluride Ski and\nSnowboard Club.\n\nAfter the Donation Day, you can still get good deals. From November 21\nthrough December 16, Telluride hosts its annual Ski Free & More program.\nWhat's it entail? Exactly what it says. Skiers and riders staying at\nparticipating lodges in the towns of Telluride and Mountain Village can\nchoose a free lift ticket, a free ski clinic, a free lunch or a free\nhalf-day of childcare for each night they stay. For more information call\n888-288-7360.\n\nAnd if you're looking forward to having a ball, why not do it right at the\nannual Black & White Affair? On November 25, the Telluride Ski and\nSnowboard Club hosts this gala event at the luxurious Telluride Conference\nCenter. Dress up and dance off your turkey. No one puts on a ball like\nTelluride!\n\n\nSLICE OF LIFE\nImagine being over 50 years old and never having seen any snow! Such was\nthe case for my friend Sarah, who recently moved to Telluride from the\nCaribbean. She and her daughters arrived late this summer, and when the\nsnows began to fall a few weeks ago, they were in rapture! Sarah ran\noutside and began to dance around (to her 17-year-old daughter's absolute\nembarrassment!) However, the daughters both caught the enthusiasm and built\ntheir first snowman ever. The snowman , of course, had a perfect carrot\nnose.. An organic carrot, no less. Hey, this is Telluride. Only the best\nfor our snowmen.\n\n\nAND SO, E-RIDERS,\nThat's all for this letter. Hope you're planning your trip to Telluride,\nwhere the snow is always whiter and the lines are always short. See you on\nthe slopes!\n\nRosemerry\n\n\nWHO'S WRITING THIS ANYWAY?\nAgainst her will, Rosemerry Wahtola Trommer learned to ski in Telluride six\nyears ago. But after a few turns, she fell ? in love with the sport. She\nlives with her husband and cat at the base of Lift 7?an ideal spot for\ngetting first chair of the morning.\n\n",

        "body": "----- Forwarded by Lara Leibman/Enron Communications on 03/31/01 09:47 PM=\r\n=20\r\n-----\r\n\r\n=09EBS Marketing & PR\r\n=0903/28/01 06:02 PM\r\n=09=09=20\r\n=09=09 To: All EBS Employees Worldwide\r\n=09=09 cc:=20\r\n=09=09 Subject: EBS Connected\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nMarket Close 3/28/01    =20\r\n58.10    -2.36\r\n\r\nBandwidth Intermediation\r\n(through 3/23/01)\r\n\r\nYTD Transactions         271  Counterparties              32\r\n=20\r\nLTD Transactions        483   Counterparties              55               =\r\n  =20\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n     =20\r\n                                                                           =\r\n  =20\r\n                                                  March 28,=20\r\n2001                                                                 =20\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nGROWING MARKET FOR BANDWIDTH\r\n\r\n=01&The market for bandwidth is developing more quickly than we anticipated=\r\n =01)=20\r\nfaster than the markets for natural gas or even electricity,=018 said Paul=\r\n=20\r\nRacicot, vice president, EBS Global Trading and Risk Management.\r\n\r\nClick here to read more.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nKEVIN HANNON ON ESPEAK\r\nRemember to join Kevin Hannon as he fields questions on eSpeak next Tuesday=\r\n,=20\r\nApril 3 at 10:00 a.m. CST.  All EBS employees worldwide are encouraged to=\r\n=20\r\ntake advantage of this great opportunity to ask questions or express your=\r\n=20\r\nthoughts and ideas.  Log onto eSpeak from eThink at home.enron.com to=20\r\nparticipate in the discussion or ask a question.  If you cannot join the li=\r\nve=20\r\nchat, you can submit a question in advance and access the transcript after=\r\n=20\r\nthe event.  If you have any questions, please contact Carin Andre. =20\r\nClick here to enter the eSpeak site.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nOnline Exlcusive: Money in the (Data) Bank\r\nBy Ted Jackson\r\nMarch 21, 2001\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nEnron Finds Retail Ally For Software Venture\r\nBy Jeff Baumgartner\r\nMarch 26, 2001=20\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nRapid New Connections\r\nBy Alan Stewart\r\nMarch 19, 2001\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nFebruary/March 2001 Issue\r\n\r\nEnron Unveils Storage Trades\r\nEnron Broadband has completed a series of deals in the data storage market,=\r\n=20\r\ncommoditising this fast-growing area for the first time.  It acted as a=20\r\nmarket maker, purchasing storage capacity from StorageNetworks - which was=\r\n=20\r\nthen sold on to Best Buy, a retailer of electronics products.  Crucially,=\r\n=20\r\nboth contracts were based on Enron's standard contract and included firm=20\r\ndelivery with liquidated damages.\r\n\r\nIn the last few years the storage market has moved from being a self-manage=\r\nd=20\r\nand owned business to one where storage is served up from a standard metro=\r\n=20\r\nnetwork.  Enron's involvement will be bring flexibility of contract offerin=\r\ng=20\r\nand imbedded optionality, according to Ravi Thuraisingham, a senior trader =\r\nat=20\r\nEnron.  \"When we sell the product to the customer we remain in the market t=\r\no=20\r\nbuy the capacity back should they wish to unwind their position later.  Tha=\r\nt=20\r\nis unprecedented,\" says Thuraisingham. =20\r\n\r\nThe storage market has historically been more flexible and more committed t=\r\no=20\r\nfirm delivery than the bandwidth market, but these trades mark a significan=\r\nt=20\r\ndevelopment.  Rather than dated damages the storage market has tended to=20\r\nfavour discounts on future purchases.  \"There is a premium in the price for=\r\n=20\r\nfirm delivery,\" says Thuraisingham.\r\n\r\nHe says that a number of other market participants are eager to commit to=\r\n=20\r\nEnron as a market maker.  In addition, equipment vendors are excited by the=\r\n=20\r\npossibilities of the market.  \"most storage equipment at the moment is=20\r\nsupplied to the enterprise market.  This development opens up the wholesale=\r\n=20\r\nstorage capacity market,\" says Thuraisingham.  =20\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nFebruary/March 2001 Issue\r\n\r\nRoundtable Preview\r\n\r\nMarcello Romano, EBS vice-president bandwidth trading in London, is=20\r\nparticipating in a roundtable on the development of the bandwidth trading=\r\n=20\r\nmarket.  Other participants include TFS Telecom Division, Williams=20\r\nCommunications, Dynegy Global Communications, France Telecom and Telemonde=\r\n=20\r\nNetworks.  Following are his initial comments to Telecoms Capacity:\r\n\r\n\r\nMarcello Romano is vice president bandwidth trading at Enron Broadband=20\r\nServices in London, arguably one of the most important players in the=20\r\ncommoditisation of the market.=20\r\n\r\nThe concept of firmness of delivery will encourage more participants in the=\r\n=20\r\nlong term. What is important to realise is that firmness doesn=01,t mean=20\r\ndelivery tomorrow. All it means is that if you commit to a date and then fa=\r\nil=20\r\nto deliver on that date you must pay damages. These are not punitive, they=\r\n=20\r\nare fair. In the telecoms sector, damages are usually payable in credits, b=\r\nut=20\r\nit=01,s important that any damages go above what was originally paid in tha=\r\nt=20\r\ncontract. Otherwise, there is no contractual incentive for the carrier to=\r\n=20\r\ndeliver on time or at all. =20\r\n=01; =01;\r\nThe downturn in investors=01, appetite to put money into telecoms companies=\r\n will=20\r\nhasten a trading culture. The carriers already trade capacity between=20\r\nthemselves to allow them to sell services. As investment for expansion=20\r\ndeclines, these options will become more attractive. But it generally still=\r\n=20\r\nmakes sense to build rather than buy where there is volume.\r\n=01; =01;\r\nPooling points are the logical conclusion to the problems of connectivity.=\r\n=20\r\nMetro platforms are a key feature of a number of carriers=01, strategies be=\r\ncause=20\r\nthey help you get around a lot of local loop issues and offer increased=20\r\naccess to buyers and sellers. Carriers are currently trying to build to as=\r\n=20\r\nmany telehouses within a metro area as possible, because no-one wants to be=\r\n=20\r\ntied. The pooling point concept takes that to a logical conclusion. It is=\r\n=20\r\nmore economical to create a hub that can then connect to all the telehouses=\r\n=20\r\nthrough the networks of the carriers involved. It=01,s efficient and fairly=\r\n=20\r\ncheap to connect. The idea that people don=01,t want to be involved with po=\r\noling=20\r\npoints because it=01,s a link you can=01,t control is nonsense. Carriers co=\r\nnnect=20\r\nwith third parties such as CLECs all the time and rely on them to complete =\r\na=20\r\nroute. It=01,s not a revolution, it=01,s an evolution.\r\n=01; =01;\r\nYou can be a player without owning a network. In Europe, Enron has no fibre=\r\n=20\r\nnetwork and is involved in the buy and the sell side of the market. That=01=\r\n,s a=20\r\npositive development, which reinforces the model we=01,re trying to build. =\r\nA lot=20\r\nof players spend a lot of money finding and closing simple transactions. We=\r\n=20\r\ncan help them do it cheaper and allow their sales force to concentrate on=\r\n=20\r\nhigher value-added sales. What=01,s wrong with that?\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nUPCOMING TRAINING\r\nBroadband Risk Management Advanced Course\r\nDate:    April 3-4, 2001 (2 days)\r\nTime:    8:00 a.m. - 5:00 p.m. (CST)\r\nLocation:  Houston, Shepherd Facility\r\nRooms:   Gulf of Mexico and Padre Island\r\nRegistration link >> =20\r\n\r\nEBS Luncheon Discussion Series\r\nTake a walk in space with Joe Edwards, former NASA shuttle astronaut\r\nDate:  April 17, 2001\r\nTime:  11:30 a.m. - 1:00 p.m. (CST)\r\nLocation: EB5C2\r\nLunch will be provided.\r\n\r\nFundamentals of Corporate Finance\r\nDate:   April 18-19, 2001 (1 1/2 days)\r\nTime:   8:30 a.m. - 5:00 p.m. (Wednesday)\r\n  8:30 a.m. - 12:00 noon (Thursday)\r\nLocation: Houston, Shepherd Facility\r\nRooms:  Padre Island\r\nRegistration link >>=20\r\n\r\nIf you have any questions regarding any of the above courses, please contac=\r\nt=20\r\nRita Ramirez.\r\n\r\n We want your ideas and feedback on EBS Connected.  =20\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n\r\n\r\n",

On Tuesday, state regulators approved an average 40 percent \nincrease in consumer electricity rates to cover the soaring cost of energy \nand pump more cash into the state's near-bankrupt utilities. \n\n     \"The energy crisis in California has ramifications for the entire \ncountry, and it looks like it's going to get worse before it gets better,\" \nRep. Dan Burton, an Indiana Republican who heads the panel, said in a \nstatement. \n\n     \"The problems are costing California's economy billions of dollars, and \nthat's going to affect the economy of the entire country,\" he added. \n\n     The committee will hear testimony from power generators, utilities, \ngovernment entities, and local organizations. \n\n     Neighboring states have complained that California's thirst for power \nhas boosted wholesale electricity prices throughout the western region, \nforcing some energy-intensive businesses like paper mills and mines to \ntemporarily close. \n\n------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n--\nCopyright , 2001 Reuters Limited. \n\n",
        "headers": {
            "Date": "Thu, 29 Mar 2001 02:33:00 -0800 (PST)",
            "From": "james.steffes@enron.com",

This approach leads to multiple resource id's for plants that are in \nmany cases managed at a plant level...not \"unit\" level as this approach \nimplies. The burden to submit resource plans at the component level and the \npossibility of receiving a Unit Specific deployments, along with the \nproliferation of resource id's (many of these plants are owned by multiple \nentities...leading to even more resource id's) points out that different \nsolution is needed. Greg Graham ggraham@lcra.org\n\nReceived: from hood.lcra.org by lcuuser.lcra.org; Mon, 14 May 2001 19:38:22 \n-0600\nReceived: from wrangell.lcra.org (wrangell.lcra.org [198.214.247.194]) by \nhood.lcra.org (8.9.3 (PHNE_18546)/8.9.3) with ESMTP id TAA09342 for \n<greg.graham@int-mail.lcra.org>; Mon, 14 May 2001 19:38:53 -0500 (CDT)\nReceived: from mail.ercot.com (mail.ercot.com [65.67.37.83]) by \nwrangell.lcra.org with ESMTP (8.9.3 (PHNE_18546)/8.7.1) id TAA19016 for \n<greg.graham@lcra.org>; Mon, 14 May 2001 19:38:52 -0500 (CDT)\nReceived: by MAIL with Internet Mail Service (5.5.2650.21) id <KFRNP4FC>; \nMon, 14 May 2001 19:38:46 -0500\nMessage-ID: <C9295233C0E3D3119214009027E52EF0A0A429@MAIL>\nFrom: \"Adams, John\" <JAdams@ercot.com>\nTo: \"Northcutt, Robert\" <RNorthcutt@ercot.com>\nCc: \"Kessler, Amy\" <AKessler@ercot.com>,        \"Boecker, Arthur\"  \n<ABoecker@ercot.com>,        \"Trinh, Thong\" <TTrinh@ercot.com>, \"Cohea, \nJames\"  <JCohea@ercot.com>,        \"Boecker, Arthur\" \n<ABoecker@ercot.com>,        \"Myers, Steven\" <SMyers@ercot.com>,        \n\"Graham, Greg\" <greg.graham@lcra.org>,        \"Donohoo, Ken\" \n<KDonohoo@ercot.com>,        \"Tamby, Jeyant\" <JTamby@ercot.com>,        \n\"Saathoff, Kent\" <KSaathoff@ercot.com>\nSubject: FW: Generator unit consolidation\nDate: Mon, 14 May 2001 19:38:45 -0500\nMIME-Version: 1.0\nX-Mailer: Internet Mail Service (5.5.2650.21)\nContent-Type: multipart/alternative; \nboundary=\"----_=_NextPart_001_01C0DCD7.6616BF20\"\n\n\n\nRobert \n\nThere has been considerable discussion and argument over the need of the \nsecurity applications to have each unit described in the model uniquely to \nallow\n\nthe stability applications to work properly. \n\nOperations has argued strongly that every unit over a size (20 mw) has got to \nbe modeled for the stability analysis modules to work.\n\nI understand that every unit modeled in registration MUST have a \ncorresponding ( one to one) entry in the network model.? \n\nAs I understant it, this leads to the following chain where the symbol => \nmeans \"requires\" \n\nOperations needs all synchronous units > 20 MW? modeled & telemeter=> \nAll units over 20 MW must be registered uniquely (elements of combined cycle \nplants registered uniquely)?? Consequence of Design\n\nAll units must be settled matching the registration database => \n??????? ??????? ??????? ??????? ??????? ??????? Consequence of Design\n\nAll resource plans must be submitted for each unit of a Combined Cycle unit \n=> \nJointly owned Combined Cycle units must submit resource plan items for each \nowner of each unit of a Combined Cycle plant for each scheduling period =>\n\nA combined cycle plant with 6 units and 3 owners results in 6 * 3 * 96 \nentries per day. \n\nI understand many QSE's are balking at this requirement as burdensome and \nun-necessary. (LCRA, OXY,etc) \n\nWe also have a problem with modeling of MANY MANY very small resources to get \nthem into the settlement system. \n\nIt occurs to me that the Operations Requirement is NOT that the individual \nunits be settled separately, or scheduled separately.? Only that they be \nmodeled separately and telemetered separately. \n\nWhy can't we have a single entry in the settlement system map to many units \nin the network model, and conversely have many entries in the settlement \nsystem (many small units) map to a single, or even NO entry in the network \nmodel?\n\nWhy can't we break the link between unit registration and the network model?? \nor at least modify it?? Or do I mis-understand the situation?\n\nPlease let me know if my understanding of the situation is correct or correct \nme if I misunderstand.? I would appreciate suggestions on how to improve the \nsituation.\n\n\n?-----Original Message----- \nFrom: ? Kessler, Amy? \nSent:?? Thursday, May 10, 2001 8:11 AM \nTo:???? Moore became expendable with the addition of veteran \nTerry Allen, and won't have any Fantasy value even if he returns.  \n\n Matt Hatchette , WR MIN - Free Agent Updated 12/12/00 \n Hatchette injured the oblique muscle above his hip during last Sunday's game \nagainst St. Louis. He's listed as day to day, but is expected to play Sunday \nagainst Green Bay. He's not someone who will help your Fantasy team much, \nthough.  \n\n Chris Walsh , WR MIN - Free Agent Updated 12/12/00 \n Walsh is unlikely to play Sunday against Green Bay after he underwent \nsurgery on Tuesday on a broken bone in his left cheek. He suffered the injury \nduring last Sunday's game against St. Louis but finished the game. Walsh has \nbeen valuable to the Vikings on special teams and as the No. 4 receiver, but \nhe's not a viable Fantasy option.  \n\n Fred Taylor , RB JAC - The Snake Pit Updated 12/12/00 \n The Jaguars will need to evaluate Taylor's sprained left knee during \npractice this week before determining his status for Sunday's game against \nCincinnati. He suffered the injury during the third quarter of last Sunday's \ngame, which was his seventh straight with at least 100 rushing yards. \nHopefully Taylor will be able to play, as he's among the best options at \nrunning back during the Fantasy playoffs.  \n\n Dennis Northcutt , WR CLE - Free Agent Updated 12/12/00 \n Northcutt will miss Cleveland's final game of the season Sunday against \nTennessee due to a sprained ankle. Believe it or not, this likely hurts the \nBrowns' quarterbacking situation most, as he was rotating in that slot last \nSunday against Philadelphia. It's best to avoid any Cleveland players at this \nstage of the Fantasy season.  \n\n Curtis Enis , RB CHI - Free Agent Updated 12/12/00 \n Enis, who missed last Sunday's game against New England due to a reaction to \nan over-the-counter flu medicine, was feeling better Monday. Still, his \nstatus for Sunday's game against San Francisco is unknown, so it's best to \nkeep him on your bench this week.  \n\n Shane Matthews , QB CHI - Free Agent Updated 12/12/00 \n Bears Coach Dick Jauron may give Matthews the start at quarterback on Sunday \nagainst San Francisco, instead of giving Cade McNown the final two starts. \nOne possible reason for that may be that Matthews aggravated an injury when \nhe was rushed back last season, and Jauron didn't want the same to happen to \nMcNown. We don't recommend either quarterback this week, despite him facing \nthe weak Niners' pass defense.   \n\n Tim Biakabutuka , RB CAR - The Rounders Updated 12/12/00 \n Biakabutuka, who has missed four games with turf toe, may be able to \npractice on Wednesday. Even if he is able to play Sunday against San Diego, \nwe wouldn't recommend Biakabutuka the remainder of the season.  \n\n Steve Beuerlein , QB CAR - Fear Updated 12/12/00 \n Although he's most likely the quarterback for 2001, Beuerlein might be \nbenched for backup Jeff Lewis for part of Carolina's final two games. Nothing \nis worse than a part-time quarterback for your Fantasy playoffs, so steer \nclear of both players if at all possible.  \n\n Jeff Lewis , QB CAR - Free Agent Updated 12/12/00 \n Coach George Seifert says that he may give Lewis some playing time over the \nfinal two games, although he has endorsed Steve Beuerlein as the starter for \n2001. Lewis has a high cost against the cap, so the Panthers need to \ndetermine soon whether he's the quarterback of the future. On the other hand, \nBeuerlein has the third-longest consecutive-starts streak in the league at QB \nand may not want to end it. Lewis isn't someone we'd recommend during your \nFantasy playoffs, whether he starts or not.  \n\n Jammi German , WR ATL - Free Agent Updated 12/12/00 \n German was unable to practice Monday, and may be placed on injured reserve \non Tuesday with a badly sprained left ankle. He has no Fantasy value.  \n\n Bills , DT BUF - Ramiro Updated 12/12/00 \n The Bills' defense has been ravaged by injuries this season, and it \ncertainly showed on Monday night. Although Indianapolis did score two \ndefensive touchdowns in the game, Buffalo's D still gave up 30 points to \nIndy. Once a solid defensive unit, the Bills are now just a shell of their \nformer selves and shouldn't be considered a starting defensive squad on your \nFantasy team.   \n\n Steve Christie , K BUF - Free Agent Updated 12/12/00 \n Christie made up for his scoreless performance last week with two field \ngoals on Monday night, including a 46-yard boot in the second quarter. He is \none of the best placekickers in the league, and should be considered a weekly \nstarter on your Fantasy team.   \n\n Jeremy McDaniel , WR BUF - FDIC Updated 12/12/00 \n The Bills' young wideout has only 12 receptions in his last six games and \nhasn't seen the end zone since Week Three against the Jets. What little \nFantasy value he may have had early in the season is all but gone now.   \n\n Mike Vanderjagt , K IND - The Fat Bastards Updated 12/12/00 \n Vanderjagt converted on all three of his field goal attempts in Monday \nnight's win over Buffalo. He is one of the NFL's most accurate kickers, \nmissing only two field goals the entire season. Starting Vanderjagt this week \nis a good idea against a tough Miami defesne that doesn't allow many \ntouchdowns.   \n\n Marcus Pollard , TE IND - Free Agent Updated 12/12/00 \n Pollard hasn't had more than two catches in any game in the last four weeks, \nand hasn't scored a touchdown since Week Five. Translation: Avoid starting \nPollard at all costs for the duration of your Fantasy season.   \n\n Ken Dilger , TE IND - Thrill Kill Cult Updated 12/12/00 \n With only seven receptions in the last four weeks, including only one on \nMonday night, Dilger has become a Fantasy afterthought. Avoid starting him if \nyour roster allows it.  \n\n Jerome Pathon , WR IND - Free Agent Updated 12/12/00 \n Pathon caught three passes for 31 yards on Monday night against the Bills. \nAt this point in the season, Pathon has no Fantasy value.   \n\n Eric Moulds , WR BUF - FDIC Updated 12/12/00 \n Moulds had another sub-par performance on Monday night, catching only two \npasses for 47 yards in the Bills' loss to Indianapolis. In the last two \nweeks, Moulds has caught only four balls for 58 yards and no touchdowns. \nFantasy owners who have Moulds should continue starting him in the Fantasy \nplayoffs and hope that he can break out of this semi-slump.    \n\n Terrence Wilkins , WR IND - The Rounders Updated 12/12/00 \n Wilkins came back down to earth after last week's 109-yard, one touchdown \nperformance against the Jets, catching only two passes for 37 yards on Monday \nnight. Wilkins has been far more effective on special teams than as a \nreceiver in recent weeks, so don't expect much production in the final two \nweeks of the season.    \n\n Marvin Harrison , WR IND - The Lie Downs Updated 12/12/00 \n To the disbelief of many Fantasy owners, Harrison was held in check in \nMonday night's game with the Bills. He caught only two passes for 27 yards \nagainst what was an injury-depleted Buffalo secondary - a performance which \nmay have helped keep some owners from moving on in their playoffs. If you \nwere lucky enough to advance, Harrison is still a must start, even against \nthe Colts' next opponent, the Miami Dolphins. In the team's first meeting, \nHarrison scorched the Fish for 74 yards receiving and two scores.     \n\n Peerless Price , WR BUF - The Rounders Updated 12/12/00 \n Price had his best performance of the season on Monday night, catching four \npasses for 93 yards and a touchdown in Buffalo's loss to the Colts. These \nwere the types of numbers that Fantasy owners were expecting all season from \nPrice, but they are still too little, too late to consider him for your \nstarting lineup.   \n\n Sammy Morris , RB BUF - The Fat Bastards Updated 12/12/00 \n Morris returned to limited duty on Monday night after missing two games with \nan ankle injury. He accounted for 34 yards of total offense and a touchdown \nin the Bills' 44-20 loss. Morris will likely be splitting time with Shawn \nBryson in the backfield, so it's a good idea to avoid starting either of \nBuffalo's tailbacks at this point.  \n\n Shawn Bryson , RB BUF - Meximullets Updated 12/12/00 \n Bryson got the majority of the carries against the Colts on Monday night, \nrushing the ball 15 times for 45 yards.  His main production, however, came \nthrough the air, where he caught six passes for 75 yards. Bryson's 120 yards \nof total offense is impressive, but he still isn't a viable option for \nFantasy owners at this point in the season.    \n\n Edgerrin James , RB IND - The Fat Bastards Updated 12/12/00 \n \"The Edge\" had a terrific Fantasy performance on Monday night, compiling 132 \nyards of total offense and three touchdowns in the Colts' big win over \nBuffalo. James will face a Miami squad that gave up 118 yards rushing to him \nback in Week 12, but also kept him out of the end zone. When it comes really \ncomes down to it, the Colts could be facing the 1985 Bears' defense and it \nwouldn't matter - James is a must start for the duration of the Fantasy \nplayoffs.  \n\n Peyton Manning , QB IND - The Lie Downs Updated 12/12/00 \n Manning had a very un-Peyton like performance on Monday night, completing \n13-of-24 passes for only 132 yards and no touchdowns in the Colts' 44-20 win. \nIt was the first time this season that Manning was held with out at least one \ntouchdown pass in a game. If your team survived Manning's poor Fantasy \nperformance, you may not like his team's next opponent - Miami. The Dolphins \nhave two of the best corners in the game in Patrick Surtain and Sam Madison, \nso it isn't out of the question for Manning to have another sub-par \nperformance. At this point in the season, it is a good idea to stick with the \nformer Vols star and hope he can have a more typical Peyton Manning day.    \n\n Brock Huard , QB SEA - Free Agent Updated 12/12/00 \n Huard is expected to miss another game while recovering from a bruised \nkidney this week. Jon Kitna will start again and might make several turnovers \nagainst an opportunistic Oakland defense.  \n\nMore Updates \n\n Rosters?Teams? \n\n\n [IMAGE]\n[IMAGE]\n Meximullets \n Eric Bass \n\n\n\n  Player  \n  TM  \n  Pos  \n  Status  \n  Next  \n  Bye  \n  Garcia, Jeff  \n SF \n QB \n Active \n CHI \n  Week 13  \n Davis, Stephen  \n WAS \n RB \n Active \n @PIT \n  Week 11  \n Garner, Charlie  \n SF \n RB \n Active \n CHI \n  Week 13  \n Holt, Torry  \n STL \n WR \n Active \n @TB \n  Week 6  \n Toomer, Amani  \n NYG \n WR \n Active \n @DAL \n  Week 8  \n Freeman, Antonio  \n GB \n WR \n Active \n @MIN \n  Week 8  \n Brady, Kyle  \n JAC \n TE \n Active \n @CIN \n  Week 10  \n Anderson, Gary  \n MIN \n K \n Active \n GB \n  Week 4  \n Ravens  \n BAL \n DT \n Active \n @ARI \n  Week 14  \n McNabb, Donovan  \n PHI \n QB \n Reserve \n bye \n  Week 16  \n Hicks, Skip  \n WAS \n RB \n Reserve \n @PIT \n  Week 11  \n Bryson, Shawn  \n BUF \n RB \n Reserve \n NE \n  Week 4  \n Autry, Darnell  \n PHI \n RB \n Reserve \n bye \n  Week 16  \n Watson, Justin  \n STL \n RB \n Reserve \n @TB \n  Week 6  \n Schroeder, Bill  \n GB \n WR \n Reserve \n @MIN \n  Week 8  \n Robinson, Marcus  \n CHI \n WR \n Reserve \n @SF \n  Week 9  \n Redskins  \n WAS \n DT \n Reserve \n @PIT \n  Week 11  \n\nTotal Active Players: 9\nTotal Reserve Players: 8\n\n  NFL Injuries for Meximullets  \n\n  Updated  \n  Player  \n  Team  \n  Pos  \n  Injury  \n  Expected Return  \n 12/12/00 \n  Autry, Darnell  \n PHI \n RB \n Shoulder \n Probable vs. Cin (Dec. 24) \n 12/4/00 \n  Robinson, Marcus  \n CHI \n WR \n Back \n Out for the rest of the season \n\n\n View?Transactions? \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n[IMAGE]?         "body": "PG&E Corporation's First Wind Farm Nears Commercial Operation; Facility is \nFirst of Its\n                    Kind in New York State \n                    Source: Business Wire \n                    Publication date: 2000-09-15\n\n\n                    BETHESDA, Md.--(BUSINESS WIRE)--Sept. 15,\n                    2000--New York State's first merchant wind farm\n                    takes another step toward commercial operation\n                    today. \n\n                     PG&E Corporation's (NYSE: PCG) National\n                    Energy Group will mark the occasion at the\n                    11.5-megawatt Madison Windpower Project in\n                    Madison County, New York with a ribbon-cutting\n                    ceremony today and a community open house\n                    tomorrow. \n\n                    \"Madison Windpower's commercial operation is a\n                    milestone for us,\" said PG&E National Energy\n                    Group President and Chief Operating Officer Chris\n                    Iribe. \"Aside from offering critical additional capacity\n                    to the New York State power market, we're\n                    pioneering a new approach to linking customers to\n                    new, renewable energy facilities.\" \n\n                    The seven-turbine facility, the first of its kind east of\n                    the Mississippi River, will sell electricity into the\n                    Northeast power grid through the New York State\n                    Electric & Gas Transmission System and the New\n                    York Independent System Operator (ISO). \n\n                    The company will also offer Pure Wind(SM)\n                    certificates to interested customers. Pure\n                    Wind(SM) certificates correspond to the\n                    environmental attributes associated with equivalent\n                    amounts of wind-generated electricity delivered to\n                    the New York power pool. \n\n                    Because wind-generated electricity has no air\n                    emissions, the avoided emissions may be\n                    compared to the pollution emitted by the average of\n                    all New York State power generation facilities. On\n                    this basis, total electricity output for the Madison\n                    Windpower facility in an average year will avoid\n                    12,000 tons of carbon dioxide (CO2), 65 tons of\n                    sulfur dioxide (SO2), and 19 tons of nitrogen oxide\n                    (NOx). \n\n                    Pure Wind(SM) certificates will also be available to\n                    consumers through a web-based sales site at\n                    http://www.purewind.net, currently under\n                    development. \n\n                    \"Wind power is a commercially available,\n                    economically viable and completely renewable\n                    energy source,\" said Iribe. \"This project puts\n                    Madison on the map as an innovative leader in the\n                    development of renewable energy; and by\n                    supporting this project, New York has jumped to the\n                    forefront in demonstrating its commitment to\n                    improved air quality,\" he added. \n\n                    To further the process of bringing renewable power\n                    to New York State, the New York State Energy\n                    Research and Development Authority (NYSERDA)\n                    awarded the Madison Windpower Project a\n                    research and development contract. \n\n                    \"As NYSERDA celebrates its 25th anniversary this\n                    week, how fitting it is for us to be here today\n                    celebrating the opening of the largest wind power\n                    plant in the Northeast,\" said Parker D. Mathusa, a\n                    member of NYSERDA's Board of Directors.\n                    \"NYSERDA's mission over those years has been to\n                    use innovation and technology to help solve the\n                    State's energy and environmental problems, which\n                    is exactly what we are doing here today as we bring\n                    clean power to the market place.\" \n\n                    The Madison project joins one of the nation's\n                    fast-growing power generation sectors. According to\n                    the American Wind Energy Association (AWEA),\n                    capacity from windpower plants has nearly doubled\n                    in the last 10 years. Currently, installed windpower\n                    facilities supply nearly 2,650 megawatts of capacity\n                    to U.S. markets. \n\n                    With wind speeds between eight and twenty miles\n                    per hour, Madison will supply enough emission-free\n                    electricity to power approximately 10,000 homes. \n\n                    PG&E Corporation with 1999 revenues of nearly $21\n                    billion and operations in 21 states, markets energy\n                    services and products throughout North America\n                    through its National Energy Group. \n\n                    The Corporation has ownership and management\n                    interests in 30 operating electric power generating\n                    plants in 10 states, providing it with a generation\n                    portfolio of more than 7,000 megawatts and more\n                    than 10,000 megawatts in new power plant\n                    development and construction currently underway. It\n                    also has one of the largest energy trading and risk\n                    management programs in North America. \n\n                    B-Roll available upon request \n\n                    Please visit our websites: www.pgecorp.com and\n                    www.purewind.net \n\n                    To order a copy of PG&E Corporation's 1999\n                    Environmental Annual Report, click on the leaf\n                    symbol on our website or call 800/743-6397. \n\n                    To order a copy of PG&E Corporation's 1999\n                    Financial Annual Report, click on the club symbol\n                    on our website or call 800/654-2582. \n\n                    EDITORS: Please do not use \"Pacific Gas and\n                    Electric\" or \"PG&E\" when referring to PG&E\n                    Corporation or its National Energy Group. The\n                    PG&E National Energy Group is not the same\n                    company as Pacific Gas and Electric Company,\n                    the utility, and is not regulated by the California\n                    Public Utilities Commission. \n\n                    Customers of Pacific Gas and Electric Company do\n                    not have to buy products or services from the\n                    National Energy Group in order to continue to\n                    receive quality regulated services from Pacific Gas\n                    and Electric Company. ",

        "body": "Judging from a number of e-mails I've gotten, this note may not have gotten\nthrough.  So here it comes again.\n\nDiane\n\n************8\n\nHI Everyone,\n\nIt's just about time to think about registering for Fall 01 classes.  Early\nnext week, TJ will be sending materials to your home addresses, and it's\nvery important that you read through them carefully.  In the meantime, I've\nattached a preliminary list of electives that will be offered.\n\nMost importantly, please remember that there are two rounds of\npre-enrollment for Fall 01 classes.  You must enroll in classes during\nRound I to retain your seniority status in classes.  So, for example, if\nyou are going to be a fifth semester student in the fall and forget to sign\nup for classes during Round I, and then try to get into an oversubscribed\nclass in Round II, you will have lost your seniority status because you did\nnot sign up in Round I.\n\nFor those of you who would like to get academic advising (e.g., \"Which\ncourses do I take if I want to be a consumer products marketer?) or program\nplanning (e.g., \"How do graduate in five semesters?\") please feel free to\nmake a telephone or in-person appointment with me.  (Advising by e-mail is\nnearly impossible because of the level detail required for effective\nadvising.)\n\nAs course descriptions become available, they will be put up on the web.\n\nUPDATES ON UNKNOWNS IN THE EvMBA ELECTIVE COURSES\n\nE220, Corporate Financial Reporting, Brett Trueman:  Brett Trueman is the\nAccounting group chair and is a fabulous teacher, winning the Outstanding\nTeacher of the Year Award in the day program.  If you're interested in\nCorporate Finance or Investments, you should take this course eventually.\n\nE234, Corporate Finance, Levy:  Amnon Levy has a PhD from Kellogg, did his\nundergraduate work in economics here at Berkeley, and is visiting next year\nfrom NYU.\n\nE236, Futures and Options, Manuel Ammann:  Prof Ammann is a visitor from\nthe University of St. Gallen in Switzerland.  He visited here last year,\nand I heard he is great.\n\nE259-1, Leadership, Nancy Euske:  Nancy teaches the core course in OB and\nhas done an excellent job.  This will NOT be Jenny Chatman's Leadership\ncourse taught by Nancy Euske.  It will be Nancy's Leadership\ncourse.  Please check the web site for a detailed description.\n\nE264, High-Tech Marketing; Rajiv:  Surendra Rajiv has a PhD from Carnegie\nMellon and will be visiting here next year from the University of\nChicago.  He's taught High Tech Marketing and Pricing Strategies in both\nthe full - and part-time MBA programs at Chicago.\n\nE268, Branding, Upshaw:  Lynn Upshaw is principal of Upshaw & Associates, a\nnational brand and marketing consulting practice.  Mr. Upshaw was formerly\nExecutive Vice President/Brand Marketing for Ketchum Communications\nWorldwide and has written two books \"Building Brand Identity:  A Strategy\nfor Success in a Hostile Marektplace\" and \"The Masterbrand Mandate.\"\n\nE278-1, Deals; Shelanski:  Howard Shelanski is a professor at Boalt, and\nthe basic premise of the course is to tie contract theory, contract law,\nand business strategy together.  \"How do structures of relationships\nbetween firms, or more generally contracting parties, change with contract\nlaw and strategic imperatives?  The course will give students some tools to\nthink about 'business development' from both a legal and economic standpoint.\"\n\nE296-4, E-Business Supply Chain Management, Hamid Noori:  Hamid is a\nProfessor of Technology and Operations Management at the Laurier Business\nSchool, Wilfird Laureir University in Waterloo, Ontario.\n\nE296-5, New Telecom Ventues, Bob Harris:  Bob Harris is a (young) retired\nfaculty member, who went on to establish a very successful consulting\ncompany.  Bob is a great teacher (I had him for Macro), and he is thrilled\nto be back teaching a course on Entrepreneurship in Telecommunications.\n\nE296-6 Pricing Strategy, Scott Davis:  Scott is teaching this course this\nsemester and is doing a great job.  He used to be a faculty member at\nWashington University in St. Louis where he won the Outstanding Teacher of\nthe Year Award, but he moved out here and established a successful\nmarketing consulting practice in the Sacramento area.\n\nCOURSES YOU MIGHT THINK ABOUT IN THE DAY PROGRAM:\nBA235 Portfolio Management (Th 2 - 4:00 pm), Jim Wilcox:  Jim teaches our\nE201B class (though he has been serving in Washington DC as Comptroller of\nthe Treasury for the past two years)  and won the Outstanding Teacher of\nthe Year Award in the EvMBA Program just before he left for DC.  This\ncourse will be banking related covering topics such as interest risk and\nmeasuring and controlling credit risk in financial institutions.\n\nBA278 Contemporary Philanthropy (Th 4:00 - 6:00  pm), Fran Van Loo:  Fran\nis a Haas economist who also runs the Public and Not-for-Profit Program.\n\nBA295C Entrepreneurship Workshop (M 2 - 4:00 pm), Danner:  This course is\nfor those students who are actually in the process of \"going live\" with an\nentrepreneurial idea.  Please check the website for details.\n\nBA299D Strategic Marketing Planning (Th 4 - 6:00 pm), Peter Wilton:  Some\noverlap with E210, but definitely a great class taught by a great instructor.\n\n\nSOME GENERAL COMMENTS:\n\n(1)  You should try to take Competitive Strategy as late in your program as\nyou possibly can.  You will get a lot more out of it if you bring to the\ncourse as much previous coursework as possible.  Obviously, you need to\nbalance this against the risk of the course not being offered in subsequent\nsemesters, but it is best to take that course later in your\nprogram.  Currently, Katz is scheduled to teach the course in Spring 02 as\nwell as F01.\n\n(2)  Finance is divided into two main areas:  Corporate Finance and \nInvestments\n- Corporate Finance:  if you are interested in corporate finance you would\nprobably want to take some combination of  E234, E220, E232, E285 (for\ncompanies doing a lot of international/global operations), and perhaps\nE233, and perhaps E222 (Valuation - for large companies involved in a lot\nof acquisitions).\n\n- Investments:  if you're interested in Investments (investment banking,\nfinancial services, etc.), you should probably want to take some\ncombination of  E234, E220 and/or E222 (for individuals going into Mergers\nand Acquisitions), E233 and/or E236, and E285 (if your company is  involved\nin intl markets).\n\n(3)  If you don't want to go into finance but feel like you need a little\nmore finance that just E203, Money Markets (E232) is a great class taught\nby a great instructor.  Please see web for more detail.\n\n(4)  If you are truly interested in concentrating in marketing, the two\n\"core electives\" for marketers are E261, Marketing Research, and E262B,\nProduct Management.  These two courses will  give you the critical basics\nneeded for careers in marketing.  Additionally, Pricing Strategy is an\nimportant course.  The many other marketing classes are more specific to\nparticular industries (e.g., Internet Strategy, High-Tech Marketing, etc.).\n\n(5)  I believe very strongly that EVERYONE should graduate with at least\none OB elective.  In addition to the very popular Negotiations course, we\nhave some other great OB classes:  Org Strategy with Bahrami; Leadership\nwith Chatman or Euske; Power and Politics in Orgs with Schroth in Spring\n02, etc..  When alums are surveyed, they always say \"I wish I took more\nOB!\"  (I know - you've heard me say this a million times!)\n\nIf anything else comes up, I'll keep you posted.\n\nCheers,\n\nDiane \n - F01electives.doc",
