        "body": "Sally\r\n\r\nI just want to summarize/clarify our discussions so far on the Commercial=\r\n=20\r\nSupport model for Enron Japan.=20\r\n\r\nMy background:\r\nIn Europe the Commercial Support function was divided into a Middle Office=\r\n=20\r\n(MO) and a Back Office (BO) part, with a European controller (Fearnley Dyso=\r\nn)=20\r\nresponsible for both functions. For Scandinavia, the only trading office in=\r\n=20\r\nEurope outside of London, I was responsible for both functions, as Local=20\r\nOffice controller, reporting into Barry Pearce, who reported to Fearnley. I=\r\nn=20\r\nJapan I also have this Local Office Controller function, as being responsib=\r\nle=20\r\nfor MO/BO activities in this region. The MO would consist of the trading=20\r\nrelated functions: Documentation (Capture & Confirmation), Risk Management,=\r\n=20\r\nSettlement and Trade Accounting. The BO would consist of G&A's, Salaries &=\r\n=20\r\nWages, Tax, Management reporting, Statutory reporting and VAT.=20\r\n\r\nBack Office:\r\nI report directly to Cassandra Scultz (VP & CAO of Enron APACHI). As much a=\r\ns=20\r\npossible are to be outsourced to our Sydney office (Heidi Mason, who also=\r\n=20\r\nreports to Cassandra), but some work has to be done in Tokyo. The reasons f=\r\nor=20\r\nthis outsourcing decision is enclosed in the Power Point presentation=20\r\nenclosed below. For payments we use Houston Treasury, as they are the only=\r\n=20\r\nones that can exercise a payment in the banking systems.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nMiddle Office:\r\n\r\nMandate\r\nWhat I have in writing is a section from Joe Hirl's Memo (Request for Japan=\r\n=20\r\nPower Trading Positions (DRAFT)) to Rick Buy and Greg Whalley dated April 1=\r\n9=20\r\nthis year (please find enclosed)\r\n\r\nBack Office Operations:  Jan Erland Bekeng in cooperation with Sally Beck=\r\n=20\r\nwill look to establish the local risk books in Tokyo and define any=20\r\nsystem     modifications necessary given the characteristics of the Japanes=\r\ne=20\r\nelectricity market.  Enron Japan will handle trade capture      and risk=20\r\nmanagement while confirmations and settlements will occur in Houston under=\r\n=20\r\nSally Beck=01,s supervision.  IT support and     system modification will b=\r\ne=20\r\noverseen by Anthony Dayao and performed in Houston.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nDiscussion -  Current & Future Situation\r\nI see more commodities than Power. Metals will arrive September 25, Weather=\r\n=20\r\nis on the way from Sydney, and Garry Hickerson will from September 1 have a=\r\n=20\r\nguy here doing IRFX, Agri and maybe Equity.  We are also looking into Oil=\r\n=20\r\ndeals, and have plans for Gas, Coal, Pulp & Paper, Credit and Emissions. Al=\r\nso=20\r\nEBS is on the way. I only see Metals, IRFX and Weather as active desks this=\r\n=20\r\nyear, maybe Oil. Power will take some more time to get active, due to the=\r\n=20\r\nvery closed market situation here right now. On the Origination side we mig=\r\nht=20\r\nsee some structures/cross commidity/finance deals go through. Thus we have =\r\na=20\r\nmix of activites from Enron APACHI, Enron Global Markets, EBS and Enron=20\r\nMetals. Basically everyone wants to do some business in Japan.\r\n\r\nTo coordinate all these activities we need to build the most cost efficient=\r\n,=20\r\nindependent, segregated, automised and service minded Japanese Commercial=\r\n=20\r\nSupport function possible. To accomplish these objectives, outsourcing to=\r\n=20\r\nSydney is an alternative that has been discussed extensive lately, and is=\r\n=20\r\nhighly recommended from our side. Labour costs in Sydney is 25% of the cost=\r\ns=20\r\nin Tokyo. Due to Sydney's experience and size they are ready to expand and=\r\n=20\r\ntake on this project. They already have the segregation and independence in=\r\n=20\r\nplace, and would give us an extra layer of segregation in the sense of bein=\r\ng=20\r\nan intermideary between Tokyo and Houston. Bilingual staff would be hired t=\r\no=20\r\nperform Japanese services, which is widely available in Sydney. And there i=\r\ns=20\r\nonly one hour in difference between us. Outsourcing these activities from=\r\n=20\r\nJapan to Australia is a growing trend, and many large corporations have don=\r\ne=20\r\nit this way.\r\n\r\nThere will be some time from the first trades until functions and commoditi=\r\nes=20\r\nare moved to Sydney. Tokyo want and needs to learn, understand all details,=\r\n=20\r\nautomise, make routines and calibrate systems first. On the confirmation si=\r\nde=20\r\nour Legal department would be heavily involved in th start, compared to lat=\r\ner=20\r\nstages.\r\n\r\nProposed MO structure for Enron Japan\r\n\r\nA) Responsibility for all Commercial Support activities in Japan to be=20\r\nsourced to Enron Japan, under Enron Japan's CFO.\r\n\r\nB) Outsource programmable tasks to Sydney:\r\n - Documentation (Capture & Confirmation)\r\n - Settlement\r\n - Trade Accounting\r\n\r\nC) Risk Management in Tokyo.\r\n\r\n\r\nI look forward to hear from you.\r\n\r\nRegards\r\nJan-Erland ",

        "body": "Here's your hook em.com fix for the day.....\n\n\nBackup quarterback\nleaving Texas\n\nAssociated Press\n\nPosted: April 26, 2000\n\nAUSTIN -- Adam Hall, the Texas Longhorns\nbackup quarterback during spring drills,\nsaid\nhe will transfer from the University of\nTexas\nthis fall, coach Mack Brown announced\nWednesday.\n\n\"The biggest factor was that I want to\nhave a\nchance to be a starter in the near\nfuture,\" said\nAdam Hall, a redshirt freshman from\nWestlake\nHigh School.\n\nThe university has released Hall from his\n\nscholarship. Hall plans to complete the\nspring\nsemester then enroll in another\ninstitution in\nthe fall. The new institution was not\nnamed in\na news release.\n\n\"I love all of my teammates and\nappreciate\neverything the coaches and staff have\ndone for\nme at Texas, but I think I will have a\nbetter\nopportunity to play sooner at another\nschool,\"\nhe said.\n\nHall completed four of five passes for 85\nyards\nand a touchdown in Texas' spring game on\nApril 1. He completed 143 of 263 passes\nfor\n2,188 yards and 21 touchdowns at Westlake\n\nin 1998.\n\nBrown said Hall was a hardworking young\nman\non the field and in the classroom.         "body": "He could have solved this problem in 20 minutes, right?\n\n\n\n\tJeff Dasovich\n\tSent by: Jeff Dasovich\n\t03/25/2001 12:40 PM\n\t\t \n\t\t To: skean@enron.com, Richard Shapiro/NA/Enron@Enron, James D \nSteffes/NA/Enron@Enron, mpalmer@enron.com, Karen Denne/Corp/Enron@ENRON, \nSusan J Mara/NA/Enron@ENRON, Sandra McCubbin/NA/Enron@Enron, Paul \nKaufman/PDX/ECT@ECT, Harry Kingerski/NA/Enron@Enron, Janel \nGuerrero/Corp/Enron@Enron, Linda Robertson/NA/Enron@ENRON, Joe \nHartsoe/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Tom Briggs/NA/Enron@Enron, Alan Comnes/PDX/ECT@ECT\n\t\t cc: \n\t\t Subject: Davis favors tiered rate increases but still clings to \"no new rate \nincreases\"\n\nPower Hogs May Get Hit In Pocketbook \nDavis favors tiered rate increases \nDavid Lazarus, Chronicle Staff Writer\nSunday, March 25, 2001 \n,2001 San Francisco Chronicle \nURL: \nhttp://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/chronicle/archive/2001/03/25/M\nN30195.DTL \nGov. Gray Davis, faced with the near inevitability of raising consumers' \nelectricity bills, is leaning toward a rate system whereby those who use more \npower pay more than those who conserve, The Chronicle has learned. \nSources close to the governor said he is being lobbied by his own staff \nmembers to accept a so-called structured rate system. \nTop officials from his own administration told lawmakers Friday that the \nstate may end up spending more than twice the $10 billion previously \nestimated to purchase power on behalf of California's near-bankrupt \nutilities. \nIf so, the officials warned that consumers' electricity rates could double. \nIn the case of Pacific Gas and Electric Co., this would mean customers' \naverage monthly power bills would rise from $60 to $120. \nConsumers throughout the Bay Area believe that at least some increase is on \nthe way. \n\"We're going to have to bite the bullet and pay the money,\" said Larry \nWebster, a retired Caltrans worker in Redwood City. \"We might as well admit \nthat electricity is no longer a nickel. It's a dime. If you're going to use \nit, \nlet's pay for it.\" \nSteve Maviglio, a spokesman for the governor, distanced himself yesterday \nfrom estimates that rates would double. The figures reported in the press, he \nsaid, \"were wildly high.\" \n\"The governor still believes he can live within the existing rate structure, \n\" Maviglio said. \"Until we know the results of the negotiations with the \nutilities, you can't conclude anything.\" \nThe state is negotiating a multibillion-dollar bailout package with PG&E and \nSouthern California Edison Co. to relieve the utilities of about $13 billion \nin debt. \nPG&E and Edison have been saying for months that there is no way California \ncan overcome its current energy woes without higher rates. The irony of the \nDavis administration now saying the same thing was not lost on the two \ncompanies. \n\"The state is in the exact same position the utilities were in last fall,\" \nsaid John Nelson, a PG&E spokesman. \"Either wholesale prices need to come \ndown or retail prices need to go up. The disparity is too large.\" \nStatewide blackouts last week drove home the precariousness of California's \nenergy situation to ratepayers -- and may have served as a blessing in \ndisguise for the governor. \nCOST VS. OUTAGES\nIf given a choice between further outages and paying higher rates, many \nconsumers said they would accept increases in their power bills. \n\"I don't like either choice,\" said Janet Leroux, facing the possibility of a \ngooey mess if the air conditioning goes out at her downtown San Francisco \ncandy store. \"But I guess I'd go with higher rates. I sure didn't like the \nblackouts.\" \nPublicly, the governor has been insisting for weeks that rates will stay \nwithin \"the existing rate structure\" -- a stealthy way of saying that \nJanuary's 9 percent increase and an expected 10 percent increase next year \nwill remain in place. \nBut privately, he and his staff are discussing additional rate increases that \ncould be spread over as long as 10 years, sources said. \nUtility executives and power generators told The Chronicle last week that a \nminimum 30 percent rate increase lasting up to a decade is in the cards. \n\"For the good of California, it's inevitable,\" said Gary Ackerman, executive \ndirector of the Western Power Trading Forum, a Menlo Park energy industry \nassociation. \nSacramento resident John Hax observed that when temperatures soar in the \nCentral Valley this summer, he'd be more than willing to pay a higher price \nfor power if this keeps the air conditioners on. \n\"It's like gasoline,\" he said. \"I don't like paying higher prices for \ngasoline, but that's the price of doing business.\" \nRatepayers draw the line, though, at any increase topping 10 or 20 percent. \n\"If it was 20 percent, I'd probably do it,\" said Tracy resident Mark \nDougherty. \"But if it was more, like 50 percent, I'd rather go with rolling \nblackouts.\" \n\"I'd rather have blackouts,\" agreed Jenny Soghomonian, owner of a shoe- \nrepair shop in San Francisco's Financial District. \"I don't want to pay rates \nthat are so much higher.\" \nNOT EVERY COST PALATABLE\nThis is the tightrope that state officials and industry players now find \nthemselves walking: While consumers may be willing to pay more to avoid \nblackouts, they aren't willing to swallow virtually any cost thrown their \nway. \nYet if rates are not high enough, they may not prevent daily blackout threats \nthis summer and beyond. \n\"Higher rates are the price signal that it takes for conservation,\" said Tom \nHiggins, senior vice president of Edison International, parent company of \nSouthern California Edison. \nSimply put, he meant that most consumers will not aggressively conserve \npower, and thus alleviate shortages, unless there is a financial incentive to \ndo so. \nRebates proposed by the governor have met with only a lukewarm response, \nrequiring, critics say, too much effort on the part of individual ratepayers. \nBut a sudden spike in monthly power bills almost certainly would prompt \nwidespread conservation measures. \n\"It adjusts consumer behavior,\" Higgins said. \"People want to get their bills \nback down.\" \nRATES' EFFECT ON USAGE\nHe and other industry sources said higher rates are perhaps the only way \nCalifornians will achieve the 10 percent conservation goal sought by the \ngovernor -- a move seen as vital if blackouts are to be avoided this summer. \n\"It's intellectually dishonest to think there's any other way out of this,\" \nHiggins said. \nConsumer activists' initial reaction to any talk of a rate increase comes \nacross loud and clear: No, no, no. \n\"No bailout. No rate increases. No secret deals,\" said Harvey Rosenfield, \nhead of the Foundation for Taxpayer and Consumer Rights in Santa Monica. \"We \nneed to get back to a regulated system.\" \nRosenfield is the biggest fly in the governor's ointment. He has threatened \nto push through a ballot initiative re-regulating California's power market \nif Davis cannot find a consumer-friendly way out of the current fix. \nBecause of Rosenfield's past success in writing a ballot measure on insurance \nrebates, which delivered about $800 million to consumers, his threat is taken \nseriously in Sacramento. \n\"We've paid too much already,\" Rosenfield said. \"A fair price is what we were \npromised by deregulation, which was a 20 percent rate decrease.\" \nHowever, when he was asked whether there was any room to discuss a structured \nrate increase such as the idea being promoted by the governor's staff, \nRosenfield toned down his characteristic rhetoric. \n\"Big users should pay more,\" he said after a moment's reflection. \"I'm open \nto a tiered system but only if it's fair.\" \nRosenfield quickly added that he would have to see how other consumer \nadvocates felt about the matter before agreeing to negotiate such things with \nDavis. \nMOVE TOWARD STRUCTURED RATES\nClearly, though, momentum is building toward a system of structured power \nrates, which probably would include increases of varying sizes for consumers. \nThe California Public Utilities Commission is scheduled to address January's \n9 percent rate increase on Tuesday. That increase originally was given only a \nthree-month duration, but most observers expect it to be renewed for at least \nanother three months, if not longer. \nPUC President Loretta Lynch declined to comment on the likelihood of rates \ngoing up but added her voice to those backing a structured system. \n\"I am a fan of restructuring rates to exempt conservation,\" she said. \"People \nwho use a whole lot of power should pay more.\" \nThe biggest electricity customer in the state is the state itself, now that \nCalifornia is purchasing power on behalf of its cash-poor utilities. The \nstate already has spent about $4 billion buying electricity and has yet to \ndetermine how the cash will be recouped from consumers. \nSan Francisco resident Rosita Magee accepts that for California to find its \nenergy footing once more, rates will probably be heading up. \"That way, you \nhave more convenience and electricity, more stability,\" she said. \nBut Magee has come up with another solution, one that doesn't involve rate \nincreases and rolling blackouts. \nShe's moving to Texas. \nChronicle staff writers Matthew Stannard and Pia Sarkar contributed to this \nreport. / E-mail David Lazarus at dlazarus@sfchronicle.com. \n,2001 San Francisco Chronicle ? Page?A - 1 \n",
        "headers": {

        "body": "---------------------- Forwarded by David M Gagliardi/TTG/HouInd on\n06/23/2000 09:01 AM ---------------------------\n\n\nTracy Ralston <wdr3@swbell.net> on 06/22/2000 10:30:48 PM\n\nTo:   wdr3@swbell.net\ncc:\n\nSubject:  FW: True Orange Fax/E-Mail #56\n\n\n\n\n-----Original Message-----\nFrom: TruOrange@aol.com [mailto:TruOrange@aol.com]\nSent: Wednesday, June 21, 2000 8:45 PM\nTo: TruOrange@aol.com\nSubject: True Orange Fax/E-Mail #56\n\n\nTrue Orange Fax/E-Mail Service\nVolume 8, Fax/E-Mail #56, Wednesday, June 21, 2000\nJerry Scarbrough's True Orange, P. Box 26530, Austin, Texas 78755 -\nPhone\n512-795-8536\n\nLonghorns Get Pledge from Euless Trinity Defensive Back\n\nBraden Johnson, 6-2, 200, 4.4, a defensive back from Euless Trinity who\ncame\nto one of Texas' three-day summer camps earlier this month, committed to\nthe\nLonghorns Wednesday.\nJohnson, a hard-hitting safety who had 42 tackles last season for the 9-2\nTrojans, who had one of the top defenses in the Dallas-Fort Worth area, is\nmoving to quarterback this season.\nHis father, David, told me his son decided to commit to the Longhorns\nbecause\n\"the Texas coaches really impressed him with their coaching methods and\nwith\nthe classy way they operate. They were very open and very straightforward.\"\nDavid Johnson said his son also attended a TCU camp this summer and went to\na\nTexas A&M camp last summer. He said several schools called his son in May,\nthe month the NCAA allows schools to make one phone call to each recruit.\nHe\nsaid calls came from coaches at Notre Dame, Oklahoma, Nebraska, Arkansas,\nTCU\nand others, but he said his son decided to commit to Texas and get the\nrecruiting process behind him so he could concentrate on his senior season.\nBraden Johnson has strong athletic blood lines. David Johnson was on a\nfootball scholarship at Oklahoma State when he suffered a career-ending\nshoulder injury and David has two famous uncles for old-time football fans.\nOne is Bill Johnson, who had a 20-year career as a player and coach with\nthe\nSan Francisco 49ers and who also coached with Paul Brown on the Cleveland\nBrowns' staff. The other is Gil Johnson, the quarterback on the great SMU\nteams that featured Doak Walker and Kyle Rote.\nBraden Johnson is a three-sport star. He plays centerfield in baseball and\nruns on the 400-meter relay in track. He also is a good student.\nJohnson is the fifth high school star to commit to Texas this month. The\nothers are WR-DB Brian Carter of The Woodlands, and OLs Jonathan Scott of\nDallas Carter, Abe Robinson of Houston Jersey Village and Will Allen of\nHouston Cypress Falls. In addition, Alfio Randall, a super OL recruit a\nyear\nago, is on track to graduate from Blinn JC in December and he told me he\nwill\nenroll at Texas in January.\nAll five of the high school prospects who committed did so after attending\none of the Longhorns' summer camps.\nScott and Robinson are on virtually all of the national top 100 lists.\nRECRUITING NOTES: The top running back and the top quarterback  in Texas\nboth\nsay they would like to commit early and the Longhorns are in strong\ncontention for both. The RB is Cedric Benson of Midland Lee, who rushed for\n3,526 yards and 51 touchdowns in leading Lee to a 16-0 season and it's\nsecond\nstraight Class 5A state championships. Both those incredible totals are\nClass\n5A records. The QB is Matt Nordgren of Dallas Bishop Lynch, who threw for\n2,500 yards as a sophomore before suffering a broken collarbone last season\nthat knocked him out of his teams' final five games. He still passed for\n1,170 yards. . . The Longhorns already have commitments from two of the 24\nmembers of the \"Super Team\" in Dave Campbell's Texas Football Magazine.\nThey\nare Scott and Robinson. The only other member of the \"Super Team\" who has\ncommitted is Madisonville RB David Underwood, the Aggies' No. 1 RB target\nwho\nannounced last week that he is going to be a Michigan Wolverine. Allen made\nthe second team and Carter made the third team. . . There are at least five\nsuper players I have seen who will be big recruiting targets next year.\nThat's right ? they were so good as sophomores that every school in the\ncountry already knows about them. They are QB Vincent Young, 6-5, 195, 4.5,\nof Houston Madison; RB Selvin Young, 5-11, 188, 4.4, of Houston Jersey\nVillage; DL Marco Martin, 6-4, 290, 4.7, of Mesquite; DE Travis Leitko,\n6-5,\n250, 4.7, of The Woodlands, and TE-OL Eric Winston, 6-6, 265, 5.0, of\nMidland\nLee. Young ran for 2,204 yards last year in a tough district. Young threw\nfor\n1,007 yards and ran for 730 more as a sophomore, also in a tough league.\nMartin is so agile that he also plays fullback and so quick that he's a\nterrific pass rusher and run stopper. Leitko was a dominating force as a\nsophomore last year on The Woodlands' playoff team. Winston is a great\nathlete who was one of the stars on Lee's title team as a sophomore. Leitko\nand Young came to Texas' summer camp earlier this month.\nIn the \"did-you-know\" department: Nebraska was 81-8 in the last seven\nfootball seasons.         "body": "The meeting went well. There was a lot of discussion regarding the current \ndeals involving the env. market.  ENA global markets presented their strategy \non trading/marketing emissions as well as compliance outsourcing \n(comprehensive services related to emissions reductions.); EES talked about \ncapturing bypassed emissions from current bundled deals as well as the \nchallenges of doing retail in states w/ varying mandates & reporting \nrequirements; EES (Bruce Stram) talked a bit about dg;  ENA origination \ntalked about a massive fuel cell project they are working on (they are \nkeeping it confidential currently); ENA West Structuring talked about \nfinancial packages to offset intermittent risk assc. w/ wind; Michael Payne \nEWC talked about wind development in the states and the associated \nopportunities w/ renewable energy credits; New Power talked a bit about their \nrollout in NJ, PA and upcoming CA.  New Power is at a point where they need \nto get up on the curve w/ regard to renewable mandates and reporting \nstandards.\n\nEveryone seemed to agree that it makes sense for environmental strategies to \nact as the \"link\" between the groups w/ regard to env. market opportunities.  \nThere are considerable synergies involved w/ ee, renewables, air emissions \nand technology control, and as we interface across the commercial groups, \nensure that the left hand is talking to the right (i.e. the deals are \ncapturing the most value and groups are aware of what others are working \non.)  We are rolling out an intranet page where we intend to offer business \nintelligence and env. regulation info.  In the near term, I'll be circulating \nthe presentations and the contact list.  There will be some sort of follow up \nmeeting that is structured completely differently than this one.\n\nHope this is helpful.     {
        "body": "Here's what I have:  I'm sure I'm on time in some time zone somewhere.  Tim \nBelden is due back from vacation on Monday.  The West desk would not give me \nany valuation estimates until Tim returned.\n\nEES\n\nPTR, Phase I  \nEnron was the only party that raised the issue of the UDCs imposing an \nartificial cap on the PX credit for direct customers (RAP '98).  The CPUC \nshined us on. Later, we ensured that it became part of ARM's case in PTR \nPhase I. The way the \"cap\" worked, the UDCs would not pay ESPs the full PX \ncredit when prices were high -- they would pay a credit that, when added to \nthe other bill components, did not exceed the frozen rate for the direct \naccess customer, thereby costing ESPs potentially a lot of  money.  It was \nclear in the previous CPUC direct access decisions that UDCs had no right to \ncap direct access credits. Because of our good case and the fact that the \nUDCs believed the chance of such high PX prices was LOW, the UDCs settled \nwith ARM on this issue in 1999.\n\n2000 NPV estimated by Dennis Benevides: $30 - 40 million\n% Attributed to Enron's Efforts: 90%\n\nGreen Credit Legislation\nEnron and other green suppliers began work in 1998 to extend the credit given \nfor sales of green power. The credit was scheduled to end by 2002. In 1999, \nthe money specified in AB 1890 was being depleted rapidly and Green Mountain \ntook the lead in pressing for legislation. We actively supported Green \nMountain by lobbying legislators and other interest groups, working with \nenvrionmental organizations, and spearheading legislative amendments.  \nAlthough this bill became wrapped up in the San Diego crisis and ISO/PX \nissues, the green credit portion of the bill remained intact.  We had also \ndecided jointly to propose a ten-year credit and were very pleased and \nsurprised that it survived into the final bill.  Governor Davis is expected \nto sign the bill. \n\n2000 NPV estimated by Dennis Benevides: $50 million\n% Attributed to Enron's Efforts: 25%\n\nRAP '99\nEnron, through ARM, has successfully made its case that retail procurement \nand retail sales costs should be removed from the Distribution Charge that \nall customers pay.  Direct Access customers would receive a credit on their \nbills in addition to the PX credit. Enron was the first party to raise these \nissues as part of RAP '98 and got a Commission decision in that case to \ndetermine the credit in RAP '99.  In RAP '99, Enron chose to use ARM to \nlitigate the case as a cheaper alternative.  Hearings were completed in the \nSpring of 2000.  ARM has negotiated settlement rates with certain parties and \nhas convinced the Assigned Commissioner to draft his own decision to \ncounteract the unfavorable ALJ decision. An additional credit of from $0.25 \nto $0.30/MWh is expected.  The decision will be voted out within the next two \nmonths.\n\n2000 NPV estimted by Dennis Benevides: $1 - 5 million\n% Attributed to Enron's Efforts: 75%\n\nECT\n\nFTR Release April 1, 2000\nI have spearheaded the release of firm transmission rights in CA since I \njoined the Company in 11/96.  Our long and painful fight with creeping \nnodalism culminated with the release of some, but not all, FTRs in April of \nthis year.  ENA actively participated in the auction and became the largest \nsingle purchaser of FTRs.  The new congestion management approach, which \nEnron also spearheaded, will require 100% release of FTRs, but will not take \neffect until next year. This valuation looks only at the FTR release in 2000.\n\n2000 NPV estimated by Tim Belden: To be determined 9/17/00\n% Attributed to Enron's Efforts: 90%\n\n\nISO Price Caps\nENA was long in the market in the West and had millions at risk when lower \nprice caps began to be discussed in CA in mid June.  Government Affairs, \nworking with Dave Parquet and others, was instrumental in significantly \ndelaying the movement to lower price caps, thereby giving ENA time to move \nout of those positions.  The following events happened in 2000.  We entered \nthe year with a price cap of $750, having fought to raise it to that level in \n1999.  In March 2000, the ISO considered lowering the price cap to $500 but \nvoted to leave it at $500, because they believed at the time that market \npower had been adequately mitigated.  After the four very high-priced days in \nJune, the ISO considered lowering the price cap to $250 with a vote on June \n22, but the vote failed by ONE VOTE. Instead, the Board lowered the price cap \nto $500.  The Board voted again on July 1 to lower the cap and again the vote \nfailed by ONE VOTE.  Finally, on August 1, the Board approved the $250 price \ncap, effective August 7.  In June, Government Affairs intitiated an all-out \nlobbying effort to convince Board members and their constituents to oppose \nlower price caps.  We also lobbied interest groups, banks, venture \ncapitalists, NYMEX and others to weigh in on this issue with individual Board \nMembers and the Board itself, going so far as to set up a special arrangement \nwith the ISO staff to allow interested parties to address the Board \ntelephonically. \n\n2000 NPV estimated by Tim Belden: To be determined 9/17/00\n% Attributed to Enron's Efforts: 80%\n\n\nNew Market-Oriented Board Member\nThe ISO recently held Board elections for the first time.  Government Affairs \nactively sought market-oriented individuals to run for the Board and replace \nthose that do not support competitive markets.  Enron was successful in \ngetting about five to run.  The Members selected or confrmed by the EOB have \nbeen held up and we do not yet know the outcome of those Board seats.  \nHowever, one seat of interest has been decided.  Dave Parquet suggested a \npotential municipal representative who was extremely market-oriented (Michael \nWood, City Attorney for the City of Pittsburgh).  Government Affairs worked \nwith him closely to decide which seat to run for, help him prepare his \napplication, suggest lobbying tactics, assist in lobbying and support him \nwith other Board Members.  He won the election and became a Board Member in \nearly September.  This effort is significant, because the munis voted nearly \n100% in support of lower price caps. The position he took was one of those \nvotes.  All other things being equal, we have now added a vote on our side \nthat could be instrumental in defeating further efforts to impose lower or \nadditional price caps, given the close votes that have taken place thus far.\n\n2000 NPV estimated based on Tim Belden's Pice Cap Assessment: To be \ndetermined 9/17/00\n% Attibuted to Enron's Efforts: 100%\n\n",

        "body": "---------------------- Forwarded by David M Gagliardi/TTG/HouInd on\n08/21/2000 10:10 AM ---------------------------\n\n\n\"Michael Gagliardi\" <mggagliardi@duke-energy.com> on 08/21/2000 07:25:59 AM\n\nTo:   DGagliardi@reliantenergy.com, David_Ricks@GSDM.com\ncc:\n\nSubject:  True Orange Fax/E-Mail #73\n\n\n\n\n\n---------------------- Forwarded by Michael\nGagliardi/Hou-ComOps/EnergyTrading/PEC on 08/21/2000 07:34 AM\n---------------------------\n\n\nTruOrange@aol.com on 08/20/2000 07:25:25 PM\n\nTo:   TruOrange@aol.com\ncc:    (bcc: Michael Gagliardi/Hou-ComOps/EnergyTrading/PEC)\nSubject:  True Orange Fax/E-Mail #73\n\n\n\n\nTrue Orange Fax/E-Mail Service\nVolume 8, Fax/E-Mail #73, Sunday, August 20, 2000\nJerry Scarbrough's True Orange, P. O. Box 26530, Austin, Texas 78755 -\nPhone\n512-795-8536\n\nBrown Says Offense Much Improved, Defense Very Solid\n\nCoach Mack Brown said Sunday the Longhorns' offense should be much better\nthis season, and he said the defense should be his best since coming to\nTexas.\nBrown said the players showed up in great shape and have shown a lot of\nenthusiasm in all of the early practices. He also said thd depth,\noffensively\nand defensively, will be better than it has been.\nThe offensive line is the main question mark, and Brown said flatly, \"The\noffensive line is much improved. There is a lot more cohesiveness. Most of\nthe guys were starting for the first time last year and they are much more\nsure of what they need to do now that they have more experience.\"\nHe said guard Antwan Kirk-Hughes is the most improved offensive linemen,\nbut\nhe also said, \"We feel like all five (offensive line starters) will be\nquality\nplayers.\"\nThe team appears to be thinner at guard than tackle on offense, but the\ncoaches have moved backup tackle Robbie Doane to guard. That is a sure sign\nthat they like the work of massive true freshman Lionel Garr at offensive\ntackle. They want to have four tackles and four guards. With Leonard Davis\nand Mike Williams starting at tackle and Cory Quye and Garr backing them up\nand Kirk-Hughes and Derrick Dockery starting at guard and Doane and Tillman\nHolloway backing them up, they get their desired two-deep. Broad also said\njunior squadman Corey Bradford has been looking good at tackle. At center,\nstarter Matt Anderson is getting a strong challenge from Beau Baker.\nBrown also has said a lot of true freshmen will play this year. \"If we\nthink\nthey can help us win, they'll play,\" he said following a two-hour practice\nsession Sunday Morning. True freshman WR Roy Williams and redshirt freshman\nWR Artie Ellis, both in the 6-3, 6-4 range, had outstanding practices.\nLooking at the 21 freshmen, it appears likely that 14 will play. They are\nGarr, WRs Roy Williams, B. J. Johnson, Sloan Thomas and Tony Jeffery, TE\nBrock Edwards, DEs Adam Doiron and Kalen Thonton, DT Stevie Lee, CB Nathan\nVasher, LB Austin Sendlein, safety Phillip Geiggar, punter Justin Smith and\nkicker Matt McFadden.  Brown has said he wants to use the two kickers, at\nleast in back-up roles, so they will have a little experience when they\ntake\nover the two jobs next year.\nTE Bo Scaife's season-ending knee injury has the coaches putting Edwards on\nthe fast track to get him ready to play quickly. TE coach Tim Brewster says\nEdwards is picking up things very quickly. Brown said, \"The thing  that Bo\ngave us was great speed down the field. Brock Edwards looks pretty fast,\ntoo,\nand he's ahead of where Bo was last year because of Bo's knee.\" Scaife came\nto Texas after undergoing surgery on his other knee.\nThe true freshmen who probably won't play, barring a rash of injuries at\ntheir positions, are QB Chance Mock, RB Sneezy Beltran, FB Will Matthews,\nOLs\nTrey Bates and Jason Glynn,  and LBs Austin Sendlein and Rashad Thomas.\nMock,\nas the third quarterback behind Chris Simms and Major Applewhite, will be\ntrained to be ready to play, but Brown said he hopes to redshirt him. He\nhas\nbeen looking very good. Beltran and Matthews also look good, but the Horns\nare deep at their positions. Brown also has said he hopes to redshirt some\noffensive linemen, and Bates and Glynn are the likely candidates.\n* * * *\nCorrection: Oh boy, when I mess up, I mess up. In last night's fax, I\nquoted\na Texas coach as comparing Roy Williams favorably with Lovell Pinkney and\nMike Williams. Obviously, I meant Lovell Pinkney and Mike Adams. Sorry\nabout\nthat. Got my Mike's mixed up.\n* * * *\nRECRUITING NOTES: Texas continues to lead for the state's best DT, Tommie\nHarris of Killeen Ellison; best LB Derrick Johnson of Waco; best safety,\nDewayne Brandon of Temple; best RB Cedric Benson of Midland Lee; best QB\nMatt\nNordgren of Dallas Bishop Lynch, and best TE, James Moses of Galena Park\nNorth Shore, , , The high school football season starts next week, and, for\nthe first time in several years, I will be able to scout five of the\nstate's\ntop players without driving very far. They are Harris, Johnson, Brandon, CB\nCedric Griffin of San Antonio Holmes (a UT commitment) and QB/Athlete Quan\nCosby of Mart.\n* * * *\nMy next fax will be Monday, August 21.\n* * * *\nThe True Orange Fax Service includes  at  least  99 faxes  a year and costs\n$99 ($79 by E-Mail). Please keep in mind this is a \ntentative draft.  Mark and Andrew still want to perform some QA on the \nresults and Torrey is still looking into some of the observations.  \n\nTo summarize, we observed a significant improvement from the last test we \nperformed a few months ago.  The systemic problems that created a large \nvolume of the discrepancies in our previous testing have been greatly \nreduced.  The majority of the discrepancies identified in the most recent \ntesting are primarily a result of random data entry errors and some deal \nbooking changes made in the back office without the Product Control Group's \nknowledge.  Torrey has already corrected the most significant discrepancies \nand is continuing to investigate the smaller items.  \n\nAndrew and I will both be on vacation for the week of August 28.         "body": "---------------------- Forwarded by David M Gagliardi/TTG/HouInd on\n08/21/2000 09:19 AM ---------------------------\n\n\n\"Michael Gagliardi\" <mggagliardi@duke-energy.com> on 08/21/2000 07:24:54 AM\n\nTo:   DGagliardi@reliantenergy.com, David_Ricks@GSDM.com\ncc:\n\nSubject:  True Orange Fax/E-Mail 71\n\n\n\n\n\n---------------------- Forwarded by Michael\nGagliardi/Hou-ComOps/EnergyTrading/PEC on 08/21/2000 07:33 AM\n---------------------------\n\n\nTruOrange@aol.com on 08/18/2000 09:58:52 PM\n\nTo:   TruOrange@aol.com\ncc:    (bcc: Michael Gagliardi/Hou-ComOps/EnergyTrading/PEC)\nSubject:  True Orange Fax/E-Mail 71\n\n\n\n\nTrue Orange Fax/E-Mail Service\nVolume 8, Fax/E-Mail #71, Friday, August 18, 2000\nJerry Scarbrough's True Orange, P. O. Box 26530, Austin, Texas 78755\nPhone 512-795-8536\n\nScaife Injures Knee, Out for Season; Roy Williams Tears Up Varsity DBs\n\nSophomore TE Bo Scaife, the guy I figured the offense could least afford to\nlose because of his blitz-breaking capabilities, tore the ACL in his left\nknee during the Longhorns' first varsity workout Friday morning and he will\nbe out for the season.\nScaife, a sure-handed tight end with great speed, had surgery on his right\nknee as a senior in high school. He was slowed by that injury last season,\nbut regained his speed by the spring and was sensational in spring drills.\nCoach Mack Brown said Scaife will undergo surgery and will miss the entire\nseason. The only good news is that he can use this season as a redshirt\nseason, since he did play some last season. That means he will have three\nyears of eligibility remaining, beginning in 2001.\n\"Now, he will have had them both fixed, they'll be stronger and maybe he\ncan\nhave three good years,\" Brown said.\nBrown said Mike Jones, the starter last season at tight end, is a\nsure-handed\nreceiver and outstanding blockers, but he said the Horns will miss Scaife's\nspeed. He said freshman Brock Edwards, who also has speed, but not as much\nas\nScaife, will get a lot of work, starting Saturday, to see if he can help\ntake\nup some of the slack left by Scaife's injury. He also said walk-on TE\nCullen\nLoeffler has shown some good things and also will get a chance to see if he\ncan contribute.\nThis was a major blow to the Texas offense, but there is some good news.\nThe\nLonghorns probably have their best secondary since 1991, but freshman WR\nRoy\nWilliams, 6-3, 208, long-armed and fast, fast, fast, treated the starting\ncornerbacks and safeties like cannon fodder in the morning workout,\ncatching\ntwo long touchdown passes and tight-roping the sideline for two other big\ncatches. He dropped only one pass all day, and it was when he ran over an\nobstacle. The team worked primarily on putting in some running plays in the\nafternoon workout, so the DBs were spared another dose of Williams in the\nafternoon.\nAll of the heralded freshmen WRs are looking good, but Williams is looking\nsensational. I can see why some veteran West Texas football watchers say he\nis the greatest prospect ever to come out of Odessa Permian. There just\naren't a lot of people his size who can run 100 meters in 10.03, high jump\nseven feet and broad jump a state record 26-5.\nEven defensive coordinator Carl Reese was impressed by Williams. \"I tell\nyou\nwhat, he didn't look like a freshman to me,\" Reese said. \"He looked pretty\ngood out there.\"\nSloan Thomas, B. J. Johnson and Tony Jeffery are the other three freshmen\nWRs, and they all had their moments Friday. Thomas made some acrobatic\ncatches on balls that appeared to be overthrown, Johnson and Jeffery, a\nhigh\nschool QB star who is making the switch to WR, both used their quickness to\nget off the line of scrimmage and make some impressive grabs.\nThe Longhorns are loaded at QB, with All-Big 12 Major Applewhite battling\nbudding star Chris Simms for the starting job. Both looked very sharp\nthrowing\nlong and short Friday, but freshman CB Nathan Vasher and backup linebacker\nO. J. McClintock picked off two of Simms' passes and both might have scored\nif it had been in a game-type scrimmage.\nApplewhite, who underwent off-season knee surgery, appeared to be back to\nnormal. He showed as much mobility as he has ever had in rolling right or\nleft, and his passes were on target. Simms also had a good day, except for\nthe two interceptions.\n* * * *\nRECRUITING NOTES:  Don't be surprised if the official visit for DE Eric\nHall\nof Clarksville, Tenn., is moved from the scheduled Sept. 9 date. Hall has a\ngame Friday night, Sept. 8, and UT's game on Saturday, Sept. 9, starts at\n11:30 a.m. UT can have a jet plane waiting for Hall after his game and it\ncan\nfly him to Austin, but his parents want to come on his visit to Austin,\ntoo.\nBut NCAA rues don't allow schools to transport parents. So, the parents\nwould\nhave to fly commercially, which means they would either have to leave\nbefore\nhis high school game that Friday, or come in Saturday, in which case they\nwould be too late for the Texas' season opener against Louisiana-\nLafayette.\n. . The early emphasis in Texas recruiting has been on offensive linemen.\nLook for the late emphasis to be on signing five or six defensive linemen,\nincluding some big ends who might grow into tackles.\n* * * *\nThe True Orange Fax Service includes  at  least  99 faxes  a year and costs\n$99 ($79 by E-Mail). The True Orange Newsletter includes  26 newsletters\nand\nis published weekly during football season and twice monthly during most of\nthe other months. It costs $45. Save by subscribing to both for $130 (or\n$110\nif you take the faxes via E-Mail  or $99 if you take the faxes and\nnewsletter\nvia E-Mail). Send check  to address at the top of page.         "body": "Electricity Trading Builds Oh-So Slowly In France\nDow Jones Energy Service, 03/23/01\n\nIndia: Dabhol guarantee: Govt awaiting Law Ministry view\nBusiness Line (The Hindu), 03/23/01\n\nIndia: Foreign companies facing tax harassment: Japanese envoy\nBusiness Line (The Hindu), 03/23/01\n\n'Panel to clear Tannir Bhavi project deal'\nThe Times of India, 03/23/01\n\nEnron comfortable with profit projection \nHouston Chronicle, 03/23/01\n\nUSA: Transmission Texas' only dereg hurdle-state grid manager.\nReuters English News Service, 03/22/01\n\nDespite Talk, Bandwidth-Trading Cos Say They're Hiring\nDow Jones Energy Service, 03/22/01\n\nUSA: UPDATE 1-Bush accused of protecting oil firms in power crisis.\nReuters English News Service, 03/22/01\n\nUSA: Enron stock slides despite earnings reassurance.\nReuters English News Service, 03/22/01\n\nSTOCKWATCH Enron lower amid market deterioration after reaffirming guidance\nAFX News, 03/22/01\n\nEnron `comfortable' with earnings estimates, but shares slide\nAssociated Press Newswires, 03/22/01\n\nEnergy Researcher Says California Not Fixing Power Problems\nBloomberg, 03/22/01\n\nEnron Reaffirms 2001 Forecast After Stock Price Falls (Update1)\nBloomberg, 03/22/01\n\nEnron Corp.'s India Unit Faces $88.2 Mln Penalty, Paper Says\nBloomberg, 03/22/01\n\n\n\nElectricity Trading Builds Oh-So Slowly In France\nBy Sarah Wachter\nOf DOW JONES NEWSWIRES\n\n03/23/2001\nDow Jones Energy Service\n(Copyright (c) 2001, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)\n\nPARIS -(Dow Jones)- Although electricity trading volumes are creeping higher \nin France, activity will probably remain subdued and irregular until a \nsatisfactory regulatory regime is put in place. \nTraders complain about the uncertainty caused by the temporary rules of grid \noperator RTE, and about tariffs for access to the network. Volumes won't take \noff without well-designed, permanent rules, they said.\nEven then Europe's second-largest electricity market may never become much of \na trading hub because of the dominance of state utility Electricity de France \n(F.EDF) which, with its huge installed nuclear capacity, is already among \nEurope's cheapest electricity suppliers. \n\"There's so much missing,\" said Katrin Durwald, an energy analyst with HEW \nEnergy Trading, talking about RTE's tariffs and rules.\"Nothing is really \nclear in France,\" she said. \nTraders are especially upset over RTE's congestion costs, which only new \nmarket entrants share and which can add as much as 50% to the price of \nelectricity. \nOther traders say access charges to the medium- to low-voltage network are \nimpossible to figure out. But permanent tariffs won't go into effect until \nJuly 1 at the earliest, French electricity regulator CRE says. \nPermanent grid rules won't reach the regulator's desk for review until early \nsummer, reckons RTE President Andre Merlin. \nEven with clearer regulation, the dominance of EDF will hold back the market. \nFormer monopoly supplier EDF is a formidable competitor, a predominantly \nnuclear power producer with some of the lowest electricity prices in Europe. \nTraders estimate between 20 and 50 trades are going through monthly in \nFrance, mostly for electricity delivered the next day or next week. \nThat's a far cry from neighboring Germany before the launch of spot \nelectricity exchanges there, when 160 short-term transactions were struck \ndaily, HEW Energy Trading estimates. \nMore immediately, what's missing in France is a steady stream of one-year \nsupply deals, a sign that foreign power companies are regularly furnishing \nelectricity to French industrial consumers. \n\"I seriously doubt whether there are companies taking risk and supplying \ncustomers,\" a trader with a large European power company said. \nFrench high-voltage grid operator RTE said 325 grid access contracts were \nsigned this year for all transactions, as of March 12, equilavent to an \naverage of four of five deals a day. \nThere are, nonetheless, some pockets of activity in France. \nTraders are exchanging blocks of electricity to help industrial consumers \ncurb costly imbalance charges, by grouping the companies' electricity needs \nto even out consumption patterns. \nRTE says 21 companies are authorized to furnish or buy back imbalance \nelectricity. \nSwiss hydro producers are also exporting spot electricity to France, analysts \nsaid, notably Elektrizitaetsgesellschaft Laufenburg AG (Z.EGL) and \nAare-Tessin AG fuer Elektrizitaet (Z.AAR). \n\"Germany and France are the biggest export countries for Swiss spot hydro,\" \nDurwald said. \nAt the same time, two Dutch energy distributors, NUON NV (N.NUN) and REMU NV, \nhave been active in France, traders said. \nNUON purchased a few small hydroelectric producers, which are bound under an \neight-year contract to sell electricity exclusively to EDF. \nBut NUON can sell electricity to new customers above the contract price EDF \nis obliged to pay under its single buyer obligation, Durwald said. \nSome traders see opportunities cropping up this year from changes to the way \ntransport capacity is allocated on France's interconnectors with the U.K. and \nwith Italy. \n\"Cogenerators (gas-fired power plants) in France with surplus capacity could \nsell to traders in Germany looking to import electricity into Italy,\" a \ntrader at a large pan-European trading organization said. \nRTE forbids electricity ordered and delivered on the same day sourced from \nGermany and Switzerland to be imported to Italy. \nThat trader also expects the daily transfer capacity auction on the \nU.K.-France Interconnector, which starts March 31, to spark more electricity \ntrading in both countries. \n\"The day-ahead risk is rather limited, not only in France but also in the \nU.K.,\" he said. \nThe following are traders and power companies said to be active in France, in \naddition to those concerns already mentioned in the article, according to a \nDow Jones Newswires survey: Belgium's Electrabel SA(B.ELE) \nSpain's Grupo Endesa SA(E.EDS) \nTXU Europe Energy Trading(TXU) \nFrench independent producer SNET \nEnron Europe Ltd.(U.ENE) \nTotalFinaElf(TOT) \nDynegy Europe Ltd.(DYN) \nElectricite de Laufenbourg SA \nRWE Trading AG(G.RWE) \nE.On AG(G.EOA) \nElectricite de France(F.EDF) \nHEW Energy Trading AG \n\nWeb site: http://www.rtefrance.com \n-By Sarah Wachter, Dow Jones Newswires; 33-1-4017-1740; \nsarah.wachter@dowjones.com\n\nCopyright , 2000 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved. \n\n\nIndia: Dabhol guarantee: Govt awaiting Law Ministry view\n\n03/23/2001\nBusiness Line (The Hindu)\nCopyright (C) 2001 Kasturi & Sons Ltd (KSL); Source: World Reporter (TM) - \nAsia Intelligence Wire\n\nNEW DELHI, March 22. THE Government is awaiting the opinion of the Law \nMinistry on the claim of the Dabhol Power Company (DPC) for the bill of Rs \n102 crore under the counter-guarantee cover, for the 740-MW Dabhol power \nproject, before deciding on making the next payment to the utility. \nThe Union Government has sought the opinion of the Law Ministry, as the \nMaharashtra Government had written to it, suggesting that the claim should \nnot be honoured, as the DPC had not complied with load despatch instructions.\nThe Law Ministry's views are crucial to any decision on going in later for \nfuture course of action which could be either arbitration or High Court \nproceedings. \nThe Government has sought an early response from the Law Ministry as the \n15-day interest free period for payment of DPCs's contentious bill for the \nmonth of December 2000 ends on Friday. \nAccording to the counter guarantee agreement, the Government will have to pay \nwith interest (at Bank rate) the outstandings, if it is paid after 15 days of \nthe receipt of the notice to the Government of India. \nThe Government has one month's time from the date of presentation of the \nclaim by the company to meet its obligations. \nLast time, the Maharashtra Government managed to make a payment to the MSEB \nin the nick of time, after DPC invoked the guarantee. \nThis time the cause for conflict is the counter claim put forth by the \nMaharashtra Government seeking a rebate of Rs 400 crore from the power \nproject sponsors. \nThe conflict hinges on a technical issue involving legal interpretation of \nthe Power Purchase Agreement (PPA) between the Maharashtra State Electricity \nBoard and project developers led by Enron. \nMSEB's contention is that the PPA requires Enron to make available power \ncorresponding to 90 per cent 'Plant Availability' within a period of three \nhours of the requisition. \nOn a particular day in January, Dabhol took five hours to achieve this task, \naccording to the MSEB. Hence, MSEB has sought rebate as penalty for non \ncompliance of despatch instructions. \nDPC, meanwhile, has contended that the despatch instructions were not in the \nformat prescribed in the PPA. \nOur Bureau\n\nCopyright , 2000 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved. \n\n\nIndia: Foreign companies facing tax harassment: Japanese envoy\n\n03/23/2001\nBusiness Line (The Hindu)\nCopyright (C) 2001 Kasturi & Sons Ltd (KSL); Source: World Reporter (TM) - \nAsia Intelligence Wire\n\nCHENNAI, March 22. THE Japanese Ambassador in India, Mr Hiroshi Hirabayashi, \ntoday complained that there were \"numerous instances\" of foreign companies \nestablished in India, being harassed by tax officials. \nDelivering a speech at the Indo-Japan Centre here, Mr Hirabayashi that the \ntax collectors \"seem to view foreign companies as an easy prey from whom they \ncould collect as much as possible without being bothered by political \npressure.\"\nOut \"of frustration and decreased chance of making profit, not a few Japanese \ncompanies have closed their businesses.\" \nMr Hirabayashi said he had taken up the matter with the Finance Minister, Mr \nYashwant Sinha, and had given the message that \"tax officers are indeed \nkilling the goose that lay golden eggs.\" \nIn a particularly blunt speech, Mr Hirabayashi said one of the reasons why \nJapanese companies are hesitant to invest in India is because \"what they hear \nis mostly sob-stories, stories of hardships faced by foreign investors.\" \nForeign companies are carefully watching the development of Enron and \nSuzuki-Maruti ventures, for instance, he said. \nJapanese companies found East and South-East Asian countries more \ninvestor-friendly and preferred to invest there. \nThe Ambassador cited two more reasons for poor Japanese investments in India: \npoor infrastructure and red- tapism. \"While the single window system for \nforeign investment is set up, yet, when a foreign investor actually \nestablishes a new venture, he has to use much nerve and money in obtaining \nplethora of clearances and permissions.\" \nMr Hirabayashi was also critical of the investment climate in Maharashtra, \nwhere \"foreign companies are constantly hammered by unlawful elements.\" \nOn the other hand, he spoke warmly of Haryana, Madhya Pradesh and Andhra \nPradesh, mentioning the names of the Chief Ministers by name. \nHe said that he found in their attitude \"perceptible changes for the better.\" \nOur Bureau\n\nCopyright , 2000 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved. \n\n\n'Panel to clear Tannir Bhavi project deal'\nThe Times of India News Service\n\n03/23/2001\nThe Times of India\nCopyright (C) 2001 The Times of India; Source: World Reporter (TM)\n\nBANGALORE: The controversial Power Purchase Agreement (PPA) on the 410 MW \nTannir Bhavi barge-mounted project will be submitted for approval to the \nKarnataka Electricity Regulatory Commission (KERC), Power Minister Veerakumar \nA. Patil told the Assembly on Thursday. \nReplying to the debate on the power tariff hike, Patil said: ``As soon as \ngeneration is started at Tannir Bhavi, the PPA will go to the KERC. All PPAs \nhave to be cleared by the KERC before implementation.''\nEarlier, A. Ramdas (BJP) alleged that the Karnataka Power Transmission \nCorporation (KPTC) had to pay a steep Rs 5.63 per unit for Tannir Bhavi power \nas per the terms of the PPA. \n``Even if we don't buy the power, we have to pay Rs 650 crore, in dollars, \nabsorbing the differences in the price of naphta, as per the PPA. What is the \ngovernment's vested interest in this project?'' he asked. \nPatil said the PPA, which includes escrow cover, had to be honoured following \na direction from the Karnataka High Court. ``We are facing power shortage, \nspecially at the height of summer, and are buying power from wherever \npossible. The KPTC Chairman and I are going to Delhi to see if we can get \nmore power from the central grid,'' he added. \nMaharashtra had offered power at Rs 3.90 per unit from Enron. ``It is \nexpensive, but if we have no alternative, we will buy power from them,'' he \nindicated. \nReferring to the bribery case in the 220 KV Kadra project, he seven of the \neight accused had been arrested. ``Director (Distribution) Vijaybhaskar, \nhowever, has taken anticipatory bail,'' he added. \nResponding to Araga Jnanendra's (BJP) allegation that the government had \nhanded over the Mavalagi project across Kali river to a independent power \nproducer instead of the profit-making and government-owned Karnataka Power \nCorporation (KPC), Patil said: ``The KPC has taken a policy decision not to \ngo for projects below 250 MW.'' \nThe minister ruled out subsidies to sectors other than agriculture, for which \nthe government has agreed to release Rs 144 crore to KPTC. ``There are review \npetitions from other sectors before the KERC, which will decide. But the \ngovernment is not in a position to give any more money,'' he maintained.\n\nCopyright , 2000 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved. \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMarch 23, 2001\nBriefs: Houston & state \n\n\nEnron comfortable with profit projection \nEnron Corp. assured investors Thursday it \"remains very comfortable\" with a \npreviously announced 2001 earnings estimate of between $1.70 and $1.75 per \nshare. \nAccording to First Call/Thomson Financial, the average estimate of 2001 \nearnings among industry analysts is $1.74 per share. \nThe Houston-based energy giant also said it would bring investors up to date \ntoday with a conference call. \n\n\n\n\n\nUSA: Transmission Texas' only dereg hurdle-state grid manager.\nBy C. Bryson Hull\n\n03/22/2001\nReuters English News Service\n(C) Reuters Limited 2001.\n\nHOUSTON, March 22 (Reuters) - Improving power transmission capacity is the \nbiggest challenge Texas faces heading into deregulation next year, the \nmanager of the state's power grid said on Thursday. \nCalifornia's Achilles' heel, a lack of generating capacity, is not Texas' \nproblem, Electric Reliability Council of Texas (ERCOT) chief executive \nofficer Tom Noel said.\n\"Capacity is not the only issue. Serving this 200,000 square miles of \nterritory and 6 million customers requires an awful lot of transmission, \ndistribution and wire,\" Noel said in a speech at the Houston Energy Expo. \n\"Also important are the constraints that exist.\" \nCurrently, has 65,000 MW of generation and a 2000 peak summer load of around \n57,000 MW. Twenty-two new power plants have been built in Texas in the past \nfive years, 15 are under construction and 30 are on the drawing board, he \nsaid. \nMoving that power from often remote plants to the biggest markets presents a \nchallenge, particularly in four areas served by ERCOT, which manages 85 \npercent of the Texas power grid. \n\"You can't get it from there to here,\" Noel said of the trouble spots. \nTransmission constraints exist in moving power from the south to the north, \nwhere fast-growing Dallas creates a high demand; inside Dallas itself; from \nthe Rio Grande Valley to Austin and San Antonio in Central Texas; and from \nlightly populated West Texas to the eastern half of the state. \nIn the last case, several companies including Enron Corp. have committed to \nbuilding wind power facilities out on the western plains, to supply power to \nthe more densely populated eastern half of Texas. \nINCENTIVES TO BUILD TRANSMISSION \nThough companies have already anted up to erect power lines in the problem \nareas, the state will have to provide attractive rates of return to encourage \ncontinuing infrastructure investments, he said. \n\"The rate of return is going to have to be a little higher than it was in the \npast,\" Noel said. \nHe expected that the Texas Public Utility Commission, which negotiates such \nrates with the utilities, would look to a range of 10-12 percent return on \ninvestment, as opposed to current rates in the neighborhood of eight percent. \nTransmission is the only major part of the state's electricity market which \nwill still be regulated after retail deregulation kicks off, he said. The \nwholesale market has been deregulated since 1995. \n\"We believe the infrastructure has to be regulated,\" Noel said. \n\"Part of our plan is to make sure that someone who owns the wires cannot \nbecome a market player and cut out people who have power to sell and can't \nget to market because they can't get to the lines,\" he said. \nUnder the Texas deregulation plan, generators will sell power directly to \ncustomers but will send it via wires likely owned by other companies. That is \npart of the reason traditional regulated Texas utilities like TXU Corp. and \nReliant Energy Inc. are splitting their regulated and unregulated businesses \ninto separate entities. \nNoel said ERCOT and the state government are both committed to starting \nderegulation on schedule on Jan. 1, 2002. The first active move toward that \nend comes on April 2, when ERCOT will conduct a mock market. \nNoel acknowledged \"it's not going to be pretty,\" because of some delays in \nsetting up the computer hardware and software needed to undertake the testing \nprior to the start date. A pilot program for 5 percent of retail customers is \nnext up on June 1.\n\nCopyright , 2000 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved. \n\n\nDespite Talk, Bandwidth-Trading Cos Say They're Hiring\nBy Erwin Seba\nOf DOW JONES NEWSWIRES\n\n03/22/2001\nDow Jones Energy Service\n(Copyright (c) 2001, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)\n\nHOUSTON -(Dow Jones)- While market-maker Enron Corp.'s (ENE) stock tumbled \nWednesday on rumors that it plans to lay off people in its broadband unit, \nother bandwidth-trading companies said Thursday they have plans to add \nemployees. \nWilliams Communications Group (WCG), El Paso Corp. (EPG) and Aquila Broadband \nServices, a unit of Utilicorp United Inc. (UCU), said they are looking for \nsome additions among traders and in other deal-making positions.\nAdditionally, Enron spokesman Mark Palmer said the rumored layoffs are \nredeployments of some personnel within the company. \n\"Redeployment is an everyday occurrence at Enron,\" Palmer said. \"Our \nbroadband business is growing and hitting its performance metrics as we laid \nthem out in January.\" \nEnron Chief Executive Jeff Skilling is scheduled to have a telephone \nconference with investors at 1 p.m. EST Friday. Palmer said Skilling would \ndiscuss the bandwidth unit at that meeting. \nIn a research report Thursday, Salomon Smith Barney reaffirmed its estimate \nof Enron's earnings and discounted the layoff rumors saying the redeployment \nwas for noncommercial personnel. Palmer declined to comment on the Salomon \nSmith Barney report. \nAt Aquila Broadband Services, Sushil Nelson expects to add two more traders \nto a staff of eight by the end of this year. \nThe broadband unit has 36 employees, said Nelson, who serves as senior vice \npresident and general manager. \n\"We're looking to hire people with origination experience,\" he said. The \ncompany has 10 deal originators. Nelson declined to say how many deal \noriginators the company plans to add by the end of the year. \nWilliams Communications has five traders on its bandwidth desk. \n\"As our business evolves, we certainly have room for more people,\" said Chris \nLemmer, executive director of bandwidth trading and risk management at \nWilliams Communications. \nA similar view was taken by Greg Jenkins, chief executive of El Paso Global \nNetworks. \n\"We are continuing with our strategy and adding commercial people to our \norganization,\" Jenkins said in a statement released by the company. \"We \nbelieve this is a good moment to be building our business.\" \nJenkins said the company plans to double its trading staff by the end of the \nyear. He declined to say how many traders the company currently has. \n-By Erwin Seba, Dow Jones Newswires, 713-547-9214 erwin.seba@dowjones.com\n\nCopyright , 2000 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved. \n\nUSA: UPDATE 1-Bush accused of protecting oil firms in power crisis.\nBy Tom Doggett\n\n03/22/2001\nReuters English News Service\n(C) Reuters Limited 2001.\n\nWASHINGTON, March 22 (Reuters) - Washington Democratic Senator Patty Murray \naccused the Bush administration on Thursday of caring more about the \nfinancial interests of big oil companies than trying to protect consumers in \nWestern states from the economic effects of high electricity prices and power \nsupply shortages. \n\"I think it is a real concern to all of us in my home state of Washington and \nthe entire West Coast that we have been facing an energy crisis for four \nmonths now,\" Murray told reporters on Capitol Hill.\n\"I can only assume the influence of the oil industry in the Bush \nadministration is keeping them from helping our economic crisis in the state \nof Washington,\" said Murray, adding that some of her constituents are facing \na 60 percent surcharge in their electricity bills. \nEnergy firms, many of them based in Bush's home state of Texas, supply \nnatural gas and electricity to California's utilities. However, some \nsuppliers have been reluctant to keep doing business with the nearly-bankrupt \nutilities. \nCalifornia's utilities have racked up billions in debts from skyrocketing \nelectricity costs that the firms are prohibited from passing on to consumers \nunder the state's deregulation law. \nLike President Bush, many of the energy firms oppose a price cap on wholesale \nelectricity prices in the West as proposed by California Governor Gray Davis \nand other governors in the region. Bush fears a price cap would discourage \nenergy firms from building new power plants. \n\"A TOUGH-LUCK APPROACH\" \n\"We have an administration that has failed to come forward with a policy...to \nput in place an energy price cap immediately to begin to solve this problem,\" \nMurray said. \"Unfortunately, this administration has advocated a tough-luck \napproach.\" \nMurray is co-sponsoring a Democratic energy bill unveiled on Thursday that \nincludes language to limit the prices generating companies can charge for \nwholesale power in 11 western states. \nThe White House defended the administration's policy against price curbs for \nelectricity. \"The reason why we oppose price caps is because they don't work, \nthey would make the problem worse by driving away supply and failing to \npromote (energy) conservation,\" White House deputy press secretary Claire \nBuchan said on Thursday. \nDespite Murray's accusations of neglect by the president, Buchan said the \nadministration cares how the energy crisis is affecting consumers in the \nWest. \n\"The president is very sympathetic to the concerns and anxiety of individuals \nin western states as they view the mounting energy issues in that area,\" she \nsaid. \nBush and Vice President Dick Cheney were plagued with accusations during last \nyear's campaign of being too cozy with big oil firms. \nThe oil industry gave millions of dollars to Bush's presidential campaign and \nother Republican races throughout the country last year. \nBush also depended on advice from executives of several energy firms, \nincluding natural gas giant Enron Corp. , in developing an energy policy for \nhis new administration. \nBush, a former Texas oilman, has named Vice President Dick Cheney, a former \ntop executive of oilfield services giant Halliburton Co. to head a White \nHouse task force to come up with recommendations to solve America's energy \nproblems that includes the West's power crisis.\n\nCopyright , 2000 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved. \n\nUSA: Enron stock slides despite earnings reassurance.\nBy Andrew Kelly\n\n03/22/2001\nReuters English News Service\n(C) Reuters Limited 2001.\n\nHOUSTON, March 22 (Reuters) - Shares of electricity and natural gas marketing \ngiant Enron Corp. slid further on Thursday amid broader weakness in energy \nstocks despite a reassurance from the company that it would hit its \npreviously stated earnings target for this year. \nEnron was off $3.34, or 6 percent, at $52.55 per share Thursday afternoon \nafter falling 8 percent on Wednesday. So far this year, Enron's stock is down \nabout 37 percent, versus a 16 percent decline for Standard & Poor's utilities \nindex.\nSeeking to reassure investors, Enron issued a statement on Thursday saying it \nwas \"very comfortable\" with its 2001 earnings target of $1.70 to $1.75 per \ndiluted share. On average, Wall Street analysts expect Enron to post earnings \nof $1.74 per share, according to data compiled by Thomson Financial/First \nCall. \nThe Houston-based company said it was confident about its strong business \nprospects for the year, adding that it would host a conference call for \nanalysts and investors on Friday. \nAnalysts who track the company said the decline in its stock price did not \nappear to be related to business developments at Enron but rather to poor \nstock market sentiment, particularly in the areas of technology and \ntelecommunications. \n\"A lot of the breakout in Enron's stock in 2000 was in relation to their \nstrategy in new areas like business-to-business and broadband \ntelecommunications, and that's just out of favor right now,\" said CIBC World \nMarkets analyst William Hyler. \nBUILDING A BROADBAND BUSINESS \nSince early last year Enron has been building a high-speed broadband \ncommunications network that it plans to use as a base to build a bandwidth \nmarketing and trading business similar to its huge natural gas and \nelectricity trading operation. \nExcitement among investors about the broadband business and about Enron's \nsuccess in developing a strong Internet-based trading platform for energy and \nother commodities drove an 87 percent rise in the company's share price last \nyear, outpacing a gain of 54 percent for the S&P utilities index. \nOn Wednesday Enron spokesman Mark Palmer denied rumors of impending layoffs \nat the company's broadband unit, although he confirmed that staff were being \nredeployed within the business. \nSalomon Smith Barney analyst Ray Niles said in a research note that he was \nnot concerned about the redeployments, nor about the recent cancellation of a \ndeal with Blockbuster Inc. to deliver movies on-demand via Enron's broadband \nnetwork. \n\"We have always placed a greater value on the bandwidth trading portion of \nEnron's bandwidth strategy, rather than on content delivery,\" he said. Niles \nmaintained a Buy rating on the company's stock and a 12-18 month price target \nof $100. \nOther U.S. energy stocks were also broadly weaker on Thursday, reflecting \ninvestor's concerns that a global economic slowdown could lead to reduced \ndemand for energy and correspondingly lower prices for crude oil and natural \ngas. \nWilliams Cos., a company with a business mix similar to Enron's, saw its \nstock decline $3.34, or 8 percent, to $38.10. \nApache Corp., a leading U.S. oil and gas exploration company, was off $3.02, \nor 5 percent, at $57.20 while Halliburton Co., the world's biggest oilfield \nservices company, was down $1.61, or over 4 percent, at $37.18.\n\nCopyright , 2000 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved. \n\n\nSTOCKWATCH Enron lower amid market deterioration after reaffirming guidance\n\n03/22/2001\nAFX News\n(c) 2001 by AFP-Extel News Ltd\n\nNEW YORK (AFX) - Shares of Enron Corp were lower in late morning trade, \nfalling 7.4 pct, pressured by the general share market deterioration as the \ncompany's reaffirmation of its earnings guidance failed to boost the stock, \ndealers said. \nAt 11.37 am, the stock was down 4.14 usd at 51.75, as the DJIA traded down \n318.9 points at 9,168.09, and the Nasdaq composite down 31.78 at 1,798.45.\nDealers attributed the stock's failure to rally, despite its positive \nearnings news, to the market's rapid deterioration this week, noting \nextremely negative market breadth. \nOn the NYSE, only 471 stocks were higher, 2,693 lower, and 195 stocks \nunchanged. \nEarlier today Enron reiterated its guidance that it expects its 2001 earnings \nper share to be 1.70-1.75 usd. The Thomson Financial/First Call 2001 EPS \nestimate for Enron is for 1.74 usd. \nDespite Enron's price declines yesterday and today, Salomon Smith Barney \nenergy and commodities pricing analyst Raymond Niles said the falls were not \njustified by company fundamentals or recent concerns over its bandwidth unit. \n\"Specifically, we are not at all concerned about non-commercial bank office \ndeployments of personnel with the bandwidth group.\" \n\"We remain confident that bandwidth trading, the key segment within Enron's \nbandwidth strategy, will show strong growth in the first quarter.\" \nlaw/gc For more information and to contact AFX: www.afxnews.com and \nwww.afxpress.com\n\nCopyright , 2000 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved. \n\n\nEnron `comfortable' with earnings estimates, but shares slide\n\n03/22/2001\nAssociated Press Newswires\nCopyright 2001. The Associated Press. All Rights Reserved.\n\nHOUSTON (AP) - Enron Corp. assured investors Thursday it \"remains very \ncomfortable\" with a previously announced 2001 earnings estimate of between \n$1.70 and $1.75 per share. \nAccording to First Call/Thomson Financial, the consensus estimate of 2001 \nearnings among industry analysts $1.74 per share.\nIn a brief news release, the Houston-based energy giant also said it would \nbring investors up to date with a conference call on Friday, which will be \nsimulcast on the corporate Web site. \nStill, shares of Enron fell $4.13, or 7.4 percent, to $51.76 amid a broad \nsell-off on Wall Street. \n--- \nOn the Net: http://www.enron.com\n\nCopyright , 2000 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved. \n\n\nEnergy Researcher Says California Not Fixing Power Problems\n2001-03-22 16:34 (New York)\n\nEnergy Researcher Says California Not Fixing Power Problems\n\n     (For more stories on the California energy crisis, see\n{EXTR <GO>}.)\n\n     Washington, March 22 (Bloomberg) -- The director of energy\nconsultant Cambridge Energy Research Associates told the U.S.\nCongress that California's actions to address its energy crisis\nwon't increase power supplies and could harm the state's finances.\n     California should accelerate power-plant construction to add\nsupply and remove consumer-rate controls to damp electricity\ndemand, Lawrence Makovich, Cambridge Energy's senior director, said\nin printed testimony for the U.S. House of Representatives\nsubcommittee on energy and air quality. The state also should avoid\nsigning long-term supply contracts with high fixed prices, he said.\n     California has spent more than $3.2 billion this year buying\nelectricity for its nearly insolvent investor-owned utilities,\nwhich have been forced to buy power on the open market for more\nthan they can charge consumers under a 1996 state deregulation law.\nWith demand heavy and affordable wholesale power scarce, California\nhas endured rolling blackouts this week and in January.\n     ``If this crisis drives California back to the heavy-handed\nregulation that launched deregulation in the first place, or to an\nexpansive public power authority, then the state is likely to find\nits electric sector becoming increasingly inefficient and\nexpensive,'' Makovich's testimony said.\n     The state is attempting to buy the transmission lines of\nCalifornia's three largest utilities, PG&E Corp.'s Pacific Gas &\nElectric, Edison International's Southern California Edison and\nSempra Energy's San Diego Gas & Electric, to provide the utilities\nwith funds.\n     The state faces years of high energy payments by signing long-\nterm energy contracts with companies such as Calpine Corp., Enron\nCorp., and Duke Energy Corp. during a shortage, Makovich said.\nCalifornia could discourage investment needed to build new power\nplants by an attempt to gain ownership of much of California's\nelectricity grid, he added.\n     California has an energy shortage because no significant power\nplants were built in the state in the last decade, even as demand\nskyrocketed. Drier-than-normal weather has also reduced electricity\nsupplies from hydroelectric plants in the northwestern U.S.\n\n--Mark Johnson in the Princeton newsroom (609) 279-4017, or at\nmjohnson7@bloomberg.net /atr\n\n\nEnron Reaffirms 2001 Forecast After Stock Price Falls (Update1)\n2001-03-22 16:56 (New York)\n\nEnron Reaffirms 2001 Forecast After Stock Price Falls (Update1)\n\n     (Updates percentage decline in first paragraph and closes\nshares.)\n\n     Houston, March 22 (Bloomberg) -- Enron Corp., whose shares\nhave fallen 17 percent in the past week on concern the company's\ntelecommunications business won't generate the expected profit,\nsaid it still expects to earn $1.70 to $1.75 a share this year.\n     The largest energy trader raised its 2001 profit estimate in\nJanuary, citing growth in European and North American trading and\nmore business from its fiber-optic network. It previously forecast\nprofit of $1.60 to $1.70 a share.\n     Enron's shares fell 11 percent on March 12 after the collapse\nof an agreement for Blockbuster Inc. to deliver movies on demand\nover Enron's fiber-optic system. The shares continued to fall this\nweek, partly on speculation Enron may exit the broadband business,\nCredit Suisse First Boston analyst Curt Launer said in a report.\n     ``The market is panicked to a certain extent,'' said Dain\nRauscher Wessels analyst Mark Easterbrook, who has a ``strong\nbuy'' rating on Enron shares.\n     Shares of Houston-based Enron fell 87 cents to $55.02 after\ntouching a 52-week low of $51.51 earlier.\n     ``Broadband is a core business of Enron's,'' spokesman Vance\nMeyer said. ``All of our businesses are doing very well, and we\nplan to hit our earnings targets, and that includes broadband.''\n     Investors also are concerned that falling natural-gas prices\nand California's energy crisis may hurt Enron's trading business,\nanalysts said. Enron also has failed to get the Indian government-\nowned Maharashtra State Electricity Board to pay its December\npower bill.\n     Easterbrook said he expects the shares to rebound once Enron\nreports first-quarter earnings on April 17.\n     ``The stock may act weak here, it may continue to act weak\nfor the next several days,'' he said. ``But I think first-quarter\nearnings will be a pretty good catalyst.''\n     The company is expected to earn 44 cents a share in the first\nquarter, the average estimate of analysts surveyed by First\nCall/Thomson Financial. It earned $338 million, or 40 cents, a\nyear earlier.\n\n(Enron has scheduled a conference call for tomorrow at 1 p.m. New\nYork time ``to provide investors with a general update on the\ncompany,'' it said. A live Webcast of the call will be available\nthrough the Investors section of http://www.enron.com.)\n\n--Margot Habiby in Dallas, (214) 740-0873 or\nmhabiby@bloomberg.net, through the Princeton newsroom (609) 279-\n4000/slb/jmg\n\n\n\nEnron Corp.'s India Unit Faces $88.2 Mln Penalty, Paper Says\n2001-03-22 23:04 (New York)\n\n\n     New Delhi, March 23 (Bloomberg) -- Dabhol Power Co., Enron\nCorp.'s India unit, has been asked by Maharashtra state to pay a\nfine of 4.12 billion rupees ($88.2 million) for not generating at\nfull capacity within three hours of being asked to do so, the\nEconomic Times reported, without citing sources.\n     The move is part of a tussle between the two sides over dues.\nEarlier this month, Dabhol said it had asked the federal\ngovernment to pay a 1.02 million-rupee power bill run up by the\nMaharashtra State Electricity Board, or MSEB, for December.\n     The government of Maharashtra, the western Indian state where\nDabhol is located, last month had to pay $17 million as its\nNovember dues after the company invoked a federal government\nguarantee.\n     The Maharashtra government asked the federal government not\nto pay the bill for December and instead offset it against the\npenalty, the report said.\n     Dabhol didn't respond to requests in time in the last three\nmonths of 2000, the paper reported. The federal government is\nexpected to decide on the issue in a day or two, the paper said.\n\n(The Economic Times, 3-23, pg. 1)\n\nFor the Web site of the paper, click on {ECNT <GO>}.",

        "body": "This paraphrased from Tom Briggs, Enron Govt Affairs, DC:\n\nThe Bush Administration has indicated that it will not support any sort of \nlegislation containing price caps.  Although something could get out of the \nSenate, it won't go anywhere without Administration support.\n\nThus, by default, the just and reasonable standard becomes the FERC's \nevolving rate-screen process, which, for imports into California, is  \"daily \nspot market gas prices and an average 12,000 Btu/kWh heat rate.\"  The \nstandard for in-state resoruces is higher, more like 18,000 Btu/KwH.\n\nInstead, expect to see legislation that will take short-term actions to \nincrease supply and decrease demand.  This could include demand buy down \nprograms, and laws the force utility financial solvency.\n\nEvery day is a new day but I am told this will likely be the status quo until \nthe congressional recess is over (recess is from 6-30 April).\n\nAlan Comnes ",
