Box 26530, Austin, Texas 78755 -\nPhone\n512-795-8536\n\nArtie Ellis Should Be Back at Practice Wednesday After X-Ray\n\nRedshirt freshman WR Artie Ellis, who suffered a stress fracture in his leg\nin spring practice, was injured in Tuesday morning's Longhorn practice when\nsomeone kicked him on the same leg. But coach Mack Brown said after the\nevening workout that an X-Ray showed no damage. He said Ellis probably will\nbe back at practice Wednesday.\nAfter losing TE Bo Scaife with a season-ending knee injury, the loss of\nEllis\nwould have been a severe blow to the team's receiving corps, and Brown said\nhe was elated when he found out the injury was minor. Ellis was held out of\nthe evening workout. Brown also said Scaife will undergo surgery on his\nknee\nFriday, and probably will be available for spring practice.\n* * * *\nBrown said Tuesday's first practice in full pads was a very good one, and\nhe\nsaid he is pleased with the second-team offense and defense.\n\"Last season, our first teams just went right through our second teams,\" he\nsaid. \"Our second teams are much better this year. The first teams can't\njust\nline up and ran over them anymore.\"\nHe also said the first-team offensive line played extremely well Tuesday.\nOffensive line coach Tim Nunez said Cory Quye has edged ahead of Mike\nWilliams for the starting job at right tackle, but he said both Quye and\nWilliams \"are having great practices.\"\nNunez also said backup guard Tillman Holloway, a redshirt freshman, \"has\ndone\na great job and is pushing for significant playing time.\"\n* * * *\nFreshmen WRs Roy Williams and B. J. Johnson both made several outstanding\ncatches Tuesday. Both also ran with the first team at times due to Ellis'\nabsence.\nI asked Brown how soon a true freshman could move into the starting lineup\nif\nhe demonstrated that he was better than the veterans. He said, \"As soon as\nwe\nwould see he's good enough to play consistently well. We wouldn't want to\nmove him up and then move him down, but if some of them play well enough to\nmove up, it probably would be next week.\"\nThere is no question right now that Williams and Ellis are the team's top\ntwo\nWRs, with Johnson close behind them. If Williams and Ellis are both healthy\non Sept. 9, expect them to be the starters in the season opener against\nLouisiana-Lafayette.\nDefensive coordinator Carl Reese said freshmen DEs Kalen Thornton and Adam\nDoiron have been looking good in practice. He said both of them should be\nable to help the team this season. \"They are big old boys who should be\nable\nto help us stop the run,\" he said. \"They both have good quickness and they\nare catching on fast.\"\n* * * *\nThe Longhorns will have a scrimmage at 5 p.m. Wednesday at Royal Memorial\nStadium. Brown urged Longhorn fans to come and show their support for the\nteam.\n* * * *\nFOOTBALL NOTES: Josh Doiron, older brother of the freshman DE, is walking\non\nas a TE. He attended Kansas State for a year on a football scholarship, but\nquit the team and attended Oklahoma last year. He did not play football at\nOU. After sitting out this year at Texas, he will have two years of\neligibility remaining. . .         "body": "This is the best I have seen yet on the going-forward cost of power. =20\r\nAssuming 60% of term at $80/MWh this summer, the weighted average CDWR pric=\r\ne=20\r\nwould be $240/MWh.  Using 75% term in winter, the CDWR average price would =\r\nbe=20\r\n$129.\r\n\r\nHarry or Robert: Can we re-run MRW's rate model using these nunbers?  Right=\r\n=20\r\nnow I think they have in there $80/MWh.\r\n\r\nAlan C.\r\n---------------------- Forwarded by Alan Comnes/PDX/ECT on 03/22/2001 10:57=\r\n=20\r\nAM ---------------------------\r\n\r\n\r\n\"Robert Weisenmiller\" <rbw@mrwassoc.com> on 03/21/2001 07:01:05 PM\r\nTo: Alan.Comnes@enron.com, Jan Smutny-Jones <smutny@iepa.com>\r\ncc: =20\r\n\r\nSubject: wow\r\n\r\n\r\nPower Deals Only Cover 33% Of Calif 2001 Needs -Official Updated: Wednesday=\r\n,=20\r\nMarch 21, 2001 06:31 PM ET Email this article to a friend!=20\r\nPrinter-friendly version=20\r\nNEW YORK (Dow Jones)--Power contracts announced early this month by=20\r\nCalifornia Gov. Gray Davis will only cover one-third of the electricity the=\r\n=20\r\nstate needs to buy in 2001, according to a report by the state's chief=20\r\nnegotiator.=20\r\nThat coverage is far less than California officials originally led observer=\r\ns=20\r\nto believe they had secured, and the gap raises questions about whether the=\r\n=20\r\nstate will be able to afford to keep the lights on this summer.=20\r\n\r\nStock Insight=09=09=09\r\n=09=09=09\r\nSymbol=09Last=09Change=09\r\n=09=09=09\r\nEIX=0912.34=09+0.30 =09\r\n=09=09=09\r\nPCG=0911.75=09+0.35 =09\r\n=09=09=09\r\nSRE=0922.25=09-0.16 =09\r\n=09=09=09\r\n=09=09=09\r\nIndex=09=09=09\r\n=09=09=09\r\nDow Jones=099487.00=09-233.76 =09\r\n=09=09=09\r\nNASDAQ=091830.23=09-27.21 =09\r\n=09=09=09\r\n=09=09=09\r\nMore Analysis=09=09=09\r\n=01=07 =09See Analyst Ratings =09=09\r\n=01=07 =09Compare Growth Trends =09=09\r\n=01=07 =09Get One-Click Scorecard =09=09\r\n=09=09=09\r\nEven counting power covered by agreements in principle, the state will be=\r\n=20\r\nabout 40 million megawatt-hours short of the 60 million megawatt-hours it=\r\n=20\r\nwill need to buy this year for customers of California's nearly bankrupt=20\r\nutilities, according to a report prepared by David Freeman, general manager=\r\n=20\r\nof the Los Angeles Department of Water and Power and the state's lead=20\r\nnegotiator on the deals, and obtained Wednesday by Dow Jones Newswires.=20\r\nCalifornia will have to cover those megawatt-hours in the market, where the=\r\ny=20\r\nwill be expensive, assuming they are available at all. The current forward=\r\n=20\r\nprice of power for the balance of the year is about $325 a megawatt-hour,=\r\n=20\r\nwhich would put California's spot-market bill at $13 billion for the=20\r\nremainder of the year. That figure is likely too low, however, because the=\r\n=20\r\nstate will be far shorter in the summer, when demand and prices are much=20\r\nhigher, than in the winter. The forward price of power for delivery this=20\r\nsummer is now averaging about $480 a megawatt-hour. Moreover, the shortfall=\r\n=20\r\ncould grow if some of the agreements in principle don't mature into actual=\r\n=20\r\ndeals, Freeman wrote.=20\r\nOn March 5, Freeman said the state had lined up contracts to cover 60% to 7=\r\n0%=20\r\nof the state's \"net short\" position this summer. The net short position is=\r\n=20\r\nthe difference between the power consumed by California's three largest=20\r\nutilities and the power those utilities generate themselves or have under=\r\n=20\r\ncontract. At that time, Freeman told Dow Jones Newswires that the summer=20\r\ndeals were only agreements in principle and not firm contracts. Freeman=20\r\nwasn't immediately available Wednesday for comment.=20\r\nIn his March 15 report to DWR Director Ray Hart, Freeman says the DWR has=\r\n=20\r\nentered into 19 final power contracts, with seven suppliers, and more than =\r\n25=20\r\nagreements in principle. In 2001, the state's deals cover at most 6,502=20\r\nmegawatts at any given time. Of that, only 2,247 megawatts are covered by=\r\n=20\r\nsigned contracts. Even that figure, however, is just an approximation, as=\r\n=20\r\nsome power is contingent upon availability or the completion of power plant=\r\ns=20\r\nthat might not be built in time, Freeman wrote.=20\r\nCoverage for 2002 so far is also slim, according to Freeman's report. The=\r\n=20\r\ndeals cover at most 7,500 megawatts at any given time, and the state will=\r\n=20\r\nstill face an uncovered short position of about 40 million megawatt-hours.=\r\n=20\r\nCalifornia put itself in the power markets in mid-January, when the=20\r\ndeteriorating finances of PG&E Corp. PCG, news, msgs) unit Pacific Gas &=20\r\nElectric Co. and Edison International (EIX, news, msgs) unit Southern=20\r\nCalifornia Edison left them unable to purchase power for themselves.=20\r\nThe state's idea was to sign lots of long-term deals, thus locking in=20\r\nsupplies and bringing down spot-market prices by reducing the level of pani=\r\nc=20\r\nbuying at the last minute. The hope was also that by spreading out the cost=\r\n=20\r\nof power over several years, the state could secure the electricity it need=\r\ns=20\r\nwithout raising consumers' rates.=20\r\nThose hopes are unlikely to be realized. As reported, California state=20\r\nTreasurer Phil Angelides has said a planned $10 billion municipal bond issu=\r\ne=20\r\n- the largest in U.S. history - will only cover the state's power purchases=\r\n=20\r\nthrough September if prices stay where they are. The California Department =\r\nof=20\r\nWater Resources, which is handling the state's power purchases, has already=\r\n=20\r\nspent about $3 billion on power, a total that is growing by about $45 milli=\r\non=20\r\na day.=20\r\nCalifornia lawmakers and regulators are increasingly saying consumers' rate=\r\ns=20\r\nwill have to rise to cover the cost of power bought on their behalf.=20\r\nThe West, heavily dependent on hydropower, is having one of its driest year=\r\ns=20\r\non record. A number of officials and analysts see blackouts as a certainty=\r\n=20\r\nthis summer, as California comes up short in its scramble for power.=20\r\n-By Andrew Dowell, Dow Jones Newswires; 201-938-4430;=20\r\n\r\n",

    {
        "body": "Yesterday, Enron settled a procedural dispute with Dynegy over Northern Natural Gas.  Our settlement allows Dynegy to exercise its option to acquire the pipeline, dismisses their Texas lawsuit and extends Enron's right to repurchase until June 30.  We reached this settlement as part of our efforts to bring Enron out of bankruptcy.  While we would like to keep Northern Natural, we still have some 9,000 miles of safe, profitable interstate pipelines as a base to rebuild our core businesses.  \n\nThe settlement provides the best opportunity to resolve the pipeline issue quickly and pursue our $10 billion damage claim against Dynegy.  It also allows us to avoid the very substantial costs and distractions from protracted litigation in state courts.  \n\nWe want to see a positive future for the employees working with Northern Natural Gas.  Below is a copy of a message from Stan Horton further explaining this decision to the employees of Enron Transportation Services.\n\nKen\n\n\n\nDear ETS Colleague:\n\nOn Thursday, Enron entered into a settlement over Dynegy's exercise of its option to acquire the Northern Natural Gas pipeline.  The settlement allows Dynegy to exercise the option and assume interim control of the pipeline while Enron pursues its damage claim against Dynegy.  \n\nIn this respect, Enron Corp. has carefully weighed the substantial costs and turmoil that litigating this possession issue would create for the company and the employees of Northern Natural Gas.  Consequently, Enron Corp. has decided not to contest interim possession and allow the transfer of Northern Natural Gas to Dynegy, while the larger issues affecting its future are resolved.\n\nThe company has concluded that with this settlement, Enron should be able to resolve the issue more quickly, as well as avoid the legal cost burden and distractions to the business from protracted litigation in state court.  For the Northern Natural Gas employees, I believe this decision should allow them to steer clear of the dispute and focus on the day-to-day satisfaction of running a valuable, successful business.\n\nBeginning immediately we will be working to achieve a smooth transition and to align the appropriate resources to assure continued safe, reliable and efficient operation of Northern Natural Gas.  \n\nOver many years we have run high quality, cost conscious and profitable businesses in ETS.  Keep up the good work!\n\nStan",

    {
        "body": "Per our discussions last week about the Kern River open season.  I expect \nthese shippers to file the same types of comments in the new expansion.  FERC \nhas a policy prohibiting pipelines from selling more firm capacity than they \nhave at any point, so to the extent these shippers can show that Kern has \nindeed oversold Wheeler Ridge, I think that FERC will have to address their \nissue.  They surely don't want another El Paso on their hands.\n\n\nNGI's Daily Gas Price Index \npublished : March 21, 2001\n\nShippers Dispute Kern's Wheeler Ridge Sales\n\nChevron, Amoco Production, CanWest Gas Supply, Aera Energy and RME Petroleum \nhave called on FERC to stop Kern River Gas Transmission from overselling \ndelivery point rights at Wheeler Ridge into the Southern California Gas Co. \ndistribution system. The Firm Shippers said in comments filed this week that, \nin a situation strangely similar to the recent El Paso capacity reallocation \ncase, Kern River has oversold capacity at Wheeler Ridge, and its proposed \nexpansion project will only exacerbate the situation (Docket CP01-31). \n\nOn Nov. 15, 2000, Kern filed an application to expand its system and provide \n74,500 Dth/d of additional delivery point capacity at Wheeler Ridge into \nSoCal Gas. But Firm Shippers claim recent data provided by Kern and SoCal Gas \nindicates Kern River already has sold more than the 450 MMcf/d of firm \ndelivery point capacity it has available into Wheeler Ridge. Firm Shippers \ntold FERC. Kern River has sold 468.4 MMcf/d of capacity at Wheeler Ridge. \n\nNot true, says Lynn Dahlberg, Kern's manager of marketing. \"We have to date \nsubscribed at 450,000 dth/d. And unless we subscribe at more than 830,000 \ndth/d, we have not sold more capacity than SoCal has takeaway.\" The combined \nKern-Mojave lines can deliver on a firm basis 600,000 dth/d, with Kern having \n450,00 and Mojave 150,000. \"We can move more than that capacity, and we \nhave,\" she added. \n\nSoCal Gas has noted that it curtails nominations from Kern on a regular \nbasis, Shippers said. With the proposed expansion project, Kern will be \n\"creating the same type of firm delivery point over-sale situation that the \nCommission found to be unjust and unreasonable on El Paso Natural Gas at El \nPaso's SoCal Gas/Topock delivery point,\" they added. While they support the \nexpansion, they do not want to see their firm delivery rights in Southern \nCalifornia degraded. They also complained that Kern's marketing affiliate is \none of the primary beneficiaries of the proposed additional access to Wheeler \nRidge. \n\nDahlberg conceded that other interstate lines also deliver to the Wheeler \nRidge point, but \"adding more players to Wheeler gives markets on Socal more \nsupply options. Shippers have to compete.\" \n\nThe shippers are concerned, however that \"substantial benefits under the \ncurrently structured proposal accrue primarily to Kern River and its \naffiliate and would restrict the firm rights of existing shippers....\" The \nCommission should prohibit Kern from selling additional firm rights at \nWheeler Ridge, or provide only rights to secondary and tertiary capacity that \nis of a lower priority than the rights of existing firm customers, they said. ",

Savings Plan, including any accounting issues related to these transactions, please forward the voice mails to  x3-6803.\n\n3.  \tIf you have any voice mails that relate in any way to Enron's public statements regarding EBS, Azurix, New Power Co., or any voice mail regarding financial transactions involving these matters, including accounting issues related to these matters, please forward the voice mails to  x3-6801.\n\n   \t4.   \tIf you have any voice mails that relate in any way to Enron's public statements regarding the proposed merger with Dynegy or the Enron Corp. Sold out 5\nyears in a row!\n\nRegister now at http://www.supercybersuds.org\n\n\n|||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||\n\n======= Top Stories =======\n\no Champion Ventures Takes Home $150 Million for New Fund\n\nREDWOOD CITY, Calif. -- Champion Ventures, which\nraises funds from professional athletes for fund-to-fund\ninvestments, said it secured $150 million for 2000\nChampion Ventures, its second investment fund. New\ninvestors to the fund include professional athletes,\nsuch as Olympic gold medalist Michael Johnson, tennis\nstar Andre Agassi, college basketball coaches Mike\nKrzyzewski and Rick Pitino, basketball player Donyell\nMarshall, and former football player Joe Montana,\nwho joins the firm as a general partner. Champion\nVentures was founded by former San Francisco 49ers\n Ronnie Lott and Harris Barton.\nhttp://www.championventures.com/\n_____________________________________________\n\no Business.com Secures $61 Million in Series C Financing\n\nSANTA MONICA, Calif. -- Business.com, which provides\na directory of Internet businesses, said it raised\n$61 million in its Series C funding. The Financial\nTimes Group led the round, which was co-led by Cahners\nBusiness Information and included IndustryClick,\nthe McGraw-Hill Companies, and individual investor\nMort Zuckerman, who owns several print and media\npublications. The Financial Times Group chief executive\nofficer Stephen Hill and Cahners Business Information\nchief executive officer Marc Teren will sit on the\ncompany's board of directors. The company will use\nthe funding to enhance its Web site's content and\nfeatures, further develop its technology, and for\ninternational expansion. Business.com was incubated\nby eCompanies.\nhttp://www.business.com/\n_____________________________________________\n\no Ness Technologies In $255.6 Million Merger With Sapiens\n\nREHOBOT, Israel -- Ness Technologies, the largest\nprovider of information technology services in Israel,\nand Sapiens International, which integrates information\ntechnology and e-commerce through its software and\nservices, said they will merge. Sapiens will issue\n40.9 million shares in a transaction valued at $255.6\nmillion. Yaron Polak, the president and CEO of Ness,\nand Aharon Fogel, Ness's chairman, will assume the\npositions of president and CEO, and chairman, respectively,\nof the merged company. Ron Zuckerman, who serves\nas chairman of the Sapiens board, will serve on\nthe board of directors of the new entity. The merged\ncompanies will operate under the Ness Technologies\nname. As a result of the merger, Ness Technologies'\nprincipal backers E.M. Warburg Pincus and the Wolfson\nGroup will retain their positions as significant\nshareholders in the company.\nhttp://www.ness.com/\nhttp://www.sapiens.com/\n_____________________________________________\n\no 3Com Ethernet Spinoff, Atrica, Has $16 Million First Round\n\nHERTZELIYA, Israel -- Atrica, which intends to provide\noptical ethernet technologies, launched with a $16\nmillion first round. Investors in the round included\n3Com, Benchmark Capital, Accel Partners, and Innovacomm,\nthe investment arm of French Telecom. 3Com incubated\nthe company prior to its launch, providing seed\nfunding, management, and development services. Both\nthe chairman and CEO of 3Com, Eric A. Benhamou,\nand Alex Valkanski, of Benchmark Capital, will take\na seat on the company' board of directors. The company\nexpects its first product, which will integrate\nEthernet technology with optical networks in metropolitan\nareas, to be available in the first quarter of the\nnew year.\nhttp://www.atrica.com/\n_____________________________________________\n\no Ex-Tech Lawyer Reback's Voxeo Gets $35 Million First Round\n\nSCOTTS VALLEY, Calif. -- Voxeo, which provides services\nthat enable Web developers and service providers\nto deploy applications for telephone users, said\nit raised its first institutional round of funding\nfor $35 million. Voxeo was founded by Gary Reback,\na former lawyer for Wilson Sonsini Goodrich & Rosati,\nwho was an early force in the Microsoft anti-trust\ncase. Crosspoint Technology Ventures and Mayfield\nFund invested $25 million, with the remaining $10\nmillion coming from undisclosed investors. Both\nCrosspoint and Mayfield Fund will have representation\non the company's board. Voxeo raised a seed round\nfrom individual investors earlier this year.\nhttp://www.voxeo.com/\n_____________________________________________\n\no Egan-Managed Capital Launches $66.7 Million Second Fund\n\nBOSTON -- Egan-Managed Capital said it raised a\nnew $66.7 million fund for investing in early stage\nstartup companies primarily in the New England area.\nA majority of the capital for the firm's second\nfund was committed by the Egan family, led by Richard\nEgan, a founder of the EMC. The fund will make initial\ninvestments of between $2 million and $4 million\nin 12-15 companies throughout the year. The firm\nmanages two funds with over $110 million in committed\ncapital. Egan-Managed Capital portfolio companies\ninclude Network Engines, Top Layer Networks, Lineo,\nand Softrax.\nhttp://www.egancapital.com/\n\n======= New Money =======\n\no Communications Firm Impinij Gets $15 Million, Round One\n\nSEATTLE -- Impinj, an adaptive communications company,\nsaid it recently secured $15 million in its first\nround of financing from lead investors ARCH Venture\nPartners and Madrona Venture Group. The company's\nfounders are Dr. Carver Mead of the California Institute\nof Technology, Dr. Chris Diorio of the University\nof Washington, and Todd Humes, formerly of TRW,\nInc. Tom Alberg from Madrona and Patrick Ennis from\nARCH have joined Impinj's board of directors.\nhttp://www.impinj.com/\n_____________________________________________\n\no Wireless Provider YadaYada Has $14.1 Million First Round\n\nNEW YORK -- YadaYada, an integrated service provider\nand personalized Web portal, said it closed its\nfirst round with $14.1 million from ABS Ventures,\nDeutsche Bank AG London, and BMO Nesbitt Burns'\nHalyard Capital Fund. The company raised $7 million\nin July from angel investors including former U.S.\nCongressman Jack Kemp, General Electric Chairman\nJack Welch, DLJ Worldwide co-founder Dan Lufkin,\n13D Research's founder and wireless technology expert\nKiril Sokoloff, and other undisclosed investors.\nhttp://www.yadayada.com/\n_____________________________________________\n\no Interactive Form and E-mail Firm Quinzer Raises First Round\n\nNEW YORK -- Quinzer, a company that provides Web\nsites that enable users to create interactive forms\nand e-mail in text, voice, video, or documents,\nsaid it raised an undisclosed ammount of first round\nfunding from NF Shops, a South Port, Conn.-based\nWeb site developer and ISP supplier. The company\nsaid the funds will be used for further product\ndevelopment and marketing of its new database service.\nPrior funding came from individual investors.\nhttp://www.quinzer.com/\n_____________________________________________\n\no Streaming Media Firm Everstream Gets $8.4 Million Round One\n\nCLEVELAND -- Everstream, which provides locally\nbranded versions of its digital network of music,\nnews, entertainment and advertising primarily to\nnewspaper Web sites, said it raised $8.4 million\nin its first round of funding from Knight Ridder\nVentures, Gannett Company, Pulitzer, and Capstar\nPartners. The company said it will use the funds\nfor product development, building an advertising\nsales staff, and marketing.\nhttp://www.everstream.com/\n_____________________________________________\n\no Web App Architecture Firm MTW Raises $26 Million First Funds\n\nMISSION WOODS, Kan. -- MTW, which provides Web-related\napplication architecture and development services,\nsaid it has received $26 million in equity investment\nfrom the Halifax Group. The investment is the company's\nfirst outside funding. The deal offers the Halifax\nGroup a 45% stake in MTW, which is primarily backed\nby individuals within the company. MTW said it will\nuse the investment for product development, and\nto build marketing and sales offerings. Telephone\n913-236-8400.\n_____________________________________________\n\no Cardiobeat, Web-based Cardio Assessment Firm, Gets Funds\n\nSCOTTSDALE, Ariz. -- Cardiobeat.com, the developer\nof a tool used for assessing cardiovascular performance\nover the Web, said it has secured an undisclosed\namount of funding from Incubate.com as part of its\nfirst round of funding. The company said it will\nuse the funds to manufacture and test its product.\nhttp://www.cardiobeat.com/\n_____________________________________________\n\no Media Resource NewsMarket Launches with $3 Million Series A\n\nNEW YORK -- The NewsMarket, an Internet site that\njournalists, media relations professionals and freelance\nproducers can use to source, share and sell broadcast-quality\nnews video, announced its launch. The company said\nit raised $3 million in its Series A funding from\nPSINet and Barn Ventures LLC. The funds will be\nused to add more features to the Web site and to\nbuild its sales force. The NewsMarket kicks off\nwith coverage from the Olympic games in Sidney,\noffering raw footage and finished reports focused\non the business, human interest and background aspects\nof the Olympic events.\nhttp://www.thenewsmarket.com/\n_____________________________________________\n\no $15 Million Round Two for Wireless Broadband Firm PipingHot\n\nLONDON -- PipingHot Networks, which develops a high\ncapacity broadband fixed wireless access system\nin the 3.5 Ghz frequency band, said it raised $15\nmillion in its second round of funding. The round\nwas led by Carlyle Internet Partners Europe and\nincluded previous investors Atlas Ventures and Kennet\nCapital. The company said it will use the funding\nfor development of its initial product through commercialization.\nThe company will also use the capital to increase\nits staff from 60 to 100 employees. As a result\nof the investment, Hossam Galal of Carlyle Internet\nPartners Europe will take a seat on the PipingHot\nNetworks board of directors.\nhttp://www.pipinghotnetworks.com/\n_____________________________________________\n\no Management Services Firm Global Factory Raises $12 Million\n\nSANTA CLARA, Calif. -- Global Factory, a developer\nof Web-based services for production management,\nsaid it received $12 million in a round of funding\nthat included Evergreen 3, Apax Israel, and Koor\nVenture Capital. Global factory provides its network\nmembers with an extended enterprise production management\nservice.\nhttp://www.globalfactory.com/\n_____________________________________________\n\no Wireless Tech Supplier Macalla Gets $7.4 Million Round Two\n\nDUBLIN, Ireland -- Macalla Software, a provider\nof mobile Internet and multi-channel enabled software\nproducts, said it secured $7.4 million in its second\nround of funding. Investors were Reuters Greenhouse\nFund, 3i Group, and the Guinness Ulster Bank Equity\nFund. The funds will be used for expanding Macalla's\nsales and marketing operations.\nhttp://www.macalla.com/\n_____________________________________________\n\no Support Site SafeHarbor Raises $25 Million in Round Three\n\nSATSOP, Wash. -- SafeHarbor.com, which provides\nWeb-based self-help customer support services to\nonline businesses, said it raised $25 million in\nits third round from investors OVP, Barnard & Co.,\nProtege Virtual Management, Wheatley Partners and\nWashington Mutual. The company said it plans to\nuse the funds to expand its staff to over 400 employees\nand to open customer support centers on the East\nCoast and in Europe. Steve Chang of Barnard & Co.\nwill join OVB partners Chad Waite and Bill Miller,\nand founders Brian Sterling, Bo Wandell and Mic\nDinsmore on the company's board of directors. Jay\nWood, founder and former CEO of Silknet Software,\nresigned from the board of directors for undisclosed\nreasons.\nhttp://www.safeharbor.com/\n_____________________________________________\n\no MachineryLink, Online Resource For Farmers, Gets Funds\n\nKANSAS CITY, Mo. -- MachineryLink, an online resource\nfor agricultural equipment cost management, said\nit received an investment of an undisclosed amount\nfrom Vance Internet, the investment arm of Vance\nPublishing, a publisher of agriculture and other\nindustry journals. MachineryLink is also backed\nby October Capital. The company said the funds would\ngo towards product development and to hire additional\nstaff.\nhttp://www.machinerylink.com/\n_____________________________________________\n\no Telecom E-Business Platform Company TeleGea Gets $1 Million\n\nWALTHAM, Mass. -- TeleGea, which provides an Internet\nbusiness platform for telecoms, said it raised over\n$1 million from strategic partner Nissho Iwai, a\nJapanese international trading company, as part\nof its third round. The company said it plans to\nexpand its operations to the Far East market. Nissho\nIwai's funding is part of the $42 million third\nround financing raised in July and led by Investor\nAB.\nhttp://www.telegea.com/\n\n======= New Products =======\n\no Geographic Targeting Service for Advertisers Quova Launches\n\nREDWOOD CITY, Calif. -- Quova, developer of technology\nthat aims to enable online advertisers, ad networks,\nand Internet businesses to geographically target\ntheir ads based on the location of an Internet user,\nsaid it has launched. Its first service, GeoPoint,\ngives Internet commerce companies, content providers,\nand online advertisers the capacity to recognize\nautomatically the geographic location of Internet\nvisitors in real-time. Quova has raised $13.6 million\nin two separate rounds and is backed by SOFTBANK,\nIDG Ventures, Fidelity Ventures, and Nexus Group.\nhttp://www.quova.com/\n_____________________________________________\n\no New Internet Browser UltraBrowser.com Launches\n\nATLANTA -- UltraBrowser.com, a free Internet browser,\nannounced its launch. UltraBrowser.com, which is\ncompatible with Microsoft's Internet Explorer standard,\nprovides customized personal space for maintaining\nfavorite sites and enables users to translate multilingual\ncontent. The company is raising second round funding\nafter securing an initial $4.7 million from a group\nof individual investors that included Ron Anderegg,\nthe principal of SouthNet Telecom, and Noveen Shanana,\na principal at Systech.\nhttp://www.ultrabrowser.com/\n_____________________________________________\n\no Online Securities Market Bondweb Launches Trading Platform\n\nSEATTLE -- Bondweb, which provides an online marketplace\nfor buying and selling mortgage-backed securities,\nsaid it launched its trading platform. The platform\nsupports an electronic exchange that enables buyers\nand sellers to trade in real time. Bondweb raised\n$1.3 million in a Series A round from individual\ninvestors and will either close on a Series B round\nwithin the next 6 weeks or form strategic alliances\nin leiu of new fundraising. Bondweb's services include\na database and search engine, anonymity for traders,\nand real-time trading services.\nhttp://www.bondweb.com/\n_____________________________________________\n\no Digital Pipe Launches E-learning Product, nCore\n\nFOSTER CITY, Calif. -- Digital Pipe, an intranet\nservice provider for delivering rich media content\nto corporate desktops, announced the launch of nCore,\nthe company's first product, a platform for delivering\nonline education applications. Financial terms of the transaction\nwere not disclosed. The merged company will be named\nCareCompass Solutions. The administrative, marketing\nand sales executive team will be located in Carlsbad\nand the technology group will be based in Columbia,\nSouth Carolina. HealthMagic is backed by Adventist\nHealth Systems. MPACS was internally funded.\nhttp://www.carecompass.com/\n_____________________________________________\n\no Online Petroleum Commerce FuelQuest to Merge with Oilspot\n\nHOUSTON -- FuelQuest, which hosts private marketplaces\nand offers an online marketplace platform and resource\nplanning service for petroleum marketers, said it\nsigned a letter of intent to merge with Oilspot.com,\nwhich provides Internet commerce services for the\nlubricants industry, for an undisclosed amount.\nFuelQuest received $14 million in April from AC\nVentures and Lehman Brothers Venture Partners.\nhttp://www.oilspot.com/\nhttp://www.fuelquest.com/\n\n======= New Directors =======\n\no Chief Scientist of Vodafone Named to LinkAir's Board\n\nSAN JOSE, Calif. -- LinkAir Communications, the\ndeveloper of a patented, wireless technology known\nas Large Area Synchronized Code Division Multiple\nAccess (LAS-CDMA), said it has appointed William\nC.Y. Lee as chairman of its board. Mr. Lee joins\nLinkAir from Vodafone Airtouch, a mobile telecommunications\ncompany, where he served as the chief scientist.\nHe also spent 15 years developing wireless technology\nfor Bell Labs. LinkAir Communications is backed\nby undisclosed institutional investors.\nhttp://www.linkair.com/\n_____________________________________________\n\no Former HNC Software President Joins Centor Software's Board\n\nIRVINE, Calif. -- Centor Software, a business-to-business\nfirm that provides information storage and manipulation\ntechniques for multiple interaction partners, said\nit has appointed Robert North to its board of directors.\nMr. North was CEO, president, and director of HNC\nSoftware. The trust will make\ninvestments in private companies developing software,\nInternet enabling technology, telecommunications\nservices, new media, leisure, healthcare, and life\nsciences technology. The company's portfolio includes\npublicly traded firms Orchestream and Surfcontrol.\nQuester manages over $281.1 million and controls\n13% of the total venture capital trust market in\nthe U.K.\nhttp://www.quester.com/\n_____________________________________________\n\no The Atlantis Group Forms $6 Million Fund for Startups\n\nRESEARCH TRIANGLE PARK, N.C. -- The Atlantis Group,\nan angel investment group, said it has raised roughly\n$6 million for a new fund, which could double through\nadd-ons. Bischak  (E-mail) ; Thomas  \"Tod\" O'Conner (E-mail) ; Tim Gallen \n(E-mail) \nSent: Friday, March 16, 2001 9:05  AM\nSubject: SBX 9 (Elimination of  Standby Charges)\n\nThe Distributed  Energy Resources industry won a major battle yesterday.? \nThe  California Senate Energy and Utilities Committee passed on a 7-0  \nbipartisan vote, Sen. Morrow's (and while her name wasn't on this  bill,?it \nwas as much Sen. Alpert's) bill on eliminating any tariff  that discriminates \nagainst DER.? SBX 9 was derived from the omnibus  DER bill SBX 35 which is \nstill alive and contains many important  provisions fro removing additional \nbarriers.? Yesterday's vote  represents a major win because even if the bill \nultimately does not get  enacted, a very important statement has been made by \nthe committee.?  I'm sure the CPUC will take notice in their  proceedings.\n?\nThe DER community  owes much thanks to Sen.'s Morrow and Alpert, and the \nUtilities Committee  Members and their staffs:\nSen. Bowen  (Chair)\nSen.  Alarcon\nSen.  Battin\nSen.  Dunn\nSen.  Murray\nSen.  Poochigian\nSen.  Sher\nSen.  Speier\nSen.  Vasconcellos\nSen.  Vincent\n?\nAlso much thanks to  everyone who worked incredibly hard and diligently on \nthis effort.?  From the business, consumer advocacy, environmental, \ngovernment,  manufacturing, and real estate communities.\n?\nHere are the  highlights of yesterday's actions:\n?\n\nFor IOU's- No  discriminatory tariffs for new DER installed between May 1, \n2000 and  June 1, 2003 if DER is in combined heat and power mode.? If you  \nhave a peaking unit with gen only, then you have until??July 1  2001, to get \nit installed.? \nDER installed within  the window gets the exemption until June 1, 2011.  \nThe maximum capacity  of the DER is 5 MW in aggregate per site.  \nThe DER must have  emissions levels of 9 PPM or better until the ARB \nestablished new  guidelines and standards, expected late this year or early \nnext  year.  \nCustomers with DER  are still required to pay interconnection, public purpose \ncharges, and  obligations incurred under the Dept. of Water Resources energy \npurchases  program.  \nThe CPUC shall  require the electrical corporations to include non-utility \nowned DER in  its planning process.  \nThe CPUC is required to  establish a firewall so that in the event that the \nimplementation of DER  results in net costs to the system, those costs stay \nwithin the customer  class.  \nThe CPUC shall  require the utilities to establish new rates for DER that \nare  non-discriminatory and take into account the benefits as well as the  \ncosts.  \nMuni's are required  to review their tariffs for barriers to entry and hold \npublic meetings  to solicit comment for recommended changes.\n\nNow we have momentum,  but there is still a tremendous amount of work to do \non the Assembly side  and with Governor's office.? We need the continued \n(increased)  support of all of you as we move this forward.\n\nSteven A. Greenberg\nRealEnergy, Inc.\n\n300 Capitol Mall, Suite  120\nSacramento, CA 95814\n916-325-2500\n\nmailto:sgreenberg@realenergy.com\nwww.realenergy.com \n?",

It would \nbe hard to make committments to use an application, without really knowing \nwhat it does.  Clarification was what we were trying to get and will require, \nto do a true gap analysis so we can quantify the extent that these \napplications fit or do not fit our business.  \n\nI received a functional spec for Envoice today and would like to get one for \nDTL and Enlighten to get a better understanding of the scope of these and \npossible enhancements that could be added on later.\n\nI am sorry if my queries caused some \"ripples\". Some clarification and a question:\n\nClarification:\nEnlighten (certainly in London) is actually a data hub, rather than an \napplication.  In itself, it will not add business value.  However, the tools \nwhich sit on top of this system will add business value.  These tools are \ncurrently DTL, Envoice, Zebra.  However, I think we all anticipate more \nrequirements being developed as this central data store becomes richer.\n\nQuestion (for business sponsors):\nWe are trying hard to coordinate US and UK efforts.  However, this will be \nextremely difficult if our respective business timelines are not the same.  \nSay - for example - Mike wants Enlighten to deliver volumetric reporting by \nthen end of 2000 but Cindy instead wants a full DPR in the same timeline.  \nOur data architects are going to struggle to coordinate and prioritise their \nwork if we are working for two separate sets of masters.  So:\n\nIf we are really to reap the rewards of a UK/US implementation, a common \ntimetable is extremely important.  Who are our primary UK and US business \nsponsors and can we ask them to agree a mutual timeline ?  I suspect if we \nare to try and make this a joint development, nothing will make delivery \nharder than having separate and sometimes mutually exclusive sets of \nrequirements from our user communities.  \n\nComments/answers please...\n\nCheers\n\nJohn\n\n\n\n\n\n\n",

        "body": "\nEarlier this week, Enron Global Technology announced the plan to decommission the use of all non-standard Internet Email address formats. As mentioned in the previous communication, this was the first of several communications to be sent by the Enron Global Technology group and we will continue to provide more details in the coming weeks regarding this significant but necessary change to our Email environment.\n \nWe are working toward a cut-off date of January 14, 2002, at which time we will no longer support Email addresses that do not follow the standard format of firstname.lastname@enron.com (or firstname.middleinitial.lastname@enron.com if your name in Lotus Notes or Outlook has a middle initial in it). We understand that it will take time to make the necessary arrangements to begin using the standard Email address format, but it is important to begin making the change now.\n \nIf you have questions, please send an Email to Enron.Messaging.Administration@enron.com.\n \nThank you for your support.\n \nEnron Global Technology\n \n \n \n-----Original Message----- \nFrom: Enron Announcements/Corp/Enron@ENRON on behalf of Enron Messaging Administration \nSent: Mon 10/15/2001 9:15 PM \nTo: All Enron Worldwide@ENRON \nCc: \nSubject: Supported Internet Email Addresses\n\n\n\nEnron Global Technology is in the process of decommissioning the support for all non-standard Internet Email address formats. The only Internet Email address format that will be supported, once this effort is completed, is firstname.lastname@enron.com. We will no longer support Internet Email address formats such as name@enron.com, name@ect.enron.com, name@ei.enron.com  (where \"name\" is an abbreviation, acronym or alternative to an employees firstname and/or lastname). Every Enron employee has an Internet Email address of firstname.lastname@enron.com and must begin making the necessary arrangements to start using this Internet address format if they are not using it already.\n\nAny new/existing application systems or business cards that reference a non-supported Internet Email address will need to be changed to reference the only supported firstname.lastname@enron.com Internet address format. It is important to remember to also notify any external contacts who are currently sending Internet email to any non-supported Internet Email addresses.\n\nTo determine what your supported Internet Email address is, take your name as it appears in Outlook or Lotus Notes and replace any \"spaces\" that appear in your name with periods and append @enron.com. For example in Outlook, Alan Smith, Robert (firstname = Robert, Lastname = Alan Smith) will have a supported Internet Email address of robert.alan.smith@enron.com.\n\nIMPORTANT : If you need to update your business card(s) to reflect your supported Internet Email address, please ensure you test & confirm the delivery of Internet email to your supported email address prior to updating your business cards. If you experience any issues with delivery of Internet email to your supported Internet email address, please contact the Resolution Center.\n\nWe will communicate further details, including the cut-off date, in the coming weeks. Meanwhile, it is imperative that you begin making the necessary arrangements to change over to using the firstname.lastname@enron.com Internet Email address format. If you have questions regarding this email, send an Email to enron.messaging.administration@enron.com.\n\nThank you for participation, cooperation and support. \n\nEnron Messaging Administration",

        "body": "Alan,\n Sorry I was slow getting to this today.  I think your changes are good \nimprovements.  I am fine with this basis.\n\nSteve\n\n\n\n\tAlan Comnes\n\t03/19/2001 12:13 AM\n\t\t\n\t\t To: Steve Walton/HOU/ECT\n\t\t cc: Jeff Dasovich/NA/Enron@Enron, James D Steffes/NA/Enron@Enron\n\t\t Subject: Re: Interconnection Benefits\n\nPlease read the attached.  If OK, I would like to forward to Tim on Monday.\n\nI revised Steve's statement of how to measure benefits.  As I read it, it \nseem cleaner to measure benefits accross interfaces (PNW-CA; DSW-CA) rather \nthan for each region seperately.\n\nIf you do it my way, price actually falls out of the equation and you \nestimate benefits simply by measuring flow times incremental production costs \non both sides of the interface.  (That being said, I also propose measuring \neconomic benefit of trade using basis differentials rather than estimated \ncosts.  Thoughts on which approach is better are welcome).\n\n\n\n\n\nSteve Walton\n03/07/2001 09:45 AM\nTo: Jeff Dasovich/NA/Enron@Enron, Alan Comnes/PDX/ECT@ECT, James D \nSteffes/NA/Enron@Enron\ncc:  \n\nSubject: Interconnection Benefits\n\nEnclosed is a first cut at a very rough approximation of interchange \nbenefits.  It assumes that the benefit to the exporting parties is a \ncontribution to their fixed costs of capacity of base load plants already \nbuilt equal to the difference between the sale price and the cost of fuel \n(estimated from gas combined cycle operation).  The tricky part is trying to \nunravel exports from the Southwest from the ownership shares of California \nparties.  The gain to California is (1) the capital savings of added peaking \nplants and (2) the variable cost savings from not operating high heat rate \nunits.  \n\n\n\n\n\n",

        "body": "AB 1890 Group:\n\nA response to the ISO's recent message regarding CMUA's proposed language is\nnecessary.\n\nFirst, CMUA proposed its language to the Group on participation of municipal\nSystem Units during the week of August 21st, and discussed the matter at\nlength with the Group when ISO representatives were in attendance and\ncommenting on various drafting suggestions. Any implication that there is an\nelement of surprise associated with the CMUA language is unfounded.  If\nanything, it is the ISO's latest suggestion to remove the language that is\ntardy.  The Letter underwent several iterative changes, during which time\nthe ISO had an opportunity to make constructive suggestions to modify the\nlanguage (preferably), or at a minimum explain its position so that the\nGroup could consider the issue.\n\nSecond, the ISO indicates that \"there is ongoing and longstanding litigation\nover how to bring MUNIs into the ISO system,\" as a reason for not including\nthe language in the proposed Letter.  Certainly, the fact that an issue is\nbeing litigated is not a distinguishing characteristic.  What issue hasn't\nbeen litigated, including Load participation in ISO Ancillary Service\nmarkets?! As we fully discussed with the Group, there are a host of issues\nassociated with municipal/ISO discussions, including ISO cost allocation to\nLoad.  CMUA's specific proposal is to uncouple issues of transmission and\nLoad cost allocation from the issue of getting generation capacity into the\nmarkets.  It is unfortunate that, when we all recognize that we need more\ncapacity in the ISO markets to deepen supply, the ISO is taking a position\nto hold on to \"chits\" in an effort to strengthen its hand on transmission\nand Load cost allocation issues.  The end result is that generation is not\nin the ISO markets (whatever the exact number, it is far in excess of\nseveral of the other recommendations made in the letter) because the issue\nis being held hostage for negotiating purposes on issues that have nothing\nto do with supply.\n\nAt this point, it appears we will not have agreement on this matter.  In the\npast, the Group has acted as a consensus organization.  CMUA would like the\ngroup to consider how the letter is characterized to the Governor, or anyone\nelse, if one or more members have remaining concerns.\n\nTony Braun\nBraun & Associates, P.C.\n915 L Street\nSuite 1460\nSacramento, California 95814\n(916) 441-1733\n(916) 441-4053 (facsimile)\nbraun@braunlegal.com\n\nCounsel to CMUA\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n-----Original Message-----\nFrom: Larson, Robin [mailto:RLarson@caiso.com]\nSent: Monday, September 18, 2000 10:42 AM\nTo: 'Karen Edson';     {
        "body": "Good Morning Jeff,\n\nCatherine is out of the office until Tuesday 3/20/01.  Not wanting to keep \nyou waiting for a reply, I thought it best to give you some feedback \nimmediately.  \n\nThe great majority of CAD's customers in CA are core.  CAD does not knowingly \nterminate any current customer prior to their expiration date. The reasons \nwhy CAD's customers are turned back to the utility are as follows:\n\n1) Upon receiving renewal pricing from the CAD rep,  the customer chooses to \nreturn to the utility.\n\n2) Understanding that the current minimum margin per meter for our customers \nis approximately $300, those customers that have extremely low annual volumes \nare sent attrition letters and turned back to the LDC, at the end of their \ncontract.  We cannot competitively price this type of customer versus the \nutility, and extract enough margin to support them. Currently in the \nCalifornia markets (PG&E, SDG&E, & SOCAL) , there exists approximately 50 \ncustomers that have usages so low that given current market conditions, we \nwill not choose to renew the contracts.  The expiration dates for these are \nbetween 5/30/2001 and 2/28/2005.\n\n3) The customer initiates a request for termination prior to the end of their \ncontractual expiration date.  As we are all aware, California customers, \nspecifically those with either an index or NYMEX product, experienced a large \nswing in their pricing during the past few months.  CAD has been inundated \nwith customers requesting to be returned to their LDC.  Although we seek to \nsatisfy our customer to the best of our ability,  returning these customers \nto the utility is the LAST thing we want to do!!!!!!!  \n\nThe steps we have taken to address this issue is to:\n a) work with customer service/credit to offer extended payment options to \nease the effect of the increase.\n b) offer to restructure the customer's contract, and reprice the customer on \na fixed price product; minimizing their risk going forward.\n c) explain to the customer, in more detail, the reasons why this has \noccurred, and how, going forward, the index/NYMEX pricing has eased.  \n\nShould you have additional questions, please reply or call.\n-Jim\n\n\n\n\nFrom: Jeff Dasovich@ENRON on 03/15/2001 04:50 PM CST\nSent by: Jeff Dasovich@ENRON\nTo: Catherine Woods/DUB/EES@EES, Dennis Harris/DUB/EES@EES, James D \nFoster/DUB/EES@EES\ncc: Roger O Ponce/HOU/EES@EES, Catherine Woods/DUB/EES@EES, James D \nSteffes/NA/Enron@Enron, Richard Shapiro/NA/Enron@Enron, Karen \nDenne/Corp/Enron@ENRON, mpalmer@enron.com, Paul Kaufman/PDX/ECT@ECT, Harry \nKingerski/NA/Enron@Enron, Peggy Mahoney/HOU/EES@EES, smccubbi@enron.com, \nsmara@enron.com, Leslie Lawner/NA/Enron@Enron, Rebecca W \nCantrell/HOU/ECT@ECT, Phillip K Allen/HOU/ECT@ECT, Richard B \nSanders/HOU/ECT@ECT, Shelley Corman/Enron@EnronXGate, Mike D \nSmith/HOU/EES@EES \nSubject: More Inquiries From CA PUC re: Switching customers back to LDC\n\nGreetings:\n \nRecall that about 3 weeks we got a call from a CA PUC staffer asking whether \nwe'd switched a particular gas customer (or two) back to the LDC.  We looked \ninto it and discovered that we'd mistakenly switched the customer back due to \na mix up about the fact that the customer had two active meters behind two \ndifferent utilities.  We informed the PUC staffer of the mix-up and explained \nthat the situation would be resolved.  \n\nThe questions from the staffer arose because the CA PUC made a bad decision a \ncouple of months ago. When gas prices ran up at the California border a lot \nof large (\"noncore\") customers attempted to switch back to the utility tariff \nin the hope of lowering gas costs.  In response, SoCalGas filed with the \nCommission asking the PUC to prohibit customers from switching back.  The \nCommission agreed and put the prohibition in place.  The Commission is now \nconcerned that if suppliers terminate their contracts with customers (for \nwhatever reason), or choose not to renew the contracts when they expire, \ncustomers won't have the option of returning to LDC service.\n\nToday, I received a letter from the President of the Commission asking me to \nrespond to the following:\n\nHave you \"stopped selling and delivering natural gas to any non-core \ncustomers with whom you have an existing procurement contract, or...notified \nany of your non-core customers that you do not intend to renew an existing \nnatural gas commodity procurement contract.  If your company has stopped or \nintends to stop serving non-core customers, the CPUC also needs to know\n\nhow many contracts you have terminated or expect to terminate\nthe natural gas volumes involved\nthe location of the non-core customer(s)\nthe reason(s) your company intends or has already acted to terminate those \ncontracts.\"\n\nThere's a good chance that the letter from the President of the Commission is \nlinked to the fact that we've recently switched our electricity customers \nback to utility service in California.  \n\nPrior to deciding whether and how to respond to the Commissioner, I'm trying \nto get handle on whether we're re-sourcing any gas retail customers to the \nutility prior to expiration, choosing not to renew contracts once they've \nexpired, etc.  Catherine, or Jim Foster, can you help out?  Thanks.\n\nBest,\nJeff\n",

        "body": "\n\ngngr\n713-853-7751\n----- Forwarded by Ginger Dernehl/NA/Enron on 03/15/2001 11:18 AM -----\n\n\tMargaret Carson\n\t03/15/2001 10:56 AM\n\t\t \n\t\t To: Ginger Dernehl/NA/Enron@Enron\n\t\t cc: Lorna Brennan/Enron@EnronXGate\n\t\t Subject: PLEASE DISTRIBUTE TO THE GROUP. THANKS.\n\nThe FT/RDI   March  14  California Conference  call discussed the plight of  \nCalifornia\nutilities and customers.  California  is  a state with IOUs on the verge of \nbankruptcy,\nthat  wants  to  buy up the utilities power grid  assets that is now seeing, \nafter more  than\na  year of  constant  natural gas  price hikes,  gas prices starting to \ndecrease.  There  are 3 ways \nfor California  to get out of  this electricty supply bind  and ease off its \npower price spikes:  add\ngeneration over capacity;  have retail users   reduce peak use consumption  \nand find\nmethods  to  use  cheaper storage of power.  The latter is not  available and \nthe first \nwill  eventually  be  available  medium  term.  Thus  dynamic pricing \nprograms  could \nhelp  the retail  power decrease  strategy.  The  California  crisis is \nindirectly  causing several\nother states  to stall their  deregulation progress, namely  Oklahoma, \nArkansas, Nevada and Missouri.\n\nFifty  percent  of US power load is used by  1 percent  of customers--the \nindustrials.\nIn California, the industrials  are only  one-third of  one percent  of \ncustomers  and they use\n25 percent  of  the  electricity in the  state.  Going  to this industrial \nmarket  and using\ntechnoogy and pricing to   conserve  electricity  use would go a long way  \ntowards reducing peak\ndemand use.   RDI  believes the gas infrastructure in the US is  there for  \n100  GW of new\ngas power plants, but many local hookups must be done to meet  super peak \ndays on\na localized basis.  California  is racing   to get  5 or  6 peakers  by this \nsummer yet there may not be enough gas\nthis summer to fill their  needs.  Plans  to add  capacity inside  the  \nstate   to receive  gas at the border\nare lagging  the plans of   interstates  to  add capacity.  \n\nSummer peak use may  be just  as difficult to meet in the US  as winter    \npeaks  have been.  As new merchant plants come online on a  regional  basis   \ndifferentials will change  a lot.   But most pressure on prices medium term \nwill be\ndownward, and the  items to watch   is  where/when the  new supplies  show up \nand  where the\nnew niche interconnects   get  built.   In California  the  Gov. does not \nwant  to  let power prices  go above current price  caps  and  this  will be  \nhard for him to do  and  still give price  signals  that  will  take off \ndemand\nat the  peak of the market.  Average electricity demand  growth annually  in \nCalifornia  has  been about  3 percent per\nyear  since   1998 but   less  than 1 percent of new capacity  has been  \nadded.  In concluding remarks, RDI's  John Egan\nnoted  due to the expected  crush of  changes, market vigilence   will be \ncritical  for the  successful  participants in the gas and power markets  \nover the next  few years.",

We were also\nsuccessful in communicating our cost-benefit analysis and delaying the\nimmediate adoption of the team. The motion (approved 5-0) read:\n\nBoard of Governors Market Repair Team\nMOVED, that the Board approve the concept of a Market Repair Team along the\nlines described in the Florio memorandum of March 14, 2001, and directs ISO\nmanagement to provide a response to the proposal addressing among other\nissues, issues of cost/ benefit, conflicts of interest, team composition at\nthe next Board meeting.\n\nIEP, CMUA, SMUD, and Grid Services were all asked to submit some proposed\nnames by today to the ISO Management, please see below e-mail from Elaina:\n\nToday during the Public Comment, you all indicated that you might have names\nas potential members of the Advisory Group for the Market Repair Team.  It\nis not clear at this point how the whole process will be structured, but we\nhave been asked to put together a proposed game plan including names for\npotential members of the Advisory Group.  Please send them to me ask quickly\nas you can:  Friday pm is what Chairman Kahn asked for.\n\nWe would like to be as responsive as possible to the request and have\nthought of the idea of proposing someone that EPSA uses in a variety of\nroles.  CMUA will also probably be proposing someone from their national\norganization. There is more information on Dr.\nRoach and Boston Consulting on their web site www.bostonpacific.com.  I\nspoke with Julie Simon at EPSA this morning and she also gave him an\nenthusiastic endorsement.\n\nAnother idea or an additional person to submit  would be an economist that\nis involved heavily in California.  Since both Hogan and Joskow have\nfinancial ties to market participants we may want to consider proposing our\nown economist.  It is the plan to submit both names to the ISO as well as a\nletter addressing the following:\n\n\n1. Raise very gently the issue of potential conflict of interest, coupled\nwith cost/benefit analysis etc\n2. Address structural issues, including how stakeholders will participate.\n3. Propose more diversity for the Market Repair Team,\n4. Propose a Stakeholder Advisory Group as a third box, and include\nstakeholders, including a regional perspective like neighboring control\nareas, and folks with operational and market experience\n\n\n\nIt is crucial that if this plan sends up any red flags for you that you get\nback to me ASAP.     {
        "body": "This article has the angle I spoke of on yesterday's call ...\n\n\n State reviews draft plan to prohibit energy exports \nPublished Sunday, March 11, 2001, in the San Jose Mercury News \nBY STEVE JOHNSON \n\nMercury News \n\n\nTo the concern of some of its neighbors, California appears to be getting \nmore serious about the idea of banning its electricity generators from \nselling to other states on days when power supplies here are critically short.\n\nA draft proposal to prohibit such exports was circulated late last week by \nthe California Independent System Operator, which oversees most of the \nstate's power grid. Although officials there could not be reached for \ncomment, the proposal said the agency plans to seek approval for the ban from \nthe Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, which supervises power wholesalers.\n\nThe proposal would require California generators ``to make full capacity \navailable'' to this state when electricity reserves dip below 7 percent, a \ncondition that results in a Stage 1 emergency. Rolling blackouts can result \nafter a Stage 3 emergency, when reserves fall below 1.5 percent.\n\nGov. Gray Davis and other California officials have been mulling over the \nidea of such a ban for months. They are concerned about California's power \nbeing shipped elsewhere, particularly when the state is scrambling to find \nenough electricity to keep the lights on.\n\nA Mercury News analysis in December found that thousands of \nCalifornia-generated megawatts -- enough to supply several million homes -- \nwere routinely being sold to other states during hours when power here was \ncritically short.\n\nIn addition, the draft proposal said banning exports could help prevent \ngenerators from engaging in ``megawatt laundering,'' in which they \nartificially inflate the price of their power by selling it out of state to \nan affiliate or an associate and then back into California just before it is \nneeded. While in-state power suppliers are somewhat limited in what they can \ncharge, no such constraints apply to power sold into California during \nelectrical emergencies.\n\nBut because California is highly dependent on electricity imports, some \nexperts fear that banning energy exports could backfire. They said other \nstates that periodically rely on power from California might retaliate by \nbarring their generators from selling power to the state.\n\n``Steps that would essentially Balkanize the intertie could be \ncounterproductive,'' said David Danner, energy policy adviser to Washington \nGov. Gary Locke, in reference to the major high-voltage line known as the \nintertie that links California to the Pacific Northwest.\n\nDanner praised Davis' recent efforts to solve California's energy problems. \nEven so, he said, any restriction on the flow of electricity could provoke \nanger in Washington state, where record-low rainfall has hurt the ability of \nthe region's hydroelectric dams to make power and where some residents have \nseen their utility bills soar.\n\n``I get calls every day from people . . . who say, `Why should I sit in the \ndark when all the power gets shipped to California?' '' said Danner, noting \nthat Washington residents have been asked to drastically cut back on their \nelectricity this year. ``There is some resentment.''\n\nRoy Hemmingway, an energy specialist in the office of Oregon Gov. John \nKitzhaber, expressed concern that the proposed ban would hinder what he \ncalled ``the mutually advantageous exchange of power between the Pacific \nNorthwest and California.\n\n``We in Oregon are pretty sympathetic to the extremely difficult situation \nthat California is facing,'' he said. Even so, he added, ``I am hoping this \nproposal would have some flexibility in it.''\n\n\n\n\n\n\n------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n--\n\nContact Steve Johnson at sjohnson@sjmercury.com or (408) 920-5043.\n\n\n\n\n# # #   \n \n ",

    {
        "body": "\n\n -----Original Message-----\nFrom: \tTruOrange@aol.com@ENRON  \nSent:\tMonday, October 29, 2001 9:38 AM\nTo:\tTruOrange@aol.com\nSubject:\tTrue Orange, October 29, 2001, Part 1 of 3\n\nJerry Scarbrough's True Orange\nThe Newsletter for the True Texas Longhorn Faithful\n\nVolume 12, No. 3, October 29, 2001\n\n Simms Throws 4 TD Passes, Benson Rushes\nFor 157 Yards as Longhorns Gore Tigers, 35-16\n\nJunior QB Chris Simms and true freshman RB Cedric Benson had career-best days\nand the UT defense held Missouri to just one first down in the first and\nthird quarters Saturday in Columbia to lead Texas to a 35-16 victory.\nOn a day when upsets reigned across the country, particularly in the top 10,\nand five of the eight previously unbeaten teams lost, the Longhorns took care\nof business and ran their record to 7-1 overall and 4-1 in the Big 12.\nWith Oklahoma's 20-10 loss at Nebraska, the Sooners, Longhorns and Aggies are\nall tied atop the standings in the Big 12 South.\nBut the Longhorns have to win out and Oklahoma has to lose another conference\ngame for the Longhorns to make it to the Big 12 Championship Game.\nSaturday's victory at Missouri was a fairly easy conquest, thanks to the\nstout UT defense and a great performance by the offensive line that allowed\nSimms to complete 24 of 30 passes (80%) for 229 yards and four touchdowns and\nBenson to run for 157 yards on 31 carries, an average of 5.1 yards a pop.\nBut some strange things happened to thwart the Longhorns in the early going.\nOn their first drive, for example, they held the ball almost 10 minutes,\nrolling 78 yards in 19 plays, but they got zero points because they stalled\nat the Tiger 2 and Dusty Mangum missed the chip-shot field goal.\nThey also drove into Missouri territory on their second possession, but again\nstalled.\nMissouri finally got rolling to start the second quarter and scored first.\nThat seemed to wake up the Longhorn offense and it took control and wore out\nthe Missouri defenders.\nHere, briefly, is how the game went\nFirst Quarter\nTexas won the toss and deferred. Missouri took the ball and Marcus James ran\nthe UT kick back to the 38. The Longhorn defense forced a quick three-and-out\nand the UT offense had its most time-consuming drive of the year, going 78\nyards in a laborious 10-minute, 19-play drive to the Tiger 2, but Dusty\nMangum missed the chip-shot field goal. Missouri went three-and-out again.\nThe Horns drove to midfield again, but stalled as the quarter ended. Texas\nhad a huge lead in statistics, with 7 first downs to 0 for Missouri, a 99-24\nedge in total offense, and a 12:03 to 2:57 bulge in time of possession, but\nthe game was all even at 0-0 in the only statistic that counts.\nSecond Quarter\nThe Tigers finally got their offense untracked to start the second quarter\nand drove 76 yards, primarily on the passing of QB Kirk Farmer, to take a 7-0\nlead with 11:12 left. Victor Ike ran the kickoff back to the 36 and the\nLonghorns went 64 yards in 10 plays to tie it up. Simms connected with WR B.\nJ. Johnson on the 5-yard TD toss, but the big play was a 27-yarder from Simms\nto TE Bo Scaife on third-and-2 at the Missouri 32. Mangum's kick tied it,\n7-7, with 5:44 left. After the UT defense forced another quick 3-and-out and\ngot a short punt, Simms found Scaife again on the first play for a 28-yard\ngain to the MU 13. A WR reverse by Johnson got 5 yards and Benson got 5 more\nand a first down at the 3 before Simms faked to Benson and hit TE Brock\nEdwards for the final 3 yards and the TD. Mangum's kick gave Texas a 14-7\nlead with 1:50 left. The Tigers stormed down the field in the final two\nminutes, primarily on the running of 5-10, 225-pound Zack Abron, who gained\n37 yards in three carries. His 16-yard tackle-breaking run to the 5 gave the\nTigers a first-and-goal, but his next try gained only a yard and Farmer threw\ntwo incompletions before Brad Hammerich booted a 22-yard field goal to cut\nthe UT lead to 14-10 with 7 seconds left. The Tigers outgained the Longhorns\nin the quarter, 120 to 104 yards and had a 9-5 edge in first downs.\nThird Quarter\nTexas got the ball and again made a long, time-consuming drive, but this time\nit counted because Simms scored from the 1 to cap a 73-yard drive and Mangum\nconverted for  a 21-10 lead with 8:50 left. the Longhorns overcame a\nthird-and-11 early in the drive when Simms scrambled and found Brett Robin\nfor 24 yards. Vasher intercepted Farmer four plays later to give the Horns\ngreat field position at the MU 48. The Longhorns couldn't move, but the pick\nkept Missouri bottled up deep in its own territory throughout the quarter and\nallowed Texas to start its possessions around midfield in a quarter that was\ndominated by defense after Texas' impressive opening drive.  The Tigers made\nonly one first down in the quarter and Texas, after getting five first downs\non that opening TD drive, managed only one more in the entire quarter.\nFourth Quarter\nThe Tigers finally figured out their best offense  was to hand the ball to\nAbron and he bulled for 16, 19, 3 and then 7 more for a TD. Missouri's pass\nfor a 2-point conversion failed and left UT on top, 28-16, with 7:41 left.\nNot to be outdone, Benson shredded the Missouri defense for 11, 20 and then 4\nbefore Simms scrambled left and found  Robin, who scampered the final 25\nyards to complete a 39-yard scoring play. Mangum's kick gave Texas a 35-16\nlead with 4:27 left.\n\nTexas and the BCS\n\nThe next Bowl Championship Series (BCS) standings will be a lot different\nfrom the first ones that were announced last week and Texas will be a lot\nhigher than it was in the last one.\nIn the first standings, which were announced last Monday, Texas was ranked\nNo. 6 behind five teams with perfect records. The BCS standings are like golf\nin that the lowest score is the best score.\nOklahoma came in at No. 1 in the first standings at 3.06, followed by\nNebraska at 6.40, UCLA at 8.34, Miami at 12.01, Virginia Tech at 13.88, Texas\nat 15.35 and Michigan at 15.91, to round out the top seven.\nBut a rash of upsets claimed OU, UCLA and Virginia Tech.\nSince OU lost to Nebraska, the Sooners won't tumble far, but Texas should\npass UCLA and VT. Of course, Michigan is so close to Texas that the\nWolverines might pass the Horns if they keep winning.\nUnder the BCS formula, the top four teams in the final standings are\nguaranteed berths in one of the four BCS Bowls, which are the Rose, Orange,\nFiesta and Sugar.\nThe Rose Bowl will get the national title game this year. Right now, that\nlooks like a Nebraska-Miami battle, but both teams have some big games left\nbefore making that date.\nTexas could make it to the Rose Bowl, but it would require some big upsets,\nlike Texas A&M or Texas Tech upsetting Oklahoma, and then Texas beating\nNebraska in the Big 12 title game.\nBut the Longhorns will make it to one of the big BCS bowls if they keep\nwinning.\n\nKey Games for BCS Watchers\n\nIf you want to keep tabs on the Longhorns' chances to wind up in good shape\nin one of the big four BCS bowls, the key is that they have to win their\nfinal three regular season games.\nAssuming that happens, here are some key games to watch for the rest of the\nseason:\nThis Saturday's key games are Michigan at Michigan State, Tennessee at Notre\nDame and UCLA at Washington State.\nThe big ones the following Saturday, Nov. 10, are Texas A&M at Oklahoma and\nUCLA at Oregon.\nOn Nov. 17, Texas Tech hosts Oklahoma, Syracuse is at Miami, Michigan is at\nWisconsin and Virginia Tech is at Virginia.\nOn Thanksgiving weekend, Michigan hosts Ohio State, Nebraska goes to Colorado\nand Oklahoma State plays at Oklahoma.\nThe big games on Dec. 1 are Miami at Virginia Tech, Tennessee at Florida and\nOregon State at at Oregon.\nIf Oklahoma loses to A&M, Tech or OSU and the Longhorns win out, Texas would\nqualify for the Big 12 Championship Game on Dec. 8.\nThe final BCS rankings will be released on December 9, the day after the Big\n12 and Southeastern Conference have their championship games.\nTexas probably will be fourth or fifth in the BCS rankings to be released\ntoday and the games mentioned above will be big determining factors in where\nthe Horns wind up.\n\nJackson, McClintock to Redshirt\n\nIt looks like senior LB Lee Jackson and junior DE O. J. McClintock will\nredshirt.\nBoth have been out with injuries all season and head coach Mack Brown said\nlast week there are no plans to play them.\nHe said Jackson is still having troubles with his toe and his leg. He said\nMcClintock won't play unless the team suffers some injuries at DE.\n\n900 Number Updated Daily\n\nI update my 900 number every day with football and football recruiting news.\nThe number is 1-900-288-8839. It costs $1.59 a minute. You must be 18 or\nolder to call.\n\nCoach's Corner\n\nThe Longhorns, now ranked No. 5 in both polls after a rash of upsets\nSaturday, are playing well, but they need to keep working to get better, head\ncoach Mack Brown said Sunday.\nAfter studying films of the 35-16 victory over Missouri, Brown said he and\nhis assistants were generally pleased with the team's play.\nBut he said the defense will work on hard on tackling this week. \"We weren't\npleased with out tackling,\" Brown said. \"We weren't pleased one back gained\nover 100 yards on us. We've got to get back to work on that.\"\nHe also said the defense did a good job in permitting Missouri to get into\nthe red zone only three times all day \"but they scored all three times.\nThat's not what we want.\"\nThe offense played a pretty good game, he said, adding that tackle Mike\nWiliams \"played great. He's our offensive player of the week.\"\nDefensively, he said the player of the week is CB Quentin Jammer, who held\nthe Tiger's nationally ranked WR Justin Gage to two receptions for 14 yards.\nHe was averaging 7.5 receptions per game and ranked second in the Big 12 in\nthat department.\nBrown also said he is concerned about some aspects of the kicking game. \"We\nkicked two balls out of bounds on kickoffs,\" he said. \"We've got some issues\nthere we've got to correct.\"\nHe said backup LB Reed Boyd, who plays on several of the kicking teams, \"was\nour special teams player of the week.\"\nAsked how he prepares his team for games like the next two, against Baylor\nand Kansas, when the opponents are losing and struggling, he said, \"Baylor\nplayed A&M and Oklahoma tough. Our guys need to play football because they\nlike playing it. If they can't get excited about playing football, they don't\nneed to be playing football at the University of Texas.\"\nHe also said, \"Our guys need to understand that everyone wants to knock them\noff.\"\n\nThe Perfect Christmas Present\nFor Horns Who Have Everything Else: A Gift Subscription to True Orange and/or\nthe E-Mail/Fax\nA subscription to True Orange is the great gift you can give again and again.\nSure beats Christmas shopping, birthday shopping or anniversary shopping.\nThe only thing better is  a gift of  True Orange and the True Orange Fax  -\nand you can give both for just $130 a year ($99 if they take both by e-mail).\n\no  I am enclosing $45 for a gift subscription ($35 e-mail)\no  I am enclosing $130 for a gift subscription to the newsletter and the fax\n($99 e-mail)\n\nName of Recipient\n\nAddress (& fax no., if applicable)\n\nCity, State, Zip\n\nYour Name\n\nAny Message You Want on Card",

        "body": "\nI know that this is a difficult time for all of us.  With everything going on inside the company as well as in the world around us, we have been carefully considering whether a holiday celebration is appropriate this year.  To be honest, employee feedback has been mixed.  Many viewed the holiday party as a unique opportunity for us to come together as Enron employees to share the spirit of the season.  Others felt a holiday party would be improper given the company's current circumstances.\n\nAfter weighing these points of view, we have ultimately decided to cancel the all-Enron holiday party that was scheduled for December 8.  Given what has transpired over the past month, it could be considered imprudent for Enron to incur the expense of such an event.  I regret that this action is necessary because I recognize that your hard work throughout the year merits a holiday celebration and so much more.  We will attempt to find other, more appropriate ways to recognize your outstanding contributions as we move into the holiday season.\n\nKen Lay",

        "body": "This is a follow up reminder about the ERCOT Retail Transition to Open\nMarket Meeting for tomorrow, November 27 at ERCOT.  If you haven't\nRSVP'd for this meeting and plan to come, please reply to this email to\nconfirm your spot.  Space is still available for this meeting.\n\nTerri Waggoner\ndesk: 512-225-7027\nfax: 512-225-7058\n\n\n>  -----Original Message-----\n> From: \tBergman, Karen\n> Sent:\tWednesday, November 14, 2001 4:10 PM\n> To:\t1 Texas Test Plan Team; 1 Standard Electronic Transactions; 1\n> Retail Pilot; 1 2001 RMS and others(Retail Market Sub.)\n> Cc:\t1 ERCOT SCS Leads; Hailu, Ted; Bojorquez, William \"Bill\"; Jones,\n> Sam; Noel, Tom; Tindall, Heather; Waggoner, Terri; Broadrick, Cherie;\n> Hetrick, Nancy; Patel, Roshni; Morales, Rita; 1 ERCOT Client Service\n> Reps; Registration\n> Subject:\tERCOT Retail Transition to Open Market - Meeting\n> 11/27/01\n> Importance:\tHigh\n>\n> Subject - ERCOT Retail Transition to Open Market\n> Date - Tuesday, November 27, 2001\n> Time - 9:30 am - 4:00 pm. Included in the\n> presentation will be an overview of the migration to production, the\n> switching process, the ERCOT portal, as well as communicating with\n> ERCOT.  Please review the attached agenda for the full list of items\n> that will be covered.\n>  << File: Retail Market Transition to Open Market.doc >>\n> This meeting is open to all CRs but will focus on topics to help the\n> new CRs in making the transition. Attendance is limited to 100 people.\n> Please RSVP to Terri Waggoner (twaggoner@ercot.com) by Tuesday,\n> November 20th.\n> Enclosed is a progress report towards the transition to the full\n> retail market operation. The first attached file was used at a\n> presentation made to the ERCOT Technical Advisory Committee (TAC) on\n> Thursday November 8, 2001. The presentation contains the status of\n> switch requests submitted by Competitive Retailers (CRs) as of that\n> date. It also presents key retail market milestones on a timeline for\n> the transition to full market operations on January 1, 2002.
