        "body": "Haas NewsWire\nSeptember 18, 2000\n\n\nCONTENTS \n\nThe Price Institute Gives a Boost to Lester Center Entrepreneurship Programs \nKnowledge and the Web: The Future of the New Economy \nThe Third of Four New Faculty Profiles: Mark Seasholes \nNew Career Center Director: Abby Scott \nHaas in the News \nHappening at Haas \nHaas Celebrations\n\n\nTHE PRICE INSTITUTE GIVES A BOOST TO LESTER CENTER ENTREPRENEURSHIP PROGRAMS\n The Price Institute, a longtime supporter of the Lester Center for \nEntrepreneurship & Innovation, has made a long-term commitment to the Lester \nCenter in the form of a $750,000 gift. The money will be received over the \nnext five years and will support the Harold Price Entrepreneurial Leadership \nProgram, which supports the Entrepreneurs Association and its affiliated \nprograms: the Partners for Entrepreneurial Leadership (PEL), the Berkeley \nSolutions Group, the venture capital internships, and other student programs. \n\n\"The Lester Center and the Haas School are very pleased with the leadership \nand support provided by the Price Institute and its president, Gloria Appel,\" \nsays Jerry Engel, executive director of the Lester Center for \nEntrepreneurship and Innovation. \"The Price Institute has always been \ninterested in our students and the fine entrepreneurial experience we strive \nto create for them. They have been there as our partner for over a decade.\"\n\nThe Price Institute has been awarding fellowships to selected Haas School \nfirst-year MBA students since 1986 to recognize their entrepreneurial \naspirations and development. Two $5,000 Price Institute Fellowship awards, \nadministered by the Lester Center for Entrepreneurship and Innovation, are \nawarded each year to eligible students interested in an entrepreneurial \ncareer.\n\nThrough the years, the institute has given programmatic funding, which to \ndate totals close to $800,000. The institute has pledged to raise its total \ndonation to more than $1,300,000 by the year 2004.\n\nFounded in 1979 by Harold Price, the Price Institute is nationally known for \nits support and development of entrepreneurship. \n\nKNOWLEDGE AND THE WEB: THE FUTURE OF THE NEW ECONOMY\n Most people doing business today have had to deal with issues of \nintellectual property and knowledge creation--and if that business is on the \nweb, these issues come up at light speed. The Haas School will delve into \nthese issues as part of a larger discussion of knowledge at the upcoming \nFourth Annual Knowledge Forum. \n\nThe conference, \"Creating and Exploiting Knowledge Assets in the \nInternet-enabled Economy,\" will take place at Haas on September 29 in the \nArthur Andersen Auditorium. \n\nThe lineup of distinguished scholars and industry leaders includes Ikujiro \nNonaka, Xerox Distinguished Professor in Knowledge at the Haas School of \nBusiness; Roger Siboni, BS 76, CEO of E.piphany and chair of the Dean's \nAdvisory Board; Sabeer Bhatia, founder of Hotmail and CEO of Arzoo.com; and \nDavid Teece, Mitsubishi Bank Professor of International Business and Finance \nand director of the Institute for Management, Innovation, and Organization.? \n\nJoining Nonaka and Bhatia in the afternoon session on \"Leadership for \nKnowledge Based Innovation\" will be Kei-ichi Enoki of NTT DoCoMo, Japan's \nleading mobile phone company.? In May, Enoki was named one of the 25 leaders \nin e-business by Business Week for his push to create i-mode, a mobile \nnet-access service in Japan that now has 6 million users.? Teece will close \nthe conference by moderating a panel on \"Value Creation in the New Economy.\"\n\nThe forum registration fee is $100 and includes lunch and conference \nmaterials.? Register by phone at 510-642-4041 or send e-mail to \nconference@haas.berkeley.edu.? Haas faculty and students may attend the \nknowledge forum lectures free of charge, but they must call or e-mail to \nreserve a space.? For more information, visit the Knowledge Forum web site at \nhttp://www.haas.berkeley.edu/~imio/knowledge/index2000.htm or call \n510-642-4041.\n\nTHE THIRD OF FOUR NEW FACULTY PROFILES: MARK SEASHOLES\n Fresh out of Harvard with a Ph.D. in economics, Assistant Professor Mark \nSeasholes also brings a wealth of previous experience to the Finance Group at \nHaas. Seasholes held analyst and consulting jobs on Wall Street, in London, \nand in Warsaw before returning to school for his Ph.D. He holds an \nundergraduate degree in physics from Wesleyan University. \n\nSeasholes studies international equity markets and is interested in the \nrelationship between cross-border flows and local market prices. Next \nsemester he will be teaching two sections of introductory finance for \nundergraduates. \n\nSeasholes can be reached at 642-3421 or via e-mail at mss@haas.berekeley.edu. \nHis office is at F694.\n\nNEW DIRECTOR OF CAREER SERVICES\n Abby Scott, the new director of the Chetkovich Career Center at Haas, joins \nHaas after ten years of working in technology companies and earning her MBA \nat Kellogg. As she puts it, she hopes to bring a \"different perspective with \na practical, hands-on approach\" to career services at Haas. \n\nAbby is responsible for managing the many different career development \nservices provided to MBA students and setting strategic direction for \nrelationships with employers. Abby most recently worked in new product \ndevelopment at Embark.com, and before that as brand manager at Intel. \n\nAbby's office is located in the Career Center, S420E. She can be reached via \ne-mail at ascott@haas.berkeley.edu or at 643-4520.\n\nAlso joining the Career Center staff is Jocelyn Newman, the new recruiting \ncoordinator.? Jocelyn worked in career services while she was a student at UC \nSanta Barbara.? Jocelyn is located in the Recruitment Center in S330. Her \ne-mail is newman@haas.berkeley.edu or she can be reached at 643-0344.\n\nHAAS IN THE NEWS\n Severin Borenstein, the E.T. Grether Professor in Public Policy and Business \nAdministration and director of the University of California Energy Institute, \nwas quoted in the September 18 edition of the San Francisco Chronicle on the \ncauses of California's high gasoline prices. He attributes the chronically \nhigh price of gasoline to the high oil prices and a tight refining market in \nCalifornia.\n\nBorenstein was also quoted in an article on the front page of The New York \nTimes business section September 15 discussing the problems that electricity \nderegulation has run into and arguing for the need for real-time retail \npricing.\n\n\"Contemporary Philanthropy,\" a course taught by Fran Van Loo, associate \nprofessor in the Business & Public Policy Group and the Economic Analysis & \nPolicy Group and chair of the Public and Nonprofit Management Program, was \nmentioned in the lead of Peter Sinton's San Francisco Chronicle column tilted \n\"Charity Begins on the Net\" on September 13. Read the entire column at \nhttp://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/chronicle/archive/2000/09/13/B\nU89423.DTL&type=business\n\nAn interview with Dean Tyson was posted on Business Week on September 12. The \nvideo clip can be found at  \nhttp://www.businessweek.com/bschools/video/index.htm.\n\nVan Loo's course, \"Contemporary Philanthropy\" was also mentioned in the \nCheers and Jeers section of the Sacramento Bee on September 12. \n\nDavid Levine, associate professor in the Economic Analysis and Policy Group \nand the Organizational Behavior Group, was quoted on CNET.com on September 12 \nin the article, \"Telecom companies go dot-com with options grants.\" Levine \nexplained that consolidation and new executive leadership have spawned \nefforts to foster updated cultures in the communications industry. Read the \nentire article at \nhttp://news.cnet.com/news/0-1004-200-2759859.html?tag=st.ne.1004.saslnk.saseml\n.\n\nDavid Aaker, professor emeritus of marketing, was quoted in US News and World \nReport on September 11. The article \"Guarding the Brand is Job One,\" was \nabout the Bridgestone/Firestone recall. Aaker commented that it was important \nto take responsibility for product failure, not try to shift the blame. \n\nThe Register quoted Hal Varian, dean of the School of Information Management \nand Systems and Haas professor, and Carl Shapiro, Transamerica Professor of \nBusiness Strategy and director of the Institute of Business and Economics \nResearch (IBER), in an article titled, \"Bubble Economy Gurus Rate Amazon's \nPricing Wheeze.\" Their book, Information Rules, was also mentioned. \n\nThe Haas School was mentioned in an article on nonprofit managers in the \nGreensboro News and Record on September 10. \n\nThe Daily Cal published an article, \"Actor Paul Newman Visits UC Berkeley, \nTeaches About Generosity,\" on September 8.\n\nWired News published an article on \"Newman's own philanthropy plan\" on \nSeptember 8. The article also mentions Van Loo's philanthropy course, and \nquotes first-year MBA students Tony Shen and Jill Snyder. Read the full text \nat http://www.wired.com/news/business/0,1367,38510,00.html.\n\nThe Contra Costa Times covered the Paul Newman event and mentioned Van Loo's \ncourse in an article published on September 8. The article can be found at  \nhttp://www.contracostatimes.com/news/stories_news/newman_20000908.htm.\n\nBorenstein was quoted in a September 7, San Francisco Chronicle article on \nelectricity rates, saying that it is easy after the fact to argue that San \nDiego Gas & Electric should have hedged electricity prices, but the hedge \nprice could have just as easily been higher than the price SDG&E ended up \npaying.\n\nDavid Levine was interviewed on KRON news earlier this month commenting on \nthe state of the economy.\n\nDean Laura Tyson debated the right way to spend the nation's surplus on the \nonline version of the NewsHour on September 7. \n\nSkyFlow, the winner of last year's Business Plan Competition, was featured in \nthe September 6 issue of the Berkeleyan.? \"When Talk Isn't Cheap\" also \ndetailed the successes of the Business Plan Competition. \n\nHAPPENING AT HAAS\n PIZZA LUNCHES WITH TYSON FOR FIRST-YEAR MBA STUDENTS Wednesday, September 20 \n12:30 p.m. The Bank of America Forum and courtyard\n\n\n\n PIZZA LUNCH WITH TYSON FOR SECOND-YEAR MBA STUDENTS Tuesday, September 26 \n12:30 p.m. The Bank of America Forum and courtyard\n\n LEADING EDGE TECHNOLOGY CONFERENCE Friday, September 22 and Saturday, \nSeptember 23, 2000 Haas School of Business Ticket Cost: $50 - All Day Saturday\n\nTickets are awarded by lottery.     {
        "body": "Alan,\n\n>>> Day-Ahead & Hour-Ahead Markets\n\n Market separation rules aside, we should resist any mandatory Day-Ahead \nMarket.  The results for day-ahead clearing markets have been bid gaming to \ninfluence price in the day-ahead market.  In PJM and NY-ISO parties submit \nfalse load and generation schedules in set price (most often this is a low \nball load estimate),then later the true load is scheduled.  I think there is \nless of a problem with the hour-ahead market since the opportunity to submit \na false bid to set price and then replace it later is very limited if not \nnonexistent.  \n\n>>> Unbalance Schedules\n\n The general direction we are going for Eastern ISO's is to allow unbalance \nschedules in the real-time market.  Tim indicated a few weeks ago that he \nstill wants this feature.  Normally there would be no imbalance penalties, \nhowever, when reserve margins are so slim that the system's security is in \njeopardy, penalties would be triggered.  The result is that parties can \nchoose to use the real-time market or they can choose bilateral schedules or \na combination.  They are not compelled to do either.  As long as reserves are \nadequate, then why should we care.\n\n>>> Unit Commitment\n\n Although not on your list, I think the primary problems that the Day-Ahead \nMarket is trying to solve is unit commitment.  While this may be the intended \npurpose, it hasn't worked very well.  Centralized unit commitment would \naddress the problem, but then the operator decisions have a large impact on \nprices without having any consequences.  We need a proposal for making sure \nthat resources will be on line and that the operator knows they will be in \nplace.  A possible approach may be as follows (as suggested by Mike Roan):\n\nThe Operator publishes its expected real-time price for the next 48 hours \nbased on information supplied by generators regarding their availability and \nbid price (one part) and the ISO's estimate of hourly loads.  The estimates \nroll forward every hour to that a continuous two day outlook is provided to \nall market participants.  The Operator provides the demand/supply curves to \nthe market so everyone has the same information.\nAs units are committed and load forecast is adjusted, the estimate of \nreal-time prices changes, providing signals for units to use in deciding to \ncommit units.  As expected price rises, more units are committed and price \ngoes down.\nAt a given point in time, such as 4 hours ahead of real-time, the Operator \nlocks units in as committed.  If there are inadequate units committed, it \npays to add capacity (call contracts).  If not enough is voluntarily bid, the \nOperator orders units on under emergency rules contained in \ninterconnection/integration agreements with the generators. \nThe cost of the call contracts or of units ordered on is included in the cost \nof imbalance energy in real-time for the hours for which those costs were \nincurred.\n\nThis procedure is a continuous bid type of approach, which provides signals \nand information to the market.  It or some other procedure like it is needed \nto address the Operators concerns that it will be able to operate the system \nand to deal with the overly conservative tendencies of a not-for-profit ISO.\n\nSteve\n\n \n\n\n\n\tAlan Comnes\n\t03/09/2001 01:10 PM\n\t\t \n\t\t To: james d steffes@enron, smara@enron.com, jeff.dasovich@enron.com, \nrick.shapiro@enron.com, tim.belden@enron.com, mhain@enron.com, \nsteve.walton@enron.com\n\t\t cc: \n\t\t Subject: CAISO Market Stabilization Plant\n\nHere are some initial reactions and questions to the CAISO market \nstabilization plan, which is attached.\n\nGive me or Sue Mara your comments and then we can turn it into message points \nfor  media / advocacy folks.\n\nIn addition to reviewing the plan, I listened in to part of a stakeholder \ncall that occured Friday 10 a.m. PST.\n\nDRAFT MESSAGE POINTS:\n\nWith limited exceptions, the plan does nothing to increase supply or decrease \ndemand.  It primarily addresses costs and market \"stability\"\n\nINTERESTING QUOTES:\n \n\"Over the edge into cost based regulation\" Duke Power\n\nAlthough the plan provides for cost control and for improving market \n\"stability\" (whatever that means), the ISO staffer (Byron Wortz) who \npresented the study admitted it \"Will do nothing to increase supply this \nsummer\"\n\nA staffer, Lorenzo,  stated (paraphrased)\" all out of state suppliers are \ncost of service based and do not need to recieve market based rates\n\nON SPECIFICS\n\nThe Ugly:\n\nResource-specific cost based bid caps (RSBC or bid caps):  cost of service \nregulation that disincent supply\nThe ISO will hold in-state resources hostage--cuts any exports when reserves \nfall below a stated critera\n\nImports can only participate as price takers.  Thus if the highest-cost \nin-state resource is below the opportunity cost of power, needed imports will \nnot come in:\n >>this will decrease supply!!\n >> Staffer stated ISO hopes to sign \"longer term deals\" if necessary to \nsecure out-of-state power but acknowledged the proposal needs more work.\n\nThe Bad:\n\nThe ISO is considering pay as bid, which is complex and does not increase \nsupply.  However, on the call they said they are leaing to a single price \nauction.  However, with bid caps the market will still be distorted.\n\nThe Good?:\n\nThe ISO wll implement an hourly day-ahead and hour-ahead market, essentially \nfilling  a void created by the PX's demise.\n >>( Enron has strongly advocated market seperation in the past but do we \nwant to consider supporting a day ahead market?)\n\nMarket separation rules (MSR).  ISO is leaning towards option 2 in which SCs \nsubmit bundled schedules but that market seperation would be suspended after \ncongestion process is conducted; i.e., final schedules may be imbalanced.\n >>What do we think of this?\n.\n\n\n\n\n\n",
        "headers": {

        "body": "Please plan to attend the kick- off of the Process Leveraging and Reporting \nteams, two of the seven teams that I introduced at the conference in San \nAntonio.         "body": "Dear Mike,\n\nThanks for your insight.  In the past few months we have established a \ndetailed approach to doorstep which includes interfacing with BRM.  Through \nmy calls the past week, I've been trying to update you so we can determine \nhow best to coordinate the Enron Europe work, as well as get an understanding \nof what resources you can supply for this global initiative.\n\nMy next step is to contact some of the people on the list you gave me to \ndetermine their skill set and what locations/commodities they'd be best to \nwork on.\n\nI'll send you an updated schedule once I've finalized this.\n\nThanks\n\nShona\n\n\n\n\n\nMike Jordan@ECT\n10/11/2000 09:37 AM\nTo: Shawn Kilchrist/NA/Enron@Enron, Shona Wilson/NA/Enron@Enron\ncc: Fernley Dyson/LON/ECT@ECT, Sally Beck/HOU/ECT@ECT \n\nSubject: Transparently controlling the wholesale trading businesses - an \ninternal approach to internal audit\n\nShawn / Shona\n\nWe have talked round this issue for some time so I thought I would try to \ntake a brief stab at documenting what my preferred approach is (we will need \nto do a great deal of talking before we would circulate widely):-\n\nAims\nAccountability for internal controls must rest with the commercial support \nteams and absolutely with the leaders of those teams.\nA culture of control and operational risk assessment requires extensive \non-going communication and a structure of measurement and tracking.\nAny independent process of review such as Doorstep and BRM should fully \nleverage the work engaged by staff in the line and indeed should be focused \nby it\nAll elements of implementing, completing and reviewing internal control \nshould generate defined output\nWe focus independently the review efforts for trading controls and \norigination controls (we have defined the control structure for trading \noffices, agency offices and origination offices and we must police our \nlabelling for each office)\nThe output from Enron's perspective is appropriate risk issue lists to be \ndiscussed at control/governance meetings (eg at Sally/Ted/Fernley's level and \nat the audit committee level) - the important issue here is that every list \nmust be extracted from an agreed database of issues - different lists have \ndifferent amounts of filtering applied - judgementally by senior/experienced \nstaff \nThe output from AA's perspective is their internal controls audit opinion \nbased upon our database and our review and management process of it\n\nTrading Process - monthly\nRoutine judgemental self assessment on areas within the trading transaction \ncycle - rating made by business controller is red, amber, green - with trend \nindicator of static, improving or declining - see attachment 2 for full \nlisting\nMonthly metrics collected for key standards set for risk management - see \nattachment 1 (you will notice that this is a summarised version of attachment \n2 - and as a senior controller I would expect the metrics to underpin but not \nsolely drive the judgement within the self assessment) - Shona, this is the \nwork that Mike Moscoso is leading\nPeriodic review meeting between controller and commercial lead to discuss \noperational risk and areas of concern (red and amber) with agreement of \naction plans for such areas\nMonthly review by controller/senior controller of database where all high \n(red) and medium (amber) risk issues are recorded.  Milestones for action \nplans revisited, reconfirmed or amended\nMonthly meeting between remote office staff and controllers to identify if \nthe risk rating for any remote offices has changed\nAll new information on issues raised by self assessment, doorstep review or \nBRM completion populated into database\nDatabase utilised globally to report to various levels of governance and \ndecision on whether original BRM and doorstep plans require amendment\n\nProcess - Yearly Planning\nCheckpoint taken of\ncurrent operational environment (say end Oct)\nproposed new offices for coming year or proposed changes to activity in \noffice, and\nIT development plans for next year\nPrioritisation made for doorstep - which offices require a visit and what \ndepth does report need to go to.  Note the doorstep review would be an end to \nend review for entire business unit and therefore is the independent review \nof the existing self assessment and would leverage the work by focusing the \nreview effort on areas of concern, the actions plans in place and concluding \non the 'mitigation of operational risk to an acceptable level'\nPrioritisation made for BRM - which functions, NOT BUSINESS UNITS, require \nexternal independent review - highly leveraging the above self assessment and \ndoorstep processes (could AA signoff simply by auditing our own internal \ngovernance process?) - most likely reviews completed on functions that \nassessed as concerns across multiple business - such as FX exposure \nmanagement, cash management, credit exposure management, IT change management \ncontrols/process\n\nWhere are we NOW - if we all thought to do this immediately\n\nWe do not have bottom up operational risk assessment for all businesses - I \nam suggesting that we demand that all business controllers at the Houston \noffsite do this? 23rd Oct\nThe above would validate a high level operational risk summary that we as \nsenior controllers could put together for the audit committee - last week Oct\nWe agree on a robust tracking process - throw out one of the BRM and Doorstep \ndatabases - November\nGiven AA have never historically risk rated their issues we should repopulate \nthe database from scratch - November\nReview Doorstep plan to check that our risk rating for business units and \nremote offices means that we have resource focused correctly - do we need to \nvisit all? - November\nReview all of the above and blend into risk based approach for BRM planning - \nend November to end December !!\n\nWow - lets chat about this\n\nMike\n\nAttachment 1\n\n\n\n\nAttachment 2 - the areas where a judgement should be proactively made by each \nbusiness unit controller -\n\nBusiness oversight\nSystem development project and change management\nPeople management - coaching and skills/headcount gaps\nModel Review\nStress testing and business risk identification\nOperational capacity assessment signoff\nError management\n\nControl Cycle\nRisk Management Control\nRecognition of risk origination\nMonitoring of trading activities - limit checking, trader mandates\nSpecific transaction analysis - DASH, CACS etc\nTransaction capture - deal form analysis and risk management system input\nLogistics support - delivery position analysis, incoming and outgoing invoice \nmaintenance, post deal execution contract management\nPortfolio edits - required amendments to previously transacted risk/contracts\nMarket risk/position signoff - both transaction specific and portfolio \nmanagement\nDPR production and signoff\nLimit excession reporting\nMarket risk feeds to GRMS - review VAR applicability (backtesting?)\nCredit risk review - liaison with RAC over provisioning for credit charges\nPrice input checking and verification\nReserving and income recognition issues\nWeekly Executive Summary\nMonthly Revenue Summary\n\nDocumentation\nDocumentation generation\nRe-review of contract loading in risk management system\nAffirmation chasing\nBroker information reconciliation\n\nTrade Accounting\nGeneral Ledger account ownership\nBalance sheet to CPR reconciliation\nAccounts receivable maintenance/monitoring\nAccounts payable maintenance/monitoring\nMonthly management accounts by profit centre/business segment\nInter company/inter entity reconciliation differences\nLegal entity balance sheet analysis for Fin Ops\n\nSettlements\nOutgoing invoice generation\nIncoming invoice reconciliation\nExchange statements reconciliation\nOTC brokerage charges reconciliation and processing\nNostro reconciliations\nCash management liaison\n\n\n\n",

    {
        "body": "Here is the explaination on \"exit fees\" for direct access under SB 27X.\n\nAll parties, including the ESPs and large customers, agree that any party\nwho takes power from DWR after Jan 17, 2001, has received a subsidy as a\nresult of the operation of the frozen rates still in effect ( plus the\nemergency penny/kWh surchage).  These customers will have to pay this\nsubsidy back in the form of retiring the revenue bonds which will be floated\nto pay off the DWR power purchase costs.  If a customer were to elect direct\naccess during the bond repayment period (or anytime after 1-17-01), they\ncould potentially escape their fair share of the these costs, and would have\nreceived the subsidized, lower cost electricity without paying the full cost\nof that power.  To prevent this, the draft of SB 27X proposed by the direct\naccess coalition says that all customers electing direct access will be\nresponsible for any undercollection for DWR power costs related to the time\nwhen they were served by DWR, until the date they stopped taking such\nservice, after which they have no more obligation to pay for DWR purchases.\nThis is subsection (d) of the coalition draft.\n\nThe second form of exit fee is that related to the actual DWR contracts for\npower.  It is this charge (to make DWR whole for higher contract costs when\nload leaves stranded capacity under contracts of a year or longer) which\nwill be waived during the period of \"open enrollment\" or \"free switching\" to\ndirect access.  There will be no exit fee during an initial open enrollment\nperiod (date to be determined, we are asking for 10-1-01) and during all\ntimes when the total long term generation portfolio assembled by DWR and the\nutilities: retained generation, QF contracts, and long term (>1 yr.) DWR\npurchases is less than the total load on the utility system, including load\ngrowth.  Then customers can switch to direct access without this second exit\nfee until the total load is reduced to match the long term portfolio. All\nswitches are first-come, first-served.\n\nOnce that equilibrium is reached any additional customers who want to elect\ndirect access may do so, but have to pay a fee equal to the net unmitigated\ncost incurred by DWR as a result of losing that customer's load.  Once DWR\ncontracts expire, creating more \"headroom\" then customers can once again\nswitch without an exit fee.\n\nI hope this clarifies what we are proposing.  Bear in mind the DWR and Dept\nof Finance may well seek substantial changes in this language.  Thanks, Mike\nDay\n\n\n\n <<sbx 27 amendments 3-7-01.doc>>\n\n - sbx 27 amendments 3-7-01.doc",
        "headers": {
            "Date": "Thu, 8 Mar 2001 04:54:00 -0800 (PST)",
            "From": "mday@gmssr.com",
            "Message-ID": "<20590596.1075843723749.JavaMail.evans@thyme>",

        "body": "Part 3 of 3\r\n\r\nOffensive Line Coach Interview\r\n\r\nOffensive line coach Tim Nunez says he went into spring football with twin\r\ngoals of developing better run blockers and finding a left tackle to replac=\r\ne\r\nAll-American Leonard Davis, who was the second player chosen in the first\r\nround of the NFL draft Saturday.\r\nIn an interview last week, he told me he is pleased about the progress his\r\nplayers made in both areas.\r\nHe said right tackle Mike Williams and right guard Derrick Dockery were\r\noutstanding this spring in every area, including run blocking.\r\n\"Mike Williams had a great spring,\" Nunez said. \"He had as good a spring as\r\nany offensive linemen has had since we've been here. He's really light on h=\r\nis\r\nfeet for such a big man, and that helps him, whether he's pass blocking or\r\nrun blocking.\r\n\"Derrick Dockery finally was healthy this spring,\" he said. \"That infection\r\nhe had last season really sapped his strength all season. He fought through\r\nit and played as hard as he could, but this spring he was flying around and\r\ndoing things he couldn't do last year. He was just a different guy this\r\nspring and he really did a good job. He and Mike really gave us a strong\r\nright side this spring.\"\r\nHe said center Matt Anderson \"played well this spring. He's a steady hand i=\r\nn\r\nthere.\" He also said backup Jason Glynn \"had a very good spring. He is real=\r\nly\r\nathletic. We just need to get him some snaps.\"\r\nJunior Robbie Doane started at left tackle all spring and Nunez said, \"I\r\nthink Robbie Doane is going to be a good football player for us. He needs t=\r\no\r\nhave a great summer and get stronger in his upper body. He really wants to =\r\nbe\r\na good player and he'll work hard this summer to get there.\"\r\nHe said Doane \"has great technique. He really knows what to do. He's just g=\r\not\r\nto get strong enough to do it on a consistent basis.\"\r\nNunez said one reason Doane might not have been an obvious standout during\r\nthe spring \"was that he was going against a great player. (Defensive end)\r\nKalen Thornton is as hard to block as anybody he'll see during the season.\r\nHe's special.\"\r\nBut the Longhorns also have some other options at left tackle. Blinn Junior\r\nCollege star Alfio Randall has passed the JC exit exam and is on schedule t=\r\no\r\ngraduate in time to join the team in August, and Dockery also worked some a=\r\nt\r\nleft tackle in the spring and did very well, Nunez said.\r\nTwo top guards missed the spring. Senior Antwan Kirk-Hughes, a two year\r\nstarter, was recovering from shoulder surgery and sophomore Tillman Hollowa=\r\ny\r\nsprained a knee early in the spring and missed the remainder of the drills.\r\nWhen they return, Nunez said it will make it easier to move Dockery to tack=\r\nle\r\nif the need arises. He said both of them should be totally recovered in\r\nplenty of time for the season.\r\nHow about depth at guard if Dockery moves to tackle?\r\n\"Bo Baker had a good spring at guard,\" he said. \"We'll continue to work him\r\nsome at center, but he gives us another good guard. He's really fast. If we\r\nhad a race, he would be the fastest of the offensive linemen.\"\r\nNunez said players like Williams, Dockery and Kirk-Hughes have had to play\r\nearlier than they should have, since none of them redshirted, but he said\r\nthose painful early learning experiences should pay off this year.\r\n\"Mike Williams really improved during last season,\" Nunez said. \"He was\r\nplaying really well by the end of the season, and he carried that over into\r\nthis spring.\"\r\nHe said Kirk-Hughes' shoulder and Dockery's infection hampered their play\r\nlast season, but he said they played as hard as they could and should be mu=\r\nch\r\nbetter this season because of their experiences last season.\r\nDockery made great strides this spring, he said, adding that he expects\r\nKirk-Hughes to again be one of the team's top linemen when he returns with\r\nhis surgically-repaired shoulder.\r\nHolloway started several games as a redshirt freshman last year due to\r\nDockery's health problems, and Nunez said he \"had to grow up during the\r\nseason. It's tough to start as a redshirt freshman offensive lineman in thi=\r\ns\r\nleague, but he worked through it and he was just playing so much better by\r\nthe end of the season.\"\r\n\"I'm excited about this group,\" Nunez said. \"They've worked hard to get\r\nbetter and I think they have a chance to be a really strong group this seas=\r\non\r\nif they can stay healthy.\"\r\nHead coach Mack Brown said at the end of spring practice the Longhorns were\r\nrunning the ball better than they have the last two seasons. Since he also\r\nsays he isn't that happy with any of the tailbacks, he obviously feels the\r\nline is doing a better job of run blocking.\r\n\"We worked on it more this spring,\" Nunez said, \"and I think that will pay\r\noff this season.\"\r\nOne thing that needs to be noted is that the perennial powerhouse teams\r\nusually don't start offensive linemen until they are redshirt juniors, whic=\r\nh\r\nmeans they are in their fourth year.\r\nExceptional linemen can start earlier, but even they usually spend two year=\r\ns\r\nbacking up before starting in their third year.\r\nThis coaching staff inherited some talent when it took over, but other than=\r\n a\r\ntalented bunch of seniors, the offensive line talent was pretty bare.\r\nEven first-round draft choice Davis spent his first year on defense before\r\nthe new staff switched him to the offensive line.\r\nTexas should be able to begin redshirting most of its offensive linemen thi=\r\ns\r\nseason, but the coaches haven't had that luxury until now.\r\nWhy? Because, despite their great overall recruiting success, they have bee=\r\nn\r\nable to sign only three offensive linemen each year until they hit the\r\njackpot with six in their last recruiting class.\r\n\r\nKelly Named Basketball MVP\r\n\r\nSenior shooting guard Darren Kelly was chosen the Texas basketball team's\r\nMost Valuable Player by his teammates to highlight the team's banquet.\r\nKelly, who earned USBWA All-District 7 and NABC/Chevrolet All-District 9\r\nsecond-team honors and third-team All-Big 12 Conference mention, led the te=\r\nam\r\nin assists (76) and minutes (34.6 mpg) and ranked second in scoring (15.3\r\nppg) and fourth inrebounding (4.6 rpg) and steals (32).\r\nFreshman center Brian Boddicker won the Most Improved Player award.  A Big =\r\n12\r\nAll-Freshman team selection, Boddicker averaged 5.7 points and 3.9 rebounds\r\nin 19.6 minutes per contest.\r\nSenior walk-on guard Yair Harari was named the winner of the Jack Gray Awar=\r\nd,\r\npresented in recognition of outstanding character, citizenship, academic\r\nachievement and contributions reflective of the Texas basketball program.\r\nOther awards and their winners:\r\nSenior Awards - Harari, Kelly, Chris McColpin\r\nEarlene Fulmer 3-Point Attack Award - Maurice Evans\r\nLaSalle Thompson Rebounding Award - Chris Owens\r\nJim Krivacs Free Throw Percentage Award - Kelly\r\nJohnny Moore Assists Award - Kelly\r\nCoaches Award for Most Blocked Shots - Owens\r\nCoaches Award for Most Charges Taken - Fredie Williams\r\nCoaches Award for Top Screener - Boddicker\r\nSpirit Award    - Drew Gressett\r\nOutstanding Defensive Player - Williams\r\nHustlin' Horns Award - Gressett, James Thomas, Brandon Mouton, Royal Ivey,\r\nBoddicker, Jason Klotz\r\nJay Arnette Coaches Award - William Wyatt\r\nCoca-Cola Solid Citizen Award - Ivey, Klotz, Thomas.\r\nBasketball Aide Moves Up\r\nRob Lanier, 32, the Longhorns' top assistant basketball coach and lead\r\nrecruiter for the last two years, was named head coach at Siena College in\r\nLoudonville, N.Y., last week\r\nUT head coach Rick Barnes  said he will  try to hire a new assistant soon,\r\nadding that he plans to hire another bright young coach who is on his way u=\r\np\r\nthe coaching ladder.\r\nSix of Barnes' former assistants have become college head coaches and that =\r\nis\r\nbecause he always hires a bright, young assistant on the way up who also\r\nhappens to be an outstanding recruiter.\r\nLanier recruited several outstanding prospects for the Longhorns, including\r\nmost of last season's top freshmen and incoming point guard recruit T. J.\r\nFord.\r\n\r\nA True Orange Subscription Is\r\nThe Gift You Can Give Every\r\nYear to Your Longhorn Friends\r\nA subscription to True Orange is the perfect gift for any occasion for a\r\nLonghorn who has everything else.         "body": "We have been analyzing various opportunities of providing electric power into \nCalifornia.  One idea is to modify existing customer emergency diesel \ngenerators such that we could turn them on and supply power to the grid when \nthe customer does not need the power.\n\nWe believe current regulations limit use of diesel (#2 fuel oil) fired \nemergency generators to only be operated when the utility is not currently \nsupplying power to the facility and in that case, maximum of 500 hoursper \nyear for hospitals and other critical services but only 200 hours per year \nfor all others.\n\nThere may be legislation currently being submitted to the California \nlegislature or other regulatory body (EPA?) to change this based on current \nneed for power in that area.         "body": " In order to provide better oversight and control of ENA legal expenditures \non large transactions, please continue to follow the procedures set forth \nbelow for transactions where outside legal fees and expenses are expected to \nexceed $25,000.00.  The purpose of these procedures is to (i) improve \ncommunication with counsel (inside and outside) on issues, fees and services \nand (ii) send price signals on legal costs (with respect to specific \ntransactions) on a timely basis to the business units.  Every effort should \nbe made to continue to provide high quality legal work that has become \nstandard at ENA.\n\n 1.  A written estimate of proposed fees and expenses and a written \ndescription of the services shall be provided by our outside counsel.  The \nresponsible business unit and the General Counsel shall review and approve \nsuch written estimate before our outside counsel is directed to provide \nsubstantial professional services.\n\n 2.  Our outside counsel shall be instructed to promptly submit a revised \nwritten estimate if such outside counsel determines that legal fees and \nexpenses for such transaction will exceed the previous written estimate by \n$25,000.00.  Such revised written estimate shall be reviewed and approved by \nthe responsible business unit and the General Counsel or his/her designee \nbefore our outside counsel is directed to provide substantial additional \nprofessional services. \n\n 3.  In order to accurately track such expenses so that the expenses can be \nproperly allocated to the various business units, a work order number should \nbe obtained for each transaction.  \n\n Thank you for your cooperation.  If you have any questions or any other \nsuggestions for controlling expenses, please call me at extension 36544.",

    {
        "body": "Part 2 of 3 Parts\n\nBig Recruiting Push Will Start at June Summer Camps\n\nThe Longhorns are being very selective in making offers to recruits so far\nthis spring, but that will change next month when they host some of the top\nblue chippers at their summer camps.\nThe Aggies have two commitments to the Longhorns' one pledge from my 25 man\n\"difference-maker\" list on page 4, but that will all change in June.\nCoach Mack Brown is the one who invented early recruiting in Texas, and he\ndid it through his June camps.\nThat hasn't changed. The only thing that has changed is that the Aggies went\nout in March and April and gave offers to about 30 kids.\nThere's nothing wrong with that, and I am not knocking their strategy.\nBut Brown's strategy works and there is no reason for him to change it. If\nyou look at the last three February signing days, you'll know why he doesn't\nneed to change it.\nMeanwhile, the Horns got one offensive lineman they wanted when they got a\npledge from terrific run blocker Bret Valdez of Brownwood.\nThe Aggies got commitments last week from center Bob Morton of McKinney, the\nguy I have rated as the best offensive lineman in the state, and L'Tydrick\nRiley of Crockett, the top recruit in the state in the \"athlete\" category.\nTexas probably would have offered Riley a scholarship at some point if he had\nnot committed to A&M, but the Longhorn coaches did not recruit Morton as hard\nas they are recruiting several other offensive linemen in the state.\nI think when the dust settles in February the Longhorns will have another\ngreat class signed and ready for delivery.\nThey got 10 commitments last June en route to a national top five recruiting\nclass, and they probably will have close to that number at the end of June\nthis year.\nMost of those commitments last June were from big offensive linemen who were\njust what the Longhorns needed.\nSeveral of them this June could be from big defensive linemen, and that's\nwhere the Longhorns need to load up this season.\nDT Lyle Sendlein of Scottsdale, Arizona, younger brother of current UT LB\nAustin Sendlein and son of former UT and pro LB Robin Sendlein, told me he\nprobably will commit to Texas when he attends the Longhorns' early June camp.\nHe is the top recruit in Arizona and is being heavily recruited by top\nschools all over the country.\nDT Earl Anderson of San Marcos also plans to attend a UT camp next month and\nhe is another possibility for an early commitment. In a year when the state\nis loaded with top defensive line prospect, he is a star among stars.\nThe best DT of them all, however, is Rodrique Wright of Alief Hastings. He\nprobably won't commit early, but he likes the Longhorns.\nWright is a 300-pounder with outstanding quickness, and he does the best job\nof staying low and collapsing the line of scrimmage of anyone I have seen in\nthe nation.\nIf Texas can sign Wright, Anderson, Sendlein and Kasey Studdard of Highlands\nRanch, Colo., they will be set at defensive tackle, and they have the inside\ntrack with all four of them.\nStuddard is the son of former UT and Denver Bronco offensive line star David\nStuddard.\nAnderson, like Keller DT Tully Janszen, is a super quick starter who could\nplay end or tackle in college.\nAt DE, the top guy in Texas is Travis Leitko of The Woodlands. He is a super\nstudent who is pretty wide open, but he likes the Longhorns and he also is\nfriends with redshirt freshman QB Chance Mock and incoming freshman WR-DB\nBrian Carter, two Longhorns who are former Woodlands' stars.\nChase Pittman of Shreveport Evangel, brother of Cole Pittman, who was\nexpected to contend for a starting job at DT with Texas this year before\nbeing killed in a tragic auto accident, also is an outstanding DE prospect\nwho is, like Leitko, very quick and very physical. He is strongly considering\nTexas.\nThe coaches also want a super quick DE, and their best hope in Texas might be\nNick Owino of Alief Elsik. They also are trying to get in on Zack Latimer,\nwho led Colorado in sacks last year with 24 at Aurora Gateway. But Latimer is\nAll-State in both football and basketball, and could opt for the latter in\ncollege.\nOwino and Latimer are the kind of outside speed rushing defensive ends the\nLonghorn coaches have been seeking since they arrived at Texas.\n* * * *\nThe two fastest junior football players in the state are also two of the best\nones. And that's no coincidence because you can't tackle something you can't\ncatch.\nRB DaBryan Blanton of Forney broke the sprint records in Class 3A with a\nsmoking 20.37 in the 200 meters and a 10.3 in the 100 meters.\nNot since the days of Roy Martin a quarter century ago have I seen a high\nschool sprinter run a 200 meters like that.\nThe times at the state meet are all fully automatic, which makes them\nofficially .24 seconds slower than hand times. In the old hand-timed days, he\nwould have had a 20.13.\nHe also anchored Forney's 400-meter relay team to victory in 41.1.\nBlanton is an outstanding running back, but he probably will be a wide\nreceiver or defensive back in college. He is pretty wide open on his college\nchoices, but he is considering Texas.\nCB Edorian McCullough of North Garland won thge 5A 100 in 10.32, finished\nsecond in the 200 in 21 flat and anchored his team's 400-meter relay team to\nsecond place, making up a lot of ground to pull from fourth to second.\nMcCullough was undefeated in the 100 meters this year. He is a top RB-CB\nprospect who favors Texas over Oklahoma.\n* * * *\nThe talent level in Texas this year is very high. About 20 Texas players have\nbeen listed on one or more national 100 groupings, and there are some other\noutstanding players who are equally talented, but who are not as well known\nyet.\nOne interesting factor this year is geography. In most year, the Houston area\nhas most of the really elite prospects.\nHouston is very strong at the top again, with the top two and three of the\ntop five players on my \"difference-maker\" list on page 4.\nBut the Dallas-Fort Worth area runs deeper in talent this year than the\nHouston-Gulf Coast area, with a 10-6 edge on my list of the top 25.\nThe other nine players on the list include four from East Texas, three from\nWest Texas and two from the Austin area.\nThe talent runs very deep at defensive tackle and defensive end this year for\nthe first time since Brown and his staff arrived in Austin.\nThere also are some big linebackers, like Glenn Jackson of Carrollton Turner,\nwho are big-framed guys who already weigh 200 and might grow into 250-pound\ndefensive ends in college.\nJackson runs a 4.6 and is an outstanding pass rusher from the corner.\nThere also is a lot of talent at quarterback, and if a school misses on a top\nsignal caller in this recruiting class, there are a pair of kids who will be\njuniors this season who already have college recruiters salivating.\nThey are James Battle, 6-2, 190, 4.6, who ran Recruiting . . (continued from\npage 5)\nand passed a Denton Ryan team that was 1-9 in 1999 deep into the Class 4A\nplayoffs last year, and Devon Williams, 6-3, 185, 4.5, of Arlington Houston,\na quick-footed runner with a powerful arm.\nBoth will be top national recruits next year.\nThe Longhorns also want to sign a great running back every year and, while\nthe class of running backs doesn't run very deep, Albert Hardy of Galena Park\nis a power runner deluxe with fine speed, and he likes the Longhorns.\nThere are some very good wide receivers in Texas this year, but the best one\nI have seen on tape is Marquis Johnson of Champaign, Ill. If he played in\nTexas, he would be high in my top 25 and would be easily the No. 1 wide\nreceiver.\nHe likes the Longhorns, and super UT recruiter Tim Brewster was in Champaign\nlast week to visit his high school. He only lives three blocks from the\nIllinois campus, so let's hope he has a yen to travel.\nHe is a big, physical receiver who has speed, moves and great hands.\nThere is one receiver in Texas I haven't seen play, but I have heard good\nthings about him and I saw him run a fine leg on Klein Forest's third-place\n1,600-meter relay team at the state meet.\nHe is Anthony Wright, another big guy with speed who has a reputation for\nbeing physical. I plan to see him play in early September and might move him\nup on the list after that.\nTexas needs to sign a tight end, too, and it will be an uphill fight to land\nEric Winston of Midland Lee, who is easily the top one in the state. He comes\nfrom an Aggie family, but says he will consider Texas, too.\n\nHorns 3rd in Baseball, Play Ags\n\nTexas wound up third in the Big 12 baseball race and will play No. 6-seed\nTexas A&M Wednesday at 10 a.m. in Oklahoma City in the first round of the\nconference tournament.\nTexas finished 19-11 in the Big 12 and 34-22 overall. The Aggies were 15-15\nin conference play and 30-26 overall.\nThe Longhorns beat the Aggies twice in Austin and lost to them once in\nCollege Station during the regular season.\nThe winner of the UT-A&M game will play the winner of a game between No. 2\nTexas Tech and No. 7 Oklahoma at 5 p.m. Thursday in a game that will be\ntelevised by College Sports Southwest.\nThe loser of the UT-A&M will play the loser of the Tech-OU game at 10 a.m.\nThursday in an elimination game.\nThe third-place finish was the Longhorns' highest placing in the five years\nof the Big 12's existence.\nJunior outfielder Matt Rosenberg of Grand Junction, Colo., made the Verizon\nAcademic All-District VI Baseball team for the second straight year. To make\nthe team, a player must have at least a 3.2 cumulative GPA.     ",

O. Box 26530, Austin, Texas 78755 -\nPhone\n512-795-8536\n\nHorns Favored by 19, but Brown Predicts Close Game Saturday\n\nThe Longhorns are 19 points over Oklahoma State Saturday in their Big 12\nConference opener that will kick off at 11 a.m. and will be televised over\nmuch of the nation by ABC, but coach Mack Brown said Wednesday he expects a\nclose game that won't be decided until the fourth quarter.\nHe said Oklahoma State has the best defense Texas has faced this year, and\nhe\nsaid 230-pound RB Reggie White, who is averaging 127 yards per game\nrushing,\n\"is the best running back we've seen.\"\nWith All-Big 12 DT Shaun Rogers likely to miss the game with a sprained\nankle\nand freshman backup Stevie Lee out for about six weeks with a broken bone\nin\nhis foot that required surgery and the insertion of a pin, Brown said the\nLonghorns don't have much depth at defensive tackle.\nHe said sophomore Cole Pittman, a former tackle who was starting at end,\nhas\nbeen moved back to tackle. Redshirt freshman Marcus Tubbs, who played well\nagainst Houston after Rogers was injured, will start alongside All-American\nCasey Hampton, with Pittman and little-used junior Miguel McKay as the\nbackups.\nI asked Brown if Lee might get a medical redshirt, since he was hurt so\nearly\nin the season, and he said Lee is eligible for one if he isn't able to play\nagain this season. If he gets a medical redshirt, he would be a freshman in\neligibility again next year.\nFor those of you who are curious about what it takes to get a medical\nredshirt, Brown said a player is eligible for a medical redshirt if he\nincurs\na season-ending injury before the fourth game if he has played in less than\n20% of the plays. Lee was injured in the second game and, as a backup\ntackle,\nhad not played in 20% of the plays. Brown said if  Lee does recover in time\nto play late this season, he would not be eligible for a medical redshirt.\nBrown said the Longhorn defense, which was outstanding in Saturday's 48-0\nrout of Houston, had an average day in practice Tuesday, \"but they played\nbetter today.\"\nHe said he has told the defense \"that they need to understand Reggie White\nis\nthe best running back we've seen this year, and, with Stevie Lee out and\nwe're not sure about Shaun Rogers, it really hurts our depth.\"\nBrown said the team goal is to \"get 100 rushing yards and hold them under\n100\nyards rushing.\"\nDefensive coordinator Carl Reese said Kalen Thornton will start at DE in\nplace of Pittman. Thornton will be the first true freshman to start for the\nLonghorns this season.\nReese also was asked if Tubbs, who had two sacks against Houston in his\nfirst\nextended action, is better as a pass rusher than as a run defender. \"He's\nabout the same guy in there,\" Reese said. \"He's a big guy with good\nathletic\nability and he played at a high level against Houston. We need to him to\nplay\nat the same high level Saturday.\"\nBecause of OSU's running ability, Reese also said his strong-side\nlinebackers, Tyrone Jones and Marcus Wilkins, will get to play a lot more\nSaturday than they have been playing. Reese pulls his strong backers and\nplays an extra defensive back against passing teams, but he said the strong\nbackers \"might get to play as much as 70% of the time Saturday.\"\nOf course, Cowboy QB Tony Lindsay is dangerous running and throwing, and,\nif\nhe gets hot through the air, that could change Reese's plans.\n* * * *\nRECRUITING NOTES: QB Brent Rawls, 6-5, 195, 4.7, of Shreveport Evangel, is\ntaking his official visit to Texas this weekend and his parents are coming,\ntoo. Rawls, the top QB in Louisiana, went to Purdue last weekend, and he\nplans to visit Florida State the Oct. 14 weekend. He also is interested in\nClemson, Arkansas and LSU.\n* * * *\nBASEBALL RECRUITING: The Longhorn baseball team  got a commitment Tuesday\nfrom catcher Curtis Thigpen, 5-11, 175, of Forney. He hit .515 as a junior\nand is an outstanding defensive catcher. He also had offers from Alabama,\nBaylor and Texas A&M.\n* * * *\nMy next fax/e-mail will be whenever events warrant.\n* * * *\nThe True Orange Fax Service includes  at  least  99 faxes  a year and costs\n$99 ($79 by E-Mail). This month's Argus Roundtable \nwill discuss the impact of time (as opposed to timing) for \nretirement investors. It is our hope that this\ndocument will assist you in communicating basic\nmarket concepts to the team of people working on\nthe successful launch of your efforts to\nparticipate in the ERCOT market.         "body": "Dear SVMG Members:\n\nAs you may know, the Silicon Valley Manufacturing Group Board of Directors\nmet this morning and voted to support two Energy proposals: The Los Esteros\nTransmission Facility and the Metcalf Energy Center.\n\nPlease find below the news release on SVMG's position, and an attachment\nthat reviews SVMG's criteria and evaluation for both projects.\n\nThank you for your time.\n\nSincerely,\n\nCarl Guardino\n\nLocal proposals part of a comprehensive platform to meet energy needs of\nSilicon Valley working families and economy\n\nFor Immediate Release:         Contact: Michelle Montague-Bruno\nMarch 8, 2001             (408) 501-7853\n\nThis morning the Silicon Valley Manufacturing Group Board of Directors voted\nin support of the proposed Metcalf Energy Center and the Los Esteros\nTransmission Project to help meet Silicon Valley's need for reliable energy.\nCompleting a thoughtful and deliberative process the SVMG board of directors\nvoted to support the generating facility, which would offer 580 megawatts of\nnew power supply to Silicon Valley and provide enough power to service\napproximately 580,000 households.  Additionally, the Los Esteros\nTransmission Project, proposed for north San Jose, provides another 800\nmegawatts of new transmission capacity that will help bring power into the\nregion - an issue that caused blackouts here on June 14, 2000.\n\"The Silicon Valley Manufacturing Group has always been a very analytical\norganization,\" said Dr. James Woody, president & CEO of Roche\nPharmaceuticals and chairman of the board of SVMG.  \"With the energy\ninfrastructure projects we developed an analytical process, and a systematic\nreview of the Metcalf and Los Esteros proposals, recommending approval after\nthoughtful consideration.\"\nThis deliberative process included the development of criteria (see\nattachment) utilized by five separate working bodies in the organization\n(three SVMG committees, its Working Council and the Board of Directors) to\nevaluate the projects and determine a position.  The organization does not\nsupport these two facilities as an exclusive means to fulfilling the energy\nneeds of Silicon Valley families and employers, and believes our energy\nchallenge requires the individual efforts of every Californian.\n\"The Silicon Valley Manufacturing Group board completed a very thoughtful\nand deliberative process that supports the generation and transmission of\npower in our back yard,\" said Carl Guardino, president & CEO of the Silicon\nValley Manufacturing Group.  \"The criteria are a prism through which the\norganization assesses energy infrastructure proposals.  It was agreed that\nthe Metcalf and Los Esteros projects would provide much needed energy to\nsupport working families, and the economy of Silicon Valley.\"\nAttached are the criteria utilized by the SVMG Energy Committee, SVMG Land\nUse Committee, SVMG Environment Committee, SVMG Working Council and the SVMG\nBoard of Directors to review the energy projects.\nSolving California's energy challenges is going to require steps beyond the\ndevelopment of the Metcalf and Los Esteros facilities, and must include\nadditional generation and transmission projects throughout the region and\nstate.  However, an immediate solution to help get us through the summer and\nbeyond is for more energy conservation at the office and at home.  The\nE-Energy Conservation Campaign ('E' stands for email), launched on February\n7, between SVMG and Governor Davis' cabinet secretary for technology, trade\nand commerce, Lon Hatamiya, is reaching out to more than four million public\nand private employees to provide tips on ways to conserve power and save\nmoney at home and at the office.  For more information on the E-Energy\nConservation Campaign, visit the SVMG Web site at www.svmg.org, and click on\nthe icon for the campaign.\n\nExpressing the need for a diverse portfolio of solutions in addressing the\nenergy crisis, Carl Guardino will discuss everything from conservation to\ngeneration at the upcoming Energy Summit on March 16, and co-sponsored by\nSan Jose Mayor Ron Gonzales, the Santa Clara County Board of Supervisors and\nthe Silicon Valley Manufacturing Group.\n\"I am proud and honored to stand with Mayor Gonzales and Supervisor Jim\nBeall to co-chair an event that will look for regional solutions to help\nsolve the issue,\" said Guardino. \"We support the mayor's plan for\nalleviating our energy problems, and believe that a comprehensive approach\nmust be implemented to survive this crisis.  No matter how one feels about\nspecific energy projects, there is no single solution, and we need a menu of\noptions, including conservation, co-generation, onsite generation,\ntransmission and major generating facilities.\"\nAttachment:  SVMG criteria to review generation and transmission proposals,\nand how the Metcalf Energy Center and the Los Esteros Transmission project\nweigh up to those criteria.\n\n - criteria MEC & Los esteros.doc",

        "body": "Powerline broadband does last mile---Goes through meters,transformers in=20\r\nGeorgia\r\n\r\nPowerline Technologies Inc (PTI) expects to have commercial broadband and=\r\n=20\r\npowerline modems ready by the fall now that it has completed a=20\r\nfull-scalefield trial.\r\n\r\nIt=01,s the first successful test in the US that solved the problem of avoi=\r\nding=20\r\ntransformers and meters, noted CEO Rick Rumbarger.\r\n\r\nThe basic technology of PTI=01,s hardware was developed in Europe and adapt=\r\ned to=20\r\nthe US by M@inNet.net --the Israeli-based powerline communications firm=20\r\nformed Powerline Technologies with US-based energy marketer PowerTrust.\r\n\r\nThey=01,ve taken the concept from the lab, putting it on the grid and prove=\r\nd to=20\r\nthe world it works, said Rumbarger. PTI=01,s core technologies are in use i=\r\nn=20\r\nGermany, Italy, Spain, France, Brazil and Sweden.  PTI used the latest=20\r\nversion of its technology to provide internet broadband services to single=\r\n=20\r\nfamily homeowners served by Coweta-Fayette Electric Membership Corp, locate=\r\nd=20\r\nsouthwest of Atlanta.\r\n\r\n=01&It=01,s the only technology that we=01,re aware of that can go through =\r\nboth meters=20\r\nand transformers,=018 besides meeting European emissions standards,he added=\r\n.\r\n\r\nServices were delivered over a live power grid using overhead and undergrou=\r\nnd=20\r\nlines.\r\n\r\nProving the technology could be a=01&last mile=018 broadband provider is im=\r\nportant.=20\r\nThe last mile refers to the leg from the user=01,s home to where it hooks i=\r\nnto=20\r\nthe main wires but in this case the connection included the last inch linki=\r\nng=20\r\na building=01,s outlets into a network.Consumers can move from room to room=\r\n and=20\r\nstill connect to the internet.\r\n\r\nHome networking is popular these days but requires some expertise and is=20\r\nconsidered a hassle to set up.The powerline connection allows various=20\r\ncomputers to connect to the internet without relying on a network router.\r\n\r\nPTI=01,s broadband worked on low and medium voltage grids. The technology=\r\n=20\r\ndeveloped by PTI accomplishes one more feat in that it can push a broadband=\r\n=20\r\nsignal over long distances without turning the line into an antenna picking=\r\n=20\r\nup stray signals.It will revolutionize broadband by giving everyone with=20\r\nelectricity an ability to have a high-speed internet connection.That would=\r\n=20\r\nsolve the problem of rural areas being left out of the broadband advance.\r\n\r\nTelephone service can be offered as well as video on demand, Rumbarger note=\r\nd.=20\r\nUtilities will be able to use the system for automated meter reading servic=\r\nes=20\r\ntoo. The powerline technology provides a =01&huge economic windfall=018 for=\r\n=20\r\nutilities that can offer these services using an infrastructure that=01,s=\r\n=20\r\nalready in place, Rumbarger explained.A utility deploying the powerline=20\r\ndevices will only expend about 25% of the cost of installing cable or=20\r\nDSL(digital subscriber line) infrastructures.  PTI=01,s next step is to hav=\r\ne a=20\r\nfull-blownpilot with the Coweta-Fayette co-op in about three months with tw=\r\no=20\r\nmore to follow at midyear including telecom.\r\n\r\nThus a CLEC will be able to provide phone services without leasing lines fr=\r\nom=20\r\nthe incumbent telephone\r\n",

    {
        "body": "My mom got me on this list that sends me a word a day. Thought y'all would\nget a kick out of today's word...\n\nFletcherize (FLECH-uh-ryz) verb tr., intr.\n\nTo chew food thoroughly.\n\n[From the practice of chewing food many many times as advocated by Horace\nFletcher, U.S. nutritionist (1849-1919).]\n\n\"Dinner table conversation comes to a halt as people around the nation\nFletcherize.\"\nMorsels from Diet History, Florida Today, Oct 19, 1999.\n\nThe idea of Fletcherizing invites the question, \"Is too much of a good thing\nbetter?\" Horace Fletcher proposed that one should grind food once for each\ntooth in the mouth. That implies that we masticate each bite of pizza as\nmany as 32 times. I'd rather stick with the idea that each byte has eight\nbits. At any rate, Mr. Fletcher, the art dealer turned nutritionist, did\nearn the moniker `The Great Masticator,' for his popular book at the time\nand got his name into the dictionary. This week we'll look at more such\nwords, eponyms, coined after people from fact and from fiction.    -Anu\n\n_________________________________________________________________\nGet your FREE download of MSN Explorer at http://explorer.msn.com",

    {
        "body": "Regarding proposed rate freeze for large SDG&E customers at 6.5 cents:\n\nAdds to DWR's burden of covering the net short positions without any further \nclarification of how shortfall will be funded.  The incentive these customers \nnow have to participate in DA and thereby remove burden from DWR is removed.\n\nCreates incentives to increase usage and decrease conservation, exactly at \nthe time that just the opposite effect is desired.  Rate at frozen level \nremoves all price signal effect in unregulated market.\n\nThese are customers who under existing law already have had choice, as an \nalternative to paying market price,  of 1) voluntarily opting in to a one \nyear 6.5 cent rate freeze, with a true-up, or 2) buying commodity and risk \nmanagement products in the competitive market, as many of them have already \ndone, and 3) reducing usage to save money.  This bill takes takes away the \nlast two choices/incentives. \n\nAdopting \"rates by proxy\" (in a sense, indexed to PG&E and SCE rates) creates \nthe potential for a regulatory nightmare.\n\nAs an alternative, the Legislature should consider extending the voluntary \nopt-in program under existing law.  This would preserve existing protection, \nkeep choices available to customers, and not unduly add to DWR's burden.\n\nAs another alternative, we could be a lot more willing to accept this IF the \n\"end of the rate freeze\" date in (f) were specified to occur no earlier than \nthe date new rates are put in place (the proposed language from 18X, \nremember?) and it were clear that existing DA contracts were not overturned \nby this Act.",
        "headers": {
            "Date": "Tue, 6 Mar 2001 09:00:00 -0800 (PST)",
            "From": "harry.kingerski@enron.com",

Also the original person called in sick at the last\nmoment,\nand I happened to be standing there at the judge's table asking\ndirections\nto the beer wagon when the call came. I was assured by the other two\njudges (Native Texans) that the chili wouldn't be all that spicy, and\nbesides\nthey told me I could have free beer during the tasting, so I accepted.\n\nHere are the scorecards from the event:\n\nChili # 1: Mike's Maniac Mobster Monster Chili\n\nJUDGE ONE: A little too heavy on tomato. Amusing kick.\nJUDGE TWO: Nice, smooth tomato flavor. Very mild.\nFRANK: Holy cow, what the hell is this stuff? You could remove dried\n               paint from your driveway with it. Took me two beers to\nput the\n               flames out. Hope that's the worst one. These Texans are\ncrazy.\n\nChili # 2: Arthur's Afterburner Chili\n\nJUDGE ONE: Smoky, with a hint of pork. Slight Jalapeno tang.\nJUDGE TWO: Exciting BBQ flavor, needs more peppers to be taken\n                        seriously.\nFRANK: Keep this out of reach of children! I'm not sure what I am\n               supposed to taste besides pain. I had to wave off two\npeople\n               who wanted to give me the Heimlich maneuver. They had to\n               walkie-talkie in 3 extra beers when they saw the look on\nmy face.\n\nChili # 3: Fred's Famous Burn Down the Barn Chili\n\nJUDGE ONE: Excellent firehouse chili! Great kick. Needs more beans.\nJUDGE TWO: A beanless chili, a bit salty, good use of red peppers.\nFRANK: Call the EPA, I've located a uranium spill. My nose feels like I\n               have been snorting Drano. Everyone knows the routine by\nnow.\n               Barmaid pounded me on the back; now my backbone is in the\n\n               front part of my chest. I'm getting drunk.\n\nChili # 4: Bubba's Black Magic\n\nJUDGE ONE: Black bean chili with almost no spice. Disappointing.\nJUDGE TWO: Hint of lime in the black beans. Good side dish for fish or\n                        other mild foods, not much of a chili.\nFRANK: I felt something scraping across my tongue, but was unable to\n               taste it. Sally, the bar maid, was standing behind me\nwith fresh refills;\n               that 300 lb. witch is starting to look HOT, just like\nthis nuclear-waste\n               I'm eating.\n\nChili # 5: Linda's Legal Lip Remover\n\nJUDGE ONE: Meaty, strong chili. Cayenne peppers freshly ground, adding\n                       considerable kick. Very impressive.\nJUDGE TWO: Chili using shredded beef; could use more tomato. Must admit\n                        the cayenne peppers make a strong statement.\nFRANK: My ears are ringing, and I can no longer focus my eyes. I farted\n               and four people behind me needed paramedics. The\ncontestant\n               seemed offended when I told her that her chili had given\nme brain\n               damage. Sally saved my tongue from bleeding by pouring\nbeer directly\n               on it from a pitcher. It really pisses me off that the\nother judges asked\n               me to stop screaming.  Rednecks!\n\nChili # 6: Vera's Very Vegetarian Variety\n\nJUDGE ONE: Thin yet bold vegetarian variety chili. Good balance of spice\n\n                       and peppers.\nJUDGE TWO: The best yet. Aggressive use of peppers, onions, and garlic.\n                        Superb.\nFRANK: My intestines are now a straight pipe filled with gaseous,\nsulfuric\n               flames. No one seems inclined to stand behind me except\nbig Sally.\n               I need to sooth my butt with a snow cone!\n\nChili # 7: Susan's Screaming Sensation Chili\n\nJUDGE ONE: A mediocre chili with too much reliance on canned peppers.\nJUDGE TWO: Ho Hum, tastes as if the chef literally threw in a can of\nchili\n                        peppers at the last moment. I should note that I\nam worried\n                       about Judge Number 3. He appears to be in a bit\nof distress\n                       as he is cursing uncontrollably.\nFRANK: You could put a grenade in my mouth, pull the pin, and I wouldn't\n\n                feel a damn thing. I've lost the sight in one eye, and\nthe world sounds\n                like it is made of rushing water. My shirt is covered\nwith chili which\n                slid unnoticed out of my mouth. My pants are full of\nlava-like stuff to\n                match my damn shirt. At least during the autopsy they'll\nknow what\n                killed me. I've decided to stop breathing, it's too\npainful. Screw it, I'm\n                not getting any oxygen anyway. If I need air, I'll just\nsuck it in through\n                the 4 inch hole in my stomach.\n\nChili # 8: Helen's Mount Saint Chili\n\nJUDGE ONE: A perfect ending, this is a nice blend chili, safe for all,\nnot too bold\n                       but spicy enough to declare its existence.\nJUDGE TWO: This final entry is a good, balanced chili, neither mild nor\nhot. Sorry\n                        to see that most of it was lost when Judge\nNumber 3 passed out,\n                        fell and pulled the chili pot on top of himself.\nNot sure if he's going\n                        to make it. Poor Yank.\nFRANK: --------------(editor's note: Judge #3 was unable To report)\n\n",

He said he called UT assistant coach Tim\nBrewster early Thursday and told him he wanted to play for the Longhorns.\nJakes is one of the top defensive line prospects in California. He played\nnose guard most of last season, but played end for the final few games. He\nhad 60 solo tackles and 14 sacks. In the game I saw on tape, he was playing\nnose guard and he had seven solo tackles and two sacks while being\nconsistently double-teamed.\nHe told me he doesn't care whether he plays defensive end or defensive\ntackle. \"I just want to play,\" he said. \"I thought all along I probably\nwould\nwind up at Texas and, after looking at everything, I think Texas is the\nplace\nfor me.\"\nHe said he had scholarship offers from Colorado, Miami, USC, UCLA, Oregon,\nOregon State \"and just about everybody else in the Pac 10.\"\nHe narrowed it down to Texas and California, cancelling a scheduled trip to\nMiami, then got an in-house visit from Washington coach Rick Neuheisel\nTuesday night  from Longhorn head coach Mack Brown  and Brewster Wednesday\nmorning before picking the Longhorns.\nJakes lived in Plano during his junior high years and said he really\nenjoyed\nhis time in Texas.\n\"I think Texas is building something special,\" he said, \"and I want to be a\npart of it.\"\nJames fills an urgent need for Texas. The Longhorns need to sign some\ndefensive linemen and he and Tommy Harris, the big DT at Killeen Ellison,\nare\nthe only top ones who have been seriously considering Texas. Harris, the\nnation's top DT prospect, has been leaning toward OU recently, but he was a\nheavy Texas lean earlier, so there is always a chance he will change again\nuntil he signs with someone in February.\n* * * *\nWR Montrell Jones, 6-2, 185, 4.4, a national top 100 prospect from\nLouisville, Ky., Male, says he is seriously considering Texas after backing\noff an earlier commitment to Kentuckiy.\nThe Longhorns don't need a wide receiver this year unless they can sign a\ngreat one. Jones is a great one with good height, great speed and very good\nmoves to go along with great hands.\nThe only other out-of-state prospects who have expressed any interest in\nTexas lately  are TE Marcus Spears of  Baton Rouge Southern Lab, DT\nMarquise\nHill of New Orleans De La Salle and  RB Eric Shelton of Lexington, Ky.,\nBryan\nStation. The two Louisiana stars say they probably will visit Texas and\nShelton says he might visit the Longhorns.\n* * * *\nFOOTBALL NOTES: The Longhorns are 6-point favorites over Oregon for their\nDec. 29 Culligan Holiday Bowl clash in San Diego . . . Look for LB Aurmon\nSatchell of Denver Jefferson, who signed with Texas last February, but ran\ninto some academic problems with the NCAA's National Clearinghouse, to\nreturn\nto Texas and enroll next  month for the spring semester. That would enable\nhim to go through spring practice and it also would keep him from counting\nagainst the 25-man limit for the enrolling scholarship players next fall.\nWith 20 commitments already, that is very important. . . TE Brock Edwards\nand\nS Lee Jackson both appear to be recovered from the injuries that knocked\nthem\nout of the last two games last year. Brown\nsaid he was embarrassed to be the Longhorn coach and he really went to work\nto bring the team back from that debacle. What he got was six straight\nwins,\na bowl game and a team that can crack the top 10 in the final poll for the\nfirst time in 17 years if it wins its bowl game.         "body": ">\n> > -----Original Message-----\n> > Electricity Daily\n> >\n> > March 2, 2001\n> >\n> > Fessler Fesses Up to What Went Wrong in California\n> > Breaking a lengthy refusal to comment publicly on the California\n> > electricity \"Perfect Storm,\" Dan Fessler (chairman and a member of the\n> > California Public Utilities Commission from 1991 to December 1996)\n> > described to a recent conference in New York why things have gone so awry\n> > in the state and what he thinks might now be done.\n> > His explanation of why the crisis arose is fairly conventional: a shortage\n> > of generation capacity; grossly erroneous predictions of the timing and\n> > strength of the economic recovery in the state; and a fatal decision to\n> > separate the California Power Exchange from the California Independent\n> > System Operator. That's a policy to which Fessler (now with the meaty\n> > LeBouef, Lamb law firm) believes that the PUC should never have agreed.\n> > \"Little did I realize,\" he told the meeting, \"that the market design to\n> > which the commission and legislature had acceded would turn out to bear a\n> > striking resemblance to the battle cruiser, that ill-fated darling of\n> > virtually every naval power in the period 1910-1914. At Jutland, it was\n> > belatedly discovered that these vessels-imbued with attributes of speed\n> > and weaponry that made them so appealing on paper-could not take a punch.\n> > Their armor was too thin: a fatal design flaw revealed only when they were\n> > tested in battle.\"\n> > So what do we do now? Fessler suggests \"a technique which I advocated in\n> > 1996 and which remains available for deployment next week. If successfully\n> > implemented, my suggestion would directly assail the vehicle of high\n> > prices by enlisting self-interested opportunistic behavior to make the\n> > demand curve elastic for the first time in the power crisis.\n> > \"I propose that California pay large users to get off the system the\n> > moment reserves approach Stage One conditions.         "body": "I thought you all might find this an interesting read.  Sorry, the complaint \nform wasn't very user friendly - I guess the person that designed the\nform is the same that hired there ticketing help.\n\n-E\n\nTo whom it may concern:\n\nI recently returned from a wonderful vacation to Telluride.  It was wonderful \nexcept for the fact that I traveled on your airline.  \n\nI was originally supposed to leave out of IAH at 6:05 AM on 12/9/00 for \nPhoenix and catch a 10:00 AM connection to Telluride \n(the only flight of the day from Phoenix to Telluride).  Unfortunately, the \nflight was cancelled due to the re-routing of our plane because \nof foggy conditions in the Houston area.  I do not blame America West for \nthis; It is understandable to cancel this flight because of \nthe danger involved in landing in foggy conditions. There is, however, no \ndanger involved in taking off in these conditions, which \nleads me to the point of this complaint.  Your ticketing staff in IAH was \nless than helpful in re-routing us on another airline \n(Continental/United/American had several flights that could have delivered us \nto Phoenix in time to catch our connection) so that \nwe could make our connection.  Instead, we were told that it was impossible \nto find a flight that could get us to Phoenix in time for this \nconnection.  Subsequently, I called other airlines and confirmed space on \nflights that would have  delivered us to Phoenix on time.  \nIt now appears that America West was more willing to sacrifice a day of my \nvacation rather than pay up to put me on another flight.  \nI am extremely disillusioned with the service we received; Because we missed \nour connection we were forced to spend a combined \n6 hrs in the Phoenix and Houston airports and eventually fly into Montrose, \nCO where we had to drive 100 miles to Telluride.  Instead \nof arriving in Telluride, Co at 12pm on 12/9 we arrived at 10pm, a full ten \nhours later.  This delay caused the waste of one full day of \nvacation.  Myself and members of my group will never fly your airline again \nbecause of this experience.\n\nFor your research I provide the following data:\nPersons in Party - Eric Bass, Larry Bass, Kathy Bass, Jason Bass, Shanna \nHusser, and Donnita Franklin.\n\nFinal Itinerary (after all changes) -\nFlt. 2765 Dec. 09 Iah-Phx 8:51AM\nFlt. 6244 Dec. 09 Phx-Mtj 3:34PM\n\nFlt. 6241 Dec. 14 Mtj-Phx 9:00AM\nFlt. 2273 Dec. 14 Phx-Iah  1:15PM\n\nSincerely,\n\nEric Bass",
