    {
        "body": "DJ REPEAT:Ercot Sees 56,373 MW Summer Peak,2% Below '00 Peak\n\nDJ Ercot: New Units Will Boost Supply to 65,064 MW\n\nDJ Ercot: 21% Summer Reserve If Normal Weather\n\nDJ Ercot Summer -2: New 345-Kv Line To Relieve Congestion\n\n\nBy Eileen O'Grady\nOf DOW JONES NEWSWIRES\n\nHOUSTON (Dow Jones)--After several tight summers, new generation and a new\ntransmission line in Texas should push the power region's summer reserve\nabove\n20%, according to a projections from the Electric Reliability Council of\nTexas.\n\nAccording to a summer assessment study compiled by Ercot, utilities and\npower\nsuppliers forecast a peak load demand of 56,373 megawatts this summer, 2% MW\nunder the record-shattering 2000 peak of 57,606 MW.\n\nThe lower peak forecast assumes a return to normal summer temperatures.\nLast\nsummer, Texas saw record heat amid a drought that lasted 84 days in parts of\nthe\nstate. That increased power demand to record levels.\n\nErcot's projected peak of 54,817 MW for summer 2000 wound up being 5%\nunder\nthe actual peak seen Aug. 31.\n\nSpot power prices jumped above $100 per megawatt-hour in four brief spikes\nlast summer, twice in May and again in July and August.\n\nWhile drought conditions have eased since last summer, the report warns\nthat\nErcot's peak could jump to 58,550 MW if forecasts provided by investor-owned\nutilities haven't included a possible shift in demand from customers\nparticipating in a retail pilot project that begins June 1.\n\nEven so, more than 3,350 MW of new generation is expected to be online\ncompared with last summer, pushing Ercot's net capacity resources to 65,064\nMW,\naccording to the report.\n\nThe Ercot assessment says the new generation should keep the region's\nreserve\nmargin above 20% in August when demand is expected to peak.\n\nThe Ercot report, however, includes 1,730 MW of \"border\" generation that\ncan\nbe sold into Ercot or into the Southwest Power Pool.\n\nA separate report from the Texas Public Utility Commission staff pointed\nout\nseveral additional merchant generating plants slated to come online this\nsummer\nin Ercot.\n\nThe PUC staff report paints a more bullish forecast for demand. The PUC\nsaid\ncoincident peak demand for power in Ercot grew at a compound rate of 4.3%\nfrom\n1995 to 2000.\n\nTotal annual energy consumption in Ercot grew by nearly 7.5% from 1999 to\n2000, according to the PUC.\n\nThe 21% reserve margin in August is twice the amount seen last summer. It\nincludes 2,870 MW of interruptible demand, slightly below last summer's\n3,000 MW\nof available load that could be curtailed.\n\nErcot transmission constraints are expected to be reduced dramatically\nthis\nsummer as an additional 345-kilovolt line running from Limestone power\nstation\nto the Watermill switchyard is expected to be in service this month,\nalleviating\nthe south-to-north congestion seen in the last two summers.\n\nAdditional lines are in the planning stages to relieve the west-to-east\nflow\nfrom Morgan Creek.\n\nOn June 1, Ercot will become a single control area as the region moves\ntoward\nfull retail competition beginning Jan. 1.\n\nThe current interregional transfer limit is 785 MW across the state's two\ndirect-current ties with SPP although there is expected to be some\nlimitation\nthis summer due to a breaker problem near the east DC tie.\n\nBecause Ercot lacks synchronous interconnection with the rest of the U.S.\npower grid, the region has limited ability to import electricity in times of\nhigh demand.\n\nErcot is a group of interconnected utilities that serves about 85% of the\npower load in the state.\n-By Eileen O'Grady; Dow Jones Newswires, 713-547-9213;\neileen.ogrady@dowjones.com <mailto:eileen.ogrady@dowjones.com>\n\n\n(END) Dow Jones Newswires 01-05-01\n\n1546GMT\n\n(AP-DJ-05-01-01 1546GMT)\n:SUBJECT: EUTL DI4 TX\nCopyright (c) 2001 Dow Jones and Company, Inc.\nReceived by NewsEDGE/LAN: 5/1/01 11:40 AM",
        "headers": {

What is the \nlevel of interest?\n\nJim\n\n\n----- Forwarded by James D Steffes/NA/Enron on 03/01/2001 09:05 PM -----\n\n\tMark Fillinger@ECT\n\t02/28/2001 02:18 PM\n\t\t\n\t\t To: Alan Comnes/PDX/ECT@ECT\n\t\t cc: Christopher F Calger/PDX/ECT@ECT, David Parquet/SF/ECT@ECT, Hap \nBoyd/EWC/Enron@Enron, James D Steffes/NA/Enron@Enron, Jeff \nDasovich/NA/Enron@Enron, Michael Etringer/HOU/ECT@ECT, Paul \nKaufman/PDX/ECT@ECT, Richard Shapiro/NA/Enron@Enron, Sandra \nMcCubbin/NA/Enron@Enron\n\t\t Subject: Re: QF Meeting Today--Highlights\n\nFor the last two days I participated in the negotiations between several QFs \nand the utilities regarding implementation of SBX 47. The goal of the meeting \nwas to present a substantially complete \"Agreement of Long-Term Gas Purchase \nArrangement\"  to Battin this Thursday. Through this document they intend to \ndescribe what the parties have agreed to and the changes required in the bill \nto conform to the parties agreement. \n\nAttendees included PG&E and SDG&E (SCE is clearly opposed to the bill), \nCalpine, El Paso, Sithe and the CCC represented by White and Case. It appears \nthat SDG&E's support for the bill is weakening with their mantra being \"if \nthis doesn't guarantee a price reduction over the five years we won't support \nthe bill.\" We explained that the goal is not so much overall price reduction \nas price stabilization, with current period price reduction. PG&E clearly \ngets it. \n\nI was successful in introducing and inserting the financial hedging option \ninto the Gas Agreement. Both PG&E and SDG&E are very supportive of such an \noption as they are currently prohibited from entering into such arrangements. \nIt is less clear if the large QFs are supportive. Their primary goal is to \nfind a safe harbor from the Wood decision for the next five years. I also \nbelieve the proposed gas procurement structure provides some option value to \nthe larger QFs. \n\nAlthough it looks like our language will be in the Gas Agreement, I think we \nneed to get some language in the bill itself. I am working with Sandi and \nMike Day to make that happen. We may also want to add the concept of economic \ndispatch to the bill. Mike, do you have any suggested language that I could \nforward to Sandi and Mike Day? Finally, I suggest we try and set up \nindividual meetings with the utilities (including SCE) to discuss our ideas \nfurther. I'm not sure what other conversations are occurring with the \nutilities, but I would be happy to set up the meetings with the appropriate \npeople.\n\nThanks,\n\nMark\n\n\n\n\n\tAlan Comnes\n\t02/27/2001 08:32 PM\n\t\t \n\t\t To: David Parquet/SF/ECT@ECT, Michael Etringer/HOU/ECT@ECT, Christopher F \nCalger/PDX/ECT@ECT, Mark Fillinger/SF/ECT@ECT, Sandra \nMcCubbin/NA/Enron@Enron, Hap Boyd/EWC/Enron@Enron, James D \nSteffes/NA/Enron@Enron, Richard Shapiro/NA/Enron@Enron, Jeff \nDasovich/NA/Enron@Enron, Paul Kaufman/PDX/ECT@ECT\n\t\t cc: \n\t\t Subject: QF Meeting Today--Highlights\n\nDespite the fact the bill, by itself, does not guarantee payment for overdue \nreceivables, the QFs on today's call decided to go forward and push for SBX \n47 irrespective of the progress on SBX 33.  A press conference is planned for \nFriday by IEP.  Bowen, who heads up the first committee that this bill will \ngo through will have hearings on this bill on Tuesday at the earliest.\n\nJan S-J asked every QF to fax to IEP a description of all QF generation and \nthe zip code of each project so that they can begin lobbying specific \nlegislators.  A significant PR push is planned.\n\nSBX 47 is opposed by SCE.  PG&E's position appears more ambivalent.  One \nangle would be to try to get PG&E to support Enron's swap/SC language and \nmake inclusion of such language a condition of PG&E's support.\n\nGAC\n\n\n",

issues resolved in the report include when to \nrequire election by licensees of their post transition DTV channel; whether \nto require replication by DTV licensees of their NTSC Grade B service \ncontours; whether to require enhanced service to the principal community \nserved by DTV licensees\teffective 4/16/01\n\tFCC\tfinal rule concerns rules and policies for attributing cognizable \ninterests in applying the broadcast multiple ownership rules, the broadcast \ncable cross ownership rule, and the cable multipoint distribution service \ncross ownership rule\teffective 4/16/01\n\tFCC\tproposed rule regarding DTV reception capability; NGSO FSS can provide a variety of new services to the public, such \nas high speed internet access, plus other types of high speed data, video and \ntelephony services; document concludes that a new terrestrial fixed \nmultichannel video distribution and data service can share the 12.2-12.7 GHz \nband with satellite operations w/out causing harmful interference\teffective 3/19/01\n\tFCC\tproposed rule to establish rules governing the migration to a 6.25 kHz \ntechnology on the 700 MHz public safety band General Use channels\tcomments due \n3/19/01; Gorons sincerely believe that Vice President Gore is a true\nenvironmentalist, when he has an environmental disaster on his own farm:\na polluting zinc mine, from which he received $500,000 of income last\nyear.\n\n   2. Gorons likewise believe that the VP is antismoking and anti-tobacco\nwhen  he has operated a tobacco farm for decades and accepted government\nsubsidies.\n\n   3. Gorons truly believe that Gore is a Vietnam war hero, when in fact\nhe was  placed by family influence in a \"cushy\"  correspondent's job and\nthe only  action he saw was that of his Brownie camera! (and his bong)\n\n   4. Gorons actually believe that Mr. Gore is justified in illegally\nraising political funds from the Office of the VP, simply because the\nVanderbilt Law  educated VP claims he was ignorant of the illegality.\n\n   5. Gorons further believe that it was OK for Al to accept large sums\nof political money from China through Buddhist monks who had taken vows\nof poverty, since he again claimed ignorance.\n\n   6. Gorons also believe that the man who claimed to \"invent the\nInternet\" would be so computationally ignorant that he could lose weeks\nof potentially  incriminating e-mail!\n\n   7. Gorons, incredibly, believe Gore's claim that he and Tipper were\nthe models for the book and movie, \"Love Story\" even though the book's\nauthor,  Erich Segal, says not.\n\n   8. Gorons, amazingly, believe that Gore will be the consumer's\nchampion against high gasoline prices although Gore holds a million\ndollars in Occidental Petroleum stock.\n\n   9. Gorons applaud Mr. Lieberman's open rejection of President\nClinton's immorality, but believe it was fine for Mr. Gore to remain\nsilent on the subject, while simultaneously declaring Mr. Clinton \"one of\nthe greatest Presidents of our history.\"\n\n   10. Gorons believe that Al Gore is an effective leader, when they\nwon't bother to look at his record as a Tennessee Senator, a record so\nineffective  that it has led to the election of Republicans as BOTH of\nTennessee's  Senators!\n\n   11.  Gorons hold the belief that Gore is a compassionate man who will\nbe the working man's friend, in spite of the eviction notice he served\nto the poor family who complained about the conditions of the run down\nslum  house that he was renting to them.\n\n   CAUTIONARY NOTE: Medical researchers acknowledge that Gorons are\ngenerally harmless, except when allowed into a voting booth. There,\nunfortunately, overcome by their gullibility syndrome, they are apt to\nactually vote for Gore! They should be carefully protected from their\nailment, since it may be  harmful to their well-being, yours, mine and\nthat of the USA.\n\n   Therefore, PLEASE, heed the Surgeon General's warning, reach out to\naid the Gorons in overcoming the syndrome, and,  PLEASE, pass this on to\nyour normal  friends, who might also know Gorons who need immediate\ntreatment.\n\n\n\n\n",

It looks like in CA ALL projects need to have CEQA \nreview regardless if they have been previously permitted or not.\n\nCOMPETITIVE LOCAL ENTRY\nCALIFORNIA\nALJ mulls penalty for Pacific Pipeline\n\nAdministrative Law Judge Sarah Thomas has decided to examine whether the\nPublic Utility Commission should penalize Pacific Pipeline Systems (PPS)\nfor constructing fiber optic facilities without first receiving PUC\napproval or undergoing an environmental review.  PPS has asked the PUC\nfor third-party access to fiber optic cable located in PPS's crude oil\npipelines.\n\nDuring a proceeding on PPS's request, the ALJ learned that the company\nalso intended to construct facilities to accommodate the third-party\naccess and lease them to Qwest Communications Corp.  PPS completed the\nconstruction after filing the application.\n\nThomas issued a draft decision granting the application and establishing\na second phase to consider whether PPS should be fined or sanctioned.\n(12/1/00 a.m.)  The commission withdrew the draft decision in order to\nconduct and complete the penalty phase before issuing a decision on the\napplication.\n\nDuring the penalty phase, the commission will examine (1) why PPS\nconstructed fiber optic facilities before obtaining PUC authorization or\nan environmental review and (2) whether the company violated the\nCalifornia Environmental Quality Act, commission rules, the public\nutilities code, or any other legal requirements.  If the PUC determines\nthat PPS violated the law or commission rules, the commission will\ndecide whether and how the company should be penalized.\n\nThomas said she will hold a March 28 prehearing conference if PPS\nrequests one.  If the company decides against the hearing, it must file\na brief and its evidence by March 28.  (Application no. 99-11-027,\nApplication of Pacific Pipeline Systems LLC for Authorization Pursuant\nto Public Utilities Code Section 851 et seq. To Permit the Use of\nCertain Fiber Optic Telecommunications Facilities)",

        "body": "In This Email:\nDon't Miss the Super Sale \nStag's Leap Wine Cellars on wine.com \nGreat Wines \nWine Team Picks: Laina Brown on Wines Worth Schlepping In \nThe Incredible Expanding Tasting: The View from ZAP \nWatch wine.com TV \n\n\nDon't Miss the Super Sale\n\nWe're featuring tons of wines at up to 40 percent off -- and we're \nadding new ones all the time. This is a great opportunity to stock \nyour cellar, fill your closet, throw a huge party, or start your \nChristmas shopping WAY early. \n\n\nStag's Leap Wine Cellars on wine.com\n\nFew California wineries enjoy the sort of status associated with \nStag's Leap Wine Cellars. When its Cabernet Sauvignon won first place \nat a famous Paris tasting over several top French Bordeaux in 1976, \nit signaled to the rest of the wine world that Napa Valley had not \nonly arrived, but had taken a place at the head of the table. \n\nSince that time, Stag's Leap's uncompromising and meticulous \nstandards have bolstered its position among wine's most respected \nnames. In addition to its prized Cabernets -- the seductive and \nvoluptuous Fay, the classically structured SLV, and the legendary \nCask 23, made only in the very best vintages -- the company now offers \na wide range of wines including a highly regarded reserve Chardonnay, \nMerlot, Sauvignon Blanc, and an assortment of accessible bottlings \nunder the Hawk Crest label. \n\nBearing all that in mind, wine.com is honored and privileged to \nannounce that the wines of Stag's Leap Wine Cellars are now available \nthrough our site. Click here to survey the selections, but a word to \nthe wise: We're talking about Napa royalty, so don't tarry. \n\nTo learn more about each item listed below, simply click on its name.\n_____________________________________________________________________ \n\nGreat Wines\n\n1997 Dominique Lafon Macon-Villages Petit Chapeau, Burgundy, \nFrance, $9.99\nA new wine at a great price from Lafon, a legend in Burgundy. \n\n1997 deLorimier Merlot, Alexander Valley, California, $15.99\nGet immediate gratification with this seductive Merlot. \n\nVirtual Vineyards Duet, $25.00\nDouble your pleasure with two bottles of Virtual Vineyards wines. \n\n1999 d'Arenberg Chardonnay The Olive Grove, McLaren Vale, South \nAustralia, Australia, $9.99\nEmphasis on purity of the fruit and minimal winemaking intervention. \n\nClub California\nThe spirit of California wine country delivered to your door monthly. \n\n1998 Punters Corner Chardonnay, Coonawarra, Australia, $19.95\nCoonawarra Chard that's crisp, chewy, and chock-full of the tropics. \n\n_____________________________________________________________________ \n\nWine Team Picks: Laina Brown on Wines Worth Schlepping In\n\nSome people are more comfortable than others plopping down their own \nbottle of wine on a restaurant table, but a certain amount of \"wine \nsnob\" labeling always bolsters the rationale. Still, if the only \nbottle you can imagine bringing is a 1947 Chateau Margaux, might I \nsuggest a few gems with attributes worthy of schlepping in: they're \nunlikely to be found on a restaurant wine list, but they're \nguaranteed to enhance your dining experience. \n\n1999 Archery Summit Winery Vireton, Willamette Valley, Oregon, $26.00\n\n1998 Baileyana Pinot Noir, San Luis Obispo County, California, $22.00\n\n1999 Pfeffingen Gewurztraminer Spatlese Ungsteiner Honigsackel, \nPfalz, Germany, $22.00\n\n1996 Val Ribeno Crianza, Ribera del Duero, Spain, $29.95\n\n1997 Wightman Winery Cabernet Sauvignon, Napa Valley, California, $49.95\n\n_____________________________________________________________________ \n\nThe Incredible Expanding Tasting: The View from ZAP \n\nA recurring pattern characterizes the annual ZAP (Zinfandel Advocates \nand Producers) tasting in San Francisco. Every year the \"people's \ngrape\" (aka \"mystery grape\" and \"California grape\") becomes more \npopular, and the tasting boasts more producers and consumers than \never before. The number of wines being poured, and the number of \npeople waving glasses, seems to reach critical mass, swelling with \nsuch huge and boisterous crowds that it can't possibly get \nany bigger. \n\nThe following year it increases by 50 percent. \n\nThis was what happened again on the Saturday before the Super Bowl, \nthe customary date of the tasting. A year ago, 6,000 tasters had \nflooded the Festival Pavilion at Fort Mason Center; this January \n(ZAP's 10th anniversary), the number was 9,200. For the first time \never, the event required two different buildings, where a total of \n500 wines were poured by 255 wineries. \n\nWhere will it all end? Well, it finished off the 1990s by showcasing \nwhat many were calling the best Zinfandel wines of the decade -- a \n\"spectacular\" vintage in the words of Ravenswood's Joel Peterson, who \nwent on to call it \"the best-balanced, most complex vintage we've \nhad. The wines have some of the fruit complexity of '91 and some of \nthe strength and power of '95; they're aren't over-the-top killers in \nterms of alcohol, but they have stuffing underneath.\" \n\nMichael Dashe of Dashe Cellars agreed that '99 constitutes \"manna \nfrom heaven. The wines are lush, concentrated, and intense, but \nbalanced.\" Donn Reisen of Ridge Vineyards called them \"awesome -- \nfull of rich, ripe, beautiful fruit.\" Bill Easton, whose '98 Easton \nEstate was one of the best Zinfandels of that year, felt that the \n'99s have \"a better fruit-tannin relationship,\" while David Noyes of \nKunde Estate found them \"surprisingly ready to drink -- I mean, \nthey're big wines.\" \n\nOf course winemakers are going to say things like that -- but the \ntasting seemed to bear out their claims. In terms of quality, the \n1999 Zinfandel vintage surpasses even the vaunted 1997, delivering a \npanoply of balanced wines with full, approachable flavors that don't \ntaste particularly alcoholic despite their ripeness. To Reisen this \nis evidence that \"Zinfandel winemaking is improving along with the \nquality of the fruit. Obviously, people are respecting the grape.\" \n\nPerhaps too much so abroad, if you paid attention to some of the \nbackstage scuttlebutt. Other than the beauty of '99, the talk among \ninsiders at the tasting concerned a recent decision by the European \nUnion (and expected agreement by the U.S. Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, \nand Firearms) to allow Italian winemakers to label wines made from \nthe Primitivo grape as Zinfandel. ZAP has supported research into \nZinfandel's European origins, resulting (among other things) in the \nscientific conclusion that it and the Primitivo di Puglia are the \nsame grape. \"The Italians called it Primitivo for a hundred years,\" \nnoted Reisen. \"But now that Zinfandel is so popular, they're trying \nto steal the brand.\" \n\n\"All [the research] really means is that Primitivo is a clone of \nZinfandel,\" said Ridge's president and winemaker, Paul Draper. \"The \nItalian move is purely commercial. It's like what happened in the old \ndays with Champagne and Burgundy and Chablis -- Americans tried to \ncapitalize on names that the French had taken years to build. ZAP was \ncreated to promote Zinfandel, not Primitivo -- but when you get down \nto it, who really cares? If, with its climate and soil, Puglia thinks \nit can compete with the best Zinfandel in the world, more power \nto them.\" \n\nLeon Sobon of Sobon Estates is going the opposite way. In Amador \nCounty in the Sierra Nevada foothills, he's making \"Primitivo\" from a \nclone imported from Italy. Sobon reported that Primitivo is easier to \ngrow than Zinfandel, resulting in \"more of a claret wine with less \nberry character.\" If you want to find out for yourself, try the Sobon \nEstates Primitivo. \n\nIn any case, ZAP is going on the offensive -- not with legal action \nagainst the Italians, but with \"EuroZAP,\" its first international \ntour. As you read this, a series of dinners, tastings, workshops, and \nseminars featuring Zinfandel wines and winemakers is now taking place \nin England, Germany, and other European countries. The aim, explained \nZAP Executive Director Rebecca Robinson, is \"to educate the world \nthat Zinfandel is grown in California and that it's America's \nHeritage Wine.\" \n\nTo check out wine.com's entire Zinfandel selection, click here. \n\n_____________________________________________________________________ \n\nWatch wine.com TV\n\nJoin us on the next \"Wine for Everyone\" show on Wednesday, March 7, \nfrom 10 p.m. to midnight EST. Hosts Joleen Benoit and (wine.com \nfounder) Peter Granoff will present a mix of wines and other features \n\"Celebrating Spring.\" The program will also feature a guest \nappearance by Andrea Immer, author of \"Great Wine Made Simple.\" \n\nTune in on the ValueVision Television Network on DirecTV channel 370, \nDish Network channel 228, or call your local cable operator for the \nchannel in your area. \n\n_____________________________________________________________________ \n\n\n\nTO UNSUBSCRIBE FROM THIS NEWSLETTER, go to: \nhttp://wine1.m0.net/m/u/vin/vv.asp?e=jdasovic%40enron.com\n\n\n\n\n\n\n ",

        "body": "I recommend that we ask MRW to do a quick and dirty (nothing more than $10k) \nto quantify Steve's qualitative analysis.  Good to have before we fight this \nout at FERC.  If someone internal can do it, great.\n\nThoughts?\n\nJim\n\n----- Forwarded by James D Steffes/NA/Enron on 03/01/2001 06:13 PM -----\n\n\tSteve Walton@ECT\n\t02/28/2001 10:06 PM\n\t\t\n\t\t To: Jeff Dasovich/Na/Enron@ENRON\n\t\t cc: Alan Comnes/PDX/ECT@ECT, James D Steffes/NA/Enron@Enron, Jeff \nDasovich/NA/Enron@ENRON, Mary Hain/HOU/ECT@ECT, Paul Kaufman/PDX/ECT@ECT, \nRichard Shapiro/NA/Enron@Enron, Susan J Mara/NA/Enron@ENRON\n\t\t Subject: Re: Cost of Protectionism\n\nJeff,\n In order for California to \"shut its doors\" it must open its \ninterconnections with the rest of the west and become a Texas-like electrical \nisland.  This they cannot do.  California has a substantial investment in \nunits located in Nevada, Arizona, New Mexico and Utah.  The lights would go \nout in California if they opened the ties.  In the 1970's there was a hue and \ncry over loop flow, with California claiming that it was being injured by \nothers, particularly by the interior systems trading practices, however they \nnever considered opening the ties, because the benefits of interconnection \nwere so large that the \"cost\" of loop flow was far exceeded by the value of \nregional trade, i.e., they are economically interdependent.\n\n If such a foolish thing were done and California full \"closed its doors\" by \nopening its ties, cost would go up in the Northwest, in California and all \nthe rest of the Western System.  There are \"gains for trade\" which accrue to \nall parties from interconnection.  The trade is more complicated than just \nsummer/winter peaks (seasonal load diversity) there is also seasonal resource \ndiversity (Spring run off effects) and finally there opportunity to \ncapitalize on storage vs base load thermal operations.  I will address the \nlast point first to illustrate the complexity of the trading patterns.\n\n The interior west (Montana, Wyoming, Utah, Arizona and New Mexico) has large \namount of base load coal plants.  As load drops off in those areas, the \nenergy flows to the coast to back off peaking plants and to back off hydro.  \nThe reduction of hydro production allows night time reservoir refill which \ncan be used to meet peak load in the Northwest and California.  This can be \nseen in the attached file, which contains a set of plots for hourly flow on \nthe Pacific DC Intertie Jun97, Dec 97, Jun 98, Dec 98, Jun 99, Dec 99, \nJun00.  In these plots the clear day/night exchange of energy can be seen, \nespecially in the Jun00 plot when sales are being made to California in the \nday and to the Northwest at night.  This day to night storage exchange \nbenefits lowers costs for everyone.\n\n On top of this daily/weekly cycle, there is the seasonal shift in load \ndiversity you noted.  For the Northwest, its peak load occurs when energy \nproduction is the lowest -- during the winter.  As a stand alone system, the \nPacific Northwest (i.e., the Columbia Drainage area) is energy constrained.  \nThe hydro in that area does not produce enough energy to meet annual needs.  \nThere is plenty of generating capacity to meet any peak, but not enough to \ntotal water flow.  Energy imports from Wyoming and Montana (e.g. Colstrip and \nBridger) are required to allow the Pacific Northwest to meet its annual \nenergy requirement.  With these energy inputs from the coal fields, the \nseasonal water budget can be arranged to get the most value out of the hydro \nsystem, although fish, navigation, irrigation, etc. impose an increasing \nnumber of constraints.  Energy imports from in the winter from the South help \nto meet this energy balance during the winter so water can be reserved until \nthe snow pack is better know in early Spring.  Some of the sales to the \nNorthwest from California during the winter are a result of displacement from \nDesert Southwest energy moving through California and then up the Interties \nto the Northwest.  \n\n Finally, the Spring run off/fish flush when production on the river is at a \nmaximum and load in the Northwest is down.  The sale of these surpluses paid \nfor the Pacific Intertie lines and remain important to the entire system.  \nMuch system maintenance of base load units has been historically been planned \nto take advantage of this factor.  Again both California and the Northwest \nbenefit from this trade.  \n\n In all cases, the parties would be worse off if the ties were open and \neveryone was on their own.  The Northwest may be capacity long, but it is \ntypically energy short, even in flush hydro years.  The winter energy imports \nfrom the South hold Northwest costs down just as spring run off sales to the \nSouth lower energy costs in California.  California cannot craft a solo \nsolution that ignores the rest of the West.  It is probably hard to decide \nwho would be worst off if California \"closed its doors\".  It is only clear \nthat total cost would rise in both California and the rest of the West from \nwhich it divorced itself.\n\n I hope this rambling response comes at the question you raise.\n\nSteve\n\n\n\n\n\tJeff Dasovich@ENRON\n\tSent by: Jeff Dasovich@ENRON\n\t02/28/2001 11:35 AM\n\t\t\n\t\t To: James D Steffes/NA/Enron@Enron\n\t\t cc: Alan Comnes/PDX/ECT@ECT, Mary Hain/HOU/ECT@ECT, Steve \nWalton/HOU/ECT@ECT, Susan J Mara/NA/Enron@ENRON, Richard \nShapiro/NA/Enron@Enron, Paul Kaufman/PDX/ECT@ECT\n\t\t Subject: Re: Cost of Protectionism\n\nTo Jim's last point.  I understand that the good 'ol utility system was often \noperated with little regard for basic economic principles, but there's \nsomething in this that seems very odd and difficult to assess, and it seems \nto always be tied to this notion that \"California is a net importer, even in \nthe winter.\"  I'm going to start with the economics and then let folks \ndescribe why it seemingly doesn't apply in Western electricity markets.\n\nJust about every theory of economics and trade would lead to one conclusion:  \nIf California closes it's doors the other Western states will pay higher \nprices for power and/or face increased threats to reliability.  I'm \nstruggling to try to determine why these basic principles aren't applicable \nto Western power markets.  I understand that the PNW is a very complex place \nand that the reasons could be embedded in the arcane structure that has \ndeveloped over the years.\n\nTo keep it simple (though not necessarily accurate), I've confined the \nanalysis to a world in which only the PNW and California exist.\n\nThe basic situation: The PNW peaks in the winter; California peaks in the \nsummer.\n\nLet's take two scenarios:\n\n1)  The West, less California, is so awash in electricity that even in its \npeak--the Winter--it still has power to send to California, i.e., it has so \noverbuilt it's system that it has persistent surpluses to sell to California.\n\nIrrespective, there have (to my limited knowledge) always been sales from CA \nto the PNW during the winter, when the PNW is peaking.\nThe only conclusion that one can make, assuming that the PNW is awash in \nelectricity, is that the PNW takes the power in California because it makes \neconomic sense to do so. That is, during the winter peaking months, it must \nbe cheaper on the margin for the PNW to buy from California rather than \nproduce itself.  Otherwise, it's difficult to understand why it would buy \nfrom California during this month, particularly if they're long.  As such, at \na minimum, the PNW's electric bill will necessarily increase if California \ncloses its doors.\n\n2) Neither the PNW , nor California, has indigenous capacity to meet peaking \nload.  Therefore, the PNW must buy California's power during its peaking \nsummer period, and California must buy power during it's summer peaking \nperiod.  In this case, not only will the PNW's bill go up if California \ncloses its doors, the lights are likely to go because they'll be short power.\n\nI realize that this is a simplistic model, and that there could be other \nlegitimate economic factors driving the flows out of California to the PNW \n(e.g., transmission costs).  And again, I also realize that economics may not \nhave traditionally been a driver in the industry.  But I thought it might be \nuseful to get a common framework in place as a starting point for the \nquestion that Jim asks.\n\nWith that, I'll pose the question (understanding the simplicity of the model \nset forth above):  Given that California sends power north--even if the PNW \nis long---how can California closing it doors not increase the PNW's cost of \npower?\n\nBest,\nJeff\n\n\n\n\tJames D Steffes\n\t02/28/2001 08:05 AM\n\t\t\n\t\t To: Alan Comnes/PDX/ECT@ECT\n\t\t cc: Jeff Dasovich/NA/Enron@Enron, Mary Hain/HOU/ECT@ECT, Steve \nWalton/HOU/ECT@ECT, Susan J Mara/NA/Enron@Enron\n\t\t Subject: Re: Cost of Protectionism\n\nIt seems to me that this information leads one to conclude that the value of \nan open transmission network is that California does not have to build 5,000 \nMW of power plant (4,500 MW max input + 10%) in state.  In other words, if \nCalifornia were to disconnect from the grid, someone would have to build \nadditional power plants in-state.\n\nThe cost to California consumers is therefore the annual carrying cost of 10 \n500 MW plants (made even more expensive after California expropriates the \ncurrent fleet of merchant generation).\n\nFrom the perspective of the remainder of the West, the question still remains \n- if California does go it alone, what is the economic impact?  Other than \nlegal arguments about Interstate Commerce, why should the Federal Government \nwant to continue to pursue open acess?  This is the hard question that we \nneed to answer.  \n\nJim\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\tAlan Comnes@ECT\n\t02/27/2001 09:40 PM\n\t\t \n\t\t To: James D Steffes/NA/Enron@Enron, Jeff Dasovich/NA/Enron@Enron\n\t\t cc: Susan J Mara/NA/Enron@ENRON, Steve Walton/HOU/ECT@ECT, Mary \nHain/HOU/ECT@ECT\n\t\t Subject: Cost of Protectionism\n\nJim, Jeff:\n\nJim asked me in a voice mail what would be the cost to California of moving \nfrom the current (evolving) system of open access to a \"protectionist\" \nenvironment where access to the grid would be determined by a political body \nresponding to populist pressures.\n\nHere are some things to consider.  We can talk more and I welcome Sue Mara or \nSteve Walton's input:\n\nCalifornia is a net importer so any restraint of trade would risk the state \nbeing able to meet its own demand.  See attached slides that show PNW-CA \ntrade.  Even in the winter, power on a net basis flows south.\n\nLimiting open access would primarily act to hold in-state generators hostage.\n this will kill incentives for new investment\n\nIf the ISO's proposal for market power mitigation are any guide of where a \nprotectionist ISO would go:\n in-state generators would be required to sell forward or lose their market \nbased rate certificates\n load serving entities would be required to contract forward for load and a \nreserve margin.  \n  This is costly: it will lead to centralized planning solutions to \nreliability rather than more efficient market     outcomes\n Artifical notions of \"just and reasonable\" rates (on top of unreasonable \nreserve requirements) would lead to severe   reliability problems.  (In other \nwords, if Steve Peace has his way, the imports into the state will drop \noff     signficanly)\n\nThere is no reason the state would be more effective at expanding the grid \n(e.g., Path 15) than the current system.  (Although, admittedly the current \nsystem has flaws.  The CAISO was set up with little thought to transmission \nexpansion planning.  Other RTOs are not repeating this mistake.).  \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n",
        "headers": {
            "Date": "Thu, 1 Mar 2001 10:15:00 -0800 (PST)",

        "body": "Jeff,\n In order for California to \"shut its doors\" it must open its \ninterconnections with the rest of the west and become a Texas-like electrical \nisland.  This they cannot do.  California has a substantial investment in \nunits located in Nevada, Arizona, New Mexico and Utah.  The lights would go \nout in California if they opened the ties.  In the 1970's there was a hue and \ncry over loop flow, with California claiming that it was being injured by \nothers, particularly by the interior systems trading practices, however they \nnever considered opening the ties, because the benefits of interconnection \nwere so large that the \"cost\" of loop flow was far exceeded by the value of \nregional trade, i.e., they are economically interdependent.\n\n If such a foolish thing were done and California full \"closed its doors\" by \nopening its ties, cost would go up in the Northwest, in California and all \nthe rest of the Western System.  There are \"gains for trade\" which accrue to \nall parties from interconnection.  The trade is more complicated than just \nsummer/winter peaks (seasonal load diversity) there is also seasonal resource \ndiversity (Spring run off effects) and finally there opportunity to \ncapitalize on storage vs base load thermal operations.  I will address the \nlast point first to illustrate the complexity of the trading patterns.\n\n The interior west (Montana, Wyoming, Utah, Arizona and New Mexico) has large \namount of base load coal plants.  As load drops off in those areas, the \nenergy flows to the coast to back off peaking plants and to back off hydro.  \nThe reduction of hydro production allows night time reservoir refill which \ncan be used to meet peak load in the Northwest and California.  This can be \nseen in the attached file, which contains a set of plots for hourly flow on \nthe Pacific DC Intertie Jun97, Dec 97, Jun 98, Dec 98, Jun 99, Dec 99, \nJun00.  In these plots the clear day/night exchange of energy can be seen, \nespecially in the Jun00 plot when sales are being made to California in the \nday and to the Northwest at night.  This day to night storage exchange \nbenefits lowers costs for everyone.\n\n On top of this daily/weekly cycle, there is the seasonal shift in load \ndiversity you noted.  For the Northwest, its peak load occurs when energy \nproduction is the lowest -- during the winter.  As a stand alone system, the \nPacific Northwest (i.e., the Columbia Drainage area) is energy constrained.  \nThe hydro in that area does not produce enough energy to meet annual needs.  \nThere is plenty of generating capacity to meet any peak, but not enough to \ntotal water flow.  Energy imports from Wyoming and Montana (e.g. Colstrip and \nBridger) are required to allow the Pacific Northwest to meet its annual \nenergy requirement.  With these energy inputs from the coal fields, the \nseasonal water budget can be arranged to get the most value out of the hydro \nsystem, although fish, navigation, irrigation, etc. impose an increasing \nnumber of constraints.  Energy imports from in the winter from the South help \nto meet this energy balance during the winter so water can be reserved until \nthe snow pack is better know in early Spring.  Some of the sales to the \nNorthwest from California during the winter are a result of displacement from \nDesert Southwest energy moving through California and then up the Interties \nto the Northwest.  \n\n Finally, the Spring run off/fish flush when production on the river is at a \nmaximum and load in the Northwest is down.  The sale of these surpluses paid \nfor the Pacific Intertie lines and remain important to the entire system.  \nMuch system maintenance of base load units has been historically been planned \nto take advantage of this factor.  Again both California and the Northwest \nbenefit from this trade.  \n\n In all cases, the parties would be worse off if the ties were open and \neveryone was on their own.  The Northwest may be capacity long, but it is \ntypically energy short, even in flush hydro years.  The winter energy imports \nfrom the South hold Northwest costs down just as spring run off sales to the \nSouth lower energy costs in California.  California cannot craft a solo \nsolution that ignores the rest of the West.  It is probably hard to decide \nwho would be worst off if California \"closed its doors\".  It is only clear \nthat total cost would rise in both California and the rest of the West from \nwhich it divorced itself.\n\n I hope this rambling response comes at the question you raise.\n\nSteve\n\n\n\n\n\tJeff Dasovich@ENRON\n\tSent by: Jeff Dasovich@ENRON\n\t02/28/2001 11:35 AM\n\t\t\n\t\t To: James D Steffes/NA/Enron@Enron\n\t\t cc: Alan Comnes/PDX/ECT@ECT, Mary Hain/HOU/ECT@ECT, Steve \nWalton/HOU/ECT@ECT, Susan J Mara/NA/Enron@ENRON, Richard \nShapiro/NA/Enron@Enron, Paul Kaufman/PDX/ECT@ECT\n\t\t Subject: Re: Cost of Protectionism\n\nTo Jim's last point.  I understand that the good 'ol utility system was often \noperated with little regard for basic economic principles, but there's \nsomething in this that seems very odd and difficult to assess, and it seems \nto always be tied to this notion that \"California is a net importer, even in \nthe winter.\"  I'm going to start with the economics and then let folks \ndescribe why it seemingly doesn't apply in Western electricity markets.\n\nJust about every theory of economics and trade would lead to one conclusion:  \nIf California closes it's doors the other Western states will pay higher \nprices for power and/or face increased threats to reliability.  I'm \nstruggling to try to determine why these basic principles aren't applicable \nto Western power markets.  I understand that the PNW is a very complex place \nand that the reasons could be embedded in the arcane structure that has \ndeveloped over the years.\n\nTo keep it simple (though not necessarily accurate), I've confined the \nanalysis to a world in which only the PNW and California exist.\n\nThe basic situation: The PNW peaks in the winter; California peaks in the \nsummer.\n\nLet's take two scenarios:\n\n1)  The West, less California, is so awash in electricity that even in its \npeak--the Winter--it still has power to send to California, i.e., it has so \noverbuilt it's system that it has persistent surpluses to sell to California.\n\nIrrespective, there have (to my limited knowledge) always been sales from CA \nto the PNW during the winter, when the PNW is peaking.\nThe only conclusion that one can make, assuming that the PNW is awash in \nelectricity, is that the PNW takes the power in California because it makes \neconomic sense to do so. That is, during the winter peaking months, it must \nbe cheaper on the margin for the PNW to buy from California rather than \nproduce itself.  Otherwise, it's difficult to understand why it would buy \nfrom California during this month, particularly if they're long.  As such, at \na minimum, the PNW's electric bill will necessarily increase if California \ncloses its doors.\n\n2) Neither the PNW , nor California, has indigenous capacity to meet peaking \nload.  Therefore, the PNW must buy California's power during its peaking \nsummer period, and California must buy power during it's summer peaking \nperiod.  In this case, not only will the PNW's bill go up if California \ncloses its doors, the lights are likely to go because they'll be short power.\n\nI realize that this is a simplistic model, and that there could be other \nlegitimate economic factors driving the flows out of California to the PNW \n(e.g., transmission costs).  And again, I also realize that economics may not \nhave traditionally been a driver in the industry.  But I thought it might be \nuseful to get a common framework in place as a starting point for the \nquestion that Jim asks.\n\nWith that, I'll pose the question (understanding the simplicity of the model \nset forth above):  Given that California sends power north--even if the PNW \nis long---how can California closing it doors not increase the PNW's cost of \npower?\n\nBest,\nJeff\n\n\n\n\tJames D Steffes\n\t02/28/2001 08:05 AM\n\t\t\n\t\t To: Alan Comnes/PDX/ECT@ECT\n\t\t cc: Jeff Dasovich/NA/Enron@Enron, Mary Hain/HOU/ECT@ECT, Steve \nWalton/HOU/ECT@ECT, Susan J Mara/NA/Enron@Enron\n\t\t Subject: Re: Cost of Protectionism\n\nIt seems to me that this information leads one to conclude that the value of \nan open transmission network is that California does not have to build 5,000 \nMW of power plant (4,500 MW max input + 10%) in state.  In other words, if \nCalifornia were to disconnect from the grid, someone would have to build \nadditional power plants in-state.\n\nThe cost to California consumers is therefore the annual carrying cost of 10 \n500 MW plants (made even more expensive after California expropriates the \ncurrent fleet of merchant generation).\n\nFrom the perspective of the remainder of the West, the question still remains \n- if California does go it alone, what is the economic impact?  Other than \nlegal arguments about Interstate Commerce, why should the Federal Government \nwant to continue to pursue open acess?  This is the hard question that we \nneed to answer.  \n\nJim\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\tAlan Comnes@ECT\n\t02/27/2001 09:40 PM\n\t\t \n\t\t To: James D Steffes/NA/Enron@Enron, Jeff Dasovich/NA/Enron@Enron\n\t\t cc: Susan J Mara/NA/Enron@ENRON, Steve Walton/HOU/ECT@ECT, Mary \nHain/HOU/ECT@ECT\n\t\t Subject: Cost of Protectionism\n\nJim, Jeff:\n\nJim asked me in a voice mail what would be the cost to California of moving \nfrom the current (evolving) system of open access to a \"protectionist\" \nenvironment where access to the grid would be determined by a political body \nresponding to populist pressures.\n\nHere are some things to consider.  We can talk more and I welcome Sue Mara or \nSteve Walton's input:\n\nCalifornia is a net importer so any restraint of trade would risk the state \nbeing able to meet its own demand.  See attached slides that show PNW-CA \ntrade.  Even in the winter, power on a net basis flows south.\n\nLimiting open access would primarily act to hold in-state generators hostage.\n this will kill incentives for new investment\n\nIf the ISO's proposal for market power mitigation are any guide of where a \nprotectionist ISO would go:\n in-state generators would be required to sell forward or lose their market \nbased rate certificates\n load serving entities would be required to contract forward for load and a \nreserve margin.  \n  This is costly: it will lead to centralized planning solutions to \nreliability rather than more efficient market     outcomes\n Artifical notions of \"just and reasonable\" rates (on top of unreasonable \nreserve requirements) would lead to severe   reliability problems.  (In other \nwords, if Steve Peace has his way, the imports into the state will drop \noff     signficanly)\n\nThere is no reason the state would be more effective at expanding the grid \n(e.g., Path 15) than the current system.  (Although, admittedly the current \nsystem has flaws.  The CAISO was set up with little thought to transmission \nexpansion planning.  Other RTOs are not repeating this mistake.).  \n\n\n\n\n\n\n",

        "body": "Mike, Clint-\n\nI've done some more research on water usage and have some revised consumption \nrates which are less than what I told you last week.\n\nUsing the rates that I have listed below, if you run 5 days/week (weekdays), \n16 hours/day (not 15 as I previously mentioned) say 6 am to 10 pm, at GE's \nworse case consumption rate (+20% margin) , the tank will just be empty \nFriday night (10 pm) at the end of the 16 hour run.  I then takes \napproximately 42 hours to refill the tank.  (filling is completed by late \nSunday afternoon)\n\nAt GE's \"expected\" consumption rate (no margin), the consumption rate is so \nmuch better that you could potentially run for 15 days straight, at 16 \nhours/day before you exhausted the tank.\n\nNext week when we run the performance test, we will know exactly what the \nactual consumtion rates will be.  In addition, I think (hope) that there \nmight be some additional capacity in the demin plant.  The 120 gpm number is \nthe guarantee from the vendor and at that rate the water quality is better \nthan what we need.  I'm going to see if I can get someone to increase the \nflowrate until we are just at the limits for water quality.  I'll let you \nknow what that number is. \n\nI do agree with you in that extra demin capacity is a no brainer.  Hopefully \nby the end of next week, I will know exactly how much extra we would need.\n\nBy the way, there is one additional piece of info that I was informed of \ntoday.  I been told that there is some language in the participation \nagreement that says our variable O&M costs increases after we exceed 1300 \nhours of operation.\n\nHope this helps.  If you have questions, give me a call.  I'm in Austin all \nweek.\n\nThanks,\nEric Booth\nx54683\n(713) 412-6873 (c)\n\nConsumption/Make-up Rates:\nDemin plant make-up rate: 120 gpm\nDemin Tank capacity:  300,000 gallons\n\nMaximum or worse case Consumption rate of the plant with all four units \nrunning full load:  236 gpm  (this has a +20% margin included by GE)\nTherefor, when the plant is running, net drawdown rate on the tank is \n(236-120) = 116 gpm\n\nExpected consumption rate for the plant with all four units running at full \nload:  197 gpm (this does not have any extra margin included)\nTherefor, when the plant is running, net drawdown rate on the tank is \n(197-120) = 77 gpm",

These change=\r\ns=20\r\nare intended to accomplish four key objectives:\r\n\r\nFirst, we need to realign all our wholesale businesses around the successfu=\r\nl=20\r\nbusiness model developed over the last decade in North America and Europe. =\r\n=20\r\nThis model relies on extensive physical and transactional networks built=20\r\naround a relatively small strategic asset position.\r\n\r\nSecond, we need to significantly streamline corporate reporting=20\r\nrelationships.  Particularly with Joe Sutton=01,s departure, the ability to=\r\n=20\r\ndirectly manage the day-to-day activities of 15 independent business units=\r\n=20\r\nhas become increasingly difficult.\r\n\r\nThird, we need to accomplish these changes without, in any way, compromisin=\r\ng=20\r\nthe ongoing profitability of all our businesses and without delaying or=20\r\nhindering our effort to monetize a significant portion of our lower-yieldin=\r\ng=20\r\nasset positions.\r\n\r\nAnd fourth, as always, we need to take advantage of the reorganization to=\r\n=20\r\nredeploy our talent into our highest value opportunities.\r\n\r\nENRON WHOLESALE SERVICES\r\n\r\nToday, we are forming Enron Wholesale Services (EWS) which will consolidate=\r\n=20\r\nour global wholesale businesses.  The closer alignment of our wholesale=20\r\nbusinesses will accomplish the following: (1) enhanced communication and=20\r\ncoordination across business units, (2) more rapid deployment of people to=\r\n=20\r\nhigher valued opportunities, (3) more effective prioritization of=20\r\nopportunities across the wholesale business, and (4) more rapid extension o=\r\nf=20\r\nEnron=01,s wholesale business model and capabilities into new industries an=\r\nd=20\r\nmarkets.\r\n\r\nEnron Wholesale Services will include our current North American, European=\r\n=20\r\n(including Japan and Australia), Global Markets, and Industrial Markets=20\r\noperations, and will be expanded to include Enron=01,s Net Works business u=\r\nnit=20\r\nas well as a new unit =01) Enron Global Assets.  In addition, Enron=01,s me=\r\nrchant=20\r\nbusinesses outside of North America and Europe will be integrated into this=\r\n=20\r\nnew structure as described below.\r\n\r\nMark Frevert, currently Chairman of each of our wholesale units, will assum=\r\ne=20\r\nthe role of Chairman and CEO of Enron Wholesale Services.  Greg Whalley,=20\r\ncurrently Chairman and CEO of Enron Net Works, will join Mark in the Office=\r\n=20\r\nof the Chairman as President and Chief Operating Officer.\r\n\r\nProviding further impetus for these organizational changes, several of our=\r\n=20\r\ninternational business unit leaders have elected to move into new leadershi=\r\np=20\r\npositions:\r\n\r\nRebecca McDonald, currently CEO of Enron APACHI, will join EWS as President=\r\n=20\r\nand CEO of Enron Global Assets. Enron Global Assets will have responsibilit=\r\ny=20\r\nfor managing all of Enron=01,s existing energy asset portfolio outside of N=\r\north=20\r\nAmerica and Europe.  Joining Rebecca in the Office of the Chairman as COO=\r\n=20\r\nwill be Jim Hughes, currently COO of Enron APACHI.  Rebecca and Jim will=20\r\nreport to the EWS Office of the Chairman.\r\n\r\nSanjay Bhatnagar, currently CEO of Enron India, has joined EBS as CEO for t=\r\nhe=20\r\nMiddle East and Asia region.  Sanjay will be responsible for building our=\r\n=20\r\nbroadband business in this region and the current EBS team in this region=\r\n=20\r\nwill report to Sanjay.  In this role, Sanjay will report to the EBS office =\r\nof=20\r\nthe Chairman.  In addition, Sanjay will continue to remain responsible for=\r\n=20\r\nEnron=01,s wholesale energy business in India and will transition this busi=\r\nness=20\r\ninto Enron Global Assets in the near future.\r\n=20\r\nDiomedes Christodoulou, currently Co-CEO of Enron South America, has joined=\r\n=20\r\nEBS as Chief Commercial Officer.  Diomedes will be located in London and wi=\r\nll=20\r\nfocus his origination activities on global opportunities, with near term=20\r\nattention to the wholesale and enterprise sectors.  Diomedes will report to=\r\n=20\r\nthe EBS Office of the Chairman.\r\n\r\nJim Bannantine, currently Co-CEO of Enron South America, will be joining EE=\r\nS=20\r\nto lead EES=01, commercial efforts outside North America and Europe.  In or=\r\nder=20\r\nto ensure a smooth transition for our South American businesses and to=20\r\nfacilitate our asset sales activities, Jim will remain in South America for=\r\n=20\r\nat least the next several months and continue to serve as CEO of Enron Sout=\r\nh=20\r\nAmerica.  Throughout the transition, Jim will report to Cliff Baxter and to=\r\n=20\r\nthe Office of the Chairman of Enron Wholesale Services.  Following the=20\r\ntransition, Jim will join EES.\r\n\r\nIn addition to these changes in our international asset operations=20\r\nactivities, we are making the following changes in our merchant wholesale=\r\n=20\r\nbusinesses and the commercial support functions:\r\n\r\nEnron Net Works\r\nLouise Kitchen will assume Greg=01,s previous responsibilities as President=\r\n and=20\r\nCEO of Enron Net Works, reporting into Mark and Greg. =20\r\n\r\nEnron Americas\r\nConcurrent with the transfer to Enron Global Assets of responsibility for=\r\n=20\r\noperating Enron=01,s South and Central America asset base, all trading,=20\r\nmarketing, and new asset development activities in these regions will repor=\r\nt=20\r\ninto a new entity, Enron Americas.  Enron Americas will have responsibility=\r\n=20\r\nfor all wholesale merchant businesses across North, Central and South=20\r\nAmerica.  Dave Delainey, President and CEO, and John Lavorato, Chief=20\r\nOperating Officer will comprise the Office of the Chairman for Enron=20\r\nAmericas.\r\n\r\nEnron Europe\r\nThe Enron Europe organization, which includes Enron=01,s businesses in Aust=\r\nralia=20\r\nand Japan, and Enron Metals, remains unchanged under the leadership of John=\r\n=20\r\nSherriff, President and CEO, and Michael Brown, Chief Operating Officer.\r\n\r\nEnron Global Markets\r\nEnron Global Markets, under the leadership of Mike McConnell, President and=\r\n=20\r\nCEO, and Jeff Shankman, Chief Operating Officer, will continue to have=20\r\nresponsibility for Enron=01,s Middle East and LNG operations.  With the=20\r\nexception of Ecoelectrica in Puerto Rico, all operating power plants and=20\r\nassociated personnel in the Caribbean and Central America will transfer to=\r\n=20\r\nEnron Global Assets.  Enron Global Markets will also continue to manage the=\r\n=20\r\ncommodity businesses in crude and products, coal, weather, insurance,=20\r\nequities, interest rates, foreign exchange, and agricultural products.\r\n\r\nEnron Industrial Markets\r\nEnron Industrial Markets=01, organization, under the leadership of Jeff McM=\r\nahon,=20\r\nPresident & CEO, and Ray Bowen, Chief Operating Officer, remains unchanged.\r\n\r\nCommercial Support for EWS\r\nThe commercial support functions for EWS will remain with, and be managed b=\r\ny,=20\r\nthe individual business units.  We are creating no incremental overhead in=\r\n=20\r\nthe creation of EWS, and in fact hope to reduce our operating costs by more=\r\n=20\r\nefficient utilization and sharing of resources across EWS.\r\n\r\nTo this end we have asked several people to take on an expanded role across=\r\n=20\r\nEWS in addition to their ongoing roles within their business units.  These=\r\n=20\r\nnewly defined roles are as follows:\r\n\r\nMid and Back Office Operations =01) Sally Beck will lead Mid and Back Offic=\r\ne=20\r\nOperations across EWS.  These services will become part of Enron Net Works,=\r\n=20\r\nwith Sally reporting to Louise Kitchen and Rick Causey, Executive Vice=20\r\nPresident and Chief Accounting Officer.  This alignment creates a coordinat=\r\ned=20\r\nservices organization with IT and e-commerce platforms to support the=20\r\nwholesale businesses and to maximize opportunities to commercialize these=\r\n=20\r\nservices.  Mid and Back Office services for all commercial activities will=\r\n=20\r\ncontinue to be organized with dedicated operations controllers responsible=\r\n=20\r\nfor specific commodities and/or geographic locations.\r\nLegal =01) Mark Haedicke will serve in the role of General Counsel for EWS.\r\nRegulatory and Government Affairs =01) This function will remain organized =\r\non a=20\r\nregional basis.  Rick Shapiro will support all EWS businesses operating in=\r\n=20\r\nthe Americas, and Mark Schroeder, who is based in London, will support all=\r\n=20\r\nEuropean and Eastern Hemisphere operations.  Rick and Mark will also contin=\r\nue=20\r\nto support all other Enron businesses operating in their respective regions=\r\n=20\r\nand will continue to report to Steve Kean, Executive Vice President and Chi=\r\nef=20\r\nof Staff.\r\nPublic Relations =01) This function is also organized primarily on a region=\r\nal=20\r\nbasis.  Eric Thode will have responsibility for North American activity,=20\r\nEnron Net Works, and Enron Industrial Markets. As this organization=\r\n=20\r\ncontinues to evolve we will keep you informed of any additional changes.\r\n\r\nENRON GLOBAL EXPLORATION AND PRODUCTION\r\nAND ENRON WIND\r\n\r\n As part of our company-wide initiative to examine our assets and investmen=\r\nts=20\r\naround the world, we are considering a variety of options with respect to=\r\n=20\r\nEGEP and EWC.  As a consequence, we are putting these businesses under Clif=\r\nf=20\r\nBaxter=01,s direction.  Jeff Sherrick, CEO of EGEP, and Jim Noles, CEO of E=\r\nnron=20\r\nWind, will report to Cliff.\r\n\r\nCORPORATE STAFF\r\n\r\n We are consolidating the corporate staff functions: Human Resources,=20\r\nGovernment Affairs, Public Relations/Communications and Administration.  In=\r\n=20\r\nthat regard, Cindy Olson, Executive Vice President of Human Resources and=\r\n=20\r\nCommunity Relations, will report to Steve Kean, Executive Vice President an=\r\nd=20\r\nChief of Staff.\r\n\r\nCOMMITTEE STRUCTURE\r\n\r\n In light of the increased leadership opportunities created by Enron=01,s=\r\n=20\r\ngrowth, the Executive Committee will be expanded to include more of our=20\r\nbusiness unit leaders.  The primary role of this committee will continue to=\r\n=20\r\nbe the communication of relevant information across Enron=01,s businesses a=\r\nnd=20\r\nthe coordination of activities across those businesses.  We will also be=20\r\ndrawing on this group to lead company-wide initiatives such as the=20\r\nperformance review process and evaluation and creation of new businesses. =\r\n=20\r\nThe Executive Committee membership is shown on the attached list.\r\n\r\n We are also forming a new committee =01) the Enron Corporate Policy Commit=\r\ntee. =20\r\nThis group will be responsible for overall corporate policy, personnel=20\r\nmanagement policy and corporate strategy.  The Enron Corporate Policy=20\r\nCommittee membership is also shown on the attached list.\r\n\r\n We are confident that these changes will align our talent and our capital =\r\nto=20\r\nour highest return opportunities.     {
        "body": " <<X16049.DOC>>\n\nHere are proposed amendments for the Ducheny siting bill, AB 970, which\nreflect the input of Sam When and Allan Thompson.\n\n\nIn addition, I have reviewed the SCE/PG&E rate stabilization proposed\nlegislation.  This legislation extends a rate cap type rate stabilization\nplan until March 31, 2003.  The language included a \"flexible\" rate cap so\nthat the commission can increase rates to reflect variations in the cost of\ngas and electricity, etc.   It has some language to ensure that the\n\"customers which benefit from stabilized rates do not avoid costs associated\nwith providing the stabilized rates\".   This would seemingly prevent cost\nshifting and retroactive ratemaking.    The main thrust is to allow the\nutility to recover all  non-CTC costs during this period.  It specifically\namends Section 368(a) to eliminate a provision which appears to require the\nutilities to absorb all costs (including CTC) not recovered by the end of\nthe transition period.\n\nMy main reaction is that this bill is not necessary.  The SCE and PG&E caps\nare still in place and will be in place through most if not all of 2001.\nThis bill is being offered now to increase its chances of passage in the\n\"crisis mode\" now prevalent.  It should be deferred until the commission has\nproceeded farther with its investigation.\n\nMike Day\n\n - X16049.DOC",

    {
        "body": "Jeanne - you shouldn't compromise Enron's prior statements on ending the rate \nfreeze.  The most important thing is that we not get a retroactive end of the \nrate freeze (retroactive to any time before the date of the order).  We may \nalso accomplish this through legislation.\n\nRegarding the book vs. market valuation, it is less important that we argue \nfor market or book than it is we should clarify for the commission how and \nwhy it should be consistent with the new legislation.  If new legislation \noccurs and means that utility generation will be priced at cost for 10 years, \nthen everyone needs to realize that is a fundamentally different construct.  \nDA Customers are not getting the value of these plants through the valuation \nprocess so they must have access to that value through the access to retained \ngeneration approach. If cost based rates are not legislated, market valuation \nshoud proceed.  What we don't want is for them to legislate cost-based rates \nand then forget about the value being stripped from DA.\n\nAlso, seems like it could be a good thing to point out that if they do \ndeclare an end to the rate freeze, if it is effective before new replacement \nlegislation is enacted, they've only created another quagmire.   I'll call to \ndiscuss.\n\n\n\n\tJMB <JBennett@GMSSR.com>\n\t02/26/2001 10:32 AM\n\t\t \n\t\t To: \"'Bob Frank (E-mail)'\" <robert.frank@enron.com>, \"'Harry Kingerski \n(E-mail)'\" <Harry.Kingerski@enron.com>, \"'Jeff Dasovich (E-mail)'\" \n<jdasovic@enron.com>, \"'Sue Mara (E-mail)'\" <smara@enron.com>, \"'Tamara \nJohnson (E-mail)'\" <tjohnso8@enron.com>, \"'sstoness@enron.com'\" \n<sstoness@enron.com>\n\t\t cc: \n\t\t Subject: Brief in Rate Stabilization Proceeding\n\nDespite the fact that the hearings will probably continue into Wednesday of\nthis week, the briefs in Phase I of the Rate Stabilization Proceeding are\nstill due this Friday the 2nd.  One of the issues before the  ALJ is the use\nof interim versus final market valuation to end the rate freeze.  I am very\nhesitant to say that the rate freeze cannot end on the basis of a Commission\napproved interim valuation as Enron has, in previous proceedings, taken the\nposition that it can.  Please let me know right away if you feel different\nabout this.  Along these same lines, the issue of the value of the assets is\nsomewhat at play (at least on an interim basis).  Do we want to take a\nposition that the assets need to be market valued (rather than book) thus\nincreasing the rate base for the purpose of cost of service regulation which\nthe assets are now under? Increased generation rate would mean an increased\nDA credit. However, it may also hurt our claim that we should get a piece of\nthe retained generation.  Again let me know as soon as possible about your\nposition. \n\nJeanne Bennett        \n\n",

        "body": "Attached is a copy of the Deal Approval Sheet (DASH) that is to be used as \npart of the transaction approval process within EGM and a copy of the \ntransaction approval requirements.\n\nAll transactions (capital expenditures or risk adjusted capital) in excess of \n$500,000 must have a completed DASH and sign off by the following groups:\no applicable EGM business unit management\no EGM Office of the Chairman\no Legal\no RAC\no EGM Operations\no Enron Capital Management\no appropriate level of Enron Corp. management (if required, see attached)  \n\nCapital expenditures include any acquisitions/divestitures of assets, \nofferings of debt, subordinated debt, equity or partnership capital or \nentering into a commodity or financial position that results in an exposure \noutside of Board approved limits.  Capital expenditure amounts embedded in a \ncommodity price to a counterparty should be analyzed separately for DASH \npurposes and authorized by the appropriate entity.\n\nPlease contact me at ext. 37647 or Bjorn Hagelmann (RAC) at ext. 57984 if y0u \nhave any questions or need assistance with the process.\n\n    \n",

We are continuing to work with EPMI to manage the risk associated \nwith selling any volume into the Cal ISO. Currently we are purchasing power \non a daily basis from the market to meet the highest common on and off peak \nhour.  This strategy leaves us long for all the other hours but reduces our \nexposure to ISO penalties for under scheduling . Our most promising options \nare to sell the excess shoulder power into the PX imbalance market or OTC \nhour ahead. We are concerned about any receivable from the ISO and would like \nto know what you think the probability is of non-payment. If we do receive \npayment over what time period can we expect to receive it.\n\nNFB ",

Surveys and \nfield studies at user and vendor companies and interaction with industry \norganizations and other research institutions will provide insight into, and \ncase studies on, such topics as aligning business and IT strategy, best \npractices, build vs. buy, and organization structures.? \n\nTo kick off the Enabling Ebusiness project, CITM held a major conference Dec. \n6, 2000 with experts from industry and academia who focussed on the \nopportunities presented by Ebusiness, strategies for achieving them and for \novercoming legacies (technologies, processes, people and organizations).? And I certainly think that=\r\n=20\r\nmaking an early tackle by  invading the \"halo\" and receiving a 5-yard penal=\r\nty=20\r\nis much better than  sitting back and possibly allowing a big return.\r\n=09\r\n=09But if we're going to  get the penalty, why not lay our ears back and po=\r\np the=20\r\nreceiver in the  mouth whether he's caught the ball or not? A big hit would=\r\n=20\r\nmake that  penalty a little easier to swallow, don't you think?=20\r\n=09?? Cody Anderson, Houston, Texas=20\r\n=09\r\n=09 BROWN:  No question about it. First, you want to try to avoid getting t=\r\nhe=20\r\npenalty. But if you are going to get the penalty, then get your money's wor=\r\nth=20\r\nand give that returner something to remember for next time.=20\r\n=09\r\n=09I hate this rule. Colorado coach Gary Barnett went so far as to say that=\r\n=20\r\nagainst a team with great returners, such as Kansas State, who has David=20\r\nAllen, it's better to violate the halo rule and tackle these guys, take the=\r\n=20\r\n5-yard penalty and keep them from breaking one 60 or 70 yards for a score.=\r\n=20\r\n=09?\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09 Q: It seems like I've been waiting forever for the offensive line to cl=\r\nick.=20\r\nDid something come together finally or have I not been paying attention? Rowell Rogers, Denton=20\r\n=09\r\n=09 BROWN:  I talked to Major one-on-one on Monday, and he said he didn't=\r\n=20\r\nrealize how much confidence he had lost this season until he got the infusi=\r\non=20\r\nof confidence by leading Texas on five straight scoring drives of the secon=\r\nd=20\r\nhalf against Oklahoma State. If the coaches are insistent about this=20\r\nrotation, it will be interesting to see if Applewhite can continue to=20\r\nmaintain or build on the confidence he seized in the OSU game. =20\r\n=09?\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09 Q: What is happening with special teams? I know they have had some rece=\r\nnt=20\r\nsuccess after missed tackles and have improved, but what I cannot understan=\r\nd=20\r\nis why the opposing team can get so close to Kris Stockton and UT, with=20\r\nsuperior recruiting and athletes, can not even get close. This has really=\r\n=20\r\nhurt us. How is our blocking so different? Why does this problem persist? =\r\n=20\r\n=09?? Chad Dieterichs=20\r\n=09\r\n=09 BROWN:  It sure appears to me that the players on the line are giving w=\r\nay=20\r\ntoo much ground after the snap. Almost every punt this season has been a=20\r\nmatter of, can Stockton get the punt off before the opposing team collapses=\r\n=20\r\nonto Stockton's pocket?=20\r\n=09\r\n=09Mack Brown gets very upset with questions about the punt team. He says t=\r\nhat=20\r\nthey use the same formation that every NFL team uses and that special teams=\r\n=20\r\nare prone to breakdowns because there aren't enough scholarships to recruit=\r\n=20\r\nspecial teams players. And he says young players have to be used because=20\r\nveterans get tired playing offense and defense.=20\r\n=09\r\n=09I asked Mack if he thought that members of the punt team were starting t=\r\no=20\r\nhave a mental block, now that two punts have been blocked this season. He=\r\n=20\r\nsaid he didn't know. He said the latest punt block against Oklahoma State w=\r\nas=20\r\nthe result of OSU players twisting and a UT player failing to pick up the=\r\n=20\r\nassignment. At least this time, the punt blocker didn't run untouched throu=\r\ngh=20\r\nthe middle of the line.=20\r\n=09?\r\n=09\r\n=09 Q: I think people get too caught up in what's happening right now to re=\r\nalize=20\r\nwhat this team will be in a year or two. All we've heard about is how=20\r\nwonderful Mack's recruiting has been and how loaded we are, yet how the=20\r\nO-line is less than impressive and how the QB situation is hurting us.=20\r\n=09\r\n=09Guess what? Most of these \"great\" players are only 18. Remember Ricky as=\r\n a=20\r\nfreshman? Didn't think so. Think about how solid we will be in two years wi=\r\nth=20\r\ncurrent players and the new recruits coming in. So if we lose another game =\r\nor=20\r\ntwo this season and end up in the Poulan Weed Eater Independence Bowl, no=\r\n=20\r\nbiggie.=20\r\n=09\r\n=09In a year or two, we'll be right in there. So here's my question. What w=\r\nill=20\r\nit take for Texas to be consistently rated up there with the great college=\r\n=20\r\nprograms? Right now, as a friend of mine would say, we have a good team and=\r\n=20\r\nwe're building a good program. It seems that Texas is heading in that=20\r\ndirection, but we have a little way yet to go. What does Texas need to be a=\r\n=20\r\ntrue Top 10 team? Is it personnel-based or is it about chemistry? =20\r\n=09?? Alex Kephart, Dallas=20\r\n=09\r\n=09 BROWN:  I think it has to do with chemistry and experience at this poin=\r\nt.=20\r\nThe talent is there. Mack Brown is recruiting winners. But each of the line=\r\ns=20\r\nhas to have experience, and there have to be some \"Braveheart\"-type leaders=\r\n=20\r\non the team.=20\r\n=09\r\n=09Right now, the offensive line is still growing, even though it has two=\r\n=20\r\nseniors. The defensive line has great senior tackles, but the ends are raw.=\r\n=20\r\nSo the defensive line probably won't be great again after this year for a=\r\n=20\r\ncouple years, if you believe that you need senior lines to win a national=\r\n=20\r\nchampionship.=20\r\n=09\r\n=09But I agree with you. Texas has all the makings of being a powerhouse in=\r\nstead=20\r\nof just a good team in the next two to three years. Everyone will put the=\r\n=20\r\nLonghorns back up in the Top 5 next year because of their schedule. But Tex=\r\nas=20\r\nwill be a veteran team with great depth in the next two to three years.=20\r\n=09\r\n=09Right now, Texas and its fans and even the media have been guilty (me=20\r\nincluded) of holding Texas to the same standard as Nebaraska and Florida=20\r\nState. But that's probably not fair just yet. The stud players Brown is=20\r\nrecruiting need time to settle into the system and get some experience. In=\r\n=20\r\nthe next couple years, Texas will justifiably be held to the same standard =\r\nas=20\r\nthe perennial powers.=20\r\n=09?\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09 Q: : I have two questions for you Chip: A) Does The University still ha=\r\nve=20\r\nthe longest scoring streak in NCAA football? B) If I find myself looking at=\r\n=20\r\nNEXT year's schedule after a payback loss at Stanford, do I need profession=\r\nal=20\r\nhelp? (P.S. You may also want to remind your readers we should NEVER feel=\r\n=20\r\nguilty about running up the score against U of H.)=20\r\n=09?? Arland Bishop=20\r\n=09\r\n=09 BROWN:  Texas has scored in a Big 12-record 231 straight games, dating =\r\nback=20\r\nto a 16-0 loss at Baylor in 1980. That is the second-longest active streak =\r\nin=20\r\nthe nation. BYU holds the longest scoring streak: 318 games.=20\r\n=09\r\n=09Next year's schedule is even more appetizing than this year's schedule. =\r\nThe=20\r\nonly non-conference road game is at Houston. The non-conference home games=\r\n=20\r\nare New Mexico State and North Carolina. And the Big 12 schedule has Colora=\r\ndo=20\r\nin Austin. UT will have Oklahoma in Dallas (as usual) and Texas A=02?at Kyl=\r\ne=20\r\nField.=20\r\n=09\r\n=09So, no, you don't need therapy. If anything, next year's schedule should=\r\n be=20\r\nanother reason to have patience with this year's team. Good times are=20\r\nobviously on the horizon.=20\r\n=09?\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09 Q: I know the subject has been worn into the ground, but I haven't hear=\r\nd=20\r\nthis view from anyone so ... In the mid-'90s Florida State was struggling=\r\n=20\r\nearly in the season with a young, talented QB named Charlie Ward (of course=\r\n).=20\r\nThey were winning the early games against less-talented teams, but just=20\r\nbarely. Then, they finally put Ward in the shotgun on virtually every down=\r\n=20\r\nand let him do his magic.=20\r\n=09\r\n=09It was like night and day.  Basically, what they did was abandon their m=\r\nore=20\r\nbalanced attack and did what their talent dictated they could do - pass ear=\r\nly=20\r\nand often. The run was still used, but it was more to complement the pass.=\r\n=20\r\n=09\r\n=09I know UT is not in the exact situation, but this may make sense for the=\r\nm.=20\r\nThe only time I thought the UT offense looked really good this year was rig=\r\nht=20\r\nwhen Major Applewhite first came in against Louisiana-Lafayette and drove=\r\n=20\r\nstraight down the field. And, Major took almost every snap in the shotgun (=\r\nat=20\r\nleast the first drive). I know it was against an inferior opponent that was=\r\n=20\r\nprobably taken by surprise, but they showed more on those drives with Major=\r\n=20\r\nin the first and second quarter than they have the rest of the season (so=\r\n=20\r\nfar).=20\r\n=09\r\n=09I believe you CAN win in college football with an unbalanced attack. FSU=\r\n has=20\r\ndone it with primarily passing, and I can't begin to name all the OU and=20\r\nNebraska-type teams that have won conference/national titles with=20\r\none-dimensional offenses. Also, the shotgun helps Major's biggest liability=\r\n -=20\r\nhis mobility. Personally, I don't care which QB is used this season - in th=\r\ne=20\r\nshotgun or not, but I really wish Mack Brown would just choose one and stic=\r\nk=20\r\nwith him. =20\r\n=09?? Aaron Ruhnow=20\r\n=09\r\n=09 BROWN:  I think you will continue to see the shotgun used only in speci=\r\nfic=20\r\nsituations. The Texas coaches are too committed to being a balanced offense=\r\n=20\r\nthat can run out of multiple sets. I do like the shotgun. The Buffalo Bills=\r\n=20\r\nused it all the time while they were going to all those Super Bowls. You ca=\r\nn=20\r\ndo a lot with it. But it probably won't become a fixture in Austin.=20\r\n=09?\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09 Q: Do you think that the pressure and expectations of Texas fans are go=\r\ning=20\r\nto be too much for Mack Brown to handle? Mike McDonald=20\r\n=09\r\n=09 BROWN:  : I hope it won't be too much for Mack Brown. He's a good perso=\r\nn and=20\r\nworks really hard. It just seems=\r\n=20\r\nlike everyone in the media, and even some our own fans, want to find=20\r\nsomething negative to heap on the program.\r\n=09\r\n=09In my opinion, Mack and the rest of the team do not deserve this. They have expressed confidence, but never boasted=\r\n=20\r\nabout their greatness. In fact, they have been the epitome of humility. Do=\r\n=20\r\nyou have any thoughts as to why this is occurring? Hook 'em. =20\r\n=09?? Marty Murray, Class of '82, Baytown, Texas=20\r\n=09\r\n=09 BROWN:  It does seem to be a ridiculous truth that when we build someth=\r\ning=20\r\nup, we inevitably end up tearing it down. Maybe the sense is that the=20\r\nstorybook season of 1998 and the victory over Nebraska last year built up t=\r\noo=20\r\nbig of expectations. The three losses at the end of last year did nothing t=\r\no=20\r\nburst the bubble and then when UT comes out flat this year, everyone=20\r\nre-evaluated and said, \"Wait, they really aren't that good.\"\r\n=09\r\n=09Mack Brown had been telling people to reduce their expectations. But whe=\r\nn the=20\r\nstar falls, people want to be the first to say it's falling. Then, they wan=\r\nt=20\r\nto add their own wrinkle as to why it's falling. So people look for cracks =\r\nin=20\r\nthe foundation to bring up.=20\r\n=09\r\n=09It's like in political campaigns. The media tends to build up a candidat=\r\ne and=20\r\nthen when the first negative story comes out, they re-evaluate, and if some=\r\n=20\r\nbad trends continue, that candidate gets torn to shreds. It all feeds on=20\r\nitself. But inevitably there is a settling period.\r\n=09\r\n=09I think the people who are quick to say that Texas isn't as good as we=\r\n=20\r\nbelieved will calm down and there will be another story to cover. Plus, Tex=\r\nas=20\r\nmay get hot, win all of its games, and then this brief bout of criticism wi=\r\nll=20\r\nhave been for naught. But sometimes criticism can be good for a coach and h=\r\nis=20\r\nteam. He can use it as bulletin board material to get the team going. We'll=\r\n=20\r\nsee how Mack Brown and the vocal minority of critics handle things from=20\r\nhere. =20\r\n=09?\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09 Q: Do you think Chris Simms would have benefited from a redshirt year? =\r\nI=20\r\nrealize we were thin at quarterback last year and it was probably not an=20\r\noption, but I look back at Major Applewhite and it appears to me he benefit=\r\ned=20\r\nfrom a redshirt year in which his only responsibility was to learn the=20\r\nsystem.
