    {
        "body": "Alan - thanks for assembling this information.  It is very useful but I want \nto throw out some ideas for discussion and ask you and others to comment on \nthe direction we take with this.\n\nI think we should characterize the Cost of Takeover as the difference in cost \nbetween the Nationalization approach Davis is taking and Enron's Market \napproach (increase supply, decrease demand, retail competition, utility \nsolvency).   Here's the direction that takes us:\n\n$13 B utility under-recovery:  required in both cases.\n$7.6 purchase of Transmission:  represents a $3.8B excess cost in Davis \nplan.  Ratepayers were going to pay for the first $3.8B anyway.  If Davis \nnets this against the $13 B under-recovery, then it's not an excess cost.\nTransmission upgrades:  required in both cases.\nDSM/DG grants:  required in both cases.\nNew construction to cover short position:  required in both cases.  Cost \ndifference is net difference between private market cost of generation and \nwhat subsidy CA must provide to induce generation at its desired cost, and \nnet inefficiency from administering a govt. bureaucracy vs. free market entry \nand exit.  These will be a function of how 6X is administered.\n\nIn other words, I see the direct and measurable Cost of Takeover now as maybe \n$4-5 B, including $1B to cover court challenges, legal costs, new bureaucracy \nand so on.  Much more important (and perhaps this is where the big $$ can \ncome in) is through indirect costs - damage to California's economy through \nreduced private investment because of heavy-handed govt threat, loss of  \ncommercial and industrial development because of short-term supply shortages, \nand long term inefficiencies because of public instead of private management.\n\nSo how about this:  direct cost of takeover is $5 billion plus a long term, \nindirect cost of $__ B because of a 5% reduction per year in the rate of new \ncapital investment  in the state.  Maybe a Robert Michael or somebody could \nfill in the last blank with a little prodding from us.\n\n\n\n\n\tAlan Comnes@ECT\n\t02/21/2001 01:49 PM\n\t\t\n\t\t To: John Neslage/ENRON_DEVELOPMENT@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT, James D \nSteffes/NA/Enron@Enron, Harry Kingerski/NA/Enron@Enron, Susan J \nMara/NA/Enron@ENRON, Jeff Dasovich/NA/Enron@Enron\n\t\t cc: \n\t\t Subject: Re: Cost of Takeover\n\nI already have a few changes:\n\nIn Davis's Feb 08 press release, it states: \"Under Governor Davis' emergency \npowers and proposals, California will streamline efforts to bring an \nadditional 20,000 megawatts online by July 2004, starting with 5,000 \nadditional megawatts by July 2001 and 5,000 more megawatts by July 2002.\"\n\nAlso, he mentions expanding by 1,000 MW the transmission line \"to Oregon\" in \nhis 2/16 press conference transcript.\n\nI have just upped the costs to reflect these numbers.\n\n\n",

O. Box 26530, Austin, Texas 78755 -\nPhone\n512-795-8536\n\nLonghorns Get Pledge from Killeen Ellison Linebacker\n\nYamil LaBron, 6-2, 240, 4.7, a middle linebacker from Killeen Ellison,\nannounced his commitment to Texas Monday, giving the Longhorns nine early\ncommitments. The Horns had pulled a big surprise earlier Monday, getting\nMike\nGarcia, a big offensive lineman from Galena Park, to switch from A&M to\nTexas.\nLaBron and  Garcia were the seventh and  eighth high school players to\ncommit\nto Texas this month. In addition, Alfio Randall, a star OT at Blinn JC,\nsays\nhe will come to Texas in January after he graduates from Blinn.\nThe other high school players who have committed to Texas are OLs Jonathan\nScott of Dallas Carter, Abe Robinson of Houston Jersey Village, Roman\nReeves\nof Livingston and Will Allen of Houston Cypress Falls and DBs Braden\nJohnson\nof Euless Trinity and Brian Carter of The Woodlands.\n\"I went to the Texas camp two weeks ago and they offered me a scholarship,\"\nLaBron said Monday night. \"I verbally committed to them when I met with the\ncoaches with my dad. I'm waiting for my mom to come home from Puerto Rico\nso\nshe can talk to them, too. To tell you the truth, I'm going there anyway.\nI'm\ngoing to be a Longhorn.\"\n* * * *\nI talked to Chris Hill, Roy Williams' mother, tonight and she said the\nshoulder injury Roy suffered on the opening kickoff of the Texas-California\nAll-Star game Saturday night, involves stretched ligaments and she said the\ndoctors say it will heal on it own. California won the game, 29-27, on a\n53-yard FG on the final play.\n\"He's in a lot of pain,\" she said. \"It's very sore. We took him to a\nspecialist and the examination showed stretched ligaments in the shoulder.\nThe specialist said it should heal on its own in a few weeks.\"\nShe also said the doctor said he should be fully recovered by the time the\nfreshmen report at Texas in mid-August.\nWilliams, a great wide receiver prospect from Odessa Permian,is one of the\ntop Longhorn recruits. He is 6-3, weighs 208 pounds and he ran a 10.03 100\nmeters last track season. He also high jumped 7-0 and he set a state record\nin the broad jump at the state meet with a  25-6 leap.\nSloan Thomas of Klein, another of the outstanding WR recruits Texas signed\nin\nFebruary, caught five passes in the second half and was one of the key\nplayers who led the Texas team's comeback from a 26-7 deficit. He caught\none\ntouchdown pass and set up two others with outstanding catches in heavy\ntraffic. On the two great catches in traffic, he was behind the secondary,\nbut had to come back because the balls were underthrown. He ran a 10.38 100\nmeters his junior year and, like Williams, has a great combination of size\nand speed. He is 6-2 and weighs almost 200 pounds.\nDE Kalen Thornton of Dallas St. Mark's, another UT signee, split time at\nend\nand tackle and was outstanding at both. He had two sacks and consistently\nput\npressure on the California quarterbacks.\nC Jason Glynn and DT Sonny Davis, the other two UT signees who played in\nthe\ngame, also looked good when they got to play. Glynn opened some good holes\non\nthe late scoring drive that put Texas ahead, 27-26, with just 17 seconds\nleft. Davis appeared to be carrying a little excess weight, but he was able\nto push the Cal blockers back into the backfield at times.\nThis was the second straight year California has won the game in the final\nseconds.\nB. J. Johnson, the nation's No. 1 WR recruit and another Texas signee,\nsprained an ankle a week before the game and was not able to play. He said\nthe ankle sprain is mild and won't hamper his ability to be in good shape\nfor\nthe start of workouts at UT in less than seven weeks.\n* * * *\nRECRUITING NOTES: DT Tommie Harris, LeBron's teammate at Killeen Ellison,\nsays Texas and Florida State are his top two teams right now, followed by\nA&M,\nMiami and UCLA. Harris  probably is the nation's top DT recruit, and he is\na\ngood friend of Greg Barnum, the center who quit the Tennessee team several\nweeks ago and is considering transferring to Texas to continue his football\ncareer.\n* * * *\nMy next fax will be whenever events warrant.\n* * * *\nThe True Orange Fax Service includes  at  least  99 faxes  a year and costs\n$99 ($79 by E-Mail). O. Box 26530, Austin, Texas 78755 -\nPhone\n512-795-8536\n\nFour Longhorn Substitutes Leaving Team; UT Will Sign at Least 22\n\nThree Longhorn reserves\n\n- sophomore CB Kendrick Turner, sophomore LB Jamal\nJoyner and redshirt freshman DB Antonio Moore\n- have quit the football team\nand will transfer to other schools, and a fourth backup\n- redshirt freshman\nFB Jason Barron\n- will miss the 2000 season for academic reasons.\nBarron said he will work to improve his grades and return to the team, but\nI\nwould be surprised if he comes back because he is far down on the fullback\nchart and the Longhorns probably will sign at least 22 players in February.\nWith 80 players on scholarship and only 13 seniors, they will need to have\nsome more players leave next year to stay within the NCAA's 85-scholarship\nlimit.\nNone of the departures came as a surprise and Turner was the only one of\nthe\nquartet who would have seen any meaningful action this season if he had\nstayed. Joyner was on suspension. He was the last to leave of the four\nplayers who were suspended prior to the Cotton Bowl game.\nBrown wished all of the young men well, and gave the three who are\ntransferring unconditional releases.\n* * * *\nEric Hall, 6-3, 235, 4.5, the outstanding DE prospect from Clarksville,\nTenn., told me today he is going to take his official visit to Texas the\nSept. 9 weekend and will see the season-opening game against\nLouisiana-Lafayette. He said he strongly favors Texas, and the only other\nschools he is considering are Nebraska and Tennessee.\n\"I see myself going to Texas,\" he said. \"I was born in Texas (Fort Hood)\nand\nI really like the state.\"\nAnother top out-of-state DE who is strongly considering Texas is Kaelen\nJakes,  6-4, 265, 4.8 of Valencia, Cal. He lived in Texas for  four years\nand\nsaid he is considering the Horns, along with USC, UCLA, Arizona and\nNebraska.\nHe said his team doesn't keep invidual stats, but estimated he had \"between\n15\nand 18 sacks last season.\" He said he played DE, DT and NG for Valencia\nlast\nyear.\n* * * *\nDT Tommie Harris of Killen Ellison is the top DL in Texas this year and is\none of the top players in the country. He says he favors Texas over Florida\nState and others. Harris has been working out in Houston with a personal\ntrainer this summer. UT center signee Trey Bates works out with the same\ntrainer. Stockar McDougle, a former Oklahoma Sooner OL who now is in the\nNFL,\nis Harris' cousin, and is paying for the personal trainer for Harris.\n* * * *\nTexas has 11 early commitments, including six offensive linemen. The OLs\nare\nMike Garcia of Galena Park (who switched from A&M to Texas), Jonathan Scott\nof Dallas Carter, Abe Robinson of Houston Jersey Village, Roman Reeves of\nLivingston, Will Allen of Houston Cypress Falls and Alfio Randall of Blinn\nJC.\nScott and Robinson are national top 100 players and Randall was a top 100\nplayer at Houston Yates two years ago. The other pledges are QB/DB Kendal\nBriles of Frenship, MLB Yamil Lebron of Killeen Ellison, and DBs Cedric\nGriffin of San Antonio Holmes, Braden Johnson of Euless Trinity and Brian\nCarter of The Woodlands.\nTen players who signed with Texas are slated to play in the annual\nNorth-South High School Football All-Star game at Rice Stadium next Tuesday\nat 7 p.m. Scheduled to play for the North are QBs Chance Mock of The\nWoodlands and Tony Jeffery of Klein Forest, WRs Roy Williams of Odessa\nPermian, B. J. Johnson of South Grand Prairie and Nathan Vasher of\nTexarkana\nand kicker Matt McFadden of Coppell.\nScheduled to play for the South are OT Lionel Garr of Diboll, C Trey Bates\nof\nFort Bend Elkins and DTs Sonny Davis of Austin Lanier and Marcel Moses of\nTexas City. Davis and Moses failed to qualify academically and are headed\nto\nthe JC ranks. Johnson has a sprained ankle that will keep him out of the\ngame.\n* * * *\nFOOTBALL NOTES: The Longhorn DBs are extremely impressed with Sloan Thomas\nand Tony Jeffery, who are two of the outstanding incoming freshman wide\nreceiver prospects. They said Thomas is a big, physical receiver with great\nspeed, and they say Jeffery is very hard to cover because he has such great\nmoves and quickness. The players have been working out against each other\nduring voluntary summer drills.\n* * * *\nWOMEN'S BASKETBALL RECRUITING: CoCo Reed, a 5-11 forward from Houston\nJersey\nVillage, has committed to play for the Texas women. She averaged 19 points\nas\na junior and averaged 23 points in AAU play this summer. She lives with 5-6\njunior point guard Nina Norman, who will be one of the nation's top\nprospects\nnext year. Reed also was recruited by Duke, LSU, Rutgers, Florida and\nMaryland, among others.\nThe Longhorn women's top incoming freshmen\n- 6-1 Stacy Stephens of Winnsboro\nand 6-2 Annissa Hastings of San Antonio Sam Houston\n- were named to the AAU\nAll-American Team Saturday at the conclusion of the National AAU Tournament\nin Clarksville, Tenn.\n* * * *\nMy next fax will be whenever events warrant.\n* * * *\nThe True Orange Fax Service includes  at  least  99 faxes  a year and costs\n$99 ($79 by E-Mail).         "body": "---------------------- Forwarded by David M Gagliardi/TTG/HouInd on\n08/15/2000 07:51 AM ---------------------------\n\n\n\"Michael Gagliardi\" <mggagliardi@duke-energy.com> on 08/15/2000 07:17:25 AM\n\nTo:   DGagliardi@reliantenergy.com, David_ricks@GSDM.com\ncc:\n\nSubject:  True Orange Fax/E-Mail #68\n\n\n\n\n\n---------------------- Forwarded by Michael\nGagliardi/Hou-ComOps/EnergyTrading/PEC on 08/15/2000 07:26 AM\n---------------------------\n\n\nTruOrange@aol.com on 08/14/2000 10:25:12 PM\n\nTo:   undisclosed-recipients:;\ncc:    (bcc: Michael Gagliardi/Hou-ComOps/EnergyTrading/PEC)\nSubject:  True Orange Fax/E-Mail #68\n\n\n\n\nTrue Orange Fax/E-Mail Service\nVolume 8, Fax/E-Mail #68, Monday, August 14, 2000\nJerry Scarbrough's True Orange, P. O. Box 26530, Austin, Texas 78755 -\nPhone\n512-795-8536\n\nRoy Williams Leads Outstanding Freshman Class in Workouts\nThe heralded Longhorn freshman class had its first two workouts Monday, and\nseveral players looked very good, but big, fast WR Roy Williams was almost\ntoo impressive to believe.\nHe's big, at about 6-3 or maybe 6-4 and a little over 200 pounds (we should\nget official heights and weights Tuesday) and he is fast (10.03 100 meters\nlast track season) and no one could cover him Monday. He caught so many\nlong\npasses I lost count.\nPitty poor Nathan Vasher, the lone scholarship DB among the freshmen. He\nhad\nto try to cover Williams, B. J. Johnson, Sloan Thomas and Tony Jeffery, the\nbest group of freshman wide receivers in the country. As soon as he got\nthrough with one and got a little breather, it was on to the next one.\nVasher\nactually did a good job most of the time on everybody except Williams, who\nwas just too big and too strong for him to handle. Vasher does a good job\nof\nman coverage, getting right with the wide receiver and staying with him on\nmost occasions.\nAlso pity poor QB Chance Mock, who probably threw more passes Monday than\nhe\ndid in his whole career at The Woodlands. He showed great accuracy and\ntouch\non long and short passes, and offensive coordinator Greg Davis,\ncomplimented\nhim for having \"a quick release.\" But I'll bet his arm is sore Tuesday.\nCoach Mack Brown said he doesn't normally want to play freshmen,\nparticularly\nearly in the season, but he said it is easier for wide receivers to play\nearly than for most other players.\n\"Take our two freshmen defensive ends, Kalen Thornon and Adam Doiron,\"\nBrown\nsaid. \"They are very good prospects, but they have never lined up against\nanybody like Leonard Davis, and that's what they'll start doing when the\nveterans show up. Their learning curve goes up pretty drastically, and they\nprobably will need some time to cope with that.\"\nBut he said it's a different story with wide receivers. \"If a receiver can\nrun, jump, catch and do something after he catches it, Brown said, \"we can\nmake the offense simpler for him,\"\nDarryl Drake, the wide receiver coach, phrased it another way, saying, \"If\na\nguy is 6-3 or 6-4, can run close to a 10-flat hundred meters and high jump\nseven feet (Williams did all that last year at Odessa Permian), we'll just\ntell him to run down the field and, if anybody can keep up with him,\nthey're\nprobably short cornerbacks and he can outjump them for the ball. We'll\ncoach\nhim next year, but he can get by with the speed and jumping ability this\nyear.\" Drake was only partially kidding.\nWhen Williams has to try to get off the line against big-time correrbacks\nlike Quentin Jammer and Roderick Babers, the two UT starters, it will be\nharder, but Brown said all the receivers are going to get a lot of work\nagainst bump-and-run coverage. He also said he expects at least two of them\nto play a lot early in the season;\nThomas, Johnson and Jeffery also had some good plays. Thomas made one great\ncatch of a high ball that appeared to be out of his reach.\nOne UT assistant coach told me today he has never seen back-to-back classes\nas outstanding as the two the Longhorns have put together the last two\nyears.\nThe freshmen will have their final workouts as a group Tuesday. The varsity\nreports Wednesday and the first full team workouts will be Friday.\n* * * *\nRECRUITING NOTES: The news got as little better today on the state's best\nquarterback, Matt Nordgren, 6-5, 217, 4.62, of Dallas Bishop Lynch. He\nvisited Colorado unofficially last weekend and came back very impressed and\nsaying he wants to delay his decision on picking a college.\nBut he told me today the Longhorn coaches are recruiting two quarterbacks\n(Bret Rawls of Louisiana powerhouse Shreveport Evangel is the other one)\n\"and\nthey gave us both a deadline of October 15 and told us to look around and\nbe\nsure what we want to do. I think that is a real sign of class,\" he said.\n\"I'll probably take some official visits before that, maybe to Colorado,\nKansas, LSU and Tennessee, and then I'll take an official visit to Texas. I\nstill say Texas will be hard to beat, but I just want to be real sure\nbefore\nI make a decision.\"\n* * * *\nMy next fax will be Tuesday, August 15.\n* * * *\nThe True Orange Fax Service includes  at  least  99 faxes  a year and costs\n$99 ($79 by E-Mail). The True Orange Newsletter includes  26 newsletters\nand\nis published weekly during football season and twice monthly during most of\nthe other months. It costs $45. Save by subscribing to both for $130 (or\n$110\nif you take the faxes via E-Mail  or $99 if you take the faxes and\nnewsletter\nvia E-Mail). Send check  to address at the top of page. I also  update my\n900 number\n\n- 1-900-288-8839\n- frequently with recruiting news. My E-Mail\naddress is: truorange@aol.com\n\n\n\n\n",

        "body": "---------------------- Forwarded by Eric Bass/HOU/ECT on 09/21/2000 08:15 A=\r\nM=20\r\n---------------------------\r\n\r\n\r\n\"Inside UT Football\"=20\r\n<InsideUTFootball@dallasnews.com>@newsletters.dallasnews.com on 09/21/2000=\r\n=20\r\n12:15:00 AM\r\nPlease respond to \"Inside UT Football\" <InsideUTFootball@dallasnews.com>\r\nSent by: newsletters@newsletters.dallasnews.com\r\nTo: \"Inside UT Football Subscribers\"=20\r\n<InsideUTFootball@newsletters.dallasnews.com>\r\ncc: =20\r\nSubject: Inside UT Football: September 21, 2000\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n  [IMAGE]  =09  [IMAGE] =20\r\n\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09[IMAGE]\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09Back to reality=20\r\n=09=20\r\n=09Sept. 21, 2000=20\r\n=09=20\r\n=09\r\n=09[IMAGE]Chip Brown, The Dallas Morning News' Texas writer, answers your=\r\n=20\r\nquestions about what went wrong against Stanford, Coach Mack Brown's respon=\r\nse=20\r\nto the loss, the continuing quarterback controversy, UT players in the NFL=\r\n=20\r\nand more. Inside UT Football appears every Thursday.=20\r\n=09\r\n=09=20\r\n=09E-mail questions to Chip: chipbrown@dallasnews.com=20\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09=20\r\n=09Listen to Chip Brown talk about the Longhorns on\r\n=09dallasnews.com's Colleges site=20\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09CHIP SHOTS=20\r\n=09=20\r\n=09\r\n=09Every year since 1983, Texas has lost or tied a game in its first four g=\r\names=20\r\nof the season. That means UT has had a blemish on its record each of the pa=\r\nst=20\r\n17 years - usually before Texas-OU weekend. =20\r\n=09\r\n=09 Orangebloods spend winter, spring and summer discussing the impact of n=\r\new=20\r\nrecruits, the prowess of future opponents and the talents of its returning=\r\n=20\r\nstarters. They spend money on season tickets, airplane tickets and alumni=\r\n=20\r\nluncheon tickets. They dream big dreams, and then by October, the high hope=\r\ns=20\r\nhave usually come crashing down.=20\r\n=09\r\n=09 Only three times since 1983 has Texas opened the season 3-0: 1984, 1985=\r\n and=20\r\n1994. Those starts were then immediately followed by either a tie (1984) or=\r\n=20\r\nlosses (1985 and 1994). In each of those seasons, Texas ended up with four=\r\n=20\r\nlosses. =20\r\n=09\r\n=09 In UT's two best seasons since 1983, a 10-2 campaign in 1990 and a 10-2=\r\n-1=20\r\nrun in 1995, the Longhorns lost their second and third games of the season,=\r\n=20\r\nrespectively. Before Texas can dream about winning a national title, the=20\r\nLonghorns have to show they can make it into October without a loss.=20\r\n=09\r\n=09=20\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09Longhorn Q & A=20\r\n=09 Q: Judging from the Stanford game (as well as the last three games of l=\r\nast=20\r\nseason) it looks like the trend of blitzing the Horns will continue. There =\r\nis=20\r\nalso no respect for our running game from any team that we face. I think th=\r\ne=20\r\nbest way to end this strategy against us is to become the aggressor on=20\r\noffense and not sit back passively and react to what the defense is giving=\r\n=20\r\nus. =20\r\n=09\r\n=09In order for us to achieve this, I think it starts with us putting our b=\r\nest=20\r\nathletes on the field on offense. These guys may not be the most experience=\r\nd=20\r\nplayers, but they will gain experience with playing time, and they have the=\r\n=20\r\nability to make a team pay for selling out with the blitz. It's time to sta=\r\nrt=20\r\nRoy Williams and B.J. Johnson at receiver (along with Montrell Flowers) and=\r\n=20\r\nplay a one-back offensive set. Our fullbacks are not a threat offensively a=\r\nnd=20\r\nHodges Mitchell is not an I-back who is adept at following the fullback=20\r\nthrough the hole. Hodges' strength is operating in space and making people=\r\n=20\r\nmiss in the open field.=20\r\n=09\r\n=09I also think Chris Simms needs to get the bulk of the minutes at quarter=\r\nback.=20\r\nMajor Applewhite has all the intangibles in the world but Simms could (and=\r\n=20\r\nprobably does) possess all of the same skills. He just hasn't had the chanc=\r\ne=20\r\nto display them. We desperately need to have all playmakers on the field if=\r\n=20\r\nwe are going to turn this thing around. If not, I could see this season=20\r\nslipping to 7-4 real quick. What are your thoughts, Chip?=20\r\n=09 ?? The Jackson residence=20\r\n=09\r\n=09 BROWN:  With any unexpected loss, the tendency is to throw everyone out=\r\n -=20\r\nchange coaches, players, even the bus driver. You do that and you are telli=\r\nng=20\r\nthis team that you have absolutely no confidence in them. There can't be to=\r\no=20\r\nmuch change at any one time. The big question is how the team responds to=\r\n=20\r\nthis Stanford loss emotionally. Something tells me if Texas can find some=\r\n=20\r\nresolve and perform really well, you'll see some solid performances at all=\r\n=20\r\nthe positions where problems currently exist. In 1996, Texas was No. 6 and=\r\n=20\r\nNotre Dame was No. 9. Texas had the game won in Austin and then lost. UT th=\r\nen=20\r\nlost three of its next four, which included games against Oklahoma State,=\r\n=20\r\nOklahoma and Colorado - all teams Texas is about to face after this week's=\r\n=20\r\nopponent, Houston.=20\r\n=09\r\n=09That was a different coach and different players. But the common thread =\r\nwas=20\r\nthat Texas hit the top 10 and then choked. If Texas is hung over from its=\r\n=20\r\nloss to Stanford, trouble could be on the horizon. If Texas can find resolv=\r\ne=20\r\nto show everyone that Stanford truly was a game in which everything that=20\r\ncould go wrong did, then I think the Longhorns will bounce back and be a ha=\r\nrd=20\r\nteam to beat the rest of the way. Tuesday night Mack Brown said the Longhor=\r\nns=20\r\nare not a very good football team right now. The challenge has been made to=\r\n=20\r\nhis team. If they come out and stink against Houston, every position will b=\r\ne=20\r\nscrutinized, every coach, even the bus driver. There will be enough fire=20\r\nbeing thrown in Austin to serve up grilled fajitas for the entire state. Bu=\r\nt=20\r\nchanges will have to be made constructively and gradually.=20\r\n=09?\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09[IMAGE]=20\r\n=09Chris Simms =20\r\n=09\r\n=09Q: What's going on with the quarterbacks?=20\r\n=09?? Mitch Golding=20\r\n=09\r\n=09 BROWN:  As the QBs turn. This week, it appears Chris Simms will start=\r\n=20\r\nbecause he was practicing with the first team on Tuesday. That has been the=\r\n=20\r\ntrend. Whoever practices with the first team gets the start. Anyway, we'll=\r\n=20\r\nsee how they respond after the Stanford game. Major Applewhite was erratic =\r\nin=20\r\nhis play, despite almost leading the Longhorns back from the dead to a=20\r\nmiraculous victory. I'm sticking to my theory that the coaches want to see=\r\n=20\r\nwhat Simms can do against Houston before picking one or the other =20\r\n=09\r\n=09to get solo duty in the Oklahoma and Colorado games. =20\r\n=09\r\n=09Granted, if one struggles along the way, the other will come in. But Mac=\r\nk=20\r\nBrown said they primarily went with Applewhite against Stanford because of=\r\n=20\r\nhis experience and the fact that it was the team's first game on the road. =\r\nHe=20\r\nsaid they still have all the faith in the world in Simms. It would seem to =\r\nme=20\r\nthat it takes away the incentive to really take control of the offense, lig=\r\nht=20\r\nit up and get on a roll when you are alternating, but I'll continue to watc=\r\nh=20\r\nlike everyone else. =20\r\n=09\r\n=09I keep trying to remind myself that Brown did this twice at North Caroli=\r\nna=20\r\nwith success. Of course, with those QBs (Oscar Davenport and Chris Keldorf)=\r\n,=20\r\nBrown had different styles and gained an advantage by forcing the defense t=\r\no=20\r\nprepare for Davenport's scrambling and Keldorf's passing. With Simms and=20\r\nApplewhite you pretty much get the same style. With Keldorf and Davenport,=\r\n=20\r\nyou also had injuries dictate a few starts.=20\r\n=09?\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09 Q: Can you tell us what influenced Mack Brown's decision regarding the=\r\n=20\r\nquarterbacks against Stanford?=20\r\n=09?? Nels Marshall=20\r\n=09\r\n=09 BROWN:  Here are Brown's exact words: \"Experience. We were in a tight=\r\n=20\r\nfootball game and Major (Applewhite) has been around a long time. I was pro=\r\nud=20\r\n- even with as poorly as we played offensively in the third quarter - that =\r\nwe=20\r\ndidn't panic. I thought that in the fourth quarter the kids did a great job=\r\n=20\r\nof coming back and giving us a chance to win. Sometimes youth doesn't look=\r\n=20\r\nlike it is trying because they're nervous. Instead, they are trying too har=\r\nd=20\r\nand get uptight. Our team tried hard. As negative as people make Saturday=\r\n=20\r\nnight, it is one of those things that you have to grow from.\" =20\r\n=09?\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09 Q: I'm glad we have two great QBs. My question is, are the receivers ha=\r\nving=20\r\nany problem adjusting to the different spin on the balls coming from a=20\r\nleft-handed or right-handed QB?=20\r\n=09?? Dave Stastny, Austin=20\r\n=09\r\n=09 BROWN:  The receivers say the varying spins are not a factor when catch=\r\ning=20\r\nthe ball. They do, however, say that Chris Simms' ball will come a little=\r\n=20\r\nfaster and a little harder than Major Applewhite's.=20\r\n=09?\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09 Q: The Longhorns are obviously going to play a lot of freshmen this yea=\r\nr.=20\r\nWhat are the rules on redshirting a player after the season starts? I know=\r\n=20\r\nthat a player can apply for a redshirt for medical reasons, but can they al=\r\nso=20\r\napply for more eligibility or take a redshirt after playing a small amount =\r\nof=20\r\ntime? =20\r\n=09?? Chad Graham=20\r\n=09\r\n=09 BROWN:  No. Once a freshman plays in a game, even for one play and he d=\r\noes=20\r\nnot suffer a season-ending injury, the chance for a redshirt is out the=20\r\nwindow. =20\r\n=09?\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09[IMAGE]=20\r\n=09Jermain Anderson =20\r\n=09\r\n=09Q: Have the coaches given any consideration to moving Jermain Anderson b=\r\nack=20\r\nto linebacker? If I remember correctly, he played LB in high school at Texa=\r\ns=20\r\nCity. He seems to still have good speed, but also a problem putting on the=\r\n=20\r\nnecessary weight to play defensive end. It just seems like he might be bett=\r\ner=20\r\nsuited for the outside linebacker rotation, especially considering the=20\r\nprogress made by young defensive ends like Kalen Thornton, Cole Pittman and=\r\n=20\r\nAdam Doiron. =20\r\n=09 ?? Micah Hurt=20\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09 BROWN:  Coaches don't think Anderson has the speed to play linebacker. =\r\nThey=20\r\nare pleased with the depth at linebacker, as well. They like Anderson's=20\r\ninstincts as a pass rusher. They are still working on his ability to stop t=\r\nhe=20\r\nrun.=20\r\n=09?\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09 Q: My husband wanted me to write and request that you put the Longhorn=\r\n=20\r\nfootball schedule in your letter each week. Through thick and thin, he h=\r\nas=20\r\nremained a loyal Longhorn fan and taken a lot of harassment from the Sooner=\r\n=20\r\nfans. Of course, he does his fair share (and probably more) of bragging abo=\r\nut=20\r\nthe Longhorns. =20\r\n=09?? Barbara and Mark Harper=20\r\n=09\r\n=09 BROWN:  As far as the schedule, UT's remaining games are:=20\r\n=09\r\n=09Sept. 23 (home) vs. Houston at 6 p.m. on Fox\r\n=09Sept. 30 (home) vs. Oklahoma State at 11 a.m. on ABC\r\n=09Oct. 7 (in Dallas) vs. Oklahoma, TBA\r\n=09Oct. 14 at Colorado, TBA\r\n=09Oct. 21 (home) vs. Missouri, TBA\r\n=09Oct. 28 (home) vs. Baylor, TBA\r\n=09Nov. 4 at Texas Tech, TBA\r\n=09Nov. 11 at Kansas, TBA\r\n=09Nov. 24 (home) vs. Texas A=02?at 2:30 p.m. on ABC=20\r\n=09Since you all have access to the Internet, log onto UT's sports Web site=\r\n=20\r\n(texassports.com) and learn what radio stations broadcast the game in your=\r\n=20\r\narea. And you can read The Dallas Morning News online every day at=20\r\ndallasnews.com.=20\r\n=09?\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09 Q: This may take some research but I was wondering if you could tell me=\r\n the=20\r\nnumber of UT players in the NFL and the status of some recent grads (i.e.=\r\n=20\r\nhow's Cedric Woodard, Aaron Humphrey, Kwame Cavil). Thanks.=20\r\n=09\r\n=09 BROWN:  The Big 12 office just released a list of former Texas players =\r\nin=20\r\nthe NFL. However, it includes some players who have been released. Jay Humphrey also was released after one year with the Minnesota=20\r\nVikings. Kwame Cavil made the Buffalo Bills after going undrafted. Anyway,=\r\n=20\r\nhere is the list as provided by the Big 12:\r\n=09\r\n=09TEXAS (21)\r\n=09Ben Adams, OL, Miami\r\n=09Taje Allen, DB, St. Louis\r\n=09Tony Brackens, DE, Jacksonville\r\n=09Blake Brockermeyer, OG, Chicago\r\n=09Ricky Brown, RB, Cincinnati\r\n=09Chris Carter, DB, New England\r\n=09Kwame Cavil, WR, Buffalo\r\n=09Phil Dawson, KS, Cleveland\r\n=09Shane Dronett, DL, Atlanta\r\n=09Priest Holmes, RB, Baltimore\r\n=09Aaron Humphrey, DE, Tampa Bay\r\n=09Jay Humphrey, OL, Minnesota\r\n=09Derek Lewis, TE, St. Louis\r\n=09Wane McGarity, WR, Dallas\r\n=09Eric Metcalf, WR, Carolina\r\n=09Dan Neil, OL, Denver\r\n=09Roger Roesler, OL, Cincinnati\r\n=09Chris Smith, TE, Dallas\r\n=09Winfred Tubbs, LB, San Francisco\r\n=09Bryant Westbrook, DB, Detroit\r\n=09Ricky Williams, RB, New Orleans\r\n=09Cedric Woodard, DL, Baltimore=20\r\n=09?\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09[IMAGE]=20\r\n=09Hodges Mitchell =20\r\n=09\r\n=09Q: Don't know whether you can address any or all of these questions in y=\r\nour=20\r\ncolumn, but I've seen some unflattering trends in Mack Brown's program and=\r\n=20\r\nwanted your feedback. Mack Brown is a great recruiter, no argument there.=\r\n=20\r\nHowever, can he motivate? It seems like he can't get the team \"up\" sometime=\r\ns=20\r\nand can't adjust the team's mood during a game.=20\r\n=09\r\n=09About offensive coordinator Greg Davis, I don't know who is responsible =\r\nfor=20\r\nthe offensive line but since it is an offensive group, in more ways than on=\r\ne,=20\r\nI put it under him. With guys the size that UT has, shouldn't even Hodges=\r\n=20\r\nMitchell be able to run? Who tagged Leonard Davis as a pro? Why does Davis=\r\n=20\r\nlove Mitchell? Sure, he gained 1,300-plus yards last year, but how many of=\r\n=20\r\nthose yards were \"move=20\r\n=09\r\n=09 the chains\" type of runs that allowed UT to hold the ball on the ground=\r\n and=20\r\nprotect a lead? I thought it was going to be running back by committee but=\r\n=20\r\nall we have seen is the coaches continuing the same mistake - abandoning th=\r\ne=20\r\nrun and using the wrong back for the wrong situations.=20\r\n=09\r\n=09Mitchell can run to the outside, but he cannot run through the defensive=\r\n=20\r\ntackles. And even if he does get holes, he still will never break through t=\r\nhe=20\r\nlinebackers for a TD. Why not put Ivan Williams or Kenny Hayter back there=\r\n=20\r\nwith Mitchell and go with a two-back, three-wide offense? You don't lose a=\r\n=20\r\nreceiver as Hodges is a nice, smart receiver.\r\n=09\r\n=09Other ramblings: Is Quentin Jammer really a corner? He got beat MANY tim=\r\ne=20\r\nagainst Stanford. I loved his hitting when he played safety but his injury=\r\n=20\r\nmay have forever changed his game if he can't play safety and can't keep up=\r\n=20\r\nwith opponent's wideouts.\r\n=09\r\n=09How is the defensive end position shaping up? The defensive tackles were=\r\n all=20\r\nover the field against Stanford, but the DEs didn't make much noise. What i=\r\ns=20\r\nup with the blocked punts? UT should be really, really embarrassed. Does=20\r\nStockton take too long? Is he too close to the line? Can the line block? Ca=\r\nn=20\r\nanyone at UT block?\r\n=09\r\n=09Does Brown ride the officials who are missing holding calls? Several tim=\r\nes=20\r\nthe camera caught clear holds by Stanford's line. Why on earth would you ru=\r\nn=20\r\nup the middle, on your own goal line against two of the best DTs you'll pla=\r\ny=20\r\nagainst?=20\r\n=09?? Andrew Bowen=20\r\n=09\r\n=09 BROWN:  I think your feelings are shared by many Texas fans who are=20\r\nincredibly pained, shocked, disappointed, angered and hurt by last Saturday=\r\n's=20\r\nevents. But in talking to Mack Brown on Tuesday, he said it's fair to beat=\r\n=20\r\nthe team up for not being able to run the ball. But he said to jump on any=\r\n=20\r\nother part of the team is to rip young, inexperienced kids who are still=20\r\nlearning what it takes to compete as a top-ranked team.=20\r\n=09\r\n=09To be fair to Brown, he did say repeatedly that his team was overrated a=\r\nnd=20\r\nneeded time to grow into some key positions - receiver, defensive end,=20\r\nfullback and some positions on the offensive line and at corner. It probabl=\r\ny=20\r\nisn't fair to question whether Mack Brown can motivate because his teams di=\r\nd=20\r\nbeat Nebraska twice, Oklahoma twice and Texas A=02?once. If a trend develop=\r\ns,=20\r\nand Texas falls apart the rest of the season, there will be a fair question=\r\n=20\r\nabout whether Brown did a good enough job of keeping his team's head screwe=\r\nd=20\r\non straight. But it's typical after losses to want to shred every part of t=\r\nhe=20\r\nteam.=20\r\n=09\r\n=09Brown said before the season that as soon as something went wrong, the=\r\n=20\r\nquarterback situation would be blamed. And he was right. The QBs are still=\r\n=20\r\nworking hard, and look for Simms to start this week against Houston. There'=\r\ns=20\r\nno question that the O-line is struggling, but so are the backs and so are=\r\n=20\r\nthe receivers. Brown said only two of the five sacks were the fault of the=\r\n=20\r\nline. He said the other three were caused by miscommunication between=20\r\nApplewhite and the receivers, causing Applewhite to hold the ball too long.=\r\n=20\r\n=09\r\n=09Mitchell was standing too deep in the backfield against Stanford, so it =\r\nwas=20\r\ntaking him too long to get to the holes. The coaches were not happy about=\r\n=20\r\nthat. They were yelling at him to move up. He should only be 6 1/2 yards=20\r\ndeep. But he was sometimes at 9 yards. Mitchell also struggled with some=20\r\nblitz pickup, which is uncharacteristic of him. So look for Victor Ike,=20\r\nHayter and possibly Williams to get a little time against Houston.=20\r\n=09\r\n=09Coaches are still high on Jammer. Again, he hasn't played corner much in=\r\n=20\r\ngames after moving from safety. But coaches are not thinking of moving him.=\r\n=20\r\nThe defensive end position is a big concern with defensive coordinator Carl=\r\n=20\r\nReese. He is willing to rifle through his whole pile until he finds a coupl=\r\ne=20\r\nwho can really play. Cory Redding was better than usual against Stanford. B=\r\nut=20\r\nthat position still needs a lot of work. The blocked punt occurred because=\r\n=20\r\none player, who blocked perfectly on 11 other punts Saturday night, failed =\r\nto=20\r\nblock a player coming right up the middle, which guarantees doom. That play=\r\ner=20\r\nhas been chewed out every which way.\r\n=09\r\n=09As far as the penalties, there were several questionable calls. But Brow=\r\nn,=20\r\nwho did a lot of yelling at officials during the Stanford game, couldn't sa=\r\ny=20\r\nanything about it after the game because he would be fined. Texas can still=\r\n=20\r\nhave a good season, and perhaps having these problem areas pointed out so=\r\n=20\r\nearly will help in that direction. We'll see if Texas takes this loss=20\r\nconstructively or destructively.=20\r\n=09?\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09 Q: Last year at times I saw blazing speed and ability from Cory Redding=\r\n. I=20\r\nknow he was considered by many to be the best high school defensive player =\r\nin=20\r\nthe country in 1998. I've waited all off-season to see him explode against=\r\n=20\r\nteams this year. I haven't seen it yet. Maybe this week against Stanford. M=\r\ny=20\r\nquestion is, why was he moved from his high school position of linebacker=\r\n=20\r\nwhere he was dominant into the defensive end role where he seems undersized=\r\n=20\r\nand average? Is Texas that low on defensive line talent? It seems our=20\r\nrecruiting has been great. Please help me understand. Hook 'em Horns!=20\r\n=09?? Ernie McAnally=20\r\n=09\r\n=09 BROWN:  Redding told me recently that linebacker is still his first lov=\r\ne.=20\r\nBut he said coaches came to him last year and said he could get on the fiel=\r\nd=20\r\nright away as a defensive end. Coaches also feel that his body (6-5, 260) i=\r\ns=20\r\nperfect for the DE position. He's tall, athletic, fast and has long arms. I=\r\nn=20\r\ntime, coaches feel Redding will develop into an All-America player. But the=\r\nre=20\r\nis no question that he has struggled against the run. He made some big play=\r\ns=20\r\nagainst Stanford, recording six tackles, three of them for losses and=20\r\nblocking an extra point attempt. He is just a sophomore. Over this season a=\r\nnd=20\r\nthe next two years, he should only get better.=20\r\n=09?\r\n=09\r\n=09 Q: I was watching the regional telecast of the TCU game today and the=\r\n=20\r\nannouncers  stated that TCU had anted up $90,000 for the Heisman campaign f=\r\nor=20\r\nLaDainian Tomlinson. Since UT has lost=\r\n=20\r\nfour out of its last five games, wouldn't a loss to Houston this week=20\r\nofficially end Mack Brown's honeymoon with the alumni, notwithstanding his=\r\n=20\r\nabundant PR program? With Brown about to land his third national Top 5=20\r\nrecruiting class, I believe fans are going to expect more gridiron victorie=\r\ns=20\r\nto go with those recruiting victories. =20\r\n=09?? T. Hough=20\r\n=09\r\n=09 BROWN:  It's true that Brown has yet to win a conference championship i=\r\nn=20\r\nstints at Appalachian State, Tulane, North Carolina and now Texas. At=20\r\nAppalachian State, Tulane and UNC, he was taking over absolutely dead=20\r\nprograms. He took Tulane to a bowl, and he had Florida State to deal with i=\r\nn=20\r\nthe Atlantic Coast Conference while at UNC. But he took UNC to six bowl gam=\r\nes=20\r\nin his 10 years at UNC and won four of them.=20\r\n=09\r\n=09A loss to Houston would certainly intensify the frustration of Texas=20\r\nfaithful. But I think anyone who would be looking to put Brown on the hot=\r\n=20\r\nseat or rip him if Texas lost to Houston would be overlooking the job he ha=\r\ns=20\r\ndone beating Nebraska (twice), Oklahoma (twice) and Texas A=02?(once) in hi=\r\ns=20\r\nfirst two seasons here. He has also turned Texas back into a destination=20\r\nschool for top recruits and brought the UT community back together. In=20\r\naddition to all that, he has done more good for UT out of the limelight tha=\r\nn=20\r\nprobably most Texas fans realize.=20\r\n=09\r\n=09Brown is now in the same spotlight as Bobby Bowden, John Cooper, Lloyd C=\r\narr,=20\r\nSteve Spurrier and Phil Fulmer. Any unexpected losses are unforgivable in t=\r\nhe=20\r\neyes of fans. It may take some time for Brown and his team to adjust to tha=\r\nt.=20\r\nUNC fans were pretty ho-hum about everything the Tar Heels did in football,=\r\n=20\r\neven when they won big. Brown wanted to win at a school with huge=20\r\nexpectations. He'll have to adjust now that it appears Texas will be starti=\r\nng=20\r\nout the next few seasons in the Top 10.=20\r\n=09?\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09 Q: Is Lee Jackson out for the Houston game?=20\r\n=09?? Virginia Blair=20\r\n=09\r\n=09 BROWN:  Again, here are Mack's words: \"I said during the pre-season tha=\r\nt we=20\r\nwere overrated. I didn't see any reason with the youth, the way we finished=\r\n=20\r\nlast year and the inexperience across the board that we should have been a=\r\n=20\r\nTop 5 football team. One of the great things about Texas is that you receiv=\r\ne=20\r\na tremendous amount of attention and publicity, but in some cases people wa=\r\nnt=20\r\nto push you too fast to get to the top. I think that we were in that positi=\r\non=20\r\nand expectations got out of hand. I knew that we would have a difficult gam=\r\ne=20\r\nat Stanford and that it would be a tough game to win. I also didn't think=\r\n=20\r\nthat we deserved to be ranked fifth in the country. Our current rank within=\r\n=20\r\nthe Top 15 is much more fitting for where we are today.\" =20\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09\r\n=09 If you received this newsletter from a friend and would like to subscri=\r\nbe,=20\r\nsign up at:   Newsletter Registration=20\r\n=09\r\n=09To find or change your password, modify your account, or unsubscribe fro=\r\nm=20\r\nthis newsletter, go to:   Newsletter Registration =20\r\n=09\r\n=09Questions?         "body": "Part 3\n\nRecruiting Roundup\n\nToday (Monday) was the day the Longhorn coaches could start another big\nrecruiting push by going to top recruits' schools and homes, but the big game\nSaturday has pushed that back a week.\nBut don't worry about it. Coach Mack Brown wrote the book on recruiting and\nhis previous four classes at Texas have been very good, and some of them have\nbeen great.\nThis year's class has a chance to be as good as any Brown and his assistants\nhave signed. There's a chance it could be the best of the bunch, even better\nthan the top-rated Chris Simms, Cory Redding class.\nThey already have 16 commitments, about half of them from players who have\nbeen on at least one national top 100 list, and their class already is ranked\nas one of the top five in the nation.\nLet's take a look at where they are and where they are going:\nOFFENSE\nQuarterback\nUT has a commitment from Billy Don Malone of Paris North Lamar, who is a lot\nbetter than most of the gurus think, and the Horns have close to a 50-50 shot\nat Vincent Young, the wonder kid at Houston Madison, who had his usual game\nFriday for the undefeated Marlins, doing everything on offense and even\nrunning an interception back for a touchdown. (Yes, he plays defense, too,\nwhen needed.)\nRunning Back\nThe Horns have a commitment from Clint Haney of unbeaten Smithson Valley and\nare in the hunt for power-runner deluxe Albert Hardy of Galena Park and\nelusive Selvin Young of Jersey Village. They have an outside shot at Lorenzo\nBooker of Ventura, Cal., the nation's highest rated running back.\nTight End\nDavid Thomas of Wolfforth Frenship, a national top 100 player on some lists,\nis already committed. He is very good. The only other TE the Horns are\nrecruiting is Eric Winston, the humongous pass catcher and blocker deluxe at\nMidland Lee.\nWide Receiver\nNational top 100 star Marquis Johnson of Champaign, Ill., and Dustin Miksch\nof Round Rock Westwood are already committed. Robert Timmons of Flower Mound\nMarcus, a supremely talented player who has little playing experience because\nof transfer problems, is a possibility, and, if the Horns don't get him, they\nmight wind up with Biren Ealy of Cypress Falls or Anthony Wright of Klein\nForest.\nLine\nThe Horns already have a pledge from Neale Tweedie of Allen, a great pass\nblocker who is on several national top 100 lists, and from Brett Valdez of\nBrownwood, a tremendous run blocker.\nThey are still recruiting Justin Blalock of Plano East and Tony Ugoh of\nSpring Westfield. Blalock is the best run blocker I've seen this year.\nDEFENSE\nEnd\nChase Pittman of Shreveport Evangel, a national top 100 player, has committed\nand will enroll in January and go through spring training, which will give\nhim a chance to see action as a true freshman. The Longhorns are in the hunt\nfor Bryan Pickryl of Jenks, Okla., a speed rusher deluxe, Larry Dibbles of\nLancaster and Travis Leitko of The Woodlands. All three are on every national\ntop 100 list I've seen.\nTackle\nTexas has commitments from four top tackles - Sonny Davis of Gulf Coast\nCommunity College, a JC in Mississippi, Earl Anderson of San Marcos, Lyle\nSendlein of Scottsdale Chapaparral and Tully Jantzen of Keller. Davis has\nsome academic issues. Sendlein also is a very good offensive lineman and\nJantzen is swift enough to play end. Texas has a very good shot at Rodrique Wr\night of Alief Hastings, the nation's top DT, and at Marco Martin of Mesquite,\nanother national top 100 player. Kasey Studdard of Highlands Ranch, Colo, who\nexcels at DT and OG, also is a strong possibility. It's 50-50 on whether he\nwill play offense or defense in college. He is the son of David Studdard, a\nformer UT offensive line star who had a long career with the Denver Broncos.\nLinebacker\nTexas starts three seniors and needs a great group. Garnet Smith of Arlington\nLamar, Brian Robison of of Splendora and Marcus Myers of Pflugerville are\nalready committed and the Horns are still recruiting several top one from\nTexas and across the country. A. J. Nicholson of Winston Salem, N. C., and\nAaron Thomas of North Mesquite are national top 100 middle backers who are\nstrongly considering Texas, and Michael Williams of Lindale and Rufus\nAlexander of Baton Rouge Christian Life, are fast outside backers the Horns\nare recruiting. Another possibility is Lance Mitchell a top JC linebacker in\nCalifornia who ir orignally from Dallas. He is considering taking a visit.\nDefensive Backs\nMatt Melton, a hard-hitting safety from Tyler, is already committed. Swift\nEdorian McCullough of North Garland, the Class 5A 100 meter champ, also is\nconsidering Texas, along with Brodney Pool, a big, fast safety from Houston\nWestbury.\nKicker\nTexas is looking for a kicker, but has not homed in on one yet. The coaches\nwant someone who can kick off into the end zone consistently.\n\nLonghorn Basketball Adds Pair\n\nTwotop basketball recruits have signed with Texas, head coach Rick Barnes has\nannounced.\nBrad Buckman, a 6-9, 235-pound forward from Austin Westlake, and Kenton\nPaulino, 6-2, 165, a com bo guard from  Los Angeles Fremond HS who will play\nfor Maine Central Institute this season, are the new signees.\n\"Signing Brad and Kenton is another sign that our program is really on the\nrise,\" Barnes said.  \"Both have great athleticism and an attitude of winning\nabout them that we need to continue to bring to The University of Texas.\"\nBuckman plays for coach Clifton McNeely is at Westlake and is a national top\n30 recruit.\nThe No. 2 high school prospect in  Texas according to Mike Kunstadt's Texas\nHoops, Buckman averaged 19.8 points, 10.4 rebounds and 4.3 blocks per game\nduring his junior season.\nHe also is tabbed the No. 15 prospect in the nation by Clark Francis' Hoop\nScoop.  Buckman earned Most Outstanding Player honors at the prestigious\nPitt3 Five-Star Camp this July in Pittsburgh, Pa.\n\"There's not a program in the nation that did not go after Brad during the\nrecruiting period, so to come out on top in that battle is a huge win for\nus,\" Barnes said.\n\"Brad turned down four of the most storied programs in college basketball\nhistory for the opportunity to play at Texas.\" Barnes said.\n\"He made one of the biggest jumps in his game that I have seen during the\nsummer camp period.\nBrad has a tremendous competitive fire and is one of those players that fans\nhere will really appreciate.\"\nPaulino plays under coach Carl Hendrickson at Maine Central.  He starred at\nFremont High School under coach Sam Sullivan, where he averaged 24 points a\ngame and earned Los Angeles Co-Player of the Year accolades during his senior\ncampaign.\n\"Kenton is one of those explosive scoring guards that we need in our\nprogram,\" Barnes said.\n\"He is a very good shooter with range and an exceptional athlete who\nhigh-jumped 6-10 in high school. Kenton is the complete guard we were looking\nfor.\"\n\nHorns Sign 2 in Softball\n\nTexas softball coach Connie Clark has signed centerfielder Tina Boutelle of\nKaty Taylor and second baseman Chezare Sievers of Aliso Niguel HS in Mission\nViejo, Calif.\n\"We are excited about signing two of the top recruits in the country,\" Clark\nsaid. \"Tina and Chezare will be immediate impact players for us. We only lose\ntwo players to graduation in the spring of 2002 and are pleased to have Tina\nand Chezare as our newest additions to the softball program.\"\nBoutelle, a 5-5 left-handed hitter, was named first team All-American as a\njunior while helping her team to a 31-4 record and a second-place finish at\nthe Texas 5A State Championship.\nShe also is an All-District and All-Greater Houston selection. She was named\nto the Texas Girls Coaches Association All-State Team and first team Academic\nAll-District in 2000.\nBoutelle helped the Katy Cruisers club team to its second consecutive ASA\nGold National Championship in 2001, playing with UT freshmen pitcher Cat Os\nterman and third baseman/shortstop Tiffany Anders. With her addition, the\nLonghorns will have five players on the roster that have played for the Katy\nCruisers.\n\"Tina is definitely a long-ball threat,\" Clark said. \"She has tremendously\nquick hands and extremely good foot speed. Tina also is the type of player to\nmake things happen because she plays with a lot of passion and enthusiasm.\"\nSievers  finished her 2001 season with a .427 batting average and 19 RBIs.\nShe was named first team All-League and second team All-County as a junior.\nThe 5-0 infielder also was named first team All-California Interscholastic\nFederation (CIF) as a sophomore. She is a member of the California Cruisers\nclub team, which placed second at the 2001 ASA Gold National Championships to\nthe Katy Cruisers.\n\"Chez can cover a lot of ground,\" Clark said. \"She is an extra-base type of\nhitter who also has the ability to play the short game. Chez also has\ntremendously quick hands and I think fans will be excited to watch her play.\"\n\nLonghorn Women Start Fast\n\nSophomore center-forward Stacy Stephens led the Longhorn women's basketball\nteam to the championship of the Paradise Jam Tournament in St. Thomas last\nweekend.\nStephens was named the tourney MVP after leading Texas past Southern\nCalifornia, 66-64, in the championship game. She had 16 points and six of\nthem came in the final two minutes.\nFreshman Heather Schreiber was named to the All-Tournament Team after scoring\n13 points, and another freshman forward, Kala Bowers, had 10 points.\nStephens and senior point guard Kenya Larkin had led Texas to a 75-70 upset\nwin over No. 23 Wisconsin in the semifinals game Saturday.\nStephens had 17 points and 13 rebounds against the Badgers and Larkin added\n14 points and six assists. She also made four free throws in the final two\nminutes.\nThe Longhorns are off to a 3-0 start and host No. 19 LSU Thursday night.\n\nTexas Men 4th in Tourney\n\nThe Longhorn men lost to No. 20 Indiana, 77-71, Saturday in the third-place\ngame in the Great Alaska Shootout Tournament in Anchorage.\nFreshman point guard T. J. Ford led Texas with 16 points and eight assists.\nSenior forward Chris Owens, held scoreless in the first half, got 14 after i\nntermission.\nTexas lost to Gonzaga, 67-64, in the semifinals. Sophomore Royal Ivey had 15\npoints for the Longhorns.\n\nThe Perfect Christmas Present\nFor Horns Who Have Everything Else - A Gift Subscription to True Orange\nand/or the E-Mail/Fax\nA subscription to True Orange is the great gift you can give again and again.\nSure beats Christmas shopping, birthday shopping or anniversary shopping.\nThe only thing better is  a gift of  True Orange and the True Orange Fax  -\nand you can give both for just $130 a year ($99 if they take both by e-mail).\n\no  I am enclosing $45 for a gift subscription ($35 e-mail)\no  I am enclosing $130 for a gift subscription to the newsletter and the fax\n($99 e-mail)\n\nName of Recipient\n\nAddress (& fax no., if applicable)\n\nCity, State, Zip\n\nYour Name\n\nAny Message You Want on Card",

        "body": "Can we discuss? For future purposes only , we need to change our message a \nbit on power pools- the problem is not the existence of a pool through which \nall transactions clear in real-time( we like and want that),....rather, the \nproblem in California was exposing consumers and the utilities nakedly to the \nvolatility of the spot market by effectively  prohibiting hedging  contracts. \nThis is an important distinction and one we need to be clear on so we don't \ntrip over our advocacy and the desires of our commercial counterparts. \nThanks.,\n\n\n\n\nKaren Denne\n02/14/2001 02:25 PM\nTo: Vance Meyer/NA/Enron@ENRON, Meredith Philipp/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Peggy \nMahoney/HOU/EES@EES, Eric Thode/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Mark \nPalmer/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Jeff Dasovich/NA/Enron@Enron, Susan J \nMara/NA/Enron@ENRON, Sandra McCubbin/NA/Enron@Enron, Richard \nShapiro/NA/Enron@Enron, James D Steffes/NA/Enron@Enron, Steven J \nKean/NA/Enron@Enron, Paul Kaufman/PDX/ECT@ECT, Harry \nKingerski/NA/Enron@Enron, Hedy Govenar <hgovenar@govadv.com>, Mike Day \n<MDay@GMSSR.com>, Bev Hansen <bhansen@lhom.com>, jkradin@marathon-com.com, \nsyamane@marathon-com.com, rlichtenstein@marathon-com.com\ncc:  \n\nSubject: San Francisco Chronicle Op-Ed\n\nAttached is the op-ed by Ken Lay we've submitted to the San Francisco \nChronicle, at their request.         "body": "  \nRedskins to stick with Johnson at quarterback \n Sept. 19, 2000\nBy Len Pasquarelli\nSportsLine.com Senior Writer\n \n\n\n\nDespite the continuing struggles of the offense and costly fourth-quarter \ninterceptions by Brad Johnson, the Washington Redskins will stick with their \nstarting quarterback for Sunday night's game against the New York Giants, \nSportsLine.com has confirmed. \n\n\"If it was just (a problem) with Brad, then we'd look at it, but that's not \nthe case,\" coach Norv Turner said. \"But it goes beyond just the quarterback \nposition. It's more than that. We're not playing well on offense in general.\" \n\n   \nRedskins quarterback Brad Johnson will remain the team's starter against the \nunbeaten Giants.(AP)   \n\nIn the wake of the Redskins' 27-21 loss to the Dallas Cowboys on Monday \nnight, there were rumblings Washington might switch to backup Jeff George for \nthe key matchup against the undefeated Giants. The Washington offense, one of \nthe league's most diverse in 1999 when it ranked No. 2 overall and second in \nscoring, has been sporadic at best in three games. \n\nA seventh-year veteran who is in the final season of his contract, Johnson \nhas five interceptions the last two games, including four in the fourth \nquarters of those losses. He has not been sharp in either his play-calling or \nhis execution, and even some teammates suggested privately Monday night that \nit might be time for a change. \n\nOne glaring shortcoming has been the inability of the Washington offense to \nthrow the deep ball and stretch opposition secondaries. The Redskins have \nonly three completions this year of more than 20 yards, and the longest is 26 \nyards. In Monday's defeat, the team's longest play was a 17-yard dumpoff to \ntailback Stephen Davis. \n\nThe Redskins, who averaged 12.7 yards per completion in 1999 with both \nstarting wide receivers averaging 18-plus yards, are averaging an anemic 9.2 \nyards per catch this season. \n\nBut Turner, who sources said was reluctant to make a quarterback change at \nthis point and retains confidence in Johnson, acknowledged the team needs new \nfocus more than a new starter. \n\n\"There hasn't been any thought to switching (quarterbacks),\" he said. \"Right \nnow, we need to get better at every position, quarterback and everywhere \nelse.\" \n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n\n\n\"Bass, Jason\" <Jason.Bass2@COMPAQ.com> on 09/20/2000 08:29:53 AM\nTo: \"'Eric Bass'\" <Eric.Bass@enron.com>\ncc:  \nSubject: RE: TV\n\n\nJeff George , QB WAS - The Snake Pit Updated 09/19/00\nSepculation is increasing that George may get a chance to start after Brad\nJohnson struggled against Dallas.         "body": "Some thoughts for folks to think about in advance of Friday:\n\n1.  Decision is great on defining LRMC-adopt ARM/ORA vs. UDCs\n2.  Decision identifies specific adjustments to ORA from Utilities, but \ndoesn't identify specific adjustments to ORA from ARM (which Dan has done) \nand which we can point to in comments. The table that compares all proposals \nis excellent!  (It's in Dan's memo) That is a great cross-reference.\n3.  Need to determine whether we support an average for the state, or \nutility-specific.  Which will be more defensible?  I think utility specific.\n4.  I have some challenges to the adjustments that Neeper ultimately adopted.\n5.  The decision requires that the utility procurement function interact with \nthe other utility functions on a comparable basis as ESPs, including access \nto information.  (Good decision language.  Don't know how to enforce.)\n\nHere is a table summarizing the thought process of the revised alternate \ndecision.  ORA-ADJ UDC, is the adjustments to ORA's proposal incorporating \ncriticisms of the UDCs.  The next line (ORA-ADJ ACCPT) are those UDC \ncriticisms accepted by Neeper.  The last is the machinations to average and \nincorporate a bump for ARM's participation.  \n\nCents per MWh\n\n\tPG&E\tSCE\tSDG&E\nUDC\t0\t.02\t3\nORA\t48\t40\t15\nARM\t59\t67\t65\nORA-ADJ UDC\t18\t.8\t6\nORA-ADJ ACCPT\t48\t28\t13\nDECISION-AVG+\t32\t32\t32\n\nI think the items that Dan has identified will provide more than a 2 cent/MWh \nadjustment, so worth quantifying for the record.  These include adjustment \nfor common costs and overheads (FF#27), which ORA said we did a better job \nthan they had.  Also, ARM's itemization of procurement related costs, which \nORA seemed to agree with, is more extensive. \n\n\nChallenges to Adjustments Adopted by Neeper (ORA-ADJ ACCPT)\n\nSDG&E-(pg. 37)\n1. Discounts PG&E's \ncriticism on customer service costs citing to the RAP decision that those \ncosts should be included in the PX credit.\n\nThis seems to be the best place to advocate use of our numbers over ORA's.  \nWe did a PG&E specific study, which I think would be a valid criticism to \nORA's numbers.  \n\nSCE-(pg.39)\nWould reduce ORA's Energy Service and Marketing costs from $12.3 to $4 \nmillion, because it includes costs related to supply from generation \nsources.  Would reduce Customer Service and Information from $21.1 milion to \n$7.7 million saying that is the amount of CS&I the Commission had allocated \nto generation. Law To Delay Portland General Sale\r\nDow Jones News Service, 02/15/2001\r\n\r\nCrt Postpones Hearing On CalPX Back-Billing Suppliers\r\nDow Jones Energy Service, 02/15/2001\r\n=20\r\nJudge Resets Enron Hearing, Cites Expected Federal Decision\r\nBloomberg News, 02/15/2001\r\n\r\nTexas Pilot Project for Electricity Competition Begins Today\r\nKnight-Ridder Tribune, 02/15/2001\r\n\r\nOil Majors Seek Details on Saudi Gas Projects\r\nReuters, 02/15/2001\r\n\r\nHouston Roundup\r\nChemical Business NewsBase, 02/15/2001\r\n\r\nUSA: INTERVIEW-NYMEX Head Says No Regrets Over Online Strategy\r\nReuters, 02/15/2001\r\n=20\r\nMacerich Puts Two Shopping Centers Up For Sale\r\nDow Jones News Service, 02/15/2001\r\n\r\nUSA: NY Gold Drops to 17-Mth Low Amid Hedging, 1999 low eyed\r\nReuters, 02/15/2001\r\n\r\nEnron Does Not Rule Out Combined-Cycle Power Plant (La empresa no renuncia =\r\nal=20\r\ncicle combinado)=20\r\nExpansion, 02/14/2001\r\n\r\n---------------------------------------------------------------------------=\r\n---\r\n-----------------------------------------------------------------------\r\n\r\nEnron CEO: Calif. Law To Delay Portland General Sale\r\nBy Christina Cheddar\r\nOf DOW JONES NEWSWIRES\r\n\r\n02/15/2001\r\nDow Jones News Service=20\r\n\r\nNEW YORK -(Dow Jones)- Enron Corp. (ENE) Chief Executive Kenneth Lay said a=\r\n=20\r\nCalifornia law has had the unintended effect of delaying Enron's sale of it=\r\ns=20\r\nPortland General unit to Sierra Pacific Resources (SRP).=20\r\n\r\nAt the end of January, California legislators ordered the state's utilities=\r\n=20\r\nnot to sell power plants before January 2006. The new law might prevent=20\r\nSierra Pacific Power, a unit of Sierra Pacific Resources, from selling its=\r\n=20\r\npower plants because it serves 40,000 customers in California's Lake Tahoe=\r\n=20\r\narea.\r\n\r\nSierra Pacific was trying to sell the assets to finance its acquisition of=\r\n=20\r\nPortland General, Lay said. Sierra Pacific is attempting to get a=20\r\nclarification of the legislation from California authorities, he said.=20\r\n\r\nLay's confidence level regarding the company's ability to close the Portlan=\r\nd=20\r\nGeneral sale remains \"pretty high, but it's not 98 percent,\" he said.=20\r\n\r\nLay said the delayed sale will not hurt the company's earnings performance.=\r\n=20\r\nIn fact, Lay expects Portland General to add to its earnings.=20\r\nLay was speaking at the UBS Warburg Energy Conference here Thursday.=20\r\n\r\nWhen asked if credit risks in California could affect Enron's earnings, Lay=\r\n=20\r\nresponded there is no scenario in the state that would make the company=20\r\nunable to reach its $1.70 to $1.75 a share earnings estimate for 2001.=20\r\n\r\nLay explained that the company is taking measures to mitigate its credit=20\r\nrisk. California's two largest utilities, Southern California Edison Co. an=\r\nd=20\r\nPacific Gas and Electric Co., have been heading toward insolvency after=20\r\npurchasing power in the state's deregulated markets at higher prices than t=\r\nhe=20\r\nutilities could charge their customers.=20\r\n\r\nMost of Enron's credit risk in California comes from the selling of gas and=\r\n=20\r\nelectric power in the state through its wholesale services operation.=20\r\n\r\n\"There's quite a mess out there, and we hope that eventually, that mess wil=\r\nl=20\r\nget worked out,\" Lay said.=20\r\n\r\nDuring his presentation, Lay also discussed the success of EnronOnline. He=\r\n=20\r\nsaid EnronOnline has reduced the average cost per trading transaction by 75=\r\n%,=20\r\nas well as help the company increase its trading volumes. Enron, of Houston=\r\n,=20\r\ntrades a variety of commodities, including gas, electric, pulp and paper, a=\r\nnd=20\r\nbroadband capacity through EnronOnline.=20\r\n\r\n-By Christina Cheddar, Dow Jones Newswires; 201-938-5166;=20\r\nchristina.cheddar@dowjones.com\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCrt Postpones Hearing On CalPX Back-Billing Suppliers\r\n\r\n02/15/2001\r\nDow Jones Energy Service=20\r\n\r\nLOS ANGELES -(Dow Jones)- A U.S. District Court Judge has postponed until=\r\n=20\r\nTuesday hearing arguments in a case involving Enron Corp.'s (ENE) request=\r\n=20\r\nthat the California Power Exchange not be able to charge the company for=20\r\nelectricity bills defaulted on by the state's two largest utilities, a=20\r\nspokesperson for the CalPX said Thursday.=20\r\n\r\nThe judge also extended until Tuesday a temporary order barring the CalPX=\r\n=20\r\nfrom billing Enron for the utilities' defaults until the case is heard.\r\n\r\nOther power marketers and generators have similar lawsuits filed in federal=\r\n=20\r\ncourt and with the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission.=20\r\n\r\nAt issue is a \"chargeback\" insurance mechanism that is meant to maintain=20\r\nparticipants' confidence in the exchange. Under the mechanism, defaults by=\r\n=20\r\nCalPX debtors are proportionally \"charged back\" to creditors based on their=\r\n=20\r\nlevel of participation in the exchange in the three months prior to the=20\r\ndefault.=20\r\n\r\nSources close to the case said they believed the court was waiting for acti=\r\non=20\r\nfrom the FERC before continuing with the case. However, this couldn't be=20\r\nimmediately confirmed.=20\r\n\r\nFERC has received a complaint about chargebacks from nine power suppliers.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nJudge Resets Enron Hearing, Cites Expected Federal Decision\r\nBloomberg News, 02/15/2001\r\n\r\nJudge Resets Enron Hearing, Cites Expected Federal Decision\r\n\r\nLos Angeles, Feb. 15 (Bloomberg) -- A federal judge rescheduled a hearing o=\r\nn=20\r\nwhether California's power market should be kept from billing its members,=\r\n=20\r\nmostly energy suppliers, because utilities owned by PG&E Corp. and Edison=\r\n=20\r\nInternational have defaulted on payments.\r\n\r\nU.S. District Judge Carlos Moreno continued the hearing to Feb. 20 at 4 p.m=\r\n.=20\r\nA temporary order issued last week to prevent the California Power Exchange=\r\n=20\r\nelectricity market from billing members such as Enron Corp. will be extende=\r\nd=20\r\nuntil the hearing.\r\n\r\nPG&E and Edison International have defaulted on at least $789 million in=20\r\ndebts; under exchange rules, all members can be charged when one defaults.\r\n\r\nEnron sued in Los Angeles federal court Jan. 31. Other generators -- Avista=\r\n=20\r\nCorp., Enova Corp.'s San Diego Gas & Electric, Sempra Energy, British=20\r\nColumbia Hydro & Power Authority's Powerex Corp. and ScottishPower Plc=20\r\nPacifiCorp =01) also went to court. Moreno indicated last week he will=20\r\nconsolidate all of the claims into Enron's complaint.\r\n\r\nMoreno extended his order to give the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission=\r\n=20\r\nmore time to issue its own ruling on whether the Power Exchange can charge=\r\n=20\r\nall its members when one defaults. Nine generators filed their complaint wi=\r\nth=20\r\nthe agency Feb. 8.\r\n\r\n--Joyzelle Davis in Los Angeles (213) 617-3855, or\r\njoydavis@bloomberg.net, through the San Francisco newsroom/gcb\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTexas Pilot Project for Electricity Competition Begins Today\r\nTerry Maxon\r\n\r\n02/15/2001\r\nKRTBN Knight-Ridder Tribune Business News: The Dallas Morning News - Texas=\r\n=20\r\nCopyright (C) 2001 KRTBN Knight Ridder Tribune Business News; Source: World=\r\n=20\r\nReporter (TM)=20\r\n\r\nSo, you're mad about your electricity bill and wish you could change to=20\r\nanother electricity company? Starting Thursday, a lot of Texans can tell=20\r\ntheir current electric company to get lost, and the customers probably will=\r\n=20\r\nlower their electric rates as well.\r\n\r\nThe state is kicking off a pilot program to see how competition in its=20\r\nelectricity markets will work. Thursday is the first day that 19 companies=\r\n=20\r\nwill be allowed to begin signing up customers.=20\r\n\r\nJune 1 is the first day that these power companies can begin providing=20\r\nelectricity to customers who decide to switch. The three and a half months=\r\n=20\r\nuntil then will be used to market their services and sign up customers.=20\r\n\r\nThe limited test will allow 5 percent of all utility customers to pick thei=\r\nr=20\r\nelectricity company -- either their current company or one of many others=\r\n=20\r\nthat have signed up to sell electricity in Texas.=20\r\n\r\nThe test is a dress rehearsal for Jan. 1, when all customers of Texas=20\r\n\"investor-owned utilities\" -- companies such as TXU Electric, Reliant Energ=\r\ny=20\r\nInc. and Texas-New Mexico Power Co. -- will have a chance to take their=20\r\nbusiness elsewhere.=20\r\n\r\n\"In essence, it's to see that all the rules and ramifications of=20\r\nrestructuring are working properly,\" said Terry Hadley, spokesman for the=\r\n=20\r\nPublic Utility Commission of Texas. \"If there are any bugs, we want to find=\r\n=20\r\nout before the full launch Jan. 1.\"=20\r\n\r\nState officials were already nervous about their grand experiment in free=\r\n=20\r\nmarkets, but the current debacle in California has them even more on edge.=\r\n=20\r\n\r\nCalifornia, which partially deregulated its electricity markets several yea=\r\nrs=20\r\nago, now has two public utilities teetering on the edge of bankruptcy and=\r\n=20\r\nunable to pay for electricity they bought. Homes and businesses have faced=\r\n=20\r\nrolling blackouts as the state at times hasn't been able to scrape up enoug=\r\nh=20\r\nelectricity to meet demand.=20\r\n\r\nWhile the Public Utility Commission and others have repeatedly said that=20\r\nTexas won't repeat the California experience, they're looking to the pilot=\r\n=20\r\nprogram to expose any flaws.=20\r\n\r\nFor the first month, the state and electric providers will concentrate on=\r\n=20\r\ncommercial customers. In mid-March, they'll turn their attention to home=20\r\ncustomers.=20\r\n\r\nHowever, Public Utility Commission chairman Pat Wood III said both=20\r\nresidential and commercial customers may sign up beginning Thursday.=20\r\n\r\nCommercial users must go through a lottery to be chosen, and the 5 percent=\r\n=20\r\nwill be based on total commercial electricity used.=20\r\n\r\nResidential customers will be added on a first-come, first-picked basis, wi=\r\nth=20\r\nthe cutoff after 5 percent of all residential customers have volunteered fo=\r\nr=20\r\nthe program.=20\r\n\r\nA key to the Texas program is the \"price to beat,\" the basic rate that the=\r\n=20\r\nutilities can charge. That price will be a 6 percent reduction from the=20\r\nelectric rates charged by the utilities before the pilot program begins.=20\r\n\r\nThe investor-owned utilities also include Central Power & Light, Southweste=\r\nrn=20\r\nElectric Power Co., Entergy, SESCO and Southwestern Public Service Co.=20\r\n\r\nOther companies can charge whatever they please, but as Mr. Hadley noted,=\r\n=20\r\nthey probably won't get too far charging more than the \"price-to-beat\" rate=\r\ns=20\r\nof the utilities.=20\r\n\r\nWhen the Texas Legislature passed Senate Bill 7 in 1999 to start retail=20\r\ncompetition in electricity, the price-to-beat rate was set up to give=20\r\ncompetitors a chance to compete against the entrenched utilities.=20\r\n\r\nMr. Hadley said the price to beat provides other electric retailers=20\r\n\"something to work against.\" In addition, the 6 percent reduction from the=\r\n=20\r\nutilities' current rates would be \"enough of a cut to provide a customer a=\r\n=20\r\nbenefit, but not so low as to prevent competition,\" he said.=20\r\n\r\nOf course, the utilities don't have their hands tied in areas outside their=\r\n=20\r\ncurrent monopoly territory, and most plan to compete aggressively for=20\r\ncustomers.=20\r\n\r\nFor example, TNP Enterprises Inc., parent of Texas-New Mexico Power, has=20\r\ncreated a subsidiary, First Choice Power Inc., to lead its fight in the=20\r\nelectric wars.=20\r\n\r\nJim Niewald, First Choice director of marketing, said the company will use=\r\n=20\r\nthe pilot period as a learning time, to test ways to compete and to market=\r\n=20\r\nits products.=20\r\n\r\n\"We're going to take a sort of moderate approach. We're not going to be rea=\r\nl=20\r\naggressive. On the other hand, we're not going to be sitting back totally,\"=\r\n=20\r\nMr. Niewald said.=20\r\n\r\nTXU spokesman Chris Schein said the Dallas-based company sees the pilot=20\r\nperiod as a time to work out kinks and discover if there are any inherent=\r\n=20\r\nproblems in the way that electricity competition in Texas works.=20\r\n\r\n\"It's important to remember that the pilot program is less of a marketing=\r\n=20\r\nevent than it is an opportunity for TXU and the rest of the state to test=\r\n=20\r\nsystems. The real marketing opportunity begins Jan. 1, 2002,\" Mr. Schein=20\r\nsaid.=20\r\n\r\n\"We are treating this as an opportunity to make sure our systems are=20\r\ncommunicating with all the state's systems to make the customers' choosing=\r\n=20\r\nprocess as seamless as possible,\" he said.=20\r\n\r\nWhile TXU will be trying to sign up customers in the parts of Texas that it=\r\n=20\r\ndoesn't now serve, it also has to deal with the price-to-beat rate freeze=\r\n=20\r\nthat will keep it from offering discounts in its current service area,=20\r\nincluding Dallas-Fort Worth, Central Texas and other spots.=20\r\n\r\nTXU is hoping that its existing customers want more than the lowest price,=\r\n=20\r\nMr. Schein said, \"in the same way that not every customer chooses a car bas=\r\ned=20\r\non price. If that were true, Kia would be the best-selling car in the U.S.\"=\r\n=20\r\n\r\nTXU will be promoting its quality of service and a package of bundled=20\r\nservices that it hopes will be attractive. For those who care about the=20\r\nenvironment, TXU will offer \"green power,\" or electricity generated by wind=\r\n=20\r\nor other nonfossil sources.=20\r\n\r\nAlso entering the fray will be Green Mountain Energy Co., which sells nothi=\r\nng=20\r\nbut green power.=20\r\n\r\n\"We are looking forward to bringing Texans the opportunity to support clean=\r\ner=20\r\nair by purchasing power made from cleaner and renewable sources,\" Green=20\r\nMountain chief executive officer Dennis Kelly said in a prepared statement.=\r\n=20\r\n\r\n\"One of the most powerful benefits of electric choice is the ability for=20\r\npeople to choose how their power is made,\" he said.=20\r\n\r\n\"As more people understand that making electricity causes more air pollutio=\r\nn=20\r\nthan any other industry,\" he continued, \"they will look for a simple way to=\r\n=20\r\npurchase electricity that includes clean renewable sources like wind, sun a=\r\nnd=20\r\nhydropower.\"=20\r\n\r\nEnron Corp., the Houston energy giant, has three companies that will compet=\r\ne=20\r\nfor customers in the deregulated world.=20\r\n\r\nTwo of its subsidiaries will target large customers: Enron Power Marketing=\r\n=20\r\nInc. will sell to wholesale customers such as utilities and other electric=\r\n=20\r\nretailers, and Enron Energy Services Inc. will go after large commercial an=\r\nd=20\r\nindustrial customers.=20\r\n\r\nFor residential customers and small businesses, Enron has teamed up with IB=\r\nM=20\r\nCorp. and America Online to sell electricity through the New Power Company.=\r\n=20\r\nNew Power is part of New Power Holdings Inc., a public company.=20\r\n\r\n\"Different customers need different products, so we've created specialized=\r\n=20\r\nbusinesses for what the market needs,\" Enron spokesman Mark Palmer said.=20\r\n\r\nFor big customers, Enron can afford real-time pricing that charges less for=\r\n=20\r\noff-peak periods, more for peak periods.=20\r\n\r\nIt can offer discounts for customers who agree to have their electricity=20\r\ninterrupted when needed.=20\r\n\r\nHowever, residential customers mainly want to see a fixed, cheap rate, Mr.=\r\n=20\r\nPalmer said.=20\r\n\r\n\"Homeowners aren't interested in real-time prices, interruptible service or=\r\n=20\r\nincentives to shut down,\" he said.=20\r\n\r\nOthers who have received state certification or are awaiting approval are=\r\n=20\r\nReliant Energy Retail Services LLC and Reliant Energy Solutions, associated=\r\n=20\r\nwith Houston-based utility Reliant; Shell Energy; AES NewEnergy Inc.; Enter=\r\ngy=20\r\nSolutions Ltd.; Sempra Energy Solutions; and Xcel Energy.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nOil Majors Seek Details on Saudi Gas Projects\r\n02/15/2001\r\n\r\nLONDON, Feb
