He steps down from the helm of the world's=20\r\nbiggest physical commodity exchange next month.=20\r\n\r\n\"I agonized over (the decision to step down) for a long time,\" he said. \"Bu=\r\nt=20\r\nI just wasn't prepared to sign on and commit for another three years.\"=20\r\n\r\nNYMEX, along with its COMEX subsidiary, trades futures and options contract=\r\ns=20\r\non crude oil, heating oil, unleaded gasoline, gold, silver, natural gas,=20\r\nelectricity, copper and aluminum.=20\r\n\r\nenymex will first offer trading in crude oil, petroleum products and natura=\r\nl=20\r\ngas. Later it will expand to electricity, coal, metals and other products.=\r\n=20\r\n\r\nenymex is well positioned to succeed, Rappaport said. Among its advantages=\r\n=20\r\nare the NYMEX brand, liquidity from NYMEX traders and clearing services.=20\r\n\r\n\"Not a single exchange from those now operating online offers real clearing=\r\n,\"=20\r\nhe said.=20\r\n\r\nIn a field of more than 30 Internet energy exchanges, observers usually poi=\r\nnt=20\r\nto Enron Corp.'s EnronOnline (www.enrononline.com) and ICE (www.intcx.com) =\r\nas=20\r\nsuccess stories so far. But Rappaport counts neither as competitors enymex=\r\n=20\r\nhas to worry about.=20\r\n\r\nEnronOnline trades an average of $3.5 billion a day, but does not accept=20\r\nthird party trades, so Rappaport doesn't put it in the same category as=20\r\nenymex.=20\r\n\r\nICE has enough liquidity to be a leader among fledgling independent online=\r\n=20\r\nexchange, but its numbers are far from those of an established exchange lik=\r\ne=20\r\nNYMEX.=20\r\n\r\nIn its first week trading crude options this year, ICE traded 3 million=20\r\nbarrels. NYMEX routinely trades more than 400 million barrels of crude in a=\r\n=20\r\nsingle day.=20\r\n\r\nThat's exactly the kind of competition the partners in ICE hoped to elimina=\r\nte=20\r\nwhen they invited NYMEX to join the venture early last year, Rappaport said=\r\n.=20\r\n\r\n\"Legally, we wouldn't have been able to launch enymex if we were part of=20\r\nICE,\" he explained.=20\r\n\r\nWith backing from some of the world's leading energy firms, ICE is in talks=\r\n=20\r\nwith London's International Petroleum Exchange (IPE) for a possible merger,=\r\n=20\r\nin a move designed to attract more liquidity to the fledgling online=20\r\nexchange.=20\r\n\r\nAfter a failed hostile takeover a few years ago, NYMEX has itself reiterate=\r\nd=20\r\nits interest in buying a controlling stake in the IPE this year, but only i=\r\nf=20\r\nthe London exchange welcomes such a move. So far, the IPE has not signaled=\r\n=20\r\nthat it would accept NYMEX's overtures, Rappaport said.=20\r\n\r\nNEW CHAIRMAN TO TAKE NYMEX TO IPO=20\r\nUnder Rappaport, NYMEX demutualized and became a for-profit organization la=\r\nst=20\r\nyear.=20\r\nThe new chairman, to be elected March 20, will have to lead the exchange=20\r\nthrough a private placement and on to an IPO.=20\r\n\r\n\"The new chairman has to go on a road show to sell the exchange,\" Rappaport=\r\n=20\r\nsaid.=20\r\nNYMEX will offer a 10 percent stake in itself in the private placement, in =\r\na=20\r\nmove to gauge the value of the exchange, Rappaport said.=20\r\n\r\nLong-time NYMEX insiders Vincent Viola and Gerald Rafferty are running for=\r\n=20\r\nthe chairman position.=20\r\n\r\nViola is a former floor trader and vice-chairman of NYMEX who owns the New=\r\n=20\r\nYork brokerage firm Pioneer Futures.=20\r\n\r\nRafferty has been a member of NYMEX for 30 years. He owns the Rafferty Ener=\r\ngy=20\r\nGroup, which in turn owns two brokerage companies.=20\r\n\r\nAs for Mr Rappaport, he said he'll spend more time with his family, as well=\r\n=20\r\nas take on other unspecified projects.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nMacerich Puts Two Shopping Centers Up For Sale\r\nBy Pat Maio\r\nOf DOW JONES NEWSWIRES\r\n\r\n02/15/2001\r\nDow Jones News Service\r\n(Copyright (c) 2001, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)\r\n\r\nLOS ANGELES -(Dow Jones)- Macerich Co. (MAC) is selling two shopping center=\r\ns=20\r\nin California, according to a shopping center trade report Thursday.=20\r\n\r\nThe real estate investment trust plans to sell Villa Marina Marketplace in=\r\n=20\r\nMarina del Rey and the Carmel Plaza in Carmel, according to a newswire repo=\r\nrt=20\r\nby the New York-based International Council of Shopping Centers.\r\n\r\nMacerich, Santa Monica, Calif., which owns interests in 46 malls totaling=\r\n=20\r\nmore than 41.5 million square feet, plans to use proceeds from the sale to=\r\n=20\r\nrepurchase shares.=20\r\n\r\nMacerich executives were not immediately available for comment.=20\r\n\r\nMacerich is also trimming energy costs. On Wednesday, the company signed a=\r\n=20\r\n10-year energy management contract with Enron Corp.'s (ENE) energy services=\r\n=20\r\nbusiness. Enron will manage the supply of electricity and natural gas and=\r\n=20\r\nprovide energy management services to the majority of the company's malls.=\r\n=20\r\n\r\nSeparately, Stichting Pensioenfonds ABP, a Netherlands investment firm,=20\r\nraised its stake in Macerich to 8.18% from 5%, according to a Securities an=\r\nd=20\r\nExchange Commission filing on Thursday.=20\r\n\r\nShares of Macerich recently traded Thursday at $20.99, up 25 cents, on volu=\r\nme=20\r\nof 52,600 shares, compared with daily average volume of 191,000 shares.=20\r\n\r\n-By Pat Maio, Dow Jones Newswires; 323-658-3776; patrick.maio@dowjones.com\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nUSA: NY Gold Drops to 17-Mth Low Amid Hedging, 1999 low eyed\r\n\r\n02/15/2001\r\nReuters English News Service\r\n(C) Reuters Limited 2001.\r\n\r\nNEW YORK, Feb 15 (Reuters) - Gold futures slid below $260 an ounce in New=\r\n=20\r\nYork Thursday, hitting contract and 17-month spot basis lows as producer an=\r\nd=20\r\nfund selling sent small speculators who had bought earlier rushing for the=\r\n=20\r\nexits.=20\r\n\r\n\"It seems to be spread around,\" said bullion dealer Bernard Penner at Enron=\r\n=20\r\nMetals. \"Some of the U.S. banks as well as the larger U.S. merchants have=\r\n=20\r\ncertainly put their imprimatur on this.\"\r\n\r\nDealers said a strengthening dollar got the ball rolling in the morning,=20\r\nadding to pessimism in the gold market. The current mood has been likened t=\r\no=20\r\nthat of 1999, when bullion hit a 20-year low just $4 below Thursday's late=\r\n=20\r\nspot price.=20\r\n\r\nApril gold fell $4.30, settling at $256.90 an ounce, up a bit from a contra=\r\nct=20\r\nlow at $256.30.=20\r\n\r\nThe move accelerated after midday, when stop-loss orders were triggered on=\r\n=20\r\nbreaking the morning low around $259. Estimated volume was a heavy 40,000=\r\n=20\r\ncontracts.=20\r\n\r\n\"When it broke the lows, the locals got out of their longs,\" said Donald=20\r\nTierney of Pell Brothers Trading.=20\r\n\r\n\"We had some stops and a vacuum. That's why you had the new lows.\"=20\r\n\r\nOn the spot continuation charts, gold futures bottomed at $255.60, the lowe=\r\nst=20\r\nsince Sept 20, 1999, following bullion's fall to a 16-month low fix at=20\r\n$258.55 in late London trade. Spot bullion closed at $255.75/6.25, down fro=\r\nm=20\r\nWednesday's close at $259.75/0.25.=20\r\n\r\nDealers said gold companies had been selling forward and using options=20\r\nstrategies to protect the price of their unmined gold reserves, which=20\r\nconsequently burrowed spot prices deeper into troublesome territory for the=\r\n=20\r\nstruggling industry.=20\r\n\r\nThe price of gold is already below the cost of production for less efficien=\r\nt=20\r\nproducers and at $250 an ounce would be near the average break-even for eve=\r\nn=20\r\nsome low-cost mining companies.=20\r\n\r\n\"They continue to keep it under pressure. It looks like some producer hedgi=\r\nng=20\r\nmuch earlier in the day that came to be hedged or sold out during the balan=\r\nce=20\r\nof in day,\" said Penner, meaning dealers were still going to the market to=\r\n=20\r\ncover hedges done by their customers.=20\r\n\r\nAlso like late 1999, overselling this year means there are few bears left t=\r\no=20\r\nkeep up the attacks on gold.=20\r\n\r\nOn the COMEX, the last time gold was near this oversold was September 1999,=\r\n=20\r\nwhen bullion was around that August's 20-year low at $251.70 an ounce. It=\r\n=20\r\nthen skyrocketed $80 to $338 on short covering by overhedged mining compani=\r\nes=20\r\nand speculators.=20\r\n\r\nTraders await the weekly Commitments of Traders report from the Commodity=\r\n=20\r\nFutures Trading Commission Friday afternoon to see if funds have added to=\r\n=20\r\nlast Tuesday's hefty 52,706-contract (164 tonne) net short position.=20\r\n\r\nMeanwhile, price sensitive consumers have also sought bargains below $260 a=\r\nn=20\r\nounce. Fears about Indian demand falling sharply have abated a bit, as the=\r\n=20\r\ntop-consuming nation starts the long process of recovery from last month's=\r\n=20\r\nearthquake.=20\r\n\r\nMarch silver briefly caught gold's downdraft, then steadied above a slight=\r\n=20\r\nnew contract and 3-1/2-year continuation low at $4.49. It ended up 0.3 cent=\r\n=20\r\nat $4.518.=20\r\n\r\nSpot silver fixed at a 6-week low at $4.515 an ounce and was last at=20\r\n$4.51/53, unchanged from Wednesday's close.=20\r\n\r\nDealers said the jittery silver market seemed content to range trade in the=\r\n=20\r\nshort-term within reach of the early January bottom at $4.48, bullion's=20\r\ncheapest price since August 1997.=20\r\n\r\nNYMEX March palladium rose $9.85 to $985 an ounce. Spot palladium was last=\r\n=20\r\nshown at $975/$995. April platinum rose $2.70 to $595.10 an ounce. Spot=20\r\nplatinum last fetched $595.10/601.10.\r\n\r\n\r\nEnron Does Not Rule Out Combined-Cycle Power Plant (La empresa no renuncia =\r\nal=20\r\ncicle combinado)=20\r\nExpansion, Feb 14, 2001\r\n\r\nEnron, the US energy group, has not ruled out plans to build a combined-cyc=\r\nle=20\r\npower plant in Mora la Nova, in Tarragona in Spain. The company announced i=\r\nts=20\r\ndecision yesterday after local authorities imposed a three-month moratorium=\r\n=20\r\non the project for the completion of environmental impact studies.\r\n=20\r\nThe company said that it will take advantage of the three-month moratorium =\r\nto=20\r\nlisten to local communities and explain details of the project to local=20\r\nresidents and interested parties.         "body": "Dotty:  Thought you and Jack might be interested in this report.\n\nJeff: How do we go about getting  in touch with the person you mentioned to\ndo the tiles?\n\n-----Original Message-----\nFrom:  gmc [mailto:gmc@mcn.org]\nSent: Wednesday, February 14, 2001 12:30 PM\nTo: eldon@interx.net\nSubject: Roseman Creek fireplace\n\nHello, Eldon...\nYour fireplace was improperly installed, and the fire was caused by embers\nfalling in between the fireplace and the hearth, igniting the plywood\nunderlayment and the wooden framing installed in front of the face and the\nheader above the fireplace opening.  There should be no combustible material\nthere, and sooner or later a fire will result.  You are fortunate the result\nwas not worse.  The important metal underlayment supplied with the fireplace\nwas not installed.  The fireplace must be moved about 5\" up to the face of\nthe wall.  All the tile must be removed and replaced with non combustible\nunderlayment.  The chimney seems ok but you must replace the cap and the\nchimney is no longer available, necessitating fireplace replacement if it\never becomes necessary due to corrosion.  The insulation is probably wet,\nwhich happens over the years and it settles, leaving hot spots in the\nchimney.  At least yours is out in the air, but it should be checked, and\nwill be if I do this job.\nYou will provide the tile, and bear in mind that some will have to be cut,\nso avoid small tiles.  You will also provide sanded grout and grout\nadditive, and a mastic (25#) such as epoxy \"Elastobon\".  Your tile supplier\nwill know what we're talking about.  I will get all other materials locally.\nYou are looking at, I estimate, $2,400.00 - $3,200.00 plus materials.  I\nprefer to work jobs like this at Time and Materials, based on my labor rate\nof $50.00 per man hour.  If I have to bid this job, it will be suitably\ninflated to deal with unforeseen variables.  I have been here for 26 years\nwithout any construction related problems, and have lots of references.\nThe materials will consist of cedar shingles, plywood, roofing shingles\n(asphalt), glue, Wonder Board tile underlayment, stainless steel cap, 2X4's,\nscrews, plumbing fittings for the gas line, sheet metal, and incidentals.\nMy estimate is done as accurately as possible, but unforeseen problems could\nchange the time I've estimated for the job.  The materials will be about\n$700.00, and this is the deposit I will require.  Let me know what the ETA\nof your tile will be.  If you prefer, I can do the job without the tile,\nleaving the Wonder Board tile underlayment exposed, which is totally safe,\nand you can decide upon tile later, after looking at the site after the\nfireplace is moved.  I will need a half square min. to do the roof of the\nfireplace pop out.\nRegards,\nWill Guyan",

    {
        "body": "Energy marketers make the money, get the blame POWER CRUNCH: But probes \nlikely to find it's all legal in deregulation era\nThe News Tribune, 02/13/2001\n\nEnron Announces Dividends\nPR Newswire, 02/13/2001\n\nEOG Resources, Inc. Declares Increase of 14 Percent on Quarterly Dividend On \nCommon Stock\nPR Newswire, 02/13/2001\n\nEOG Resources, Inc. Declares Dividends on Preferred Stock\nPR Newswire, 02/13/2001\n\nAzurix says to end dispute with Argentine province\nReuters, 02/13/2001\n\nUSA: US Stockpile awards 3,400 tonnes lead to 3 firms.\nReuters English News Service, 02/13/2001\n \nMarathon Oil in race for Enron stake in oil fields \nThe Financial Express, 02/13/2001\n\n------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n-------------------------------------------\n\n \nFront Page\nEnergy marketers make the money, get the blame POWER CRUNCH: But probes \nlikely to find it's all legal in deregulation era\nLes Blumenthal\nThe News Tribune\n\n02/13/2001\nThe News Tribune Tacoma, WA\nSouth Sound\nA1\n(Copyright 2001)\n\nWASHINGTON - Their names may not appear on your electric bill, but they are \nthe largest energy marketers in the nation, and they're cashing in on the \nskyrocketing electric rates in the Northwest. \n\nAs ratepayers throughout the West are socked with double-digit increases in \ntheir bills, regulators throughout the region are looking into suspicions \nthat this new breed of energy companies has manipulated the overheated market \nto maximize profits. So far, there is no evidence they are doing anything \nillegal.\n\nCalifornia Gov. Gray Davis has called them pirates and plunderers. The San \nFrancisco city attorney has filed a $1 billion lawsuit against them, saying \nthey are playing with \"marked cards\" and looking to make a \"quick buck\" at \nthe expense of consumers. The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission is \ninvestigating, as are state regulators in Washington, Oregon and California. \n\n\"Based on hints of manipulated energy supplies and allegations of price \nmanipulation, I think we owe it to Washington utilities and consumers to make \nsure the soaring prices are not the result of illegal practices,\" Washington \nAttorney General Christine Gregoire said in announcing her office's antitrust \ndivision would investigate. \n\nThe power marketers, though, say they've done nothing wrong. The real \nproblem, they say, is there simply isn't enough power being generated to meet \ndemand. \n\nThe players include Enron Corp., Dynegy Inc., and Reliant Energy, all of \nHouston; Duke Energy of Charlotte, N.C.; Southern Energy of Atlanta; AES Inc. \nof Arlington, Va., and Calpine Corp. of San Jose, Calif. \n\nEnron's profits were up 34 percent in last year's fourth quarter. Duke's \nfourth-quarter revenues doubled; Dynegy's earnings more than doubled in the \nfourth quarter. \n\n\"When we hear about these stunning profit increases, I think we need to \ninvestigate,\" Gregoire said. \n\nCorporate raider Charles Hurwitz also could profit handsomely. His Maxxam \nInc. owns Kaiser Aluminum Corp., which has shut down its Washington mills \nand, under a special contract provision, is reselling power on the open \nmarket for much more than it paid the Bonneville Power Administration, the \nfederal agency that sells hydropower generated at dams along the Columbia and \nSnake rivers. Hurwitz could make half a billion dollars before the contracts \nexpire this fall. \n\nAnd the holding companies of two huge California utilities on the edge of \nbankruptcy have made billions of dollars off the West Coast electricity \nmarket through a financial juggling act. Audits by outside auditors hired by \nstate regulators showed Southern California Edison and Pacific Gas & Electric \nturned over billions to their holding companies, money that could have been \nused to ease the cash crunch they now face. \n\nThe utilities say they were engaged in accepted business practices when they \ntransferred the money, which the parent companies used for such things as \nstockholder dividends and stock buybacks. \n\n\"Is it capitalism or profiteering?\" said Ed Mosey, a BPA spokesman. \"The very \ncomplexity of these markets allows these companies to hide in the grass.\" \n\nA few years ago, the energy industry was tightly regulated and utilities and \ngenerators were allowed to recover their costs and make a decent return on \ntheir investment. \n\nBut beginning with the deregulation of wholesale electricity markets in 1992, \nenergy marketers, generators, independent power producers and others became \nmajor players. Regulated utilities opened computer-driven trading rooms as \nthey scrambled to find the cheapest electricity available. \n\nNow electricity is sold on spot and longer-term markets, traded for \nelectricity available in other parts of the country or even swapped for \nnatural gas. \n\n\"Power can pass through three or four hands before you even buy it,\" Tacoma \nPower Superintendent Steve Klein said. \n\nThe latest jolts in the Northwest market began last summer when California \nexperienced severe shortages and prices soared. \n\nBecause the entire West Coast is connected by one power grid, the rate shocks \nwere felt in the Northwest and grew even more as California's problems \ndeepened and a winter drought prompted fears of a near-record low runoff in \nthe Columbia and Snake rivers. \n\nSome called it a \"perfect storm\" scenario, and BPA saw the price it paid for \npower in January grow sixfold over the previous year. \n\n\"We will buy from anyone who will sell to us at a reasonable prices, but the \nproblem is finding a reasonable price,\" said BPA Administrator Steve Wright. \n\"The marketers are recovering a substantial amount of money.\" \n\nThe same companies making money in California are making money in the \nNorthwest. \"These are for-profit companies,\" said Mark Crisson, who heads \nTacoma Power. \"These folks don't answer to a (state regulatory) commission \nand they don't answer to ratepayers. They answer to their stockholders and \nI've seen no effort by them to minimize prices.\" \n\nCritics say the energy marketers have manipulated the market by shutting down \ngenerating facilities in California in an effort to restrict the supply and \ndrive prices up. \n\nAccording to some utility executives, generating plants are usually off-line \n5 percent of the time because of unforeseen problems and that an off-line \naverage of 10 percent to 15 percent would be considered high. During some \nmonths, certain California generating plants have been off-line 30 percent to \n50 percent of the time. \n\n\"We are seeing abnormal rates,\" Crisson said. \n\nAsked whether he thought the companies were manipulating, or gaming, the \nmarket, Crisson said, \"I would stop short of accusing them of that, but there \nis something funny going on.\" \n\nThe California generators and marketers say the outages have been the result \nof running aging plants hard in an effort to supply power in a tight market. \n\n\"We think these allegations are a little unfair,\" said Randy Wheeless, a \nspokesman for Duke Energy, which operates four power plants in California. \nDespite several investigations, Wheeless said, his and other companies have \nalways been cleared. \n\n\"We're trying to feed the market, not manipulate it,\" he said. \"There isn't \nany one single person or company to blame. The remedy is to get more \ngeneration on line.\" \n\nEnron doesn't own any power plants in California but sells and trades energy \nthroughout the West. Spokesman Mark Palmer agreed that the key to solving the \ncurrent crisis is adding more generation and truly deregulating the \nCalifornia market so there is real competition. \"Everyone is scrambling for \npower,\" he said. \n- - - \n* Staff writer Les Blumenthal covers Northwest issues in Congress. Reach him \nat 1-202-383-0008 or lblumenthal@mcclatchydc.com.\n\n\nEnron Announces Dividends\n\n02/13/2001\nPR Newswire\n(Copyright (c) 2001, PR Newswire)\n\nHOUSTON, Feb. 13 /PRNewswire/ -- The Enron Corp. (NYSE: ENE) Board of \nDirectors declared today a regular quarterly dividend of $0.125 per share on \nthe corporation's common stock payable on March 20, 2001, to stockholders of \nrecord as of March 1, 2001. The indicated annual rate is $0.50 per share. The \nBoard also declared a regular quarterly dividend of $3.413 on the Cumulative \nSecond Preferred Convertible Stock payable April 2, 2001 to preferred \nstockholders of record as of March 16, 2001. The indicated annual rate is \n$13.652 per share. \n\nEnron Capital LLC, a wholly owned subsidiary of Enron Corp., declared its \nmonthly dividend of $0.166667 on the Enron Capital LLC 8% Cumulative \nGuaranteed Monthly Income Preferred Shares for the month of February, payable \nFeb. 28, 2001 to stockholders of record as of Feb. 27, 2001. The annual \ndividend rate is $2.00.\n\nEnron Capital Resources, L.P., a Delaware limited partnership in which Enron \nCorp. is the sole general partner, declared its monthly dividend of $0.1875 \non the Enron Capital Resources, L.P. 9% Cumulative Preferred Securities, \nSeries A, for the month of February, payable Feb. 28, 2001 to holders of \nrecord as of Feb. 27, 2000. The annual dividend rate is $2.25. \n\nEnron is one of the world's leading electricity, natural gas and \ncommunications companies. The company, with revenues of $101 billion in 2000, \nmarkets electricity and natural gas, delivers physical commodities and \nfinancial and risk management services to customers around the world, and has \ndeveloped an intelligent network platform to facilitate online business. \nFortune magazine has named Enron \"America's Most Innovative Company\" for six \nconsecutive years. Enron's Internet address is www.enron.com. The stock is \ntraded under the ticker symbol \"ENE\". \n\n/CONTACT: Karen Denne of Enron Corp., 713-853-9757/ 16:00 EST \n\n\nEOG Resources, Inc. Declares Increase of 14 Percent on Quarterly Dividend On \nCommon Stock\n\n02/13/2001\nPR Newswire \n(Copyright (c) 2001, PR Newswire) \n\nHOUSTON, Feb. 13 /PRNewswire/ -- The Board of Directors of EOG Resources, \nInc. (NYSE: EOG) (EOG) has declared an increase in the regular quarterly \ndividend to $.04 per share on the common stock of the company, payable April \n30, 2001, to shareholders of record as of April 16, 2001. The indicated \nannual rate is $.16. \n\n\"By increasing the dividend, we are signaling to shareholders that EOG \nremains aligned with their interests,\" said Mark Papa, EOG Chairman and Chief \nExecutive Officer. \"Last year we generated over $300 million of cash flow \nbeyond our capital program, and at current prices, we expect to generate \nsignificant cash flow beyond our capital program again this year.\"\n\nEOG last increased its dividend from $.12 per share to $.14 per share during \nthe first quarter 2000. \n\nEOG Resources, Inc., formerly Enron Oil & Gas Company, is among the largest \nindependent (non-integrated) oil and gas companies in the United States, with \noperations and substantial reserves in the U.S., Canada and Trinidad. EOG \ncommon stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange and is traded under the \nticker symbol, \"EOG\". \n\nThis press release includes forward looking statements within the meaning of \nSection 27A of the Securities Act of 1933 and Section 21E of the Securities \nExchange Act of 1934. Baldwin of EOG Resources, Inc., 713-651-6EOG, or \n713-651-6364/ 15:40 EST \n\n\nAzurix says to end dispute with Argentine province\nBUENOS AIRES, Feb 13 (Reuters) - U.S. water company Azurix Corp. (NYSE:AZX - \nnews) said Tuesday it would formally agree this week to improve its Argentine \nwater services after it was accused of providing poor service to Buenos Aires \nprovince. \n\nAzurix, an affiliate of energy supplier Enron Corp. (NYSE:ENE - news) which \nsaid in January it would take a fourth-quarter charge of $470 million on its \nArgentine operations, had previously fended off the criticism by blaming \nBuenos Aires province's poor infrastructure. \n\n``This week an agreement will be signed,'' an Azurix spokesman told Reuters. \n``The cost of the projects during 2001 will be less than $30 million.'' \n\nThe dispute climaxed in January, when Buenos Aires province said it would \nreview Azurix's 30-year, $439 million water and wastewater service contract. \nIt said there were widespread customer complaints, such as low water pressure \nand algae contamination in the city's reservoir. \n\nAzurix argued that the province did not provide the necessary infrastructure \nor allow the company to charge fair market rates for services. \n\nShares of Azurix added 1 cent at $8.32 Tuesday on the New York Stock \nExchange. \n\n\n\nUSA: US Stockpile awards 3,400 tonnes lead to 3 firms.\n\n02/13/2001\nReuters English News Service \n(C) Reuters Limited 2001. \n\nNEW YORK, Feb 13 (Reuters) - The U.S. Defense National Stockpile Center said \nTuesday it awarded approximately 3,400 metric tonnes of lead to three firms \nin its latest solicitation of offers. \n\nNey Smelting & Refining Co. Inc., Lead Products Co. Inc. and Enron Metals & \nCommodity Corp. received the material for an estimated market value of $1.6 \nmillion.\n\n\n\nMarathon Oil in race for Enron stake in oil fields \nThe Financial Express, 02/13/2001 \n\nAnupama Airy & Kavita Bhaskaran \n\nNew Delhi, Feb 13: The US-based energy major, Marathon Oil and Gas Company \nhas emerged as one of the strong contenders for picking up Enron's 30 per \ncent stake in the Mukta, Panna and Tapti oil and gas fields. \n\nTop industry sources disclosed that Marathon has also been shortlisted in the \nfirst round of bidding along with Reliance and ONGC for buying Enron's stake \nin these fields. \n\nWhereas, both Reliance and ONGC are part of the consortia already developing \nthese fields, Marathon is the only company which has been shortlisted outside \nthe consortia. \n\n\"Currently, Marathon is doing the due diligence of Enron's assets following \nwhich it will submit the financial bids along with other shortlisted \nparties,\" the sources said. \n\nSources informed that Marathon possesses some of the best oil and gas \nexploration technologies in the world, and, at one point of time, even ONGC \nwas in talks with Marathon for acquiring its technology. \n\nAsked if there was any possibility of ONGC and Marathon joining hands for \nsubmission of financial bids, industry sources said both the companies have \ndecided to bid independently. \n\nMoreover, for all these discovered fields, ONGC does not require any \nfinancial or technical support from others. Reliance, however, is not \nqualified to be the operator of oil and gas fields as it does not have \nsufficient experience in the area. \n\nOn the other hand, Marathon possess strong technical skills in this area and, \nif selected, can easily qualify as an operator.ONGC is the biggest partner in \nthe consortium in terms of its equity stake. \n\nIt has 40 per cent with the remaining 60 per cent, shared equally between \nReliance Industries and Enron Oil and Gas India. \n\nHowever, Enron is the operator of this $900 million joint venture between \nReliance and ONGC. Both ONGC and Reliance have the pre-emption rights by \nvirtue of being partners in the joint ventures operating these companies. \n\nBut this does not mean that they will get it any cheaper. They will have to \nmatch the highest bidder, sources said. \n\nIt may be recalled here that Enron has recently decided to sell its entire \noil and gas assets in India. The buyer for these assets is to be selected \nthrough a two-stage bidding process. \n\nCredit Suisse First Boston has been appointed as the investment banker to \nderive current value of its stake in the joint venture. These oil and gas \nfields in Gujarat and Mumbai offshore are reportedly producing around 300 \nmillion cubic metre of gas and 29,000 barrels of oil per day. \n\nCopyright , 2001 Indian Express Newspapers (Bombay) Ltd. \n\n\n \n\n\n\n",

    {
        "body": "Enron, as part of our alliance, ARM, has entered into a settlement w/ SDG&E, \nORA, DGS and the Golden State Cooperative on Direct Access Service Fees.  \nThese are fees that the utility could assess on either DA customers or ESPs \nproviding service to DA customers.  This settlement has been filed with the \nCPUC.  IT HAS NOT BEEN ADOPTED YET.  I will notify all if, and when, that \nhappens.\n\nSDG&E went particularly \"hog-wild\" on the number of fees proposed as well as \nthe level of the fees.  By our settlement, I believe, conservatively, we have \neliminated about $100 of additional charges per customer per year.\n\nWe have agreed that no fees will be assessed for services that the utility \nprovides as part of its market facilitation function through 2002.  This is \nin keeping with the fact that the utility is currently recovering those costs \nthrough distribution rates as part of a settlement in a separate proceeding \n(376).  Those functions include MSP and MDMA certification, DASR processing, \nEDI acceptance testing, ESP and EDI agreement processing, credit \nestablishments and on-going credit checks, processing meter change \ninformation, providing customer data.\n\nPOTENTIAL NEW CHARGES:\n\nSpecial Services:\n\nWhere we ASK the utility to perform functions for us (researching data, \nproviding administrative support, non-standard processing of information (ie. \nmanual vs. EDI)) there will be a charge.  They must specify to us that the \nservice that we are requesting will result in a fee being assessed and what \nthe charge will be.  We must agree to the terms before the service is \nprovided.  This means we must be very clear in our communications with the \nutility on special requests.  \n\nException Fees:\n\nThis is where we fail to meet our obligation to the utility and they assess, \nessentially, a penalty.   Examples include missed appointment meets, late \npayments, failure to provide usage data by 11th business day causing utility \nto estimate data, causing a rebill for failure to provide valid usage data.  \n(More detailed description is contained within the attached documents.) \nWe have negotiated that there be a .5% deadband before any fee is assessed \nfor estimating data.  We have negotiated that, to the extent the utility is \nresponsible for causing US to rebill, we can accumulate banking credits to \nuse against any charges that the utility would assess us.  It provides some \nreciprocity.\n\nWe do have a dispute resolution process.  However, if we need an internal \nbriefing on the settlement so folks are comfortable about how it will work, I \nwould be happy to assist with that. \n\nPlease contact me with any questions.\n\n\n---------------------- Forwarded by Mona L Petrochko/SFO/EES on 09/20/2000 \n07:03 PM ---------------------------\n\n\n\"Delaney, Laurie\" <LDelaney@sempra.com> on 09/14/2000 03:02:49 PM\nTo: \"'sfc@cpuc.ca.gov'\" <sfc@cpuc.ca.gov>, \"'jbennett@gmssr.com'\" \n<jbennett@gmssr.com>, \"'abb@eslawfirm.com'\" <abb@eslawfirm.com>, \n\"'rmccann@cal.net'\" <rmccann@cal.net>, \"'athomas@newenergy.com'\" \n<athomas@newenergy.com>, \"'msw@cpuc.ca.gov'\" <msw@cpuc.ca.gov>, \n\"'mpetroch@enron.com'\" <mpetroch@enron.com>\ncc: \"Thompson, Vicki L.\" <VThompson@sempra.com>, \"Szymanski, Paul\" \n<PSzymanski@sempra.com> \nSubject: A99-06-041 Joint Motion for Adoption of Settlement and Joint Peti \ntion to set Aside Submission & Reopen the Record for Purposes of Admittin g a \nLate Filed Exhibit\n\n\n\n\n - ld2d-#75429-1.DOC\n - ld2d-#75426-1.DOC\n - ld2d-#75427-1.DOC\n - ld2d-#75428-1.DOC\n",

If you prefer not to\r\nreceive TR Daily, please reply to customerservice@tr.com.\r\n\r\n--------------------------------------------------\r\n\r\nTable of Contents\r\nClick here for the full issue:\r\nhttp://www.tr.com/online/trd/2001/td020501/index.htm\r\n\r\nFRUSTRATED JUDGES FOCUS ON BACKGROUND IN `AVERAGE\r\nSCHEDULE' CASE\r\nhttp://www.tr.com/online/trd/2001/td020501/Td020501.htm\r\n\r\nCLECs WANT RECORD ON PACIFIC BELL\r\nInterLATA SERVICE BID `REFRESHED'\r\nhttp://www.tr.com/online/trd/2001/td020501/Td020501-01.htm\r\n\r\nCONSUMER GROUPS CALL FOR `PRO-COMPETITIVE' FCC\r\nACTION\r\nhttp://www.tr.com/online/trd/2001/td020501/Td020501-02.htm\r\n\r\nMOBILE PHONE INDUSTRY FACES LATEST HEALTH-RELATED\r\nLAWSUIT\r\nhttp://www.tr.com/online/trd/2001/td020501/Td020501-03.htm\r\n\r\nILECs:  `DISTORTIONS' FROM `RECIP COMP' COULD GET\r\nWORSE\r\nhttp://www.tr.com/online/trd/2001/td020501/Td020501-04.htm\r\n\r\nNEWS IN BRIEF\r\nhttp://www.tr.com/online/trd/2001/td020501/Td020501-05.htm\r\n\r\n\r\n*******************************************************\r\nFRUSTRATED JUDGES FOCUS ON BACKGROUND IN `AVERAGE\r\nSCHEDULE' CASE\r\n\r\nAppeals court judges today vented their exasperation at the inability of\r\nattorneys to explain how universal service support for each small,\r\n\"average schedule\" company is determined.  The attorney representing the\r\nFCC bore the brunt of the judges' frustrations and, at times, caustic\r\ncomments on that issue.\r\n\r\nBut on the legal issues, the lawyer representing the National Exchange\r\nCarrier Association, Inc., in its challenge to an FCC decision seemed to\r\ntake the harder hits.  The U.S. Court of Appeals in Washington must\r\ndecide whether the FCC acted \"arbitrarily and capriciously\" in prescribing\r\na 6.5% increase in \"average schedule\" universal service support.\r\n\r\n\"Average schedule\" companies use formulas derived by NECA and\r\napproved by the FCC to approximate their per-loop costs of providing\r\nservice.  This is in contrast to so-called \"cost companies,\" which perform\r\nstudies to calculate their actual per-loop costs.\r\n\r\nThe case marks the first time that NECA, which the FCC has charged\r\nwith updating the formula used by \"average schedule\" companies to\r\ncalculate universal service support, has asked the court to review an FCC\r\norder, NECA attorney Richard A. Askoff pointed out during oral\r\narguments this morning.\r\n\r\nThe judges spent as much time seeking information on how the \"average\r\nschedule\" mechanism works as they did questioning attorneys about their\r\nlegal arguments.  Judge David S. Tatel asked for clarification of how the\r\n\"average schedule\" formula was applied to individual companies.\r\n\r\nAfter FCC attorney Laurel Bergold spent nearly all her allotted time in an\r\nunsuccessful attempt to clarify that aspect of the case, Chief Judge Harry\r\nT. Edwards commented, \"We get hard things from the FCC, but this\r\n[case] is bizarre.\"\r\n\r\nMr. Askoff apparently cleared up the matter for the judges during his\r\nrebuttal arguments.  He explained that certain data (such as the number\r\nof loops per exchange) is plugged into the \"average schedule\" formula to\r\ndetermine a given carrier's amount of support.\r\n\r\nBut Mr. Askoff faced some tough questions from Judge Douglas H.\r\nGinsburg regarding NECA's argument that it hadn't received proper\r\nnotice of the FCC's intention to prescribe the 6.5% adjustment.  Judge\r\nGinsburg wondered what NECA would have said to the FCC, if it had\r\nreceived notice, that it didn't say in advocating a 33% increase in\r\nuniversal service support for \"average schedule\" carriers.\r\n\r\nMr. Askoff said NECA would have discussed the \"fallacy\" of the FCC's\r\nbelief that universal service support should be tied to growth in the\r\nnumber of local loops.  Judge Edwards replied that NECA already had\r\nmade that argument before the FCC.\r\n\r\nThe case (\"National Exchange Carrier Association, Inc., v. FCC,\" no. 00-\r\n1055) stems from an FCC decision to reject NECA's proposed \"average\r\nschedule\" universal service formula for 1998-1999.\r\n\r\n\r\n*******************************************************\r\nCLECs WANT RECORD ON PACIFIC BELL\r\nInterLATA SERVICE BID `REFRESHED'\r\n\r\nThe California Office of Ratepayer Advocates, several trade associations\r\nrepresenting competitive local exchange carriers (CLECs), and nine\r\nindividual CLECs have asked the state Public Utilities Commission to\r\n\"refresh\" its record on Pacific Bell's compliance with federally mandated\r\nmarket-opening standards before deciding whether the telco has met those\r\nstandards.\r\n\r\nIn a joint petition filed Friday, Feb. 2, they argued that the record in th=\r\ne\r\nproceeding was \"too stale\" for the commission to reach credible\r\nconclusions about Pacific Bell's compliance with the market-opening\r\nmandates by May 24--the date the commission is scheduled to issue a final\r\ndecision.\r\n\r\nCompliance with a 14-point competitive \"checklist\" of market-opening\r\nmoves outlined in section 271 of the federal Telecommunications Act of\r\n1996 is a prerequisite to Bell companies' receiving FCC authorization to\r\nprovide in-region interLATA (local access and transport area) service.=20\r\nThe FCC is required to consult with relevant state commissions and the\r\nJustice Department before ruling on a Bell company's section 271\r\napplication.  Bell companies typically try to convince the state regulators\r\nof their compliance before submitting an application to the FCC.\r\n\r\nThe joint petitioners told the California commission that the record in the\r\nproceeding could be supplemented \"in a relatively prompt and efficient\r\nmanner.\"\r\n\r\nIf \"Pacific Bell intends to include updated or other additional information\r\nin its application to be filed with the FCC, then it should make\r\nthatinformation available to the [California commission] and the parties to\r\nthis proceeding now,\" the petitioners said.  Such action would be\r\n\"consistent with the FCC's goal that the state commission be the principal\r\nforum for resolving factual disputes in the first instance, rather than\r\nrequire the [California commission] and the parties to address Pacific\r\nBell's showing for the first time after being thrust into an expedited\r\nreview process before the federal agency in Washington, D.C.\"\r\n\r\nIn addition to the Office of Ratepayer Advocates, the joint petitioners\r\nwere the California Association of Competitive Telecommunications\r\nCompanies, the Association of Communications Enterprises, the\r\nCompetitive Telecommunications Association, AT&T Communications of\r\nCalifornia, Inc., WorldCom, Inc., Advanced Telcom, Inc., XO\r\nCalifornia, Inc., Spring Communications Co. LP, New Edge Network,\r\nInc., ICG Telecom Group, Inc., Rhythms Links, Inc., and Time Warner\r\nTelecom of California, Inc.\r\n\r\n\r\n*******************************************************\r\nCONSUMER GROUPS CALL FOR `PRO-COMPETITIVE' FCC\r\nACTION\r\n\r\nThe Consumer Federation of America and Consumers Union today issued\r\na report stating that policy-makers have failed in their attempt to expand\r\nconsumer choice in local and broadband services.  In \"Lessons from the\r\n1996 Telecommunications Act,\" the groups called for increased regulation\r\nof large companies that \"continue to monopolize the cable TV and local\r\ntelephone industries.\"\r\n\r\nThe report said the Act's failure stems from the fact that the major\r\nproviders of cable TV and local phone service have chosen to merge\r\nrather than compete.  \"Most of the local phone service market still\r\nbelongs to the regional Bell monopolies, which, thanks to a series of\r\nmergers, have shrunk from seven companies in 1996 into just four today,\"\r\nthe groups said.\r\n\r\nThe report asked lawmakers to promote \"meaningful competition\" among\r\nlocal service providers by pressing for adoption of certain market-opening\r\nprinciples nationwide.  It specifically cites local market-opening moves in\r\nNew York and Texas.\r\n\r\nIn the broadband services market, a handful of dominant companies have\r\nrefused to enter each other's markets, agreeing instead to merge and swap\r\nassets, the report says.  \"Cable monopolies have saddled consumers with\r\nhuge rate increases and sought to impose their closed business model on\r\nthe broadband Internet by making it nearly impossible for outside\r\ncompanies to offer Internet services over the monopolies' cable lines,\" the\r\ngroups stated.\r\n\r\nThey asked lawmakers to put an end to \"abusive\" cable TV pricing\r\npractices, require telcos to provide nondiscriminatory access to their\r\nhigh-speed networks, enforce media ownership limits that promote\r\ndiversity, and block further consolidation that undermines potential\r\ncompetition. =20\r\n\r\n\r\n*******************************************************\r\nMOBILE PHONE INDUSTRY FACES LATEST HEALTH-RELATED\r\nLAWSUIT\r\n\r\nThe wireless phone industry is facing another lawsuit, this one filed on\r\nbehalf of a 38-year-old Georgia man who says his cellphone caused his\r\nbrain tumor.  It's the latest in a growing number of such lawsuits alleging\r\nthat the industry manufactured and marketed the devices despite knowing\r\ntheir potential adverse health effects.\r\n\r\nThe lawsuit, \"Brian Lane Barrett and Diana Barrett v. Nokia Corp. et al.\"\r\n(case no.2001CV33385), was filed in Fulton County Superior Court in\r\nAtlanta Jan. 29.  In addition to Nokia, the lawsuit names BellSouth\r\nMobility, Inc., and the Cellular Telecommunications Industry Association\r\n(now the Cellular Telecommunications & Internet Association) as\r\ndefendants.  It seeks compensatory and punitive damages but doesn't list\r\nan amount.\r\n\r\nThe 10-count lawsuit claims that the defendants \"knew or should have\r\nknown\" the phones \"to be defective, unreasonably dangerous, and\r\nhazardous.\"\r\n\r\nSpokespersons for the defendants declined to comment on the lawsuit.=20\r\n\r\n\r\n*******************************************************\r\nILECs:  `DISTORTIONS' FROM `RECIP COMP' COULD GET\r\nWORSE\r\n\r\nIncumbent local exchange carriers (ILECs) say their reciprocal\r\ncompensation payments to competitive local exchange carriers (CLECs)\r\nare continuing to increase, making it even more imperative that the FCC\r\nchange its rules regarding the payments  between carriers for terminating\r\nlocal traffic.  The ILECs told the FCC that declining network costs and\r\nincreasing traffic flows are producing \"ever greater economic\r\ninefficiencies and distortions.\"\r\n\r\nRobert T. Blau, vice president-executive and federal regulatory affairs at\r\nBellSouth Corp., addressed the issue in a Feb. 1 letter to Common Carrier\r\nBureau Chief Dorothy Attwood.  He wrote on behalf of BellSouth, SBC\r\nCommunications, Inc., Verizon Communications, Inc., and Qwest\r\nCommunications International, Inc.\r\n\r\nMr. Blau acknowledged that reciprocal compensation rates are declining,\r\nbut he said dial-up traffic to the Internet is increasing faster.  Most\r\nobservers project that dial-up access minutes will continue to grow rapidly\r\nfor at least the next three years, Mr. Blau said.  In addition, changes in\r\ntechnology and capital cost reductions are \"offsetting reciprocal\r\ncompensation declines,\" he said.\r\n\r\nMr. Blau estimated that the cost to CLECs of carrying dial-up calls to\r\nInternet service providers (ISPs) \"works out to about $0.0001 per minute,\r\nor about 2% to 5% of current reciprocal compensation rates.\"  He said\r\neliminating reciprocal compensation in favor of a \"bill-and-keep\" system\r\nwould not force CLECs to raise per-line fees for ISP customers.\r\n\r\n\r\n*******************************************************\r\nNEWS IN BRIEF\r\n\r\nFormer National Telecommunications and Information Administrator\r\nGregory L. Rohde is heading up e-Copernicus.com, a new subsidiary of\r\nthe government relations firm Dutko Group, Inc.  E-Copernicus will offer\r\nconsulting services to domestic and international Internet-based businesses\r\nand companies involved in electronic and mobile commerce....\r\n\r\nViatel, Inc., says Alfred West has resigned as chairman.  He was founder,\r\nchairman, and chief executive officer at Destia Communications, which\r\nViatel acquired in December 1999....\r\n\r\nYuval Bloch has been named president and general manager of Invisix, a\r\njoint venture of Motorola, Inc., and Cisco Systems, Inc.  Mr. Bloch was\r\nvice president and GM in Israel for Motorola's Telecom Carrier Solutions\r\nGroup....\r\n\r\nSteven M. Reimer has been named senior vice president-customer\r\noperations at Mpower Communications Corp., a Rochester, N.Y.-based\r\ncompetitive local exchange carrier.  He was VP-operations at AT&T\r\nBroadband....\r\n\r\nWireless broadband technology manufacturer Malibu Networks, Inc., has\r\nnamed John Skoro senior vice president-marketing and business\r\ndevelopment.  He was marketing director-broadband wireless solutions at\r\nNortel Networks Corp....=20\r\n\r\nShaya Phillips was named networking director at Global Broadband, Inc.,\r\na New York City-based integrated communications provider.  He was\r\ndirector-enterprise networking services at St. John's University....=20\r\n\r\nDouglas G. Bonner has become a partner in the Washington law office of\r\nLeBoeuf, Lamb, Greene & MacRae LLP.  Elizabeth Dickerson and Brett\r\nSnyder were named associates.  They've come to the firm's telecom\r\npractice group from Arent Fox Kintner Plotkin & Kahn PLLC....\r\n\r\nIn the House Energy and Commerce Committee, Will Nordwind has been\r\nnamed counsel to the telecommunications subcommittee.  He was deputy\r\nchief of staff, legislative director, and counsel to Rep. Fred Upton (R.,\r\nMich.), who has become chairman of the subcommittee.  In other staffing\r\nnews, Commerce Chairman W.J. (Billy) Tauzin (R., La.) announced\r\ntoday that Patrick Morrisey will be his deputy staff director and policy\r\ncoordinator.  Mr. Morrisey previously worked as a health counsel to the\r\nCommerce Committee.  In the subcommittee on commerce, trade, and\r\nconsumer protection, Rep. Tauzin has tapped Ramsen Betfarhad to be\r\ncounsel.  Mr. Betfarhad previously was counsel and economic adviser to\r\nformer House Commerce Committee Chairman Thomas J. Bliley Jr. (R.,\r\nVa.)....\r\n\r\nTelecom Italia SpA intends to raise as much as 12.8 billion euros ($12\r\nbillion) by exchanging ordinary shares for a lesser class of stock called\r\nsavings shares.  Shareholders who participate in the exchange would pay\r\nTelecom Italia 6.25 euros per share ($5.87) to upgrade their stock.=20\r\nTelecom Italia would use the proceeds to buy back up to 10% of its\r\nordinary shares, including those held by parent company Olivetti SpA.=20\r\nIf the share exchange and buyback go as planned, Olivetti's stake in\r\nTelecom Italia would drop from 58.4% to about 40%.  But the transaction\r\nwould provide Olivetti with up to 5.1 billion euros ($4.8 billion) to use\r\nfor debt reduction.  The companies expect to complete the transactions,\r\nwhich are subject to shareholder approval, by August....\r\n\r\nQwest Communications International, Inc., is offering to buy back about\r\n$1.1 billion in senior notes.  A cash tender offer for the notes will expir=\r\ne\r\nMarch 5.  Qwest said it intended to retire the notes because they have\r\nhigh interest rates....\r\n\r\nCommunity News LLC has agreed to make a voluntary $7,500\r\ncontribution to the U.S. Treasury for failing to obtain FCC authorization\r\nbefore transferring control of a land mobile radio station.  The agreement\r\nwas part of a consent decree with the FCC's Enforcement Bureau.  The\r\nMassachusetts company used the station to communicate with newspaper\r\ndelivery trucks and personnel.  The bureau released the decision today in\r\nfile number EB-00-IH-0433....\r\n\r\nThe FCC's new universal licensing system (ULS) for electronically\r\nprocessing applications and other paperwork still isn't working properly,\r\naccording to the Association of Public-Safety Communications Officials-\r\nInternational (APCO).  APCO is asking public safety agencies that have\r\nmade frequency-allocation requests to be patient in light of the delays in\r\nimplementing the system.  In most cases, applicants must obtain frequency\r\ncoordination through a certified coordinator before their paperwork can be\r\napproved.  Phase II of the conversion of the land mobile radio services to\r\nthe ULS took effect last October, APCO pointed out.  But no public-\r\ncertified frequency coordinator successfully has submitted an application\r\nelectronically to the FCC, it said.  The new ULS forced frequency\r\ncoordinators to redesign their software in just a few months, APCO\r\nsaid....\r\n\r\nThe Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission says\r\nit will establish two numbering-relief planning committees to develop\r\ntelephone number resource-allocation plans.  CRTC plans to form a\r\ncommittee to assess numbering needs within area code 519; another\r\ncommittee will study area codes 613 and 819.  The committees will\r\nsubmit to the CRTC relief-implementation proposals that, if approved,\r\nwould require mandatory compliance by all telecom carriers serving those\r\nareas, the CRTC said today....\r\n\r\nThe FCC has renewed the charter of the Public Safety National\r\nCoordination Committee (NCC) for two more years, beginning Feb. 25.=20\r\nThe NCC advises the agency on technical and operational standards for\r\nthe 700 megahertz band interoperability channels.\r\n\r\n\r\n********************************************************\r\nTR DAILY Copyright 2001 Telecommunications Reports International,\r\nInc., (ISSN 1082-9350) is transmitted weekdays, except for\r\nholidays.     {
        "body": "Attached is Mary Schoen's analysis of Gov. Davis' Executive Order on \nexpediting siting and maximizing output. \n\nI have asked Mary to try and identify the # of MWs that may be impacted by \nthese actions.\n\nJim\n\n\n----- Forwarded by James D Steffes/NA/Enron on 02/11/2001 02:49 PM -----\n\n\tMary Schoen\n\t02/09/2001 03:58 PM\n\t\t \n\t\t To: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron@Enron, James D Steffes/NA/Enron@Enron, Richard \nShapiro/NA/Enron@Enron, Leslie Lawner/NA/Enron@Enron, Robert \nFrank/NA/Enron@Enron, Sandra McCubbin/NA/Enron@Enron, Jeffrey \nKeeler/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Michael Terraso/OTS/Enron@ENRON, Stacey \nBolton/NA/Enron@Enron, Heather Mitchell/HOU/EES@EES, Robert \nFrank/NA/Enron@Enron, Harry Kingerski/NA/Enron@Enron, Jeff \nDasovich/NA/Enron@Enron, Susan J Mara/NA/Enron@ENRON\n\t\t cc: \n\t\t Subject: Summary and Very Brief Analysis of Governor Davis's 2/9/01 \nExecutive Orders\n\nBelow is a brief summary of the five Executive Orders issued by Governor \nDavis on 2/9/01.  \n\nFor those of you that want the Cliff Notes Version:\n\nThese Orders appear to be an attempt to accomplish three things:\n\n1.  Expedite Siting for New Powerplants and Expansions or Modifications of \nExisting Powerplants\n2.  Maximize Output and Minimize Outages at Existing Facilities\n3.  Centralize Authority and/or Mitigate Issues Impacting Powerplant Siting \nand Construction\n\nThe tone is both one of we feel your pain in the complexity of permitting \npowerplants; and that we will tolerate no excuses for not running at full \ncapacity.  (ie; the carrot and the stick)\n\nThey also includes some targeted incentives to encourage powerplant operators \nto sell their power under contract to the State Dept. of Water.\n\nSome of the critical issues impacting the effectiveness of these orders will \nbe:\n\n- How much capacity is truly \"idling\" and will be able to be brought back on \nline or increase its output?\n- Will the state be able to better manage air quality issues and create \nflexibility within the framework allowed by the Clean Air Act in order to \npositively change the air quality issues impacting power plant construction \nand operation?\n- How quickly can the accelerated permitting procedures be implemented and \nhow soon will we see movements in the market to increase new generation given \nthe other issues in CA?\n\nWe will continue to analyze the impacts of these orders, but wanted to get \ninformation to you in a timely manner.\n\nD-22-01  Increased Output/Expedited Siting Mandates \n  \nCEC exemption from siting requirements for increased output by existing power \ngenerators. \n- limited to less than 50MWs using existing installed capacity b/w \n06/01-10/01/01 \n\nExpedited processing of applications for certification of existing thermal \npowerplants that require retooling and a current license to operate.\n\nAccelerated review from all agencies involved in the licensing of proposed \nthermal powerplants.\n\nAction by the State Water Resources Control Board  to insure wastewater \nissues do not preclude thermal powerplants from operating.\n\nRequirements for the State Dept. of Water Resources to purchase power from \npowerplants using renewables and other resources that may currently have not \nother market for their power.\n\nExpires  12/31/01 unless extended\n\nAnalysis:\n\nThis Order is intended to take away the excuses for why some powerplants are \ncurrently not operating or not operating at full capacity.  It does not waive \nair quality requirements (they are addressed in a separate order).  \n\nD-23-01  Appropriate Maintenance and Efficient Operation Requirements\n\nISO Requirements:\n- Require generators to submit planned outage schedules to the ISO\n- Prepare a coordinated outage plan to be updated quarterly\n- Identify generation maintenance criteria to be met by generation facilities\n- Maintain records of any unplanned generation facility outages and provide \nthose records to Electricity Oversight Board\n- Conduct independent audits of generation facilities that have fallen below \nperformance benchmarks est. by the ISO\n- Consider seeking the authority under state law of federal regulation to \nimpose fines on those generation facility owners whose generation facilities \nhave fallen     below performance benchmarks est. by the ISO\n\nRequires that the Electricity Oversight Board review the ISO Tariffs and \nProtocols to identify any necessary revisions to increase the ISO's ability \nto ensure adequate power during peak demand.\n\nInstructs the CPUC to ensure that generation facilities still owned by \nutilities are operated as required to maintain reliability.\n\nRequires the Electricity Oversight Board to propose legislation to expand its \nauthority to issue audits of generation facilities that do not meet est. \nbenchmarks for availability and performance, and issue fines against those \nplants, after a hearing.\n\nAnalysis:\n\nAgain, the tone of this order is that the state won't tolerate outages as an \nexcuse for not generating.  It is also an attempt to better manage planned \noutages to prevent situations that happened last fall when too many plants \nwhere off-line for maintenance at the same time.\n\nD-24-01  Air Pollution Flexibility and Mitigation Measures\n\nMandates that local air districts modify emissions limits that limit hours of \noperation in air quality permits to ensure that power generation facilities \nthat provide power under contract to the Dept. of Water Resources are not \nrestricted in their ability to operate.\n- Requires air districts to require a mitigation fee for all applicable \nemissions in excess of the previous limits\n- If air districts do not comply, the Board (CARB?) shall impose \nmodifications on the permits in lieu of districts\n\nThe Board shall establish an emissions reduction credit bank using emissions \nreductions from all available sources:\n- Credits will be made available to powerplant peaking sources that need \nemissions offsets in order to add new or expand peaking capacity for the \nSummer Peak Season in 2001\n- In the case of powerplants that agree to sell their power under contract to \nthe Dept. of Water Resources, CA will make available where necessary and \navailable the required emissions credits at up to a 50 percent reduction,\n- In order to maximize the amount of electrical generating capacity, \nemissions reduction credits for new generation capacity shall be provided to \nfacilities where necessary and available.\n- Proceeds from the sales of these emission reduction credits shall be made \navailable to fund emissions reduction programs in the air district where the \nnew or expanded facility is located.\n\nExpires 12/31/2001 unless extended\n\nAnalysis:\n\nThis order requires the air districts to modify permit limits on run hours \nfor air quality reasons by allowing those powerplants that sell to the Dept. \nof Water to pay a mitigation fee and creates an emission reduction credit \nbank available for use by other sources.  There are a lot of details that \nremain to be clarified, including how the state is going to locate emissions \nreduction credits where developers were unsuccessful.  However, it is a step \nin the right direction by creating flexibility and beginning to drive \nauthority back to the state level.\n\nD-25-01  Acceleration the Construction and Upgrading of Approved Powerplants\n\nExpedites review and approval of post-certification amendments to increase \noutput from thermal powerplants by the Energy Commission.\n\nAuthorizes the Energy Commission to suspends the requirements of the statutes \nand regulations that normally control post-certifications to the extent that \nthey impact prompt mitigation of this emergency.\n\nRequires the Energy Commission to establish milestones for both initiation of \nconstruction within one year of certification, and for the construction phase \nof the project.  Failure to meet milestones without prior approval by Energy \nCommission based on a showing of good cause shall constitute forfeiture of \nthe certification.\n\nExpires 12/31/01 unless extended\n\nAnalysis\n\nAgain, no excuses for not getting your powerplant modifications approved and \ncompleted in a timely manner.\n\nD-26-01  Accelerating the Availability of New Generation Sources\n\nRequires all relevant agencies shorten the review periods to 7 days for \nrequired environmental impact documents prepared under CEQA for all \npowerplants that are not subject to the Energy Commission (under 50MWs) and \nthat are proposed to be on line by summer 2001.\n\n Energy Commission shall expedite its licensing process in the following ways:\n- Expedite processing of applications for peaking or renewable powerplants \nfor construction and operation by July 31, 2001.\n-Peaking or renewable powerplants that have a current contract with the ISO \nand can be online by July 2001 may also apply to be permitted by the Energy \nCommission under the emergency siting process.\n-Rules which provide a license for a simple cycle thermal powerplant within \nfour months, shall apply to any proposed simple-cycle thermal powerplant that \ncan be brought on line by August 31, 2002  and that have an application for \ncertification complete by Dec. 31. 2001.\n-Under regulations for the expedited licensing of powerplants, emission \noffset credits are not required at the time of filing an application for \ncertification\n-The Energy Commission shall conduct a study of potential peaking power sites \nin the state and prepare a report by 02/21/01  identifying those areas of the \nstate that would benefit from the installation of peaking powerplants to \naugment supplies and ensure reliability through the summer of 2003.\n\nIOUs must complete necessary interconnection studies within 7 days of receipt \nof completed application.\n\nExpires 12/31/01 unless extended.\n\nAnalysis:\n\nThis is an attempt to accelerate the permitting of smaller sources and \npeaking units.",
        "headers": {

        "body": "Jim Steffes suggested that I forward this to you for discussion at the \nCalifornia Conference call tomorrow.\n\nSteve Walton\n----- Forwarded by Steve Walton/HOU/ECT on 02/08/2001 05:08 PM -----\n\n\tSteve Walton\n\t02/08/2001 04:50 PM\n\t\t \n\t\t To: James D Steffes/NA/Enron@Enron\n\t\t cc: \n\t\t Subject: Ownership of California Transmission System\n\nJim,\n\nI got a call this afternoon from Paul McCoy, a principal in TransElect.  We \nspoke to them about being a transmission operator during the E-Trans \nconsortium discussion last fall.  Paul told me that they have been actively \npursuing an offer for the transmission systems of PG&E and SCE as an \nalternative to the State of California taking title to the transmission \nsystem as part of the legislative solution.  Some of our fellow marketers are \nsufficiently concerned about California ownership that they have offered to \nprovide funding to the effort, not as investors which would taint the \nacquisition, but more of grant to assist the effort.  Paul did not tell me \nwho the parties are, but it is probably the \"usual suspects\" who own \ngeneration in California (my guess).  \n\nPaul called to see how we would view this effort.  They are interested in the \npossibility of our supporting a private acquisition of the transmission \nassets, not necessarily financial, but the use of our contacts and personnel \nto provide public and private support to such an effort.  \n\nAs I think about the State owning the transmission system and being the \npurchaser of energy, it seems like they are assembling a large vertically \nintegrated public power utility under the control of the Governor -- de facto \nre-regulation only worse.  Once the state own the transmission system, I \ndoubt it would every be privatized.  \n\nWhat are your views?  Would Enron be interested in supporting this effort?\n\nSteve",

Regulatory expects to receive confirmation next week that \nthe 1% annual Singapore telecom license fee will apply only to Singapore \nbandwidth.  Given that Asia trading will be centralized in Singapore, we want \nto make sure that the activities of traders outside of Singapore do not cause \nthe Singapore trading operations to be subject to tax outside of Singapore.  \nIn this regard, Asia traders should keep in mind the following general rules:\n\nTraders that regularly engage in the execution of trades outside of Singapore \nwill create a taxable presence outside of Singapore that will likely result \nin double taxation.\nTraders that regularly engage in the negotiation of trades outside of \nSingapore will create a significant risk that local tax authorities will \nassert that such activities created a taxable presence outside of Singapore \nthat would likely result in double taxation.  EBS Tax would want to monitor \nsuch a situation very closely, so please let us know immediately if these \ncircumstances arise.\nTraders engaging only in the solicitation of business and the provision of \nproduct information (including pricing) outside of Singapore will not create \na taxable presence outside of Singapore.  In this regard, please note that \neven if traders restrict themselves to business solicitation, a large scale \npresence in any given country could attract the attention of the tax \nauthorities who may adopt aggressive positions with regard to the creation of \na taxable presence.  \n\nWhen in doubt as to the application of these general rules to a specific \nsituation, please do not hesitate to call.\n\nThanks.\n\nW.     {
        "body": "Some corrections to the write-up for the first one for EES, some attribtuon \nchanges (I think) and an additional valuation for EES.  Also, includes \nchanges to the write-ups for ENA and what I got from Tim Belden.  I also have \na note discussing Tim Belden's \"philosophy\" in giving me valuations.\n\nEES\n\nRAP '98\nEnron raised the issue of the UDCs imposing an artificial cap on the PX \ncredit for direct customers during the very first proceedings during which \nthe method of CTC collection was raised.  The CPUC shined us on. Later, we \nraised it in the very first Revenue Adjustment Proceeding (RAP '98) RAP '98 \nand ensured that it became part of WPTF's case as well.  The way the \"cap\" \nworked, the UDCs would not pay ESPs the full PX credit when prices were high \n-- they would pay a credit that, when added to the other bill components, did \nnot exceed the frozen rate for the direct access customer, thereby costing \nESPs a lot of  money  potentially.  It was clear in the previous CPUC direct \naccess decisions that UDCs had no right to cap direct access credits. Because \nof our good case and the fact that the UDCs believed the chance of such high \nPX prices was LOW, the UDCs settled on this issue in 1999.\n\n2000 NPV estimated by Dennis Benevides: $30 - 40 million\n% Attributed to Enron's GA Efforts: 90%\n\nGreen Credit Legislation\nEnron and other green suppliers began work in 1998 to extend the credit given \nfor sales of green power. The credit was scheduled to end by 2002. In 1999, \nthe money specified in AB 1890 was being depleted rapidly and Green Mountain \ntook the lead in pressing for legislation. We actively supported Green \nMountain by lobbying legislators and other interest groups, working with \nenvironmental organisations, and spearheading legislative amendments.  \nAlthough this bill became wrapped up in the San Diego crisis and ISO/PX \nissues, the green credit portion of the bill remained intact.  We had also \ndecided jointly to propose a ten-year credit and were very pleased and \nsurprised that it survived into the final bill.  Governor Davis is expected \nto sign the bill. \n\n2000 NPV estimated by Dennis Benevides: $50 million\n% Attributed to Enron's GA Efforts: 25%\n\nRAP '99\nEnron, through ARM, has successfully made its case that retail procurement \nand retail sales costs should be removed from the Distribution Charge that \nall customers pay.  Direct Access customers would receive a credit on their \nbills in addition to the PX credit. Enron was the first party to raise these \nissues as part of RAP '98 and got a Commission decision in that case to \ndetermine the credit in RAP '99.  In RAP '99, Enron chose to use ARM to \nlitigate the case as a cheaper alternative.  Hearings were completed in the \nSpring of 2000.  ARM has negotiated settlement rates with certain parties and \nhas convinced the Assigned Commissioner to draft his own decision to \ncounteract the unfavorable ALJ decision. An additional credit of from $0.25 \nto $0.30/MWh is expected.  The decision will be voted out within the next two \nmonths.\n\n2000 NPV estimated by Dennis Benevides: $1 - 5 million\n% Attributed to Enron's GA Efforts: 75%\n\nSan Diego Marketing\nGovernment Affairs worked closely with EES origination to help the staff \nunderstand the wildly fluctuating regulatory and political arena in San Diego \nand to assist its efforts to take advantage of the unique marketing \nopportunity afforded by volatile wholesale market prices.  EES created a new \nEnron milestone.  Beginning at a point with no personnel working on San Diego \ndeals, EES moved in and was able to sign deals worth $1 million in three \nweeks time.  EES has received kudos from the highest levels of Enron for this \neffort, which continues today.  Martin Wenzel and Doug Condon of EES \norigination have stated their belief that these deals would not have happened \nwith the assistance of Government Affairs.\n\n2000 NPV estimated by Doug Condon: $1 million and growing\n% Attributed to Enron's  GA Efforts: 90%\n\n\nENA\n\nNote:  Tim Belden, VP West Trading Desk, discussed with me how these \nvaluations would be used.  He found it difficult to assess Gov Affairs' \ncontribution to the ENA dollars made.  In the end, he settled on the concept \nthat Government Affairs works, sometimes for years, to present ENA with an \nopportunity to make money and then it is up to ENA to run with it.  So, the \nvalue Tim provides is the value ENA made with the opportunity.  I think this \nis consistent with the way Dennis Benevides calculated the value for me.\n\n\nFTR Release April 1, 2000\nI have spearheaded the release of firm transmission rights in CA since I \njoined the Company in 11/96.  When I joined Enron, the plan of market \nparticipants was to have financial-only rights.  I began working immediately \nto move people in the direction of physical rights. A very long and painful \nfight ensued, including a number of personal appearances by Bill Hogan. This \nculminated with an ISO decision to have physical-type FTRs and to release \nsome, but not all, FTRs in April of this year.  ENA actively participated in \nthe auction and became the largest single purchaser of FTRs.  The new \ncongestion management approach, which Enron also spearheaded, will require \n100% release of FTRs, but will not take effect until next year. This \nvaluation looks only at the FTR release in 2000.\n\n2000 NPV estimated by Tim Belden: $20 million\n% Attributed to Enron's Efforts: 90%\n\n\nISO Price Caps\nPrice caps have been discussed in California beginning a few days after the \nmarket opened in April 1998.  Over the course of the last two years, \nGovernment Affairs had as a number one priority to provide rapid advance \ninformation on price caps, educate Board members on the effects of price \ncaps, and, when appropriate, work to move price caps.  By June, 2000, ENA had \na substantial long position in the market in the West and had millions at \nrisk when lower price caps began to be discussed in CA in mid June.  \nGovernment Affairs, working with Dave Parquet and others, was instrumental in \ndelaying the movement to lower price caps by six weeks, thereby giving ENA \ntime to move out of those positions in an orderly fashion .  The following \nevents happened in 2000.  We entered the year with a price cap of $750, \nhaving fought to raise it to that level in 1999.  In March 2000, the ISO \nconsidered lowering the price cap to $500 but voted to leave it at $500, \nbecause the Board believed at the time that market power had been adequately \nmitigated.  After the three very high-priced days in June, the ISO considered \nlowering the price cap to $250 with a vote on June 22. Government Affairs \ninitiated an all-out lobbying effort to convince Board members and their \nconstituents to oppose lower price caps.  We also lobbied interest groups, \nbanks, venture capitalists, NYMEX and others to weigh in on this issue with \nindividual Board Members and the Board itself, going so far as to set up a \nspecial arrangement with the ISO staff to allow interested parties to address \nthe Board telephonically.  The vote on June 22 failed by ONE VOTE. Instead, \nthe Board lowered the price cap to $500.  The Board voted again on July 1 to \nlower the cap and again the vote failed by ONE VOTE.  Finally, on August 1, \nthe Board approved the $250 price cap, effective August 7.  In the end, it \nwas the end-use customers, Enron and the generators who opposed price caps.  \nUtilities and munis favored them. Enron was the only party lobbying against \nthe lower price caps (the generators gave up early in the fight) and had \nsignificant credibility with the end-use customer reps on the Board.\n\n2000 NPV estimated by Tim Belden:  $16 million\n% Attributed to Enron's Efforts: 70%\n\n\nNew Market-Oriented Board Member\nThe ISO recently held Board elections for the first time.  Government Affairs \nactively sought market-oriented individuals to run for the Board and replace \nthose that do not support competitive markets.  Enron was successful in \ngetting about five to run.  The Members selected or confirmed by the EOB have \nbeen held up and we do not yet know the outcome of those Board seats.  \nHowever, one seat of interest has been decided.  Dave Parquet suggested a \npotential municipal representative who was extremely market-oriented (Michael \nWood, Attorney for the City of Pittsburgh).  Government Affairs worked with \nhim closely to decide which seat to run for, help him prepare his \napplication, suggest lobbying tactics, assist in lobbying and support him \nwith other Board Members.  He won the election and became a Board Member in \nearly September.  This effort is significant, because the munis voted nearly \n100% in support of lower price caps. The position he took was one of those \nvotes.  All other things being equal, we have now added a vote on our side \nthat could be instrumental in defeating further efforts to impose lower or \nadditional price caps, given the close votes that have taken place thus far.\n\n2000 NPV: Tim did not feel this is measurable at this time, but agreed it \ncould be worth millions if future votes are as close as they have been\n% Attributed to Enron's Efforts: 100%\n\n\n\n\n",
        "headers": {
